column8:
Behold! An ACTUALLY "Dead game." God, I forgot this even existed. It's weird knowing Terraria has some cross over stuff with this, and nothing ever happened with this game other than the game just being dropped, splatting like an egg on the floor with no one to clean up after it, and all those left in the aftermath gazing down upon this broken thing with frustration.

I don't think the game was ever actually *finished.* I remember always just feeling perpetually confused in the EA (when it was actually worked on), never being entirely sure *what* to do. I guess at some point they must have "Finished" the game and removed the label, but we all know it's not actually done.

I'd say "Go play starbound instead", but chucklefish are full of unethical business practises, and starbound is painfully mid at best.
Go play Terraria instead, then, I guess.
Edge of Space? More like... more like, uhhh...
Edge of.. Finished Product?
Edge of Potential?
Edge of... Edge of uhhh...

Bought this game in the early days because it seemed like it had potential, early builds were confusing and hard to get into with very little tutorial or pointers, but I stuck it out because it was still being worked on.

Wish I could refund the game at this point, it's been abandoned by the devs and the "release" update made it even harder to do anything in the game, with a barebones tutorial and a HUD that would make Ubisoft jealous with how much info it spits at you with no explanation.

Don't bother buying, it's a waste of your money.

column8:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handâ€”the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedâ€”the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

column8:
Wow. I've never actually written a review for this hoping it would some day be finished, huh?

It's been said before, but consider the game in an eternal beta. There's a post on the forums from 2016 talking about how the devs have abandoned the game and functionally dissolved as a company, so the odds of any significant updates are basically zero.

The game has some interesting mechanics as an early Terraria clone, but the controls feel clunky, the balance is poor, basically every system that's implemented is done so poorly, and very little has been done to make the game feel good to play, as opposed to just being functional.

column8: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

column8:
Imagine a person goes to use the restroom and end up clogging the toilet. Lets say, for hypothetical reasons, this person does not own a plunger but instead only has a kitchen knife and a well used toilet brush. It takes them a solid ten minutes of intense labor to finally clear the clog.

Now let's say this metaphorical 'person' is the anthropomorphic representation of the company Handyman Studios. At the time of their unfortunate 'toilet escapade' they were throwing an open-house party for a brand new game that they had started making. 

During the party several of the guests after having a chance to play Handyman's game commented, "Where's the rest of the content? Why are there so many bugs?" Mr Handyman became quickly disillusioned and distraught because no one thought it was a good game since it wasn't finished and had all sorts of bugs and, for all intents and purposes, appeared to be an almost direct copy mechanically as another very popular game called Starbound. 

After suffering a existential crisis and a mental breakdown, Mr Handyman decides to take the still *heavily soiled* kitchen knife from the bathroom and go on a murderous rampage stabbing all the guests to death.

Continuing to spiral into the mental void of oblivion, Mr Handyman then decides to carryout their own dark fantasies by using the *heavily soiled* toilet brush to, for lack of a better word, copulate with the still warm bodies of the guests.

Ladies and gentlemen, this sad tale has been a metaphorical analogy to the relationship that Handyman Studios had with their playerbase. The lesson? Finish the games you start. Even the bad ones. Have enough moral, ethical, emotional, and personal stability to accept criticisms. Don't scam people and be wary of empty promises from companies.  Lastly, if you throw a party, don't stab your guests with poopy kitchen knives and, for the love of all that is good and wholesome in this world, don't fornicate with dead bodies using a soiled toilet brush.

column8: Abandoned when it had no end-game ... Now it has an end-game? Fell through the cracks. It was fun when it came out because you had "more coming" and it never did come. Now I can look back and go "gross"...Gross waste of money, and time for feeling like an abandoned game for so long it lost my interest. Couldn't help but feel like they released it just to be done with it.

column8:
This game has been completely abandoned. The Developers "Company" has shut down, their website/forums are down, and none of them will respond to any E-Mails/Social Media inquiries about the game. They have taken the money and left, with no intention of finishing this game.

So...here's some background:

The game had a history of being buggy and unstable, with long-standing and well-known glitches not being fixed. The combat was awkward, the balancing was poor, and there was a LOT of unfinished content. But despite this, since it was "Early Access" and a lot of people liked the concept of the game, we gave the devs a chance.

But before any of this was fixed, the devs started talking about "Full release time" approaching. A lot of us were absolutely puzzled by how they could be looking that far ahead with so many serious, game-breaking bugs still being ignored and only a tiny fraction of the promised content being done. The devs had mentioned that they had somewhere around "10% of the total content" in the game! Were they deciding to ignore everything wrong with the game and push it out unfinished?

In September, that was exactly what happened. The developers decided to slap the game with a fancy "Version 1.0" label on this, despite it not being anywhere close to finished, to get it out of Early Access so it'd be featured on the Steam Store Page and net them some easy holiday-season sales.

They added a bunch of unfinished, even more buggy content for about 3 months after release to ensure that the game kept popping up on the main page as "Just Updated!" during the holiday sales season. Most of these updates were just them unsuccessfully trying to fix things that had been broken since the Alpha Versions or tossing in half-finished buggy content.

In December, they claimed to be "Going on break for the holidays" and weren't heard from again until April. We would later be told by LadyAijou, the Community Manager, that she had departed from their project in January. By all appearances, it seems like no more work was being done on the game at this time, as Bug Reports failed to send properly, E-mails to the devs wouldn't get responses, and there was no interaction on the Forums or Twitter.

Their last post on Steam was in April, coincidentally right before they put their game into the Humble Indie Bundle in May to squeeze any last possible amount of revenue out. The post was a pretty blatant attempt to make potential Bundle buyers who look on the News Page for the game think it was still being actively developed and supported. By then, their Community Manager was no longer working with them, and one of their devs posted a "We'll have information for you soon!" message from his private steam profile. They haven't been heard from since.

To be frank, this is looking like a classic Early Access scam, with the developer drastically overpromising, then running with as much money as possible and leaving the game uncompleted.

Normally, I would just shake my head and move on, but this one really offended me. They had obviously realized very early that they wouldn't be able to finish their game. But instead of telling their customers, they calculated exactly how to milk the most sales out of their unfinished mess. They got their "Full Release" up just before the Holiday Season, and kept putting out very minor patches every week or so not to fix the game, but to ensure that the game would keep popping up in the Steam Store's front page as "Recently Updated" to maximize sales during the holiday season.

No updates after that and only a vague "Please be patient" message from a private steam profile 3 months later, right before a Humble Bundle sale.

This is the kinda crap people need to spread the word about. Stuff like Edge of Space and Towns are scams that people are not only getting away with, but making a lot of money on. Let people know what happened here. Let people looking at this game know to not waste their money and to be very, VERY discerning when looking at future early-access titles.
column9:
This game has been completely abandoned. The Developers "Company" has shut down, their website/forums are down, and none of them will respond to any E-Mails/Social Media inquiries about the game. They have taken the money and left, with no intention of finishing this game.

So...here's some background:

The game had a history of being buggy and unstable, with long-standing and well-known glitches not being fixed. The combat was awkward, the balancing was poor, and there was a LOT of unfinished content. But despite this, since it was "Early Access" and a lot of people liked the concept of the game, we gave the devs a chance.

But before any of this was fixed, the devs started talking about "Full release time" approaching. A lot of us were absolutely puzzled by how they could be looking that far ahead with so many serious, game-breaking bugs still being ignored and only a tiny fraction of the promised content being done. The devs had mentioned that they had somewhere around "10% of the total content" in the game! Were they deciding to ignore everything wrong with the game and push it out unfinished?

In September, that was exactly what happened. The developers decided to slap the game with a fancy "Version 1.0" label on this, despite it not being anywhere close to finished, to get it out of Early Access so it'd be featured on the Steam Store Page and net them some easy holiday-season sales.

They added a bunch of unfinished, even more buggy content for about 3 months after release to ensure that the game kept popping up on the main page as "Just Updated!" during the holiday sales season. Most of these updates were just them unsuccessfully trying to fix things that had been broken since the Alpha Versions or tossing in half-finished buggy content.

In December, they claimed to be "Going on break for the holidays" and weren't heard from again until April. We would later be told by LadyAijou, the Community Manager, that she had departed from their project in January. By all appearances, it seems like no more work was being done on the game at this time, as Bug Reports failed to send properly, E-mails to the devs wouldn't get responses, and there was no interaction on the Forums or Twitter.

Their last post on Steam was in April, coincidentally right before they put their game into the Humble Indie Bundle in May to squeeze any last possible amount of revenue out. The post was a pretty blatant attempt to make potential Bundle buyers who look on the News Page for the game think it was still being actively developed and supported. By then, their Community Manager was no longer working with them, and one of their devs posted a "We'll have information for you soon!" message from his private steam profile. They haven't been heard from since.

To be frank, this is looking like a classic Early Access scam, with the developer drastically overpromising, then running with as much money as possible and leaving the game uncompleted.

Normally, I would just shake my head and move on, but this one really offended me. They had obviously realized very early that they wouldn't be able to finish their game. But instead of telling their customers, they calculated exactly how to milk the most sales out of their unfinished mess. They got their "Full Release" up just before the Holiday Season, and kept putting out very minor patches every week or so not to fix the game, but to ensure that the game would keep popping up in the Steam Store's front page as "Recently Updated" to maximize sales during the holiday season.

No updates after that and only a vague "Please be patient" message from a private steam profile 3 months later, right before a Humble Bundle sale.

This is the kinda crap people need to spread the word about. Stuff like Edge of Space and Towns are scams that people are not only getting away with, but making a lot of money on. Let people know what happened here. Let people looking at this game know to not waste their money and to be very, VERY discerning when looking at future early-access titles.

column8:
On sale worth a buy: This has a lot of negative reviews, so hear me out on this one.
TLDR: I enjoyed this more than singleplayer terraria. Even ignoring for a while then replaying, I've enjoyed this more than terraria. It's more combat exploration with rewarding progress than terraria's building + useless non-progress and giant skips.

If you play single player (I would like to try multiplayer, but my friends have consuls...)
Love/hated terraria or are tired of the same feeling games 
and want something fresh
and wanted more space shooter than mining... (sorta)
want the game to reward you rather than penalize you for not doing the only 1 thing that you are caged into
Then this is for you.

Does it eventually fall flat? yes... But so do 'finished' games that lack real story or just end poorly
So if you are ok with an experience that is fun for a while then ends, great! You have a game that feels like more a shooter that rewards whatever you feel like doing vs say terraria..
EG terraria has very uneven scaaling that reward skipping massive tiers and jumping straight to a higher tier, which means all the other stuff is meaningless. EG wasted materials with absolutely no value! Activities are wasted time in terraria. Jump strait to jumgle, then find worthless items until you mind like crazy (for no reward) to get low enough to find the occasional rare reward worth having. is that a good experience?
HHow about instead: 
This game uses 'low tier' items continuously and gives exp for any activity you feel like doing. Killing stuff? Yes = exp. Mining? Yes = exp. Short mission? yes = exp and bonus materials to soffen the "find enough iron" effect. Rare Items? Yes = feel worth it.
Does it encourage pushing yourself? yes = higher level or deeper = more exp and better items, so go ahead and risk pushing deeper and levelling faster (but you will need to risk lighter gear to do that).

Story? not really. Did terarria? I shure didn't find one there. So how about you just have fun space blasting and getting stronger and facing meaner stuff. 

Other notable games: planet centuri, signs of life, terraria, starbound, darkout, windforge! All have a different feeling but are similar ish. I loved signs of life's fast mining. Windforge felt weird... until I started jumping over attacks and sky raiding and chomping entire islands with a grinder ship! All are fun, but Edge of Space offers the most space shooter focus. I have no idea why it was abandoned/not popular enough. Similar games have survived far worse issues (eg signs of life has continued past several early issues and continues to receive updates to it's credit)

This is very comparable to Darkout:  it'is abandoned as well but also worth your looking at. It stands as one of the most visually beautiful but runs into a story hard stop. enjoy it for the little gem while it lasts. Edge of space focused on combat and fast exploration (in comparison, terraria pushes lack of skill + proper equipment to force finding exceptionally rare items/mining, which feels like a grind)

Terraria got boring. This felt like I wanted to keep going.

column8:
this unfinished abandoned game is by all definition shit but i oddly enjoy it quite a bit i particular enjoy the combat something about it feels really good, starbound had amazing melee combat but nothing special on guns well eos has amazing gun combat, and controversially i think terrarias combat is a little dull when compared to the two but its a jack of all trades and has the most variety and has visually the best weapons 
this game over the two is really good at atmosphere over art direction (starbound) and charm (terraria) 
mining in eos is a pretty annoying unlike starbound where its incredibly fun to mine and terraria thats eh at it 
character movement is the best out of the three starbound having the worst because it never improves and terraria being a pretty annoying because default player speed feels horrible to me probably because im so used to wings and the speed boots, eos player movement a pretty great because jetpack from the start and it only gets better very quickly 
this game has a pretty alright rpg systems and you have the knowledges 
out of all of them this game has the worst pacing you never really know what youre doing and this game is very obtuse alot of things are just really stupidly complicated, i had to look up for shit alot so realistically i wouldnt actually really recommend this game to anyone but i really enjoyed and its a shame it was never finished because this game does genuinely has some great things that are better then some things in terraria and starbound and to me was at least worth playing, im not sure if i technically beat this game or not my only condition was beating omegatron since hes the only boss with an achievement but after trying him 7 times i got him really low and my nav data ran out so i was like done because omegatron is just a really shit boss with alot of health and four moves what i did was good enough for me 
all in all i give this a 7.9/10 a REALLY generous score

column8:
Ok, so this is the first bad review I've ever given... How should I start?

Well, ok, let's start with this: I came expecting some kind of Terraria-like game with a space element, but got a trashy, very limited and extremely clunky controls instead. Gameplay is bad because of that very reason, your caracter seems stiff and every action looks and feels very bad. Battles are trashy, and I couldn't bring myself to play enough to face any bosses, but I'm expecting them to be as bad as your regular enemy in this game. This really feels like a Terraria-gone-bad thing, if you want a good Terraria-like game in space, try out Starbound. 

Conclusion:
Don't waste your money on this when we got Starbound, please.

column8:
"reminder: good graphics do not cover up for bad gameplay

edit: hi!
        and this is me from the future, am here to test my previous theory.
        wish me luck <3" was my previous review.

But I discovered that not only my theory was true, But also that every time I re-download this game, It underwhelms my expectations. I'll be honest with you, I thought this game would be a starbound clone and yet it's still bad.

Crafting, Combat, Exploration, All lack in depth. I do not even know how you'd be able to lack depth in combat, Combat is just attacking and dodging and yet it's still bad in this game.


If you truly want a good experience, Play these instead:

https://store.steampowered.com/app/105600/Terraria/
https://store.steampowered.com/app/211820/Starbound/
https://store.steampowered.com/app/385380/Planet_Centauri/
https://store.steampowered.com/app/929670/Orion_Sandbox_Enhanced/
https://store.steampowered.com/app/280520/Crea/
https://store.steampowered.com/app/697550/It_Lurks_Below/
https://store.steampowered.com/app/315460/Dig_or_Die/
https://store.steampowered.com/app/881100/Noita/


And remember; Have fun, Because I know I didn't <3

column8:
This game is incomplete, with some major flaws.  With a little bit of spit and polish, it could be a rather good game, unfortunately it seems the developers have given up.  That being the case, just find a willing developer like myself to take over, eh?

First glaring issue is the game is built in Unity3D but does NOT provide options to play in full screen.  Read the other reviews and you will find lots of people complaining about this, as it does make it unplayable for most people.  You can work around this issue by also buying Borderless Gaming app from Steam.

Secondly, the title screen simply looks horrid.  The planet on that screen is clearly a copy-paste from another image, and i have to say it was not cleaned around the edges properly.

Third, many menus and UI elements show signs of amateur development.  Many UI elements react by clicking on the text, not the button or tab.  Some UI elements do accept clicks on the tab, but do not see the click if your mouse is on the text.  As an experienced Unity dev, I can attest these are amazingly simple issues that can be resolved in just a few seconds each.

All in all, the development issues I see are all simple to fix.  I dare say they could all easily be fixed in just one dayâ€™s work.  The sheer fact that they persist in the game more than five years after its release, says a lot about the developers themselves.

column8:
I've played this game five years ago when it was pretty feature limited. I didn't play a whole lot of it. Felt like a clunky Terraria that controlled worse and had a confusing UI. Needless to say, I dropped this game rather quick and stuck with Terraria.

I come back to this game five years later, the game loads in a window too big for my screen. The first thing I see in this window is a popup page for a well-known website-making service. I attempt to change the resolution, but the window refuses to resize itself, basically making the game uncomfortable to play.

I recently installed a whole slew of games that I haven't played in a while, yet ignored this one in particular. Now I know exactly why I didn't bother. Should've just left it uninstalled.

I listed this as being received for free because I can't recall ever paying any money for this game, and I can't find such a transaction in my purchase history. In hindsight, I'm really glad I didn't pay for this game. To those of you that did, I feel bad for you.

[spoiler]The only good thing I can say of this game is that the S.D.M.G. managed to escape from this mess and into Terraria.[/spoiler]

It might have been a very good game. Pretty graphics and music, nicely executed mechanics. But sadly it is unfinished. If You do not mind it's current (and probably ultimate) state, want to do some mining, crafting and building to kill boredom - sure, play it. I give it a positive review for what it could have been basing on what it is. I'd like more games like this and hopefully finished :).

column8: It's been 5 years!!! And the game still isn't done. And somehow it's still available and being sold at full price?? I enjoyed giving feedback to the team during Beta around 2014 or so but even after it was fully released, it was so bad. The game has no sense of progression besides items and biomes...which had incomplete descriptions. The spawning mechanics were too high and sporadic. Way too many glitches. They had so much potential to be a great game with all the financial support and dedicated players like myself who believed in the game. Just get Starbound or Terraria, please. They won't disappoint.

column8: Spent most of the time in this game trying to figure out what to do in this game. This is just another attempt to recreate Terraria but this time the developers gave up about 1/4 of the way there. NPCs stand around talking about nonexistent quests, progression system is poor and just sums up to: go here, get this sword, go here, get this helmet. Game is wildly broken and as far as I know, no one is working on it anymore, it's just dead in the water. Don't bother with this broken pipe dream of a game.

Scrolling through my Steam games list for something to play. Came across this game, bought it in early access many many years ago because it looked like it was going to be Terraria in space. But in the end all this game became was an abandoned, unfinished product that should NOT be for sale any more. That also means anyone who purchased this game from the day it was abandoned till now should be granted a full refund.

Don't be fooled by the lack of an early access tag on this game. Push out a "1.0" update, call it done to have that early access removed then drop the game leaving it for sale to fool new customers.

There are better games to play in this genre. Like Starbound & Terraria (which has been being supported for 9 years post release btw, unlike this mess) for example.

Any future early access products that get abandoned by the devs should be made unable to be purchased and the store pages for those games should stay up and be flagged as "ABANDONED EARLY ACCESS PRODUCT" so if anyone finds a game (especially early access) and decides to check out that developers other products to maybe see how their finished products look as a hint to how their newly in production Early Access title may look (if) when completed, it will give the potential buyer that red flag to warn them that the developer they are looking at had abandoned products in the past.

column8:
Usually I like to write really nice and long-winded reviews for games, but this game is dead.
The developer killed it.
It's a good game but it's not receiving updates, multiplayer doesn't work well, and the content will get stale eventually.
And honestly sometimes that scares me knowing that Starbound, a sort of sister game to EOS, is only kept alive by the modding community, and were that community to fail the game would quickly die, especially with veterans of it like me... I know that's not related to this game really but I needed to vent it somewhere and I figure nobody will see this.

Anyways, if this game was to be updated enough I would recommend it, but as it's not, I don't. Simple as that.
column9:

I know that's not related to this game really but I needed to vent it somewhere and I figure nobody will see this.

Anyways, if this game was to be updated enough I would recommend it, but as it's not, I don't. Simple as that.

column8:
[H1]An exercise in frustration.[/H1]

TL;DR - Fun for a few hours, but repetitive. The game is abandoned in its unfinished state.
 
[I]Edge of Space[/I], henceforth as EoS, had a lot of promise going in and is akin to games such as [I]Terraria[/I], [I]Starbound[/I], or [I]Minecraft[/I]. In fact, there is crossover content from [I]Terraria[/I] within EoS. The base premise is the same as those other games -- the player explore (and fight) through various biomes gathering resources to build new items and structures. In that respect, the game does an excellent job of letting the player explore their respective sandbox right out the gate. Unfortunately, at the same time the game plops the player down right into the sandbox without any sense of direction.

Regardless, the game is quite fun... at first. The character you control heads out exploring this new world he or she finds themselves in, encounters various flora and fauna (not all of which are hostile in this upper biome), discovers new resources, and acquires knowledge which in turn unlocks new craftable items. Thus, the first few hours is actually quite interesting and enjoyable. However, even at this point, the player may encounter "hiccups" in what's happening in the game. And it soon becomes apparent that this game feels unfinished, because it is.

There are three major biomes in the game -- protolife, comet, and barren. Think of them as layers on a cake, if you will, with an upper, middle, and lower layers, respectively. Each have unique creatures to that layer and can contain mini-biomes such as ice and crystal caves or nesting sites for a certain type of creature. The protolife if filled with numerous flora and docile creatures, while the comet biome is an arctic tundra with more dangerous creatures the deeper you go, and finally the desert-like barrens biome with even deadlier hostiles. Nonetheless, each biome doesn't necessary feel any different than the one preceding it. That's because there's very little non-cosmetic changes between the layers. A few creatures and resource types are added or exchanged, and that's quite literally it. Leading the game towards a direction of sameness and repetition overall.

The game is further marred on its craftable side as well. The list of craftable items is great and expansive. Sadly, the player will not likely craft most of the items from this list. That's because the materials to craft certain items are virtually unacquirable or by the time one does obtain an ample supply those items are no longer relevant. The rest of the craftables are either cosmetic in nature, not viable in your game, or flatout useless. Worst still is that apparently some items will break your game or its save via corrupting either your character or the world it used to populate. I found myself crafting the same few items over and over again which were [U]Plasma Torches[/U] (as a permanent light source), [U]Walls[/U] (for walls, obviously, and for base-building, defense, and the creation of platforms while exploring), [U]Earthen Door[/U] (to get in and out of your many bases), and [U]Command Nodes[/U] (to teleport between other nodes and command centers). Anything else was generally not worth it (i.e., weapons systems requiring ammunition which can potentially break your game, or the convoluted and unnecessary power management system). 

As I've hinted at, EoS had the potential to be something great (even earning awards during development), and I wondered why it failed to achieve it. Upon further research, I've discovered that EoS is extensively gutted, with many things gone unimplemented, and is a sad shell of what it should have been. For example, more variety of creatures and structures, something more than a superficial plot and the inclusion of questlines, and even a basic tutorial (which barely exists spiritually in the codex). From the old data (here on Steam, Kickstarter, Google documents, and elsewhere), one can see that the developers worked tirelessly, even changing the game engine, and interacted with the community during those earlier years. Through a terrible set of circumstances, miscommunications, and unfulfilled promises they got into a vicious cycle of just surviving on other contracts and running out of money while either putting EoS on the backburner or adding a mess of things to it (and ultimately culling most of it). Doing so kept pushing EoS further and further from the finish line. Apparently, the developers salvaged what they could, removed many of the game's systems, and released the hallowed shell that EoS is today before abandoning the project altogether. That's right. The state of the game with all its flaws, bugs, and technical issues will forever be the final version. At least it's playable for the most part. In the developer's own words, truncated (from the Google Documents link sourced here [url]https://steamcommunity.com/gid/103582791434400882/announcements/detail/1685922756609775177[/url]):
[I]It's not making enough for us to focus on it. The technological barrier is huge and makes it impractical to work on. Engine related bugs [will] never be fixed. The honest end answer is we don't have the capacity to go back and update EoS. Nor would it be technologically viable to do.[/I]

So why did I put in as many hours (~91) as I did at the time of this review given all that I have said? Well, I didn't know anything about EoS when I first started, and I wanted to put in a good faith effort into the game to see if my mid-initial impressions would change. Additionally, my perseverance (and perhaps a bit of anger) to reach the third major biome and mess around in there for a while once I had reached it fueled me more than I care to admit. My time would have been better served elsewhere. Nevertheless, I may revisit this game from time-to-time to incrementally expand a few bases and network the megabases together for the sheer absurdity of it all.

This game was gifted by a friend.

column9:
I strongly advise against it. It's not even worth more than 5 euros at the most.

The game is messy. We don't really understand what to do, and there's not much to explain. The scenery is nice, but the fact that the map is scattered across floating islands quickly becomes boring (not to be vulgar).
The weapons, armor, and tools are not fun to unlock. It's long, and there are materials you can't find to craft them. Excavation is a real ordeal until you unlock the drill, which is a tool specialized in "Builder" armor (the armor is separated into three categories, each with its own research branch: combat/explorer/Builder).

The combat system is really not great, and I'm not even talking about the weapons, which are difficult to upgrade to kill higher-level enemies. The enemies, by the way, tend to fire an outrageously high number of bouncing grenades and guided missiles.

There are vehicles. Mouhai, in this world they quickly become useless, especially because you can't pick them up. They therefore become useless in this world where you have to dig downwards to advance. (With the exception of the excavator, which allows you to dig, but it is quickly destroyed by enemies.)

Add to that other problems related to this type of game, like crafting, which doesn't take into account what's in your base's chests, no button to automatically store our materials, if you don't clean ON the crafting table, the craft doesn't start, etc.

Finally, as for those who say it resembles Terraria or Starbound, personally I don't see how, apart from the sandbox aspect. The game is "empty" and the setting isn't appealing.

So I don't recommend it, unless you have nothing to play and it's 3 euros.

On that note, enjoy the game.

column9:
About the story:

Become an agent of the Ark Corporation, sent to the far reaches of the universe in search of habitable planets to terraform. However, after a long space journey, you awaken from cryotherapy to discover your ship has veered off course and is disabled near a strange new world. With no other choice but to descend to the surface and figure out how to survive long enough to complete your mission, you board the escape pod.

Along the way, you'll collect resources to craft armor, weapons, facilities, and vehicles to help you explore the world and conquer its aggressive inhabitants. Your base of operations will evolve from a few basic facilities exposed to the elements into a hardened fortress brimming with advanced technologies that allow you to perform incredible upgrades to your equipment and alter the environment itself.

Be careful, though; almost everything down there wants to kill you, including ferocious laser sharks, polar bears with heavy artillery, wickedly fast jet penguins, and even the craziest horrors. At the edge of space, you must adapt or die. Good luck, ArkCo Operative!

------------------------------

Edge of Space is a game (or at least that's what they say it is) from Handyman Studios. Let's get to the points (This review will be quick):

Audience:

[ ] Newborns
[ ] Children.
[ ] Teens.
[ ] Adults.
[ ] All audiences.

Game Difficulty:

[ ] A potato can do it
[ ] A monkey can do it
[ ] An incompetent human can do it
[ ] A trained or skilled human
[ ] An alien or genius can do it

Game Art:

[ ] A child can do it better
[ ] The graphics quality is average compared to other pixelated games.
[ ] Good textures, shadows, and effects
[ ] Great quality, someone took the time to make it. [ ] A human being has difficulty distinguishing between filmed and computer-generated.

Music and Sound Effects:

[ ] Play without sound
[X] We can call this noise and noise
[ ] By definition, music (after all, some people hear worse things)
[ ] Pleasant Harmony
[ ] This composition touches your soul deeply (Beware of melancholy, nostalgia, and depression / Call 188 for the Life Appreciation Center)

---------------------------------------------

Cons:

They didn't deliver on what they promised; what they did deliver was incredibly late, a complete disappointment. The game doesn't do the bare minimum of similar competitive games like Starbound and Terraria; it lacks the basics.

Bugs/Glitches:

[ ] Error 404 Game not found (Give up)
[X] Kingdom of Bugs and Crashes
[ ] Some common errors (A mod or setting can fix this)
[ ] You need to work hard to find an error
[ ] No errors found (Is this a challenge?)

-------------------------------------------

Is it worth buying?

[X] I'd like my money back.
[ ] The sale is included.
[ ] It's paid!
[ ] Buy all the DLCs, all the content, support development, and keep more like this!
[ ] Why aren't billionaires (Elon Musk) investing in this?

Don't waste your time and money, go back to the store!

column8:
Don't pay a dime to this company or the publisher that keeps this on the store. The game is unfinished, buggy, and abandoned. And the shady practices from the devs has garnered exactly the type of reviews you see here. 

If you supported during Early access like I did, right click on game in your library, click manage, then Hide this game. Until Steam allows you to completely remove a game from your list, Edge of Space will continue to take up too much space. Even a line item in the library is more than it deserves.

This game had the right tools to be a good game. But it ended up failing so bad.

I remember buying this game on Early Access 3 years prior official release. Played for some days until how far the game allowed to go at that specific development stage, went to foruns to tell about all the bugs and missing content, and they had indeed put in the game some of those things later.. I did this thing 3 times, once per year. Until they finally launched an official release. 
I started playing and couldnt finish because it was boring as hell.
A game that I have been following for years and "free working as a bug reporter" hoping to be the cool game I expected to be, and I couldnt even finish when I had the chance because of how lame the game ended up being.

The multiple sub characteristics of each individual material is very seductive to TRY to explore. But that's all. They ended up not being very well utilized in the game. Like when I want to make a prototype weapon with random status boosts, it says that needs like 30 "mineral". I use the cheapest one, iron i think. But IF I somehow managed to get titanium instead, they should influence the status boost, but no. Even with the hability to compress and refine materials, it ended up giving us useless materials, or at least not well explored in the game.
Anyway, enough about materials. Let`s move on: The gameplay is annoying, the enemies annoying, fighting is VERY annoying, movements, physical impacts, weapons.. ahhh! I feel like a part of my life were stolen from me for dedicating time trying to help improving this game.

If you loved Terraria and wanted something else to try, this is not the game. The only downside of Terraria is that they display a random window message when you alt+tab it, and sometimes it says "also try Edge of Space". NO! JUST DON`T!

column8:
This game was a cautionary tale for me as to why one should not purchase games before their formal release. When things started off, it was great, but subsequent updates really bogged the game down and it became unplayable (and I'm not usually very picky). I was excited when I saw that the creators started posting again in 2018, but it looks like they still haven't done anything with this game. Fool me twice, shame on me. 

Do not buy this game - it is a waste of time. It should, frankly, be pulled from Steam for how unplayable it is for $15. And to the creators - shame on you. This could have been a really great game - it had a lot of potential.

column9:
You're an Ark Corporation operative sent to the farthest reaches of the universe in search of habitable planets for terraforming. However, after a long space voyage, you awaken from cryosleep to find your ship far off course and disabled near a strange new world. With no choice but to descend to the surface and figure out how to survive long enough to complete your mission, you board an escape pod.

Along the way, you'll gather resources to craft armor, weapons, objects, and vehicles to help you explore the world and defeat its hostile inhabitants. Your base of operations will evolve from a few basic facilities exposed to the elements to a fortified fortress brimming with advanced technology, allowing you to achieve astonishing upgrades to your equipment and alter the environment itself.

Be careful, though; almost everything out there wants to kill you, including ferocious laser-wielding space sharks, artillery-wielding polar bears, viciously fast jetpack penguins, and even crazier horrors. At the edge of space, you must adapt or die. Good luck, ARCCO operative!

10 out of 10

column8:
(Note: I bought and played this game a couple of years ago, but it doesn't looked like much has changed about it since then.)

This game looked like it had the potential to be amazing, but in my few hours of playing it, nothing much interesting happened. It doesn't really make it clear what the goal is, or what you should be doing, and nothing (at least in the early parts of the game) feels that rewarding.
I bought this hoping it would be like Terraria, but I was sadly disappointed. The really sad thing is that this game (at least from the description on the store page) looks like it has a lot of cool stuff in it, but it was just too boring for me to get in to and I uninstalled it after a few hours.
Don't buy if you want another Terraria. This game looks interesting, but only if you invest a whole lot of time into getting to the interesting bit.

column8:
Just don't. save yourself the trouble of buying this game.
When I first got it, there were a few troubling reviews but it still looked cool. Unfortunately as time went on I realized every one of them was right, from the game being buggy to difficulty in aquiring *any* better weapons or armor (side note, I don't think that having "So Many Weapons" ought to be your selling point for a game like this, especially when there aren't actually that many.) and the game includes the weird idea of "you need better armor to go further down" despite the fact that the world is mainly comprised of floating islands that aren't even always visible one to another so it's almost always a leap of faith.

The Devs have abandoned this game, and you should too. 1/10 (the 1 is that some of the art is kinda neat)

you want a good Space Terraria game? play Starbound.

Pity that this game seems to be abandoned. Encountered annoying bug where I had all NPC's, nice and cozy, their quests done too. However, during exploration, one of them popped next to me. i talked to it and all my NPC's were gone from space. Had to start from scratch...
Combat is bit unbalanced; too many mobs at a time and I struggle even with good gear at hand.

What I did like lot was research.

This is good game in own way. Despite bugs...

column8:
This game popped into my head recently, as I'd forgotten it even existed about 4 years ago. I dug it up from my library, and installed it. I'd done a similar thing with Starbound, and although I still dislike that game, I can appreciate the effort put behind it. As the window split itself across both my monitors, and then proceeded to crash on startup, I checked the forums. Based on what I read, this game hasn't had a single significant change in all those years I left it behind.

It's saddening that I could refuse to use words like "is" or "has" in favor of "was" or "had" and any review I could create would be largely unchanged. As for what this game is actually like, here's what I have to say.

If you get the game running, you'll find yourself bombarded with text once you load in. Once you actually get moving, you'll realize that the design of the world is based on broken islands that are easy to fall off of. You'll also notice that the controls of the game are janky at best. Moving feels both slippery and sluggish, hotbar selects items in the wrong direction (although this may just be a matter of preference), enemies just feel... wrong to fight, etc. The game is broken in the way only early access games can be. It's incomplete, has no endgame content at all, and is built from systems that don't function well together.

Being young, with nothing else new to play, I powered through it all for 54 hours. One day, I turned it off, and decided to never play it again. While I don't remember that day, I finally know why I did it.

Coming back to this game has made me think of early access games as grains of sand blown by desert winds. Some grains catch the winds of development and get to soar, ending up unfathomable distances from where they started.
Other games, like Edge of Space, are tossed into the air, only to fall into the ocean, and never feel the wind again.

Do not buy Edge of Space, but heed the warning it represents. Early access games do not become playable from a broken state. They can only rise above a functional state.

column8:
Bought the game in early access. A 1.0 version was pushed out that was still essentially a beta product, and to this day there are still plenty of issues plaguing the game.

- The tutorial is virtually nonexistent and there's little guidance regarding controls or objectives.
- There doesn't seem to be a story to speak of other than "You've crash-landed."
- The only gating on new recipes is what resources you've managed to find (with no guidance as to what the resources might look like or where to find them). Recipes themselves are unlocked with XP, which you get from pretty anything, including just mining dirt.
- You start on top of one of a number of small floating landmasses and have to drop down further for more advanced resources, so you either stay up top running the risk of dying in a fall and with nothing but dirt, mud, and clay, or you drop down and have trouble finding your way back to your cryopod. There's no logical reason to start on tiny floating islands, or to even have them in the first place.
- You can't build or mine in some areas until you "dominate" them which seems to always be by destroying four mob-spawners. Sometimes these mob-spawners are behind unpowered doors and the game offers no tips on how to open the doors. You can't remove them (because you haven't "dominated" the area and therefore can't mine), and Googling has been unhelpful.

This was in development at the same time as Starbound and the difference between the two is night and day. Starbound is polished, has ongoing support, offers an actual narrative, a less-cluttered and more intuitive interface (as well as a greater aesthetic charm). Edge of Space, on the other hand, just seems like an abandoned cash grab on the formula.

What's more, the game's page claims it features "Continual Support - Regular post-launch updates will bring fresh new content" and yet there was an entire two-year gap in news from the devs, who admit in one of the latest news blurbs (from 2018) that "[they] have been silent and gone for awhile, and the fact [they] have not updated [players] when [they] promised [they] would. Is not fair to [players]."

As an aside, I've noticed some of the positive reviews talk about community support on Discord. It shouldn't fall to the community to support a game in order for it to be functional and feel complete.

tl;dr: Unpolished and does a poor job of teaching the user how to play the game, so even the most basic of tasks feel like an uphill struggle. You're better off getting Starbound.

column8:
People hate on it because it's not Terraria or Starbound.

As a long-time player of Terraria, and a would-be starbound player, I can say that the negativity surrounding this game is complete and utter ignorance.

I love this game.

Yes, I was hooked by the 'Terraria-Esque' nature of the game. It's got the same heart, after all. It's a 2D sandbox with mining and fighting. But, the game provided such a new, fresh approach to that core that saying it's a worse version of Terraria is comparing apples to oranges.

Now, I can understand why people hate on this game. The start of it is so rough, so confusing, so rigid, that it doesn't really pull you in like other games might. I bought this game a long time ago, and, while I mostly blame the massive lag my previous computer had from repelling me, I was very uninterested in the game at the time of first playing.

However, I don't know why, but just recently, I came back. In the span of less than a week, I've logged 28.5 hours into this game. 

And I don't regret a single minute of it.

I'm hooked!

I haven't felt this excited to be home and play a game since I played heavily modded Terraria with friends. It's something that really makes me excited to have some spare time in my life, which is an experience I don't find with nearly any other game.

It took some time to really understand the mechanics of this game because, after all, it isn't just a fancy space version of Terraria like everyone wants it to be. It's so different. Which brings me back to why I love this game. Why it's so different from Terraria.

Exploration.

I find that Terraria's exploration system comes to be a bit lack-luster, especially after several playthroughs, normal, expert, hardcore, modded, and modded expert. It always feels grindy, boring, and, with enough dying, extremely frustrating.

But this game let me love the one thing I always wanted. Exploration. It's what this game is all about, in my opinion. Sure, there's monsters, mobs, bosses, grinding, building, mining, all of that. Maybe it doesn't do those things as well as Terraria, but I have no issue saying it's not far behind. But, the exploration in this game? It's heavenly, it's serene, and it's simply amazing. 

The very core of this game and what makes it so enjoyable to play is the vast landscapes for you to explore. And Edge of Space's formula makes this so much better. An alien planet, quite different from yours, for you to explore and grow within. Edge of Space captures this perfectly. I've never seen this much originality in the habitats you can discover. It's so unpredictable, and you never know what to expect. It's great, it's fresh, and it's fun. 

Take a look at the Achoa biome. It's magnificent. You start your adventure in this place which seems so familiar and yet, can't be more alien. Flying jellyfish are a lurking threat, yet friendly creatures like snails and frogs are fun to hop on and take a ride to the deepest depths of the world. (Seriously, thank you for letting the player stand on these and share fall speed. It's so much fun to stand on a snail as it falls miles downward into assumably certain death.) And the implementation of docile creatures is a very fine move. It allows the player to find relative peace on their travels, or, if they wish, wreak complete havoc and devastation to the population which surrounds them. It allows for a wide range of playstyles in this game, which gives it both replayability and personalization, which is one of my favorite aspects of any game, period. 

Speaking of playstyles, I should mention the elements of RPG in this game that really give it that signature Edge of Space experience.

Personally, I'm in a love-hate relationship with this portion of the game. I'm really happy that they allow for 3 types of both armor and weapon paths, but the xp system could possibly use improvement. It's honestly a gripe, not even a complaint, but it's worth noting that the xp caps at 10,000. This isn't an issue for a good portion of the game, but reaching the later half of the game really opens up some frustration, as I find myself in a rush to spend my xp at times, which is really kinda ridiculous. This only really happens when I reach that cap unknowingly, and, wishing not to waste any xp, stop whatever I'm doing and invest it in an upgrade which may or may not be extremely important to me at the time. The main issue with this is that this happens quite frequently in the middle of large-scale battles, like when I'm being surrounded by a horde of nautiluses or artilla bears, or fighting off dungeon or nest monsters. It's not even that big of a deal, but I find it somewhat annoying personally.

With all that being said, there's really nothing in the game I have to complain about. It's not the most intuitive of games, but that gives you some real satisfaction in learning and progressing. It's just a fun game. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for a unique and fresh experience in the 2D sandbox platform.

[TL:DR] Edge of Space is a brilliant game which encapsulates the wonder and curiosity of an alien planet with the dangers and hardships one may face in that environment. Disregard the negative reviews on this game and realize that this isn't Terraria. If you're looking for the exact same experience as Terraria, then go play Terraria. However, if you love exploration, space, or just 2D sandbox games, I would highly advise you to give this game a go. It has a really shaky beginning, but just give it time. I promise you it's worth it.

column8:
When Terraria was big, but didn't have as many updates as it does now, was when this game popped up. There was this game and Starbound. Now I liked Terraria and it's a really good game. But this game, I bought it as soon as I could because I wanted more of that Terraria feeling, same with Starbound. Seeing how both games were in space, which opens a door to a much bigger game; I had a lot of hopes.

I initially played it for a while, coming back every now and again to check on the new stuff. But as later on, when I booted it up again after about a few months of not playing, I noticed nothing changed, I just played for a bit and that was that. When I played it recently, it was still in the same state. I went to the reviews and forums to see all the posts about this, and how the game is abandoned.

This saddens me because it could have been great if the devs worked on it with more passion, actually trying to compete with Starbound. But from what I am seeing, Starbound completely changed how it was to how it is now; while Edge of Space is just a skeleton now, not a corpse, a skeleton. Also kind of funny seeing my friends reviews for Starbound saying how that game is bad and how Edge of Space is better.

So just remember, check the dates for the reviews to get a good timeframe of what was going on. Also, in case this wasn't clear, don't buy this. Unless the devs or someone comes along to revive this game, it will just be another Terraria-like game.

But if you do want a game like this but actually has more stuff to it, play Starbound.

column8:
So, I didn't want to write a review of this game until I was sure it was dead.

Sadly, I'm sure it's dead. I backed this on Kickstarter way back in May 2012. The original delivery day was Aug 2012, but I'm sure no one with any experience backing stuff on Kickstarter is unsurprised to learn it missed it's delivery day. That was fine, honestly. I hung out in their chatrooms, played the early builds and I feel I got my money's worth playing those builds.

But.. it was never complete. If you read the latest announcement (August 2018, as of this writing), you'll see they had to take contract work to fund EoS. They had to do some changes to the unity engine to get it to work, and etc. etc.. Still, work progressed, so I kept playing (on mostly pre-Steam pre-releases)

Then the Steam release hit.  While it added more content, I'd still regard it as fundamentally incomplete. But that's fairly common for the projects I backed, so while I went 'hmm..' I reserved judgement.  Then the devs vanished. Oh, dear.

I didn't think most of it until I read the most recent review. While I can admit it's nice to go 'We screwed up, we can't fix this..'.. it still means that only at 75%+ discounts, is this game remotly worth it. And.. at that, I still wouldn't recommend it.

This game is effectively incomplete and abanonded. Unless this changes, do not buy it.

column8:
Going into detail on the theme, graphics, or almost anything else is a moot point at this juncture. This is for one simple reason: This is an incomplete/unfinished game. A familiar story about developers in over their heads that could not deliver what they promised. If you wouldn't pay for an unfinished meal at a restaurant; then please don't do yourself the disservice of wasting your hard earned money on this over inflated proof of concept piece.

Developers came out recently with a discord interview belaying their woes of why this game was abandoned then followed by *years* of radio silence. As a small business owner myself, I'm a little lacking in empathy here. I don't really care why Handyman Studios failed to deliver. I also don't care why it took so long to break the radio silence. None of this matters in a consumer & business transaction. I also don't believe Handyman Studios owes me anything more; not legally at least (ethically...well, That's a can of worms I don't want to open). 

The one thing the studio does deserve is the reputation it *earned* itself. My own success or failure is dependent on the same thing: the reputation I build as a business. This applies to every and all businesses on the planet. Based on Handyman Studios(or whatever they may re-brand themselves as) self-earned reputation, I would consider any future purchase from them a risk not worth taking. This is simply an opinion based off their past performance. Nothing more.

Its 2018 and no Update in sight. I still come back every month click the second Vid on the Steam sale page and listen to this amazing Music. Everytime i do this i wish the Devs will come back and finish what they have started. EoS is at the moment not a great Game. Compared to Starbound or Terraia ...it is fun for while but you will lose interest very soon. 

Now that there are Signs of Life from the Devs my Hope is coming back, that they have not abondend this game and will finish and / or polish it. EoS deserves to be a good Game. It has the potential and in the right hands it will be a great Game.

I give it a thump up.... because...hope should never die!

column8:
"To try to even bring it current would be out of scope, as we literally built an engine that sat ontop before unity to make the 2d rendering and all the things we needed for it to work.  A lot of our standing bugs are related to unity memory management issues at that point.   

As we move forward, is going to be do we feel there is a strong enough community and enough support and we can pull it together to work on a new EoS game or a new other game.  The honest end answer is we donâ€™t have the capacity to go back and update EoS. Nor would it be technologically viable to do.  

I know that sucks, and I am going to talk about what we do to give back and paying it forward to those who have helped us and got EoS and honoring them.   Thatâ€™s the harsh reality on how everything has played out. " 
From the devs mouths themselves

We got an apology for it being abandoned, but 2 years too late, and this was after being silent once already.  I can't recommend this game, it's unfinished and will never be fixed.

I can only hope the devs learn from this wreck and improve, they have a lot to work against now.

For those looking for a game similar, I'd suggest:
Terraria
Starbound (when on sale)

Or if you like Harvest Moon esque games:
Stardew Valley

column8:
Think of it like this. Terraria and Starbound had a kid that hasn't fully matured yet. Interface scaling and sprite resolution are in desperate need of higher resolution support. I mean the sharpness of sprites needs to be better when playing at 1080p and up and the UI scale needs to change with screen resolution rather than be locked at pixel scale. That is the biggest issue I have with this game. It's obvious with character creation. The game has a rather interesting storyline and your choice dialogue when talking to npc's is black and white. The first npc you meet is a hover shark. Cute voice but not fitting for that size of a character. Everything else is fine to me.

I can recommend this game as long as the devs keep updating it. I'd recommend it even more if the texture resolution and UI scaling were much better.

column8: Mangel an tutorial info und schlechte bau assistenten machen das game zum absolutem albtraum

Abandonware. Years of silence from a dev team that didn't manage to complete the game for the 'full release', let alone the enormous amount of time that has passed since. 

All the reviews were scrubbed, despite this title being out since 2015. Allow me to assure you it was sitting at a well deserved Mostly Negative. Handyman Studios doesn't have any other titles on Steam, and Reverv Triple XP has 'published' several super low effort/abandonware titles, most notably Osiris. 

If you're looking for a game that fills this niche and wasn't just a shameless cash grab, I highly reccomend Terraria or Starbound. Both are fantastic side scrolling pixel survival crafting games that accomplish much more than this title would've, even if it'd been completed. 

Also, check my review history. I'm nearly certain this is my first negative review ever. I'm not that guy. I consider this a public service announcement. I wouldn't buy it again for $5. 

Learn from my mistake.
column9:
Abandonware. Years of silence from a dev team that didn't manage to complete the game for the 'full release', let alone the enormous amount of time that has passed since. 

All the reviews were scrubbed, despite this title being out since 2015. Allow me to assure you it was sitting at a well deserved Mostly Negative. Handyman Studios doesn't have any other titles on Steam, and Reverv Triple XP has 'published' several super low effort/abandonware titles, most notably Osiris. 

If you're looking for a game that fills this niche and wasn't just a shameless cash grab, I highly reccomend Terraria or Starbound. Both are fantastic side scrolling pixel survival crafting games that accomplish much more than this title would've, even if it'd been completed. 

Also, check my review history. I'm nearly certain this is my first negative review ever. I'm not that guy. I consider this a public service announcement. I wouldn't buy it again for $5. 

Learn from my mistake.

I liked the game single player but then I got bored, and wanted to play multiplayer. It was incredibly hard to try to play a multiplayer game. I was told by a dev to open a port? I've never had to do that for a game, ever. I'm pretty sure all modern games have some sort of programming that would automatically use one the unused ports on your system. IT still didn't work after opening that port. I closed that port right back up...

Fun game, until it wasn't.

column8:
A Boring Game with sleeping Developers.

1.Overview. Depressing landscape and music. :(

2.Characters. They look like, they spent the holidays on Jupiter. :(

3.Enigmatic story. I don't know what's going on. :/

4.Technology Tree. I like it. :)

5.Challange Rooms. Not bad. :)

6.Quests. Maybe stupid one like "how to chop trees". :/

7.Graphic. Is okay. :/

8.Performance. It did not hang anywhere. :)

9.Bugs. Sometimes the shadows went away. :/

10.Multiplayer. I didn't come to a server. :/
But all in all a average to run-down game. 2/10. You can try it ,but buy better Starbound or Terraria.

some items have no good description
some weapons don't aim well

column8: You may want to pick this game up if its on sale for like 99 cents, but ive played through it, ive seen what it has to offer, and it isn't that much. It had promise and content a few years ago, but now it seems kind of like garbage terraria. I was like a 12 year old when I bought it, and forgot to look at the reviews. column8:
the first thing I see when launching this game is a 404 error.

then a codex that wants me to read about how to start.this is anoying. and bad design. 

what is this lighting system? I've done a bit of unity work before and it seems the darkness is a forground object. it experiances paralax realitive to its background so as i move towrads darkness it dosn't stay over whatever ovbject it was over it moves realitive to the layer game objects are on. this is probabbly unity doing this and can't be fixed by the game devs. the problem is this is not how you make a lighting system. I would feel ashamed turning this game in for a class project putting it on steam should be a mark of eternal shame.

I'm on a planet during the day. I am in darkness. i can tell it is day because I can see the sun. I am in darkness. If i jump a few feet up I am in light. darkness feels more like a gass or a shadow here than absensce oflight. why is it dark here? I do not know I can see the sun. below me underground theret is light? is there light coming from somewhere? no. it seems that darkness is what travels this place.

what demons cursed your code with this pointer system? so I can see my mouse pointer and i can tell that I move the point that my miner/gun is pointing at by moving my mouse. the laser is not pointed at my mouse. ok a dsync?(NO)  the laser/gun   spases out sometimes and decidse it doesn't want to point where you are trying to point it and flips off in some random direction. this makes it so the position of the mouse pointer is meaningless to where the laser/gun is pointed

column8:
To address all the people saying this game is "abandoned" - as far as I can tell after 10 hours, it's a mostly complete game. There are a few bugs, a couple unimplemented items that say "(SOON)", but it seems like everything you need to play the game is there. I don't know if there's an ending because I'm never going to get that far, but I get the feeling that a lot of people are salty that the devs didn't spend years and years adding new free content like Terraria.

That said, Edge of Space isn't terribly fun past the first 5 hours. At the start it's very similar to Terraria - you kill, mine & craft   your way up the tech tree. However, the higher you progress, the more you get bogged down with useless items, needing to use many different machines to craft each of the different alloys, clunky menus, stale combat, mining scarcer and scarcer materials, etc. Basically after 5 hours it becomes a joyless grindfest - higher tiers of tech stop bringing new mechanics and instead just bump up the numbers, but each tier is progressively harder to achieve than the last.

Was it worth the US$3 I paid for it? Yes, it was fun for long enough. But it would have been a Recommend if it were just a 10 hour fun game, instead of being 5 hours of fun, and probably 50ish more hours of grind.

column8:
~Neronix17

If you're not happy with the way an early access game ended up then that's your problem not the developers, what you expect will never line up with what the developers aim for in any EA game. The state the game is in currently is perfectly fine for an OK game, when you buy into early access you accept that you could end up with an unfinished product for many reasons, in this case they officially released it, "unfinished" or not you folks not recommending but having played it for 200+ hours got your moneys worth.~

I see reviews like this attacking a less then satisfied customer base all the time. I would say it's like saying "I don't care if that hamburger gave you food poisoning you ate it and enjoyed it at the time you should have known the risk."
It's the how dare you be angry about this mentality that I think is a complete joke. 
The funny thing is I would almost agree with Neronix17 if the game was still in EA and this unfinished broken promise of a game was not being sold right now (at $14.99 for the standered edition no less) as done.

With all that said let me review the game.

Gameplay:  It's unfinished
Sound:        It's unfinished
Graphics:    It's unfinished
Controls:     It's unfinished

Conclusion: Edge of space is known to be crap go with the hamburger (It's cheaper too!!) you have a better chance of it being good and only a possibilty of it giving you food poisoning.

column8:
[h1] An unfortunate title [/h1]

In a world where there was no [b]Terraria[/b] or [b]Starbound[/b], this might have done better.

But in [u]this[/u] world, my review would merely be comparing Edge of Space to those titles, and there are plenty of those types of reviews present here.  I feel like there was some love in creating this title, and to be compared with Terraria and Starbound means they did something right.  Unfortunately, I played this AFTER those games and with all the content present in Starbound and Terraria, there's little reason to f[spoiler]art[/spoiler] around in this game.

Maybe co-op is good, but none of my friends own this game, and its probably better that way.

[i]Note: It's not a great sign when the message of the day that pops up at the title screen points to a 404'd url[/i]

column8:
The fact this hasn't been removed from steam yet is ridiculous as the dev abandoned the game years ago. Bad controls, bad mechanics, poor systems layed atop each other to the point of nausea. 

Spend money on just about any other 2D side scrolling game and you'll get your moneys worth tenfold.

-August Edit/Update-

The devs have formally acknowledged that the game is dead due to outstanding bugs with the code base it's written on and it only took them 3 years to state "sorry we couldn't finish what we started."

Good on them for admitting it but shame on them for adding that there may be another Edge of Space game some day.

A new game that will also cost you because their dead game just didn't work out.

Was abandoned long ago, developers went radio silent for a couple years, only popping up to give the illusion of working on the game with vague unmet promises of more information in future. Last communication from them was a 2 year late half assed apology which didn't seem to actually have any goal outside of getting some attention.

The state of the game, does not matter with a developer like this, who has openly admitted that the game is unfinished, not even polished to a usable state, but yet still sells a special edition of it as if it was finished and has any value beyond being an additional digit in your Steam Library.

column8: #ERROR!

This is the first review I'll be leaving about a game I have actually not gotten around to playing yet. Little hard to when I have so many others I'm still working on, not to mention, the little time I have to play games, busy updating mods I have made or taken over for other titles. The reason for this review? Check the forums for Edge Of Space and it screams plenty. If you want a game like this, but with support and modability, huge forum, and game play where after spending 100 hours on it, you havent scratched the content? Then buy Starbound. Want a game thats incomplete, crashes, or just don't care losing $15 to $40? Then buy Edge Of Space. I bought it for $4.50 to tinker with if I ever get bored with my other games, and that has not happened. 
I visited the forums a few times for Edge Of Space, and the complaints are in the thousands. It's bad enough when I hear of adults getting scammed, but to see how many kids lost their money for a game that had showed promise, and then the dev ran off, thats just wrong. 
As of this review, 4 new price deals are now showing. $14.99 standard edition, $24.99 Special Edition.( If there is no one writing code for this game, how on earth can special content be added? it can't! You get the same incomplete game at $14.99 or $24.99) Then there is the 4-pack for $39.99. The last one, Special Edition upgrade $11.99. Zero Times Zero = Zero. Zero + Zero = 0. 
As I said before, the games been at $4.50 for a long time. Anyone could have gotten 10 copies for $45.00. Guess the company figured no one would notice a 70% price increase for the holidays.
When I bought this title for $4.50, I already read the complaints not just in the reviews, but the forums as well. If you just want something to tinker with, I suggest waiting till the price drops back to $4.50 or less, or even one of those 90% coupons. 
This is not one of those titles where trolls are leaving negative reviews because updates are slow in coming. It's because the people who started this game, just left. Three years ago. Had you clicked the developer link before Steam had updated the game client, you would have gotten a page not found.
Seems the Publisher has no issue of taking peoples money, their link is still active. 
Anyway, if I ever get the time, I will update this with information about what game play is possible. Christmas is just around the corner. There are so Many games like this, but MUCH better. Some are early access (EA) some not. I highly recommend Spacebound, Terraria, Dig or Die, Crea, Planet Centauri, Signs Of Life, and Wayward (Small multi-player game but still fun, and cheap too!) All the games I suggested, are either completed or still getting improved but very playable and very little or no bugs at all. Every one of the suggested titles, have their own multi-server program which is either stand alone, or built into the game client to allow friends and family to join you, plus you can build and explore in every one of them. Some games have endings, some infinate, some so huge you will take ages just to scratch the content. Most have workshop mods too. Look them up, but please, don't make the mistake of paying full price for Edge Of Space and expect a full working title. Read the forums, and see for yourself. 90% complaints can't all be trolls.
As for (EA)Early Access games; dont let one like this ruin it for everyone else. Games like this that  actually made it, or came close , had difficult starts because of games like this and no one wants to pay full price for a game to get burned. If your unsure of a new game, check first on what the publisher put up. It may not always be accurate, as some things may not be in game yet, or had to be temperarily removed. A new game that only shows stills, no actual game play or tries to get your attention by putting up a fancy video that has nothing to do with the advertised game, those you need to be wary of. Check youtube to see if anyone posted information or game play footage. If the person is reputable, then Id say the game is worth the investment. 
One last thing to look for, is if you did get burned. Check the publisher, and note their other titles. If you got burned by them on one title, most likely, others they sell will be the same.

column8: For anything this game has to offer, either Terraria or Starbound did it better. For example, multiplayer. They evidently didn't want to host servers, so they took the obvious route: make your playerbase *dig through the files* just to host a game. Why should I need knowledge of how to use Command Prompt in complex ways just to host a local game? Don't get me wrong, I am a programmer and have been for years, but this is ridiculous. An unpolished game experience not worth the money.

column8:
A fun game when it runs. Crashes a lot. Saves on its own schedule (i.e. host doesn't choose when the game saves; the game chooses when it saves). Eats items/progress arbitrarily (happened to me twice in the space of 4 hours of playing). Has potential but thus far has had insufficient follow-through. Port forwarding (1337) is an annoyance.
On a positive note, there seem to be a fair number of things to craft and it has plenty of stuff to kill.

column8:
I got this game back when it was in Early Access, it had a great community and the developer was involved with us. The game wasn't great back then, but it had potential, and it was easy to see everyone was excited aout it.

A few months later the dev slaps on the 1.0 tag and increases the price while it still plays like an underdeveloped Beta patch made ten years ago, and since then nothing has changed and the devs have disappeared.

It's sad to say this game has single handedly ruined all Betas and Early Accesss games for me.
I can't recommend it - at any price.
