column8:
I have over 600 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. 

One Hour Reviews #54 - Edge of Space

You'll get an immediate sense of the quirky writing in Edge of Space as you start by having a conversation with a talking shark.  There isn't that much of a story to tell, just that your spaceship crashed and now you are stranded on a planet.  The writing is definitely tongue-in-cheek.

I liked how the game began, and appreciated that it wasn't too difficult to begin with.  Although I do wish they had explained some things a little better.  The game includes a "tutorial video" that I felt was kind of a shortcut, as opposed to just better integrating a tutorial into the game.  Still, the first set of quests you get involve gathering various components to then craft into items, which is a pretty major part of the gameplay.

I wish the controls were better.  I found mining to be frustrating at times.  You use a mining pick that you aim with your mouse.  But the aim is weird at times.  I kept wanting to just point my mouse cursor at a block to mine.  But the aim is actually based on the position of your cursor relative to a point on your body in order to determine direction.  This means sometimes, even when your mouse cursor is on a block, the aim is actually causing the laser to hit a different block.  It's a minor annoyance but mining is such a major part of the gameplay that it definitely adds up.

If you've played Terraria, then you'll pretty much know exactly what to expect here.  It's pretty hard not to consider this game a knock off.  There are some minor differences with crafting, like the way you can use different items to fill a recipe.  But as a whole the gameplay feels extremely familiar.   I don't hold it against Edge of Space for being a knock off, but when you're borrowing from another game, you should at least make some notable improvements.  And it really doesn't feel that way.  And when you add the fact that Terraria is cheaper ($14.99 vs. $9.99 regular prices), I really can't recommend this game unless you've just played Terraria to death and want to scratch that itch with a different game.

column8:
Game design is one of those things that, when done really well, goes almost unnoticed. Sadly, this is the one area where Edge of Space really fails to deliver. The art isn't bad, the worlds are imaginative, and some aspects of gameplay are actually very fun! Tearing through rock with a high-powered mining lazer feels great. Unfortunately, these high points are all brought down by clumsily implemented features that are frustrating and poorly explained. A lot of things nagged at me during the 12-or-so hours I spent trying to enjoy Edge of Space, but I'll focus on the worst: dungeons.

At a certain point in the game, progression through the tech-tree is halted by materials that can only be obtained from a dungeon. No problem! Except the dungeons are awful. The freedom of your jetpack and mining laser are stripped from you, and you're forced to clumsily hop along through some kind of half-baked platformer full of dark, confusing, repetitive rooms. Exploring the rest of the dungeon after going down a dead-end branch involves slowly backtracking through rooms that are even harder to navigate in reverse. It's so tedious that it's easier to just die so that you can start again from the top. The drop-rate for those materials you need is abysmal to boot. Just terrible all-around.

column8:
Played randomly through its early release phase and then played after release.  It's a fun game the soundtrack is fairly nice and honestly I was a bit shocked to see people saying its a buggy mess perhaps I played right after major bug fixes were put in because my only problem is random hitching (2-3 second freeze which im guessing is a worldsave or trash collection that isn't optimized due to unity being a bit bad at stock).

The game has changed a lot since i played it when it first came out, it's a bit more non linear then some games and doesn't seem to have a clearcut path but that isn't a dealbreaker for me.  All in all the enemies are diverse and I've gotten about 10 tiers out of 15 into some of the research in a fairly short stint of time.   I would say it still meets my 1$ per hour level of entertainment quota making this game a suggested game in my opinion.

Can't really come up with a pros/cons list at the time because I feel theres not a ton of super strong points to be made.  I'm a terraria fanatic and also loved starbound but I can't feel the need to compare them aside from saying "I enjoyed this one too".

It's a good game, quite polished as of today in its 1.9 version.
If the developers keep it up, it could reach the level of a futuristic Terraria version. My recommendation for all fans of the genre. You won't regret getting this game.

column8:
Feels very weird in comparison to a game like terraria/starbound, and is very difficult with a very VERY slow progression path, I myself didn't enjoy it.
But I'm sure it has many fun endgame items and mechanics, as I have only played it for a short period of time. so I would recommend it if you've got the patience to deal with the unexplained beginning.

column8:
Annoying tutorial with annoying characters, all forced upon you in the beginning.  Worst of all, it isn't even a good tutorial.  Nothing important is told to me (how to craft, attack, etc) and I need to figure it out myself, instead I'm just told to do things.  I couldn't be bothered to go any further than that, why should I waste my time trying to search for entertainment?

Play Terraria or Starbound, those games are far better than this trash.

column9:
It's fun, but the gameplay is a bit odd.
As a Terraria-style 2D sandbox game, it has enough content to provide 10-20 hours of enjoyment. The latest patch has largely addressed critical system flaws and bugs, and there are no major obstacles to gameplay. However, the game's content is fundamentally incomplete, and the rich content early on thins out as you progress, which can be a bit boring. Also, because the game isn't complete, there's no clear goal to complete, making it difficult to maintain motivation.

The gameplay is standard for a Terraria-style 2D sandbox game, offering a wide variety of gameplay elements, without leaning too heavily toward exploration, mining, combat, or action. If I had to say, the building element feels a bit weak.
In terms of the system, you can unlock recipes using experience points gained from combat and mining, and check the required items from the recipes, eliminating the hassle of checking the Wiki along the way. The items you can craft are sci-fi-inspired, with a wide variety of patterns and practicalities, including a variety of long-range weapons, flying units, vehicles, and pets.
Additionally, special maps that can be accessed by clearing certain conditions feature pure 2D action and boss battles where building and mining are not possible.
To be honest, the early stages were fun and exciting, and I could sense its potential.
However, as you progress, the game's unfinished parts begin to appear, and my excitement turns to disappointment.

Perhaps the result of trying too hard to make a game that allows anything to happen in every direction, the game's level of completion drops drastically midway through.
First of all, the game has a hierarchical structure of roughly five layers of environments stacked on top of each other as you progress, but only three levels of these biomes are properly created. Below the third level there is simply an empty space covered in dirt blocks. Furthermore, only the first level has properly balanced combat and events, while the second and third levels feel like they're mostly just filled with new ores and enemies.
There's no final boss or anything like that even as you progress through the game, and other than a few early bosses, there's no other indicator of progress. So, halfway through, there's no other purpose beyond defeating enemies, digging up ore, and crafting new weapons and armor.
Ultimately, the game only feels well-crafted for the first 10 hours or so; after that, it feels completely unfinished. Furthermore, since there's no clear goal to complete, the only point of playing is to see how unfinished the game is.

While I was playing and writing this review, several updates were released, so the developers' enthusiasm isn't lacking. However, judging from the patch fix list, most of them address minor bugs, and no major changes that would address the overall incompleteness of the game, as I've written in this review. Considering the time between this game's early access release and its official release, I honestly don't think this development company could complete a game of this scale after such a long time. However, it's possible that major improvements have been made in the future, so please check the date and time this review was written.

Unfortunately (or fortunately?), this game isn't completely unfun. If it were unfinished and unfun, I would simply call it a crappy game and be done with it, but I can at least say that I found the first 10 hours or so fun, so if you understand that it's unfinished and are happy to enjoy it for around 10 hours, then I think it's worth playing. ...But even so, it's still difficult to recommend it to others.

column9: The game is boring. If you're interested in what's where, where, and why for the first few hours, there's simply nothing to do. Some projects have NPCs for whom you can build houses and other things, but here they're just statues that spin in one place and give a few quests. If you play, it's only on a network with a friend. It's impossible to play this game alone for long.

column8:
I bought this back in January of 2013. The game was shitty back then but it was early access so that was to be expected. It's now 2016 and the devs no longer have this marked as an early-access game. That means that the overwhelming number of bugs, lack of features, and overall crappy feel are inexcusable.

I can't and won't recommend that anyone buy this game, especially not for $14.99.

column8:
First for all, my english still on improvement. Sorry for that and be patient, please.

I am really, but really impressed with this game. When I saw the others players reviews, I start to think what could be wrong with those negative reviews and I choose to see by my own eyes plus my experience and I can tell you securely: all is going nice and well here.

First for all, see my account details: I have 196 hours of Terraria and 149 of Starbound, and guys, this game has a lot of potential. Can almost surpass this two games right now, if they keep working on this game, maybe it can happen.

In the first hour playing this game, I liked everything, didn't have any issue with anything. They have a very nice progression sistem, the challenge rate of the game is very well done, many content to explore, craft, learn... Enemies are nice and have many dangerous.

Some guys said than is confuse, but I desagree. If you stop to read a little bit, you see than everything is quite understandable. Ill put some points of the game than are great potential if compared with other games like him, as Starbound for an example.

- Ambience. The amount of creatures, plants, all the ecosystem around you is very rich and alive. You don't have to walk so far to find ruins, dangerous creatures and radiation points.
- Transport. Great amount of options and all of them is very nice. Many of them is using some aliens, so you can imagine.
- Radiation levels. You never will know what place will have radiation until got your first step and start to die. Is a very nice hardcore surprise. No milk drinkers like this, I know, and I like it.
- Experience. Kill, mining, solving quests from regions (like exterminate nests of zombies for dominate the local), all of this give you experience points.
- Science progression. Here enters where you spend those experience points. You can focus on exploration, building, weapons, researching, transport,... I believe if you want to get all of this, you will have to play a good time, making things interesting.

This is all I saw in just one hour of play. I'll play more and redo that review from the game, but from now, I can say than the game is very well done, nice, quite of nice ideas implemented, worst every coin and is very enjoyable an playable. Yes, I recommend this game. If you like the challenge and fight from Terraria with the spacial atmosphere from Starbound but with very more nice content and more serious implentation, you will love this game.

Oh god, this game is so intense, has a huge learning curve, and has bad art. I was exited to play another terraria knockoff, but it was so difficult. I had to turn off most of my applications because its a RAM-hog, plus I had to watch 5 min vids just to learn how to use the tool I spawn with. Mediocre concept, bad execution, good art style. JUST KIDDING BAD ART STYLE.

column8: ive tried to love this game i really have the story and such is cute but bland there is no drive to keep going like you hope the grind is annoying to say the least and feels highly unbalanced and as for most of the game it self just feels unpolished for a game that was trying to almost become a successor to terraria or something honestly idk what they were going for the game just sucks im not that great at reviews but just dont get it unless you got a bunch of friends who want to play with you and one of you knows how to port forward because yes this game has no easy multiplayer killing it even more imo(why have a multiplayer possable game on steam that doesnt use it and requires you to manually port forward) just lame and i know it costs mony to run a server but what are we paying for then because almost nothing has changed and ive owned this since the beginning almost, ok rant over i give the game a 5/10 because it DOES have a few saving graces for a while.....a short while

column8:
At v1.09 the game still feels like it should be in beta. Not buggy from my experience but the mechanics are very clunky and directionless. Some things the game desperately needs:
Bigger map/minimap
Better tool aiming (I should be able to break a block right in front of me without moving back and forth)
Better introduction
Fewer items- Within an hour of playing you'll have at least 20 different stacks of items with no indication of their relative worth or even where they came from sometimes. Inventory fills up quick and there's no good way to manage it, especially when you need some items to craft something.
column9:
At v1.09 the game still feels like it should be in beta. Not buggy from my experience but the mechanics are very clunky and directionless. Some things the game desperately needs:
Bigger map/minimap
Better tool aiming (I should be able to break a block right in front of me without moving back and forth)
Better introduction
Fewer items- Within an hour of playing you'll have at least 20 different stacks of items with no indication of their relative worth or even where they came from sometimes. Inventory fills up quick and there's no good way to manage it, especially when you need some items to craft something.

column8: Ive been playing this game for the last couple of days and i have to say that it is a phenomanally gameplay rich game filled with fun and engaging contenet.  Alot of people on here are claiming it is a Starbound ripoff but at least this game is finished and runs smoothly on my pc (with the minor hiccup here and there) but all in alli have had no game breaking bugs or crashes in my play time. As i mention there is alot of content to play with, one example is the ability to travel to dungeons changing the gameplay from a Terraria style build and crafting game into somthing a kin to Super Metroid or Castlevania Symphony of the Night. The gun play is satisfying and a multitude of guns gives a lot of choice to the player as to what they want to use.  Do you use the laser shotgun to blast your foes to pieces with a point blank blast to the frontal lobe? or do you take the Volter and electricute two enemies at the same time disintegrating there bodies!  when it comes down to it i would definetly recomend this game!!

column8:
I've played the game off-and-on for the last couple of years, and it is a fun game.  It's Terraria or Starbound, but with better graphics.  However, the content of the game, while not terrible, is still lacking a bit, and there's still a lot of work that needs to be done.  The recent 1.0 Release I feel was a bit premature, as they actually removed some content from the game with the intent of it being added-in later (hopefully not as DLC).

I tenatively rate this with a thumbs-up, but I might change this depending on how it progresses.  I've heard some rumors that some of the planned content for the game will instead be released as DLC, but until that's confirmed I won't downvote it, as I have gotten my money's worth out of the game.

The easy description of this game?  Starbound with better graphics but with less content.

column8:
An interesting experiment testing what would happen if a game was made with a quality programmer and a talented game artist but without a designer.  To me it feels like a game made by committee, everyone added a bit of what they wanted and no one walked away happy.  I dislike being negative about a game because its obvious a lot of effort went into this, but it feels, akward, and forced.  The humor is wierd, from the laser shark to the quests, the progress is jerky and unsatisfactory and the world is a jumbled nightmare.  Ultimately, this game has twice the content of a game like Crea, and none of the charm.

tl;dr - good bones, awful execution, give it a miss in its current state.

column8: Ho acquistato questo gioco nell'agosto 2014, perchÃ¨ mi sembrava un gioco che prometteva bene e meritava il pre acquisto. A distanza di un anno e mezzo, Ã¨ ancora un enorme work in progress. Non lo trovo giocabile. I mob sono troppi e continuano a spawnare e impediscono addirittura di muoversi, si accumulano letteralmente negli angoli e se ti avvicini troppi rischi di venire trasportato via mentre stai cercando di camminare o prendere risorse. Il nuovo tutorial Ã¨ costituito da un video in inglese senza sottotitoli e da un menu da cui non Ã¨ possibile capire bene neanche i comandi. La mini mappa non funziona e ci sono diversi bug grafici. Non mi sta piacendo e lo dico da amante di Terraria e di Minecraft. Non mi aspettavo ovviamente lo stesso gioco, ma lo trovo difficile non tanto da giocare, ma proprio da usare. Spero ci saranno dei miglioramenti. Nel frattempo vi sconsiglio di comprarlo e aspettare che gli sviluppatori si schiodano un po' dalla via che stanno percorrendo, perchÃ¨ per me non funziona.
column9: I bought this game in August 2014 because it seemed promising and worth pre-purchasing. A year and a half later, it's still a huge work in progress. I don't find it playable. There are too many mobs, they keep spawning, and they even prevent you from moving. They literally pile up in corners, and if you get too close, you risk being carried away while trying to walk or collect resources. The new tutorial consists of an English video without subtitles and a menu where you can't even understand the controls. The mini-map doesn't work, and there are several graphical bugs. I'm not enjoying it, and I say this as a Terraria and Minecraft fan. I obviously wasn't expecting the same game, but I find it difficult not so much to play, but to use. I hope there will be improvements. In the meantime, I advise against buying it and waiting for the developers to change their approach a bit, because it just doesn't work for me.

column8:
Ok......The review.......Mixed?????

Before anyone else bashes this game more for being "Terrible" hear me out, this game was released September 17, 2015 which I remind you this game before hand had been worked on for a consecutive 4 years before its release.

The reason I bring the release date up is that the popular game "Starbound" came out on Dec 4, 2013 and yet it has yet to have come out of early access.To remind you Edge of space yet it came out earlier got out of early access faster then "Starbound".

Another important issue to point out is how people after buying The "Edge of Space Special Edition" complained about not getting the content immediately, let me remind you that a game is very difficult to program and create a whole new game from scratch,

Oh yea and if you want to see how much was put into this game look at the The "Edge of Space The Journey through early access" image.

I am one of the not many people on steam who will accept any game no matter what it is . In my oppinion this game is great because it has just the right amount of content.

A message to everyone on steam before you rate a game think about how it took this person or team hours of their own time to create the game you are criticizing.

column8: I tried to like this  game as I bought it in a bundle thinking it might be like Terraria. Was wrong. I think the epic music from the trailers sucked me it is the only real highlight. This seems a bit of a mess of a game with terrible controls, painful graphics, vague storyline and unintuitive gameplay. You spend an hour in horrible menus just trying to configure the thing to run properly. Then you get these tutorial videos in tiny windows that won't even fullscreen that still don't seem to make much sense. On at least two of my machines all I got it music because the game got stuck in the loading screen forever ... please spare yourself the pain.

column8:
this game just wasnt ready for primetime. it should be called mining simulator cause the majority of time spent was on mining materials to make crap to mine crap faster.
I dont think any amount of tweaking can fix how boring and tedious this game is. on top of being boring its poorly designed .It had potential but it falls flat on its face from orbit. The dungeon design is so bad its a sin and your boosters are disabled in dungeons so its even more boring than it should be. there is no soundtrack just some depressing background ambience crap. most of the dungeon fights take place in really cramped quarters with no whrere to dodge (I still managed to beat the enemies for the record) .  The pathfinding is even worse sadly so its easy to get lost because of dead ends and dungeon loops. Ill continue to try at later date hopefully with updates the game is less painful to endure 4/10 for now

column8:
I waited a long time to review this game, mainly because I don't like or want to contribute to negative reviews. 

I acquired this game in pre-Alpha back in 2013 and it was a rather RAW version of the game back then. The forums were kicking on the main webpage and wheels were turning with update ideas and the direction of the game. Fast forward 2-3 years and there is a lot of development, a lot of change, and a game that has been finished. There were many character wipes and world wipes along the way = That was to be expected. I bought it on pre-order before early access, and played for about 6-8 months through early access, so a few save wipes isn't a huge deal. 

However, I think another user said it best " I think the negative reviews are born mostly out of frustration with how long the game took to get from early access to release." 

Here we are three years later with a game that is no longer in Early Access but still has clunky controls and somewhat of a grind feel. However - it has come a long way, and if you came  here NOT expecting to grind in order to craft and survive, I don't know what you were expecting.

I played some of the most recent updates and will update my review from not recommended to recommended, but with a disclaimer attached: This game still doesn't feel 100% to me. But, Terraria never did either - far from it - and everyone loves to compare this title to Terraria. Terraria was lacking in story line, direction, but had an abundance of content and playability with constant updates. This game is proceeding along a similar path, but a  year or so ago they introduced a Tutorial stage at the beginning of the game. Instead of the tutorial level - the game now appears to have something else, that exists more as a dialogue feature that I won't spoil.

I"ll keep checking in on the updates as they come along.

column8:
I understand I only spent a few minutes in this game, but unfortunately that was all I needed.

First problem I encountered that immediately threw me into a rage...audio crackling.

Normally I would believe this to be some sort of sound driver issue, but as someone who regularly uses Skype, Pandora, numerous other games and software with absolutely zero problem in sound, I found this to be the foreshadowing of the only stain in my library out of (currently) 147 other items. Reinstallation of drivers and the game itself has produced no fix. Fabulous.

Second issue, which I should say was already mentioned by someone else in the reviews on this item...sluggish gameplay. It feels like you're trying to swim through molasses. I was trying to gun down uh, floating jellyfish and other unpleasant critters and it felt like I was in a slow-motion Matrix scene (minus the badassery by a long shot, that is).

Third issue. There were no prominent enough sound effects for mining or busting something's skull in. I expected some splattering or crumbling or something. What I got was a piss-poor puff noise for most of it. Seriously? What kind of horse crap is this?

Fourth issue. I'm very happy I was able to adapt to the game itself as quickly as I did, because the game not pausing with the tutorial UI up in my face was extremely unsettling and left me open to get owned by the nearest hungry maw. Someone with very little experience with games like this will not be so fortunate in the future.

Fifth issue. This game  has some sloppy sprite work on the player avatars. Normally I would let this slide, but I know this game has been worked on for quite some time, so no, I am not going to let it go. Hell no. You can definitely tell a lot of the features you're able to add onto the avatar in creation were lazily pasted on. Thankfully, the fitting futuristic artwork helped balance it out.

Sixth issue. OH HOW CUTE THE GAME ONLY HAS A RESOLUTION CHANGE OPTION AND V-SYNC FOR GRAPHIC SELECTIONS. LOL WTF IS THIS, 2004?!

Edge of Space was supposed to be the answer to the demand of an outer space sandbox game like Terraria. In fact, when it was advertised, it was proclaiming to be better and a bit of a sequel to the installment. What a waste of cyberspace and time! Terraria is everything this game wanted to try to be. You know, functional and good?

In fact, if you want a good sandbox game similar to Terraria that occurs in space, either sit down with Minecraft and some mods, or get a game that actually does this shit right; STARBOUND.

Save your money, ladies and gents. This title belongs in the dev studio for quite a few years more before it should touch the stores.

I can't believe my friend wasted his money to get this for me. I want to actually pay him twice the amount of what he spent on this game just to compensate for the disgrace I went through in giving this a chance.
column9:
I understand I only spent a few minutes in this game, but unfortunately that was all I needed.

First problem I encountered that immediately threw me into a rage...audio crackling.

Normally I would believe this to be some sort of sound driver issue, but as someone who regularly uses Skype, Pandora, numerous other games and software with absolutely zero problem in sound, I found this to be the foreshadowing of the only stain in my library out of (currently) 147 other items. Reinstallation of drivers and the game itself has produced no fix. Fabulous.

Second issue, which I should say was already mentioned by someone else in the reviews on this item...sluggish gameplay. It feels like you're trying to swim through molasses. I was trying to gun down uh, floating jellyfish and other unpleasant critters and it felt like I was in a slow-motion Matrix scene (minus the badassery by a long shot, that is).

Third issue. There were no prominent enough sound effects for mining or busting something's skull in. I expected some splattering or crumbling or something. What I got was a piss-poor puff noise for most of it. Seriously? What kind of horse crap is this?

Fourth issue. I'm very happy I was able to adapt to the game itself as quickly as I did, because the game not pausing with the tutorial UI up in my face was extremely unsettling and left me open to get owned by the nearest hungry maw. Someone with very little experience with games like this will not be so fortunate in the future.

Fifth issue. This game  has some sloppy sprite work on the player avatars. Normally I would let this slide, but I know this game has been worked on for quite some time, so no, I am not going to let it go. Hell no. column8:
I have stayed away from this game for a while due to its low ratings, but decided to buy it during the christmas sale. I wanted to play it for myself to see how it was. Here are my thoughts from just an hour and a half of playtime.


Pros:
+ Has something like a main quest line
+ Has mini events that appear on the planet, with objectives
+ Has a crafting system with trees that look like they have a reasonable amount of items
+ Has an npc with a bunch of dialogue, uncommon for this genre
+ Has a strange (but interesting) artstyle that reminds me of AVwW, but a little different
+ Some of the equipment looks well drawn, and very nice as future outfits

Cons:
- Crafting system requires large amounts of materials to make mundane or low tier objects
- Enemies and destructibles drop lots of loot and it feels like my inventory is weighed down with junk just a few minutes into the game
- The tiered system for items/crafting isn't intuitive or sensible (other than weapons/tools named "Mk. 1", "Mk.2", etc.)
- The tiers locking you out of building or crafting some items feel arbitrary despite being in an already arbitrary game setting
- Mining the necessary materials for the beginning quests or items is very slow, boring, and repetitive; it's so unengaging that it feels like busy work
- Mining laterally is A PAIN at times because the laser eminates from your upper chest and you can't mine a straight line below or above that level due to that constraint - you have to mine extra blocks to get line of sight for your laser (which technically makes sense, but this isn't real life and an arbitration could be made here, even just letting us CROUCH would fix half of the problem)
- Moving the character is clunky, you stop on a dime and using the jetpack arrests upward movement to begin a slow acceleration upward (but using the jetpack to slow your fall does very little to slow you unless you were already falling at a slow speed)
- The npc with dialogue is annoying, makes annoying sounds each time you respond to it, and doesn't help you with the early game much other than telling you what the tutorial pane (accessed with the U key) does.
- Several parts of the game are very arbitrary, like being magically unable to mine in an event area until you complete the event (but then able to mine with no problem afterward)


Conclusion: The game almost has the barebones of a sandbox crafting adventure game, with what looks like a reasonable amount of content added in. But content doesn't make a game, it only adds to it. The base gameplay, the platforming, the item collection and crafting, just feels bad. It does not feel finished. It feels like a prototype with extra content.

column8:
CAUTIOUS RECOMMENDATION:

As of now this game has a solid start. The premise is good and the skill tree is interesting, easy, and fun to make your way through. The game itself is still a bit buggy, with framerate on a singleplayer world as if you were lagging on a multiplayer one. The UI also leaves you wanting something a bit better and easier to use. However, the developers are still putting time into fixing up the game so I am hopeful that issues such as the framerate and UI are addressed. There is also a drastic increase of difficulty as you move deeper into the world, as the enemies become much faster and stronger than you really have any feasible hope to overcome...which means lots and lots of deaths, a minor issue. It just begins to feel grindy and repetitive after the silly penguins and/or bears kill you out of nowhere for the 100th time while you are minding your on business.

column8: Unfortunately the game is dead. The developers all but ceased to exist, their website was hacked multiple times, last time replaced with  malware laden porn which was probably the death blow. Therir website no longer exists. The facebook site hasn't been checked by any of the former devs far over a year, same for twitter. The developer team is essentially defunct and steam should have removed the game from it's store a long time ago. The game had potential, but without anyone behind it to fix the issues and improve upon what's there it's a lost cause, don't waste your money on a festering corpse.

column8:
The positives: Uh...... it has a terraria reference?
The neutral stuff: Kinda grindy and mining is slow. 
The stuff that are pretty big flaws but could have been okay:  A "research" system. In other words, not just one, but TWO methods of forcing you to work your butt off to get a incredible reward!..... Just kidding, you 'll also get stuck behind so many progression walls there are enough for several mazes of utter misery with the slow mining and finding out SURPRISE!
you now need a new workstation. Alright, i'll go dig out ANOTHER massive crater to get some XP so I can research that. (An hour later) Alright let's see what I need for this thing. Looks like some uranium and a ton of aluminum (That's not actually a recipe but an example of the sorts of recipes there are) Time to go get some aluminum!.... Got that, what about uranium? Oh... I can't mine it. So what do I need to make a laser to (hopefully) mine it? Looks like more giant crater making for me. Hooray. Three cheers for whoever decided holding down on your mouse and moving it for hours was a neccecary game mechanic.
What killed the game: There's no satisfaction to ANYTHING. Completing quests? Grindy and unrewarding. Exploring? Fun until you realize all the terrain is the same. Progression? There's progression? Where? Where'd you find precious progression? WHERE?!?! Combat? Yes there is! It's combatting the woefully weak jellyfish who die after about 20 seconds of holding the mouse button down! There isn't even different fighting styles. Sure you can pick between "pew pew" guns, "pew... BOOM" guns or "PEW............... PEW" guns but compare that to terraria where you can get a massive variety of weapons, from classic swords to lances to boomerangs to flails to variants that deal more damage, look cool, fire off an array of projectiles from various actions (hitting enemies, when swinging, whenever there's an active hitbox...) or inflicting debuffs. And that's just THE MOST BORING CATEGORY. Not to say they aren't cool, it's just they're the trump 6 out of sixes and tens. There's also guns, bows, bow/gun hybrids, spellbooks wands+rods and staffs, throwing lances, throwing knives, shuriken, yo-yos,  a portal gun, a voodoo doll, and that's just the stuff I thought of in a few minutes. Sorry about the massive rant. Overall, it's a 2.5/10 on the scale of games that aren't stupendous but aren't one of "those" games. You know them. Zelda CGI, Flight Control, Slaughtering Grounds. The type that get videos dedicated to laughing at the sheer amount of crap that they are. Anyway, hopefully this helped the devs and the people who are thinking about buying it. Here's some games that hold up to the 1$ per hour of fun rule. Terraria: a 157 hour epic, and i've only gotten to late prehardmode and skill is the limiting factor in that. Cave Story+: The original indie game with new graphics and a handful of extra content including difficulty settings, new characters and a new level cut from the original game because it was apparently too dark (clones of a friendly character who attack you) which makes no sense considering it involves drowning as well as being forced to kill a character who was fed the red flowers (you'll understand if you play it) along with a character who tried to protect his friends and killed them accidentally. Seriously. It also has multiple endings. Undertale: AWESOME game involving SPOILER SPOILER who SPOILERs SPOILER. It's kinda loses half its appeal if you already know the story. Not to say the story is great and the gameplay is bad; all of undertale is fantastic. It's just that the story and gameplay are SO interconnected that spoiling one makes the other not quite have the impact it's supposed to. Also, bring a friend and a tissue or two. Seriously. Undertale is the only game ever to make me laugh so hard or cry anything exept tears of frustration.

column8: This game seemed to have a lot of potential especially if it continued to develope.  I will say that the Devs are very active and not just "Holiday season" active to make it seem like they are still putting time into the game. This team keeps pumping out updates almost 1 to 2 a month and providing feedback for future updates. The game is a little hard to follow and a very pricy for it's type. If you like this type of game though and can catch it on a really good sale, pick it up, you may find something you like about  it. I don't feel that I can recommend it though, for the price to value ratio just isn't there. If you like Terraria, and are expecting this to be as good or a lot like it, you would be in error. Other than being the same type of game (2D crafting exploration game) it lacks a lot of polish, and flavor. It is still early access though so it could becore a great game, but I don't know yet. If it ever does, I will have to update my review.

column8:
The game is out of Early Access now and I've played what I consider to be the majority of the content in the game, so I'm updating my review.

This game's pretty good and I do recommend it for a good 20 hours of playtime.

Pros:
Scifi setting is nice
Goofy humour is good and prevalent throughout the game if you're into that kind of thing
Game runs smooth for me and I've encountered few bugs since coming out of early access
A lot of different blocks and placeables for building bases
A lot of different items and armours
Dungeons are a lot of fun
Music is great and matches the mood
NPCs that give quests
Easy to fast travel between bases

Cons:
Nothing to really do in the 3rd biome but grind for materials to build end game gear.  Also, there doesn't appear to be a dungeon in the 3rd biome
Light radius is small (spamming torches helps but that's just annoying)
Weapons never really get powerful, even the Death Dealer takes multiple hits on spike balls (personal con, I like to feel powerful when I get to the end of a game)
Still a lot of stuff that feels unfinished (many items share sprites, no dungeon in 3rd biome)
I didn't try multiplayer but it sounds like it takes quite a bit of work to set up a server and to get people to join

They are still working on the game, but at a much slower pace.  I hope they make another game because I have enjoyed Edge of Space for what it is and I would like to see something new using what they have learned developing this game.


OLD REVIEW:
I would recommend the game at the stage it is currently at if they sold it as a finished game.  So, the fact that they are still working on it and improving it all the time makes it an easy recommendation.  The devs are very active in the forums and constantly updating the game.  One of the devs even broadcasts on twitch sometimes while wearing a shark suit.  This game has come a long way from its original early access release and is going to go a lot farther.

column8: Great game with a large world for many hours of game play. This game has come a long way since the beginning and continues to be a favorite of mine with 1200+ hours played. Edge of Space has 3 different ways to play, experience point and a large crafting system. It is well worth the giveaway price of $14.99. Also, it is quite different than Starbound and Terraria which I own and have spent many hours playing (Starbound 109 hrs played.Terraria 164 hrs played).

column8:
This is a boring game and overly complex. 

There are tons of games like this out there and I asume it tries to stand out with its falvor and all that. But I feel like the menus aren't well designed, the crafting and collecting is needlessly complicated and not fun, and all attempts to pull me in and interset me fall very flat. Oh and most of the visual design is at best messy.

There are a lot of better games that are very similar, just get Starbound,

column9:
[b][h1]If you think Terraria and its games are the same genre just because they're from the same company, you're mistaken.[/h1][/b]
Even though Terraria features building and digging, most of its game elements end up in RPG form. However, this game has become a true RPG-focused digging game. In other words, weapon crafting typically requires probable items like gunpowder and iron, or energy-containing ores and duralumin.
But instead, things like making guns requires dirt, or making food requires organic matter.
Due to the "inorganic matter anyway" mentality, even in a futuristic sci-fi game with a strong RPG feel, digging has become a necessity. You can find inorganic items everywhere you dig, and you can craft a gun with 10 of them. It's not just guns, they make everything...

Moreover, the very early game is seriously difficult, giving you a single 9mm pistol and telling you to survive in a Zerg base with only a rifle, much like Mengsk, and it's also seriously lacking in "consideration for the very early game." (It was a bit worse half a year ago. It took about 15-20 seconds to hit a very weak, very early monster with all the bullets. If I compare it to a JRPG, it would be like going out to the field for the first time and hunting, and it would take about 5 minutes to kill a single slime. On top of that, I would die immediately after getting hit by about 3 times. Creepers are slow, so you can run away, but back then, the monsters were like zerglings in front of a medic. On top of that, everything was preemptive. Those things would pop out from both sides of the map every 3 seconds, and to upgrade that gun, you had to dig a long way down the ground, which took about 2 seconds to dig a block, to get dozens of minerals. To put it in Korean, it was like AMY's game falling behind. It took about an hour to survive and upgrade the gun for the first time.)
The movement was too heavy, the character size was unnecessarily high, and the digging speed was also incredibly frustrating compared to other games. While this can be true in the early stages of any game, this game doesn't differ much in the later stages. Other sandbox adventure RPGs at least offer similar movement and don't force players to dig as much. The phrase "for hardcore gamers..." is absurd. This game actually screws hardcore gamers over, while casual players are left with a sense of shame.

Difficulty adjustments will likely be addressed in the future, but it's difficult to pinpoint the game's core focus.

Minecraft focuses on minerals, Starbound on better weapons and upgrades, and Terraria on stronger enemies. This game offers all of these, but with a paltry amount of content and an ambiguous balance, completely ruining the experience.

Sixteen thousand won... Including a tiny bit of useless DLC, it's 27,000 won... (Honestly, I still don't know what the current DLC does.)
If the game were to drop below 3,000 won, it'd be worth a try (though considering Logic's arrogance, it's hard to expect an 80% off sale).

At the current price, it's probably better to buy two chickens and then quickly turn them into poop.

Even the most prominent button you see when you start the game is "Beat us!" That's right. It's asking you to voice your opinions and share your ideas with Passion Pay. A game made that way costs 16,000 won. Are you married?
Please... I hope the development team and the developers all go in a good direction... (Since I already paid for it.)

Oh, and by the way, I once gave a big slap to the Early Access purchasers who generously invested in the game. Back then, the basic version might have been cheaper, but only the Standard Edition was available. I don't even know what the current Special Edition is for, but it didn't exist back then. Ultimately, users who purchased it then have to pay an additional 16,000 won for the upgrade, rather than the bundled price difference (-11,000 won). This is a huge sales pitch, and [strike]I'm going to smash your head in... This is so infuriating...[/strike] 
I sympathized with it, but the more heavy users, the more hurt it felt. It's a little more infuriating than [u]someone who donates with good intentions and then asks where the money came from and demands more taxes[/u]. Now that it's my business...
Even if it had been as popular and fun as Starbound at the time of purchase, I might have understood the "early payment" aspect of Early Access. However, as I mentioned above, [strike]Ao-pak-chi-ne-jjin-jja[/strike] back then, the game balance was so bad it was nearly "impossible" to play.

--------

+ Additional Correction
It's not the developer Logic. Thank goodness. I think I mistook it because Logic collaborated with me a while back.

There was a time when it was 3,000 won. It was on sale for 80% off...

This game is so bad that playing it is not just a waste of time; it's a game that demands money. As of this revision, the 30-day recommendation rate is 7%. That means 7 out of 100 people enjoyed it.
Roughly speaking, if the ratio of sadists to masochists is 50/50, then you can think of it as 7 of those people being extreme masochists who find pleasure in wasting their lives.

If you look at my playtime, it says 12 hours, but in that 12 hours, I never upgraded my weapon more than twice. To use an old-school analogy, it's like changing the "shabby wooden stick" you're given at the start of an RPG into a "wooden sword"â€”it takes 12 hours of playtime. I still don't know what the final item is, what the Demon King is, or what the actual purpose of this game is.

Ã“timo jogo, muito bom, eu acho ele melhor que Terraria, Starbound e Craft the World pela facilidade de craftar e uma aÃ§Ã£o boa. column9:
Great game, very good. I think it's better than Terraria, Starbound, and Craft the World for its ease of crafting and good action. You have infinite ammo weapons, which you craft over time, and some weapons require ammunition creation. You earn XP, a maximum score of 10,000. When you reach 10,000, you use these points to upgrade crafting items. There are several options, including base items (bed, table, lights, refrigerator, etc.), food, armor, mining tools, and many others. Unlike Terraria, Starbound, and Craft the World, where you have solid ground and can go far, Edge of Space is a bunch of large, small, and variously sized blocks scattered in the air; you'll fly a lot. In the game's background image on the desktop menu, you'll see a planet with one part intact and the other shattered, with the pieces heading off into space. So, in my opinion, these pieces of this planet are the chunks of land you can explore. There are smaller, tiny, and very large ones to explore, but I couldn't complete a test where I kept descending and descending until I found solid ground where, if I drilled a hole to reach the planet's core, I could get there and face the monsters hiding there. I couldn't complete this test to see if there was solid ground like in standard survival games like Terraria.

Your mining tool isn't a small, sharpened stone knife (like in Craft the World), which you mine and use to make new tools, such as pickaxes and axes, with the resources. In this game, you have a laser tool that burns matter, even the most resistant one you have; it burns, and a little ball the color of the matter appears. To mine the bottom, since the bottom always remains, press the TAB key and the red laser changes to blue. The blue laser removes that bottom to provide more resources depending on what you're extracting: stone, aluminum, earth, etc. You cut down the trees and strange plants after you craft a laser saw, which is infinite; that is, it doesn't wear out; you can cut everything. I think it's cool that these tools are infinite.

The game's action is good. I haven't gotten far enough to face the bosses yet. I mostly mine. I've already created my baseâ€”more of a little house than a base, actuallyâ€”which is cool. There are more things to discover and research, but so far the game has its potential. So far, I haven't found it bad.

For me, a game should be more about fun than graphics; I don't care about that. But I really like games with good fun, because I'm from a time when games didn't have graphics, but were just pure fun.

I don't understand the negative player reviews. Some are understandable, as the game is being updated. Those who gave negative reviews are because the game was in its early stages, Alpha or Beta. But right now, it's good and has great potential. The co-op mode is the "classic" one; to join your friend's server, you have to add their IP address.

I do recommend this game; it's good, and I have fun playing it.

You can create a character; he's an astronaut-style fighter, of course, because it's on another planet. It's worth it. I recommend buying it, but it's best to buy it on sale, of course. The bigger the discount, the better. Buy it when you think it's at the best price.

column9:
After 50 hours of play, I can confidently say that Edge of Space is more interesting than Terraria and much more challenging, especially in crafting.

Pros:
1) Huge, interesting world.
2) Lots of equipment, including gear from dungeon resources.
3) Excellent soundtrack.
4) Constantly spawning robotic machines make the game easier. You can use it to descend lower and kill difficult monsters, thereby farming EX, but you won't be able to ascend with it since it doesn't fly.
5) You definitely won't get by with a single base, like in Terraria.
6) Tower defense-style dungeons.
7) There are certain arenas that require you to clear out zombies, crabs, penguins, jellies, or bears using shoulder-mounted rocket launchers. And in these same arenas, you can settle in without wasting time building a hut.
8) Funny NPCs. Especially the shark with the funny voice.
9) Lots of monsters.

Cons:
1) The inventory, crafting, and menu windows are terribly slow when moving them or items. 2) The windows are huge, and a couple take up the entire 22" monitor when you open, say, the inventory, chest, or crafting window.
3) I only managed to reach one boss in the entire 50 hours, and he's a 100% copy of Megatron from Terraria.

At first glance, Edge of Space is overly difficult and confusing, but after 10 hours of play, you'll get the hang of it and you'll love it. I'll also add that most people write reviews after playing for no more than two hours and write negative ones. I remember when I bought Edge of Space, I quit after 10 minutes and abandoned the game for a long time. After playing for a year or two, I realized I hadn't made the same mistake and written a negative review.

I don't recommend buying it! The game is still crap, and there are no updates!

column8: I love Terraria, so this game is nice.  I have had it for a while and started it back up after awhile and it was awesome. :)
column9: I love Terraria, so this game is nice.  I have had it for a while and started it back up after awhile and it was awesome. :)

column8: I really REALLY want to like this game but I just feel like the game is going nowhere, Im having trouble trying to find the stuff thats in the trailer. Also, I think the world gen needs to be toned down, it needs to be more smooth. The GUI is buggy, at least for me, nd the GUI should be more smooth. Please make this game more complete. At THIS point in development, I wouldnt really recommend it but i think that if the devs fixed these problems and made a little bit more of a storyline, this game could be GREAT.

column8:
Still looks like beta... that game isn't fun at all. It supposed to be much better than Starbound and Terraria combined, but who cares? Bugs, eye-pinching graphics... and that slooooooooooow mining tool. Give me a pickaxe, please, I'll dig a grave for my ugly helmet at Edge of Space. Oh, look at backgroungs, don't you like tile desktop wallpapers?
Seriously, just a loss of money.

column8:
Playable but still feel a lot missing, and creating base can annoy you because you cannot control blocks shape and you have laserpick!

At least you still got the fun collecting something, from weapon, armor, furniture, vehicle, mount, pet, resource, and loot.

Like:
[+] not chibi-char pixelated-art style thing.
[+] you can zoom close enough to see how cool char detail, tho the helmet design is ... meh
[+] removed the ugly space station used for tutorial. the tutorial content is okay, but I can't stand how bad to look at the space station design, from tile, furniture to background image....
[+] resource has its own classification info, like aluminium tile is raw-mineral-metal-aluminium, ice tile is raw-chemical-ice, biomass tile is raw-organic-biomass. kinda feel fresh than other game in the same genre that I play.
[+] more flexible on crafting, since some items not directly specify resource name, instead it uses resource class like mineral or metal so that item can be craft with all item that classified as mineral or metal... etc.
[+] all kind transportation, from living being transport to deadly transport vehicle, from digger vehicle to fast moving with jumppack vehicle, from hover/flying vehicle to land explorer vehicle.
[+] mech that go pew-pew... but I just don't understand why it scattered around map...
[+] power system? to powering your energy hungry base, tho kinda simple.
[+] epic opening music, tho the in-game music is meh, especially the night time and in cave... 
[+] vertical biomes.
[+] pet that help you with buff, from chicken and fire fox to angry croc.
[+] prospector transport vehicle is really help with mining operation. make me wish there is autonomous vehicle to clean up the entire contingent/land
[+] Kit, from "helping you from teleport you around map" to "something that make you a walking hi-tech tool bech"
[+] flying shark with laser and razor teeth.
[+] armor with special class function, from armor for fighter to armor to builder.
[+] player statistic that write down all kind info of player char. tho not really detailed cus only practical stat, no global stat like kill count of each enemy, distant move with foot, with vehicle, with mount ... etc
[+] when you die, your friend can help to revive you so you don't need to revive at spawn location. 


Meh, but okay:
[=] all weapon from range to melee, from small to big... is 1-handed type...
[=] few/no particle effect, like something left behind after you boost your jetpack... oh right, hi-tech and in space no need something like that.
[=] there is puking boom in every wild nest...
[=] NPC is just a talking static turret quest giver...
[=] face right side and your char became left-handed, face left side and your char became right-handed....
[=] kinda useless melee weapon, since they are just flapping like a dodo.
[=] vehicle cannot ramming to tile for easy destruction...
[=] bad sound effect... at early access , I tho it was just place holder... but now the sound of pickaxe is like radio static with volume at 5%...
[=] music volume can't be apply directly, you must exit game to menu first before you hear the diff...
[=] [opening video] why the hell the space transport attack each others...
[=] very few critter type.
[=] annoying snail and frog that can drag you around.
[=] game menu and gameplay menu is... well, placed together, I should be hate this kind thing, but whatever...
[=] meh UI design, I like the old one for showing player condition like HP, shield, and energy.
[=] why only 8 active slot ...


Hate:
[-] no world map? only mini map... hmm maybe later... I don't know....
[-] background parallax is trying to mimic my windows background by using tile setting... seriously... this kinda lazy... tho I like the cloud but the flying land image is too repetitive.
[-] no ecosystem, like snail eat all kind vegetation, raptor eat snail, headhunter eat raptor?... I saw frog used his tongue... but I don't know what he ate? so now everyone either ignore me or just try to kill me on the spot!
[-] some projectiles that should not pass thru a tile... kinda annoying seeing that homing on me.
[-] removed char creation background, with dull UI... well the old one was not that good but still better than current char creation...   
[-] some...many items has same icon.
[-] static furniture, ex: like you can not use fridge to store consumable items; or you can not see the periodic table when right clicking on periodic table furniture....
[-] dull light effect... hahaha I don't know how to call it, but ... ex: flood light illuminate all surround area but still in small area, I thought it should only illuminate spot area.  
[-] metallic jetpack use earthen jetpack icon.
[-] invisible headhunter totem decoration.
[-] still using "Update Me" on Artilla Bear transportation 8 description 
[-] sometimes char can not go down from platform.
[-] sometimes platform image-sprite still in game world tho the item has already mined.
[-] enemy spawn directly near you on event at massive mob... just like "puff-puff-puff" near you and then go pew-pew or berserk like hungry croc. 
[-] the way laserpick works is annoying, from just mining to building your base you can destroy any nearby furniture and tile just to get 1 of your miss placed/target tile... doubling your works.
[-] cutting thing is very slow, and yield small amount resources...
[-] lack sound effect, like no door sound effect, no facility sound effect...
[-] no weapon knockback... 
[-] you can't change block/tile shape, the game will do it all for you, of course in ugly way....
[-] radius of torch can illuminate area is small, since I don't like the torch design, well it's very disturbing seeing my base cover in torch... LOL
[-] cannot crouching tiger.... lol, I mean with the way laserpick dig, this crouch should be added... aw..
[-] missing auto pick resource function on some facility UI.
[-] no sorting function on inventory. dikira yg main babu apa...
[-] no auto stack on storage from player inventory, make items more prone to scatter in many storage...
[-] some UI cannot use right-click to instant move item to player inventory


Recommend : Not Recommend
51% : 50%
Since I like very much this kind of game genre ... so... recommend with a hard feelings...

column9:
Yet another survival/exploration game... Why not, I like it. Okay, first point: it's ugly. Mind you, I'm not talking about the technical quality or the graphical power, but rather the art direction, which is ugly, even though I find Minecraft (and yes, how could I not mention it...) very pretty.
Then the atmosphere. For once, it really resonated with me. It's weird, a bit like a sci-fi book from the 50s and 60s. A bit odd, but why not.
And finally, the game and its gameplay. I didn't find anything new, but the relatively easy handling (compared to other attempts in the genre) and the crafting/knowledge tree enticed me.

Meh.

After the first two discovery sessions, I quickly start to think to myself: "What's the point?" Farming for hours just to advance in a knowledge tree and "have fun" crafting as many items as possible? As much as it works in Minecraft (gosh, him again!), because the discovery and wonder are still there, in Edge of Space, it didn't take off. The most annoying thing in my opinion is the perceived lack of interest in crafting at the beginning of the game. Apart from a few obvious improvements to the equipment, there is no indication of the usefulness of the other recipes. In the end, after the discovery, nothing held me back and the small flaws started to jump out at me. In a world where games of this genre didn't exist, I might have insisted longer and been more involved, but the competition is tough and of high quality, so there is no point in persevering.

column8:
Played the game on a Lan Server, about every 15 to 30 min a network loop error occured and I had to shut down the game and the server. Sometimes the whole screen turned black expect for the character, therefore had to restart again. Seems like a fun game, however there still are a lot of bugs.

For example when in the headhunter dungeon while going through a door, spawning in a wall, unable to move. 
Miscalculating in task requirements (if you have more than a stack of the item). 
Some background tiles from destroyed bases are not removable.

Better explaining of the game mechanics would be nice, after you finished the quest with the shark, you dont really know what to do. It would also be good to know where to actually get the crafting materials.

Some of the mechanics could be better aswell, for example the mining tool which sometimes seems random in what it actually hits.
The game may have potential but there are still some really annoying bugs. And since you spawn at your spawn again after closing the game, some of the bugs that force you to restart are really annoying and take the fun out of the game.
Due to the frequency of the appearence of the bugs on a Lan server the game is baisically unplayable there, since you cant even finish one dungeon.
Games like Starbound or Terraria have almost the same game concept but they are much more enjoyable, though that may be personal prefrence.
The idea of the game with fun mobs and dialogs is really good, but at the moment it has to many issues. Hope you keep working on it and fix it cause the game has potential.

column9:
[b] CURRENTLY UNPLAYABLE [/b]

Another piece of crap from Steam Early Access, like 90% of the games there. They've sold enough copies that you can just forget about it and pretend you're still working on the game. It's very convenient. Especially after the release of Starbound, the developers screwed up and decided to give up.
The mechanics are flawed, and it's boring to play. But most importantly, the game is a buggy demo. After a couple of hours, the game starts to lag and you have to completely restart it. If the developers couldn't fix such an obvious bug, what can we say about the entire game?
Play for an hour, restart, play for an hour, restart... and it still takes a long time to load.

You'd be better off playing Terraria, Starbound, or Darkout.

column8:
Disappointing. I wouldn't recommend to friends.
The release version of the game feels more like a version that should be releasing on to Steam Early Access for the first time, to go through those last few months of finishing, polishing and feedback before actual release. It still feels in a rather "beta" state, which is disappointing for a game that's already been in Early Access for two years.

For instance rockets are represented in the player's inventory UI as an ammo type, but there is actually no weapon that requires it, nor any recipe to make it. An unfinished stub of a feature like this shouldn't be left in the release version, it's misleading and cringingly "beta".

I wanted to like it, I like the genre and loved [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/105600/]Terraria[/url]. I wouldn't have stuck with playing this for so long if I didn't, and I like some of what it does differently. I could list other problems I perceive with it, but instead I'll just say that overall It's a disappointment, and probably needs another year in the oven.

Edit: It's been over a year since I posted my review, and a year since the last minor patch. It doesn't seem like we can expect any major patches, and I don't think the game will ever reach a state that I could consider finished, so my recommendation is unlikely to change.

column8:
So first off, let's just say I don't particularly like this game. And when I say that I don't like this game, I mean that I really don't like this game.
I got this game on release day, installed it on release day, played around 2 hours on release day. It was a weird experience to say the least. I think that pretty much everyone who picked up this game on release day was expecting something that was literarily just "terraria in space". This game is anything but that. From a terraria perspective, the characters are a weird size, seeming just too big. The game is similar to starbound with the way you mine and build things, but starbound just feels more complete. The game has a weird graphics style that just doesn't quite complete. It seems a bit rough around the edges. I am not saying that no one could love it, just that I can't. 

If you own Terraria and want a similar experience, then get Starbound. "But I already have Starbound" you say? Wait for an update to Terraria and then you will be right.
If you own Startbound and want a similar experience, then get Terraria. "But I already have Terraria" you say? Wait for an update to Starbound and then you will be right.

I cannot recommend this game for the simple reason of there are already games out there that do everything this game does but better; want a great 2D building/exploring/sandbox experience? Get Terraria. Want a great 2D space building/exploring/sandbox experience that isn't quite complete, but still great?. Get Starbound. Want some weird space thing? Get Defy Gravity.

P.S. Just as a warning for this game, there are save wipes
P.P.S. I have also played this game since release day, enough to find form valid arguments about this game.

column8: I have played the game for around 558 hours and have really enjoyed the experience so far. The only downside is that it takes a heck of a lot of searching for some crafting items and there is little in the way of instructions on gameplay for quite a few things. This will probably change over time since this game recently came out of beta and there were a ton of changes just in the last year. The developers have done a great deal of work on the game and I appreciate all the detail in appearance and play. The game is challenging and fun. I recommend this game .

column8:
For a game that is supposed to be 1.0, I find it is only of the quality of a Beta or Alpha release.

Pros:
Lots of content and recipies
Innovative crafting system
Excellent soundtrack

Cons:
Laggy and buggy, requiring a restart to make it playable again
No decent mapping system, sometimes I have no idea where I am going
Poor lighting effects (see above comment)

One revuewer said it quite well, this game feels like a generic space Terraria ripoff. (Yes, I know Terraria let them use a similar version of Skeletron.)

I'll probably visit this game in a afew months to see if much has improved, but for now, I cannot give it a passing grade.

4/10

column8:
Edge of Space takes dedication to be appreciated. I recomment this game because I've grown to enjoy it after about 2 months of intensive in-game experimentation, but it was a winding road with a dull beginning.

The biggest flaw with EoS is its glaringly lacking help menus. This is a significant flaw because the opportunities offered by the game far outweigh the amount of helpful information about the different tools and installations you can craft. This can lead to extended periods of aimless mining and construction that can feel pointless and frustratingly anti-climactic (I've been surprised quite often at how little I could accomplish during long hours of continuous play because of a lack of clear objectives).

That being said, I've grown to enjoy Edge of Space very much. Here's a bit of context: you are dropped on a foreign planet after a spaceship crash and evacuation. Your codex (the help menus) is obviously incomplete and written very much like the entries in The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy: unfocused and essentially devoid of any useful information beyond vague hints at a distant purpose. As the player, it is your job to extrapolate meaning -and ultimately results- from what little help and guidance you are offered by your interplanetary employer.

Edge of Space plays very much like the old NES and SNES Metroid games, with the added elements of terraforming and crafting. The bottom line is that once you've "figured out" the basics, the game works. Very well.

So, provided you're willing to tolerate fuzzy objectives and the occasional quirks, you should enjoy Edge of Space for what it is: a wacky, competely over-the-top sandbox with a lot of potential and a ton of fun! And laser sharks!

FREE TIP: Keep digging deeper. And when you think you've gone deep enough, keep going. Edge of Space offers a BIG world!

Your codex (the help menus) is obviously incomplete and written very much like the entries in The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy: unfocused and essentially devoid of any useful information beyond vague hints at a distant purpose. As the player, it is your job to extrapolate meaning -and ultimately results- from what little help and guidance you are offered by your interplanetary employer.

Edge of Space plays very much like the old NES and SNES Metroid games, with the added elements of terraforming and crafting. The bottom line is that once you've "figured out" the basics, the game works. Very well.

So, provided you're willing to tolerate fuzzy objectives and the occasional quirks, you should enjoy Edge of Space for what it is: a wacky, competely over-the-top sandbox with a lot of potential and a ton of fun! And laser sharks!

FREE TIP: Keep digging deeper. And when you think you've gone deep enough, keep going. Edge of Space offers a BIG world!

column8:
Just played it again for the first time in over a year.  Last time was during Early Access.

Didn't recommend it then, don't recommend it now.

Interface feels rather slow to respond when working with inventory.
The minimap is a complete joke.  It's too tiny of an area to be useful, and there doesn't seem to be a big map you can bring up to see where you've explored.
Mining for resources is VERY tedious at least with the initial and first additional tier of of tools.
The power system used in base building feels cumbersome, and not very intuitive.  

Better than it used to be back in early access.  
But I woundn't recommend it.

column8:
I've tried to enjoy this game through its many iterations and complete changes. In it's current (release) state, the game is tolerable, but lacking in many respects still, the largest being actually fun. I only play games of this sort multiplayer, so the experience may be different for playing solo.

The mining tool is my biggest gripe. It fires in a line, that is based on an unusual place on your character, making getting at specific tiles difficult, and hard to aim at anything but straight up/down/left/right. The mining tool is INCREDIBLY slow compared to other games such as Terraria or Starbound. In the latest incarnation, they added new mining tools that slowly (at about half-speed) dig out the tiles around the tile it's hitting, but generally this doesn't help much because it's slower and you can't generally dig in a way to take much advantage of it.

Then there is dealing with the plants of the world, which require a saw of some sort to gather. This is even slower than the mining tool, you just sit and wait and wait for it. And finally get your 2 protovine or whatnot. Good luck finding any seeds!

And then creating much of anything requires so many resources, but you have a tiny inventory and finding storage is time consuming. And though it is an interesting idea to have tiers of what sort of item something is (eg, "Inorganic - Mineral - Radioactive - Uranium"), when you need to build something that just needs a mineral, it should just say "Uranium" or similar names... but it has the entire long list for Uranium, making it hard to tell exactly what it is you need without really long names for things.

And the world itself is just a bunch of skylands, with occasional larger ones tossed in there for actual "ground", except that when you get lower, you have another giant gap of space before getting to the next "tier" of skyland below you. You generally find out about that after having walked off a cliff of your "ground" near the beginning of the game, because it is very abrupt: "Just walking along, oh there's a little hill, let's hop down... no, there's no bottom. NO! Oh, I'm dead again..."

The game USED to have an entire tutorial, teaching you how to use the interface, move around, use the laser pick, etc. but the release version removed all of that in favor of a talking shark that just tells you to get it things... without any details on how to do much of anything. I'm glad I already knew how to switch between foreground and background tile mining/placement from the previous tutorial, because I probably would have gone nuts trying to figure it out.

There are now side missions that take you to your own personal instance that are not multiplayer at that point... there are random NPCs to get that don't do much (a couple give you ok-ish rewards for doing tasks)... there are various weapons, but most require ammo that is frustrating to get.

All of this and, while playing, you still have no idea what you're actually doing. The premise seems to be something about terraforming, but to what end?

column8: If you're looking for a game in the veins of Terraria, this game focuses mostly on combat.  However, the game is not finished yet.  It's out of early access, yet the "final biome" isn't done yet. You just fall down to a dark area with nothing but dirt, meaning that there is no end game.  So yea, I can't recommend a finished game.  And if they didn't finish it in early access, then I wonder if they will ever finish this.  Just stick with Starbound or Terraria.

column8:
They say the game is released, but I don't really see it. It's still buggy, and it looks like half of the content is missing. The network support is terrible, the UI is uncomfortable.

 The crafting system is complex, yet there is nothing to craft. To learn the recepieces you need to grind for exp, and the "quest system" is rudimentary. The flying laser shark was funny as a "first test of a quest system", but I never thought it'll be left there after the release.

All in all, it looks like the developers tired of this project half-way through. Now they are nowhere to be found, their website lies in ruins, and their promises are forgotten.

Go for Starbound instead. While Tiyuri had his share of delayed releases and controversies, and while he was a couple of years late, at lease he delivered a game. You know, the one that works, and is fun to play.

column8:
I'll keep it short -- read the other negative reviews if you want a big elaboration on what's wrong with Edge of Space.

This game is basically the lovechild of Terraria and Starbound, but only if that lovechild inherited all the recessive genes. 

The user interface is clumsy but not in a charming way, the gameplay is very mechanical and without reward, their new player tutorial has gone from a list of YouTube videos to an interactive tutorial back to a list of YouTube videos (to be fair, maybe they somehow detected I played the game seven or eight months ago and didn't show the tutorial last week because of that?). 

Playing the game is an unimaginably boring; hell, it was boring when it was in early access and releasing it as "1.0" doesn't seem to have changed things. Beyond the kinda-quirky character customization, the game isn't satisfying at all, and I struggled to play as long as I did (which should be about 6-7 hours).

Maybe there's some amazing gameplay curve hiding in it, and if you play for 10 or 11 hours it suddenly becomes a breath-taking experience, but I just couldn't make it that far.

Can ride snails around and shoot other snails

Character looks very big on screen
A lot to take in at once

column8:
well i hate to say it but this is just a mess multiplayer is non-existant as it currently fails to load most of the time.

Charecters are restricted to per instance/world loading (you cant have charecters in multiplayer on both you and someone elses world.) the game is very laggy often crashes even in single player. the multiplayer uses a vulnerable port that often cannot be opened/hosted while an antivirus is running or a firewall is active. finaly multiplayer isnt easy to setup as you need to know how to forward ports find your ip and other technical knowledge that most players like me lack completeley.

the singleplayer lacks a story and most of all is very repetative each 3 layers adds 2 new ores.... wow.... it takes hours to actualy find most of these ores in a decent quantity and often the mobs kill you before you can mine it. talking of mobs they seem to spawn everywhere especialy in the 3rd 6th and 9th islands the 6th island is inacessable to players without armor found 3 layers deeper (that you then wouldent be able to craft) the games drop rates need a massive boost as they currently are they are far too low.

 the "bosses" in the game lack any difficulty whatsoever and additionaly drop next to nothing for your time especialy the dj penguin whose armor set may need 30~40 kills to aquire and 21 hours of my gameplay was wasted making it.

 the game`s mobs are no better the egnoid matiriels take hours to find also the mobs that drop them dont seem to spawn as often making it very hard to get anywhere.

endgame the dungeons are nice but dont have any reward execpt 1 mob worth of science xp (not worth it) the ambient mobs eat viechles so it isnt worth crafting them especialy as they are single use.

Finaly the singleplayer lacks a map and this isnt acceptable the maps is needed for the game to be minorly enjoyable as of now players just get lost in the middle of nowhere.

While I recommend fans of 2D/sandbox/crafting games try this, I myself, could not get into it. I didn't like the graphic style, the music, or the collection mechanics of the tools. There are also some bugs with respect to dominating areas and getting credit for it. I find the quirky server startup in an empty command prompt which grabs focus annoying as well.

Good game, not great for me... might be great for others.
