Above all things, am I the only one who felt EoS is somewhat like Terraria+Windforge ?


I haven't played Early Access version, so I don't know how it got better.

I played EoS from v1.0 (on my friend's), thought it was still on beta since it was quite buggy and stuttering like 100's hrs played good old  mega-modded Baldur's Gate Trilogy (if you played old BG hundreds hours, you know what I mean). However, it was playable, so I consumed all the contents available in less than 15hrs on single player (only friend having EoS was the one I was playing on that time). I felt like there're still some unfinished works.

Few days back, heard EoS is ver1.05 now, I purchased it for myself hoping thing getting better, started new game on single player. Yeah, I had to admit that it is little bit better than v1.0, yet it's still buggy and has UI lagging problem. Therefore, I have to say I am pretty disappointed so far.

Of course, it's possible the dev's gonna update some contents and fix all those annoying glitches, and EoS do have lots of potential as Windforge had (and it disappointed me a lot). However, all I can say so far is, if this is what becomes as "released" after long time of "early access," nope, not yet. You need li'l bit more work.

I was sick of Early-access Starbound got lost its own way, and hoping EoS does not complete itself soon.

In conclusion, I won't recomment EoS yet. If you are considering about purchasing it, I'd say wait a bit longer, and see how the updates go.

Well, for fans of sandboxes, Terraria, and sharks shooting lasers, this game is brilliant. As an alpha, it still has some processing issues, but these issues aren't really bothersome. Occasionally, there's a FPS drop, but it doesn't impede gameplay. There are a LOT of things to do, so it's worth investing some time in.

Anyway, for my first review, I'd give it an 8/10.

-Good graphics
-Silly puns
-Sharks with lasers (hue)

column8:
I got this, I think, as a part of a promotion ages ago for buying Terraria? Back when it was in open beta if I remember right.

The game, now that I've bothered to redownload it, still feels like it's in an open beta, which is disheartening. There's a lot of stuff that the game doesn't tell you easily, like about upgrades, progression, zones, etc. Granted this also happens with other similar games (including Terraria), but they don't feel like you're being thrown to the wolves. It took me most of one play session to figure out how to pick up items after you put them down, because the game doesn't explain it well and most online sources don't explain it well either. It just doesn't feel like you're doing much other than occasionally jumping off ledges and falling to your death. It's written well, like the flavor text is entertaining pmuch all of the time, but I'm not playing for flavor text, I'm playing for the game.

Guns and jetpacks from the start are fun but I don't know much of what to do and the game feels really glitchy for a full release, so I wouldn't really recommend this myself.

column8:
I have not played this game in about a year, so I decided too re-install it, and look at it, as well as the reviews... and I see nothing has changed. It's still the confusing heap of garbage it was a year ago. The dev's seem to have abandoned this game. The game still feels like it's in an Alpha stage. It's choppy, the sprites are glitchy at times, and the amount of work you need to do to be able to get anything, it's outrageously difficult.

I had been an avid Minecraft and Terraria player, having LAN parties with my friends. We had beaten Minecraft, and had beaten all the regular bosses in Terraria. Then, one of them found this game. It looked cool, so we bought the game, and ran it. 5-7 hours in, and we still have the basic tools. None of us could figure out how to upgrade them, or get new tools! All the crafting involved electrical gates the technicians use!! We ended up abandoning the game, and never spoke of it again.

So, unless you're a senior technician that knows electrical gates by heart, don't waste the $15 on this game.

On another note: Terraria is about 250 mb. Edge of Space of a little over 2 Gb. Terraria has hours upon hours, upon hours of gameplay, with lots of replayability, and an active online community. Edge of Space has very little content, very little to no online presence, and actually very hard to set-up a server for. Hmm, I wonder what the better choice is....

If you don't know what Terraria is, and just found this game by surprise, get Terraria.

---EDIT---

So, another year has passed, and my friends decide to check this game out again. From what I've seen, and remember of this game, it has defintely changed, for the better. The crafting is easier to understand, the leveling up system, albeit a bit demanding and stops gameplay, is pretty interesting. The gunplay is great, the mining system could use a bit of work, and the UI is still pretty bad with my only issue being that every individual thing, such as inventory, crafting, skills, etc., requires a different button to press in order for that specific menu to come up(how hard could it have been for it to just open up with one button, and have different tabs for everything?).

Me and my friends played this for about 5 hours straight, and we all said that it is definitely fun. Though there are still issues, the game is in a playable state. But... I don't think mutch will change in the future, unless these developers are secretly working on this without giving updates, as the last form of any game update was last year(April 28th 2015, if I remember correctly), while the last time a dev spoke about the game(on steam at least), was 2 months ago(April 25th). The post said that they were sorry for being silent about the game, and that logistical issues came about, and that they would get back to the playerbase and explain what was happening. Well, it's been 2 months. Where's the explanation?


tl;dr
In the state this game is in currently, I still wouldn't recommend this to anyone. Unless you have a group of friends to play with, know how to portforward(because Hamachi doesn't work), and have some extra money laying around, then don't buy this game. It still seems like the developers have abandon this game, or don't have a whole lot of motivation for it.







I would still rather play Terraria.

column8:
Those who are willing to put in the time to explore the world of Edge of space will find a colossal amount of content just waiting to be discovered and enjoyed. The sheer variety of weapons, deployables, pets, mounts, materials, dungeons, bosses etc is impressive, and although there are some obvious similarities to Terraria for instance, it is in fact a very different game. I would definitely recommend trying to find someone else who you can play with though, as it does enhance the experience a lot.

There is a sort of tutorial in the form of a friendly laser shark who asks you to do a few short quests to get you used to the basic mechanics of the game, but the rest is mostly left up to you to figure out, (there are instructions on how to do everything if you dig in the menu) and so a degree of effort is required in order to get into the real meat of the content. Once you do however, you'll realise just how much there is to do and discover.

Edge of space is very colourful and is graphically the equivalent of eating too many packets of Skittles in one sitting, the pallette is well chosen and easy on the eye, the art style is great, and everything stands out. Some players have complained about the lighting system but personally I haven't had any problems with it. 

The music is great, very relaxing and suits the mood well. The best thing however is the splendidly warped sense of humour that the developers obviously have and that comes across not only in the design of the world but in many of the descriptions and explanations that are there to be read if you take the time (and I recommend that you do)

Gameplay is a lot of fun and some of the weapons in particular are extremely satisfying to use. I know I have only just started to scratch the surface but already I am enjoying flying around on a net full of jellyfish with a small glowing fox creature following me around and helping to light my journey into the planet's extensive cave systems.

In summary, if you like randomly generated 2D exploration games with crazy amounts of content and are willing to put in the time and effort required to get through the initial learning stages, then you will get very good value from Edge of space, even more if you can find someone else to team up with.

column8:
[h1]Abandoned Game That I Love[/h1]

After going through the beta I didn't play much of version 1. I never really gave it a proper chance. I know it is abandoned but I always loved this game and want to make it to the bottom layer. There are a bunch of bugs because it is abandoned but I have dropped a bunch of hours on it and still had a lot of fun despite the glitches. After booting it up years later I still really enjoy the atmosphere of Edge of Space.


[h1]The FA-Q of Space[/h1]


Updated Review
-------------------------------------------------

Not so much a review as it is text of sadness. No word since April from the devs. I tried to go to the website today and got a godaddy this page does not exist site. I didn't get to the level that some other players did but had fun while playing. It's sad that this really has been abandoned. Don't give up!

[h1]Zen of Space[/h1]


Original Review
-------------------------------------------------
I have been playing the game since beta. Overall it has been a positive experience for me. Playing version 1 was a big surprise. They added a ton of stuff. Personally I get sick of all the wizzard and warrior stuff so I love the fact that this is in space. Definetely has the Metroid feel you hear others talk about. Sound track is wicked, great art style! Starbound is in space but for some reason that game never keeps my attention like Edge of Space and Terraria. I have a ton of the open-world sandbox build, survive games. Like, A LOT of them. This game is one of my favorites.

I really enjoy what you have created here. Great job! I get burned here and there by early access but am super happy that you guys got to version 1. Looking forward to all the great updates to come.

column8:
REVISED 11/4/2015

Being a follower via Early Access; I must say that this game has come a long way in its development, and I am quite happy with the launch result. The game runs smooth, the 2D graphics are amazing; I definitely love how the developers broke away from the typical pixel art you see in most games of the genre. What definitely makes me appreciate this game, is not only the quality of the visuals and the sound; but what makes it different from other games like Starbound or Terraria. That being said, it has its drawbacks; which are mainly peeves on mine as mentioned in the cons section.

Pros:
+ Exceptional 2D artwork and visuals, definitely shines brighter than others of its genre.
+ Nice and fitting contemporary Sci-fi theme.
+ Biome diversity and abundance of interesting places to explore.
+ The PIOS system which allows you to wire power to objects.
+ Technology tree and research aspects are present.
+ Nice crafting system. 

Uncertain:
= The game feels grindy, but at the same time it prolongs the game.

Cons:
- The NPC's you get are really lame. You have a flying shark that sounds like a 5 year old, and a bunch of annoying furry "aliens". Really devs, couldn't you be more creative and make up some interesting sentient alien species?
- Sometimes, there is an excessive amount of creature spawns. 
- Some creatures have a very obnoxious knockback.
- There needs to be more biomes/content.

Overall: If you like these kind of open-world, randomly generated 2D platform games; this is definitely for you.

Possui um excelente potencial para ser um excelente jogo. Ate o momento o jogo possui alguns bugs que estÃ£o sempre sendo atualizados para corrigir. O preÃ§o da versÃ£o Standard estÃ¡ muito bom, da versÃ£o Special jÃ¡ nÃ£o digo isto.

Finalizando: Jogo muito divertido, mas jogando solo depois de algum tempo se torna tedioso (mas pelo menos irÃ¡ querer chegar nos melhores crafts do jogo), com amigos a diversÃ£o e muito alta e duradoura.

So here we are....finally at 1.0 and we still feel like we are in a beta. 
The game is laggy, choppy, the sprites clip and glitch around, the physics are wonkey for gravity (shoot enemy they fly straight upwards?), it's such a mess at the start. Their idea of a tutorial involves talking to a flying shark and gathering stuff.....it's very dull. 

I'm sad that waiting for nearly a year on this resulted in this mediocrity. Stick with terraria, this feels like a generic knock off terraria in space.

Of course, we still hope that the official can add Chinese to the game.

column8:
Bought this game since it first appeared in Early Acess. Played it on and off until they announced an official release date, so let's get to the details and where this game fell apart.

  First, for a space exploration/craft game it's mostly about just digging down....down down and only down. The crafting menu is categorized but it's still very messy and not pretty. Explanations on how switches work with power are also few and far between so you're going to have to do your own troubleshooting for a while. There is a variety of weapons, i won't deny that, but in terms of USEFUL weapons there are only a few types which work well. So you can basically ignore all the melee and energy fueled weapons, stick to the projectile and plasma weapons. But the worst part of this game is the enemies...their hitboxes are really funky, and to make matters worse the hurt boxes on your weapons are terrible as well. So mixing hard to hit enemies with weapons that are hard to aim...great. And the movement of the enemies is particularly annoying and random. Otherwise I applaud its effort to be different but this game feels poorly done to me.

column8:
For version 1.0.3

Though the developers have released this from Early Access, it really should not have been.  First off, the bugs:
[list]
 [*] missing image assets
 [*] broken dialog trees/subquests
 [*] spelling mistakes
 [*] crafting window which gets laggier and laggier each time it's opened.
 [*] constant shaking of the screen when left unattended for long enough (in my case, once to answer a phone call and another to deal with a someone at the door).
[/list]

Beyond the bugs, the content of the game itself is surprisingly sparse.  You just constantly descend without much incentive to explore other than to discover upgrade stations.  You can also find NPCs and get their subquests, but even if those subquests aren't broken there's no real payoff for completing them.

At its current level, the amount of active development and polish needed before this would be worthwhile is probably measured in months, not days or weeks.  I'd check back in six months to a year to see if things have gotten better or if the move out of Early Access is an indication that the dev team is abandoning the game and so might as well call it done.

column8:
After extensive playing of Edge of Space since the release I decided to rewrite my review.

Pros:

Sci-fi setting with a good intro video explaining why you are on a planet thatâ€™s hostile and heck bent on killing you.

I love the sci-fi graphics, and the look of the broken planet landscape.

Excellent array of items to craft, in fact, the list is HUGE, including three different sets of armor (each with their own upgrade tree), all kinds of different weapon types, and a lot of other things that give my love of farming resources, and collecting new, interesting bits and pieces, a lot of reasons to feel content.

A very large selection of base building decorations, workstations, defenses, etc. And yes, the advanced items require extensive farming and playing the game to gather enough resources to make, which some might feel is grindy, but I feel motivates me to keep exploring and mining for â€œa few more minutesâ€ and then turns out to be two-three hours of game time I didnâ€™t even know slipped by when I glance at the clock.

Iâ€™ve heard a lot of negatives about the user interface, but personally I see nothing wrong with it, and you can see it demonstrated in action via screen-shots, youtube videos, and streams, so itâ€™s not like the developers are trying to hide somethingâ€¦ If it doesnâ€™t interfere with my game-play and fun, I donâ€™t see how itâ€™s a problem.

Lots of biomes, and mobbies, and some good humorous moments.

Tons of new areas to explore, and lots to keep you busy.

Developers that are getting the kinks worked out as fast as possible, and they are very active and responsive in the forums begging those with issues to send them logs so they can fix any issues for everybody else.

Iâ€™ve put a ton of time in and I am thoroughly enjoying myself, because I find the game both extensive and challenging.

I myself havenâ€™t crashed even once, and though I experience lag here and there it only happens for me after playing for several hours straight. My computer is an Asus Rog Gaming Laptop, win 10, and I have an nvidia card.

The mini patches since 1.0 hit have improved the game a lot, in my opinion.

Active Devs that really want this game to succeed and are willing to do whatever it takes â€” though they get knocked around a lot by players that seem unwilling to give them time to hear and fix any issues that might be presentâ€¦

Cons:

The Lead Dev has said the game was designed more for multiplayer, so mobs tend to spawn in waves that can overwhelm a single playing characterâ€¦ After reading that bit of info, I was sad, because I look at these games as something I wish to spend a lot of time with soloing. Like in Terraria when I played with a friend he wanted to kill this boss, and that boss, and I wanted to just find resources. I never played with anyone again, though once I got to Moon Lord I lost interest, because I realized that fight wasnâ€™t balanced for single player at all (my opinion).

EOS needs some patches to iron out the kinks, and I bet my life SO WILL Terraria Otherworld when itâ€™s released. Even Terraria has had at least a half dozen mini patches since 1.3 hit, and I donâ€™t see anyone knocking Terraria for itâ€¦ And Starbound will continue to see many updates and patches before and after its 1.0 version hitsâ€¦ Whenever that might happen â€” sooner than later, me hopes!

Players rush to leave negative feedback, rather than logging the problem and helping the Devs get a handle on it. They have asked and asked for player input via logs, but some grumpy, unhelpful players would rather sink their chance at sales than help get the game working perfectly for everyone.

The game is extensive and resource gathering takes a long, long time. And some ingredients are very hard to find and farm â€” like Penguin parts and even Headhunter parts, and though I love to farm resources, even I wish these dropped more oftenâ€¦

Sometimes things feel unfair, unbalanced, such as weapon upgrades that donâ€™t do much to make you feel like the mobbies are being hurtâ€¦ I swear there was a penguin laughing at me at a Penguin Rave â€” it was hysterical, this little penguin dancing at a Rave as Iâ€™m shooting him, pew pew for half a minuteâ€¦

It seems New Players find the beginning confusing, and perhaps because the game is so extensive more time should have been put into a longer, more engaging tutorial, with an option to skip it for more advanced playersâ€¦

Final thoughts:

Personally Iâ€™m enjoying my time in the game, and though I have a large library, it keeps pulling me back with that one more node feeling, and I wake up excited to play and find new areas and new upgrades, etc. Some might not like gathering, farming games, and if the game is balanced around MP, I think MP should have been a bigger priority, as I believe a lot of complaints have stemmed from the MP community, AND I feel us solo players might not find the game as satisfying in the later stages, if the game really cannot be completed single player (which Iâ€™ve no idea if it can or cannot, but Iâ€™m hoping!!!)

column8:
TL;DR: Game effectively abandoned, used to have potential but developers failed to adapt to criticisms and appear to have dropped the project. Starbound offers better exploration and a proper story (albeit super linear) while Terraria offers more interesting combat and a more rewarding grind (even though I don't care for grind myself).

Some history:
Game offered some cool features when it came out. Felt like Terraria on space steroids. However it quickly became apparent that the developers were missing some pieces to the puzzle for creating the whole game experience, as they were experimenting with different formulas that became more and more restrictive and further from the initial impression I got when I first played. The same thing happened with Starbound, they took a really free and open world with exploration and turned it into a linear progression system which people do. not. want. in this genre. Oxygen Not Included seems to have a much better formula (I watched my friend play it yesterday and it was fun even to watch).

I was initially strongly attracted to Edge of Space because it offered much better movement and maneuvering than Terraria, which is honestly a fairly grindy endeavor to play through with fresh characters. Top that off with a tech system that doesn't require exploring dozens of worlds like Starbound and I felt like I had a winner. HOWEVER the base building was not thought out much beyond "like Terraria" and I don't recall enjoying combat at any point. The atmosphere was pretty cool though, I do wish it had the support it deserved and I still feel like there is a good game buried in here. It WAS fun for the first few hours I played!

column8:
Yeah, when this game was in EA it was a little rough around the edges, but it was still a game, which I can say is more than most can say at this point, but it's out and 1.0. Does it still have a few rough spots? Sure, but what game doesn't on initial release, but they are working hard on it, to fix what is going on, and are very connected with the community giving us regular updates on whats up.

The game is built around the idea of exploration, terraforming and expansion. Each of which is handled very well.

The experience system that has been added in replacing the old way of researching is MUCH better and a welcome addition, as is all the UI cleanup that has been done.

One thing I love about this game is there is nothing you pick up that is completely worthless (except building structure tiles if you don't plan to build with them). You can use Dirt, Stone, Biomass, jelly, shark stuff, to make guns, armor, jetpacks, tools and ammo.

The Game is deep, and has more content in it than I will ever have time to discover, but for those of you whom have enjoyed Terraria, Starbound and Crea this is a welcome addition to the collection.

Like I said, it's not a perfect game, but it still a heck of a lot of fun, I'd give it a 8/10.

(Also be very warry of the negative reviews, most were done while it was in EA and a lot has changed since then, or many have been posted since it went live, but they have 0.0 hours of play time since it has.)

column8:
First, I love this game, I loved terraria, and I definitely believe this game has so much potential just like terraria does. Throughout all of the builds I have loved this game, they tried a bunch of new ways to have the player level up and go through the story and I gotta say I like this one the most.

Hey, I know the game has some issues running right now, but I have confidence in this team, they have been developing the game for the longest time now and they are always improving it, if you don't like it right now, that is fine, but maybe in a month or two you can come back and check it out again to find it to be more than satisfactory.

This game has amazing art, cool combat, and a crazy terrain. Only boss I found was Omegatron and he was pretty awesome to fight, but just imagine the other bosses they made. 

Again, there is some optimization needed in the game, but the game is fresh out of launch and perhaps this isn't what they expected to happen at launch and I bet they are working on it right now, so just take it with a grain of salt, ok?
column9:

Throughout all of the builds I have loved this game, they tried a bunch of new ways to have the player level up and go through the story and I gotta say I like this one the most.

Hey, I know the game has some issues running right now, but I have confidence in this team, they have been developing the game for the longest time now and they are always improving it, if you don't like it right now, that is fine, but maybe in a month or two you can come back and check it out again to find it to be more than satisfactory.

This game has amazing art, cool combat, and a crazy terrain. Only boss I found was Omegatron and he was pretty awesome to fight, but just imagine the other bosses they made. 

Again, there is some optimization needed in the game, but the game is fresh out of launch and perhaps this isn't what they expected to happen at launch and I bet they are working on it right now, so just take it with a grain of salt, ok?

column8:
Sadly, had to stop recommending the game. Here's why: The developers abandoned it. It's a shame, I was starting enjoying this game.
I suggest you to try Terraria or Starbound instead, at this point.

Previous review I did (and still the Pros of this game):
At first I didn't know what to do on this game. I didn't care much about talking with that shark with a funny voice and thought there wasn't much to do. Found this is such a fun game and learned a lot of things on the second hour of my gameplay. The environment colors are amazing, great background music, a bunch of achievements... 
- Crafting system, which allows you to craft any kind of items - building, armor, weapons, tools...
- Claim great rewards for XP earned and achievements completed
- Evolve your character
- Have a pet and a house
- Destroy or create terrain of any kind
- Travel on a snail
- Zombie aliens
- Friendly shark

Depois de muito tempo acompanhando o desenvolvimento, voltei para verificar a versÃ£o final. Acho que aquele que procura algo como Edge of Space Ã© por ter um passado em Terraria e um presente em Starbound. E sinceramente eu digo que o ponto forte em Edge of Space Ã© o combate. Ã‰ meio old-school e bem desafiante. E Ã© bem por isso que vou recomenda-lo. Abaixo alguns prÃ³s e contras.

p- Removeram aquele inÃ­cio chato de dentro da Nave - finalmente.
p- Adicionaram quests, instÃ¢ncias, eventos e conversaÃ§Ã£o com NPCs.
p- O planeta agora Ã© melhor estruturado.
p- Bastante coisa pra criar e os custos do craft sÃ£o bem justos. 
p- O lance do aprendizado (XP de ciÃªncia) Ã© bem interessante.
p- Quanto ao combate, a tela pode ficar facilmente forrada de inimigos - o que Ã© meio esquisito - mas a gigantesca variedade de armas e equipamentos atÃ© que compensa pela esquisitisse do spawn.

c - O jogo nÃ£o parece estar muito otimizado... Meu PC estÃ¡ superaquecendo logo em 20 minutos de jogo. Ã‰ um AMD FX - esquenta mesmo - mas o estranho Ã© que com jogos como Starbound ou atÃ© mesmo Medieval/Space Enginners eu nÃ£o sofro com aquecimento assim.
c - Ainda existem bugs sÃ©rios como ficar preso em tiles indestrutÃ­veis.
c - Texto de alguns itens nÃ£o faz o menor sentido.
 
- EDIÃ‡ÃƒO - VersÃ£o 1.04

Os devs resolveram todos os problemas que eu listei acima o_o' EntÃ£o eu preciso assumir que os caras estÃ£o de olho e ativos, e isso Ã© Ã³timo!
column9:
After a long time following the development, I came back to check out the final version. I think those looking for something like Edge of Space are looking for something that has a Terraria past and a Starbound present. And honestly, I'd say that Edge of Space's strong point is the combat. It's kind of old-school and quite challenging. And that's exactly why I'm recommending it. Below are some pros and cons.

p- They removed that annoying in-the-ship start - finally.
p- They added quests, instances, events, and conversation with NPCs.
p- The planet is now better structured.
p- Plenty of things to craft, and the crafting costs are very fair.
p- The learning aspect (science XP) is quite interesting.
p- As for combat, the screen can easily become overrun with enemies - which is a bit weird - but the huge variety of weapons and equipment more than makes up for the odd spawn.

c - The game doesn't seem very optimized... My PC is overheating after just 20 minutes of gameplay. It's an AMD FX - it really gets hot - but the strange thing is that with games like Starbound or even Medieval/Space Engineers, I don't experience this much heat.
c - There are still serious bugs like getting stuck on indestructible tiles.
c - The text on some items doesn't make any sense.

- EDIT - Version 1.04

The devs have fixed all the issues I listed above. o_o' So I have to assume they're keeping an eye on it and are active, and that's great!

column8:
Nachdem ich in der Zwischenzeit etwa 27h gespielt habe, mÃ¶chte ich auch meine Meinung kundtun:

ZunÃ¤chst durch die Vielzahl der negativen Reviews abgehalten, habe ich mich dennoch entschlossen, "Edge of Space" zu kaufen, da ich diese Art von Spiel mag. NatÃ¼rlich habe ich auch Terraria und Starbound gespielt und Vieles ist sehr, sehr Ã¤hnlich zu den beiden.
Und dennoch geht EoS auch seinen eigenen Weg, auch wenn es nicht bugfrei und eher einsteigerfeindlich ist. Aber ich mag es, wenn einem nicht alles auf dem Silbertablett serviert wird. Zudem: EoS ist gut spielbar. Ich habe noch keinen einzigen Absturz erlebt und auch keinen Bug, der mich am Weiterspielen gehindert hÃ¤tte.
Ich hoffe auch darauf, dass die Devs am Ball bleiben, Fehler ausmerzen und vielleicht die eine oder andere fehlende Komfortfunktion einbauen.

FÃ¼r mich ist EoS auf jeden Fall einem positive Ãœberraschung. Ich bereue den Kauf nicht und bin der Meinung, dass die Entwickler bisher eine gute Arbeit geleistet haben. Deshalb von mir 8/10 Punkte!

PS: Trotz recht vieler negativer Reviews gehÃ¶rt EoS nicht zu den vorhandenen faulen Eiern, bei denen  die Devs entweder unfÃ¤hig oder Abzocker oder Ã„hnliches sind. Und ich empfinde es als Ã¤rgerlich, wenn diese einem regelmÃ¤ÃŸig zum Kauf angeboten werden.
column9:
After playing for about 27 hours, I'd like to share my opinion:

Initially put off by the multitude of negative reviews, I decided to buy "Edge of Space" anyway, as I enjoy this kind of game. Of course, I've also played Terraria and Starbound, and many things are very similar to both.
And yet, EoS also forges its own path, even if it's not bug-free and rather unfriendly for beginners. But I like it when everything isn't handed to you on a silver platter. Furthermore, EoS is playable. I haven't experienced a single crash yet, nor have I encountered a single bug that has prevented me from continuing to play.
I also hope the developers keep at it, eliminate bugs, and perhaps add one or two missing convenience features.

For me, EoS is definitely a pleasant surprise. I don't regret the purchase and I think the developers have done a good job so far. Therefore, I give it 8/10!

PS: Despite quite a few negative reviews, EoS isn't one of those bad eggs where the developers are either incompetent or rip-offs or something similar. And I find it annoying when these are regularly offered for sale.

column8:
Nice intro. Nice music in intro and main menu. Too bad that here end the nice things and game begins.
This game took lots of inspiration from Terraria. Developers analyzed flawlesly what is the best about Terraria - the open, proceduraly generated world, great combat system, pixeled but detailed graphics, massive crafting, home building, interesting and very different bosses, etc, and with expert precision took it all out.
The combat system is bad, your greatest enemy are not the very few mobs, but aiming system, reloading and limited energy. The game is far from polished, it looks like beta+, not full release. Graphics are relatively nice and detailed, but for some reason look worse then Terraria. Crafting is on one hand better - you don't search wiki for recipes, but that is the only plus it has. World generation is strange,  on one hand looks completely unnatural, on the other is hard to navigate and the way jetpack is implemented is not helping you. There is no real need to build your home - at best you create long flat terrain to place your factories at.
I could continue, but enough is enough. I Can't recommend this game. Maybe, maybe in a year, if they fix the bugs, mobs, world generation and combat, it will be interesting game. Of course, such complete overhaul is very unlikely.
Edit: played mostly in offline mode, so real time playing doesn't display in Steam.

column9:
Well, the game's initial positive review didn't live up to expectations. The developers made a killing and then abandoned the gameâ€”that's the problem with Early Access... the community trusted the developer, but the developer has no obligations because the profits have already been made.

I'll leave my naive early review:
I bought the game back when it was in Early Access (2014), when it was so raw that you could see chunks of the source code between the textures. After a year of development, the game left Early Access, but little has changed. And the bugs have become so numerous that the developers are obliged to provide players with the source code so they can finish the game as they find them.

The current state of affairs is as follows:

Pros:
+ Original progression concept (biomes increase in difficulty from top to bottom)
+ Dungeons
+ Multiplayer available
+ RPG elements

Cons:
- Lack of content (you'll have to work hard to find something to do)
- Numerous bugs, worthy of alpha test status
- Bugs in multiplayer
- Bugs in dungeons
- At the current stage of the RPG system, it's a grind
- Very infrequent updates (the developers are taking their time making the game)

I'm giving the game a positive review because it has good potential. I hope the developers don't abandon it, and then another decent sandbox game will appear.

22/09/15 06:41
Come on, game! I just told people how good you work, and now you weirdly lag all over the place? Whatever. I can take that. Also found out I can wear helmet, and take off my jetpack. Also, I have a jetpack. Nice! I don't know however, how to open those crates laying on the ground. Anyway. Back to the exploring!
@Edit: Also, I can ride on a snail. Not the fastest way to move around, but hey. It works. xD

22/09/15 06:58
I just found out, that this game has quite awesome intro! Also I thought, quick restart would fix the fps drops. It did. In the meantime a tree grew up next to my cryopod. That's good I guess. xD Back to exploring.

22/09/15 08:04
Figured most of the controls, cleared 2 zombie infested buildings (And blew them the hell up. xD), finished helping my sharky friend. Today was a good day. Quite lost now, but whatever. I'm tired for now. Game's so far great. :)

22/09/15 23:52
Things are becoming a little complex. Power nodes? Command Center? Command pods? Factories? Mounts? Wehicles? And you thought building a base will be an easy task. Also terraforming. Yeah. Other than that, I built myself a sweet shotgun. So at least some progress was made. xD

column8:
Good game, haven't got much time in but thatnks to a friend of mine and Twitch streamer, Gam3k3y. He got me into this game. It's a fun and interesting. Alot of people try to say it's terraria, but there is so much more than what you expect. 
I have yet to find any game breaking, or show stopping bugs yet. And the devs are helpful. They have even been on my friends stream, giving him advice and help with the game. Same with the community manager LadyAijou, she has been in the chat and giving advice, and inteacting with the community. 
Overall, great game, great devs. And great community support.

column9:
It just so happens that I love sandboxes. If I get my hands on something that lets you freely explore the world, mine resources, build boxes out of dirt, and generally do whatever you want, I'm in for a long time. This time, things were different. I didn't dig very deep, didn't explore very far, and spent about 15 hours in the game. I decided to write about the reasons for this.
The game is as scary as a space slug inside your spacesuit, and just as raw. There are still practically no things to find and mine, but there are now a ton of mini-biomes where we're supposed to have fun, and a bunch of NPCs with whom we can talk and complete quests for them. Our hero is also making progress technicallyâ€”he uses XP to learn the basics of spacecraft and learn to craft new items. And everything would be fine, except...
A game in which one of the main tasks is resource mining must create conditions for mining. There's not much to dig hereâ€”a few types of metals, a few types of radioactive/biological minerals, and no rare ones at all. Extracting plant resources is simple and straightforward; they can be regularly found in the same fields, and you don't even have to leave the base. Ultimately, digging is very tedious because you don't have to search for anything, there's no sense of actually getting anything (since there are no rare resources), and most of the time you just watch things peel off from walls and ceilings. The game is quite crude, so we can also expect to get our heads stuck in the ceiling and have a fascinating search for an angle at which to dig out.
Interesting locations where we complete tasks should add variety to the process. It could be a defensive platform, a terraformer, a cave with zombies, a cave with crabs, a cave with jellyfish, a cave with floating heads... yes, there are a lot of monotonous caves where we destroy nests and then click switches where we destroyed them. And everything explodes beautifully. There's no reward for this, though, so most of these mini-biomes are not only boring but also useless.
They've also added several dungeons. The dungeon features a branching system of rooms, one of which contains a boss. The concept is good, but the poorly written gameplay mechanics create a strange scene. The player arrives at their first dungeon and, clearing rooms, reaches the boss without any problems. Suddenly, defeating the boss becomes practically impossible, as the best weapon the player has at that moment can't kill it, and its ammunition is too low (yes, even if you carefully fire every rocket, shotgun, and rifle bullet the player can carry at the boss, it won't even lose half its health). Ultimately, a weak blaster with unlimited ammunition is pulled from your pocket, and about eight minutes of point-blank shooting awaits. But the boss refuses to stand and wait to be shot. Basically, it's impossible to defeat it using gameplay methods without abusing mechanics. Theoretically, you can upgrade your weapons and armor with materials found in the dungeon itself, but its chests are mostly filled with ubiquitous junk, while the dungeon's unique resource for crafting next-level gear is so rare that you can easily reach the boss without even having enough for a spacesuit helmet. Ultimately, you'll have to play through the dungeon many, many times. The game is still in its infancy, so there are also potential for annoying glitches, like a door not opening after a boss, and the boss's behavior is single-phase.
And finally, we're offered quests. During our wanderings, we'll meet a bunch of interesting characters who will settle in our base and give us tasks. Unfortunately, these tasks mostly involve gathering resources, which, as I mentioned above, are very common. So, usually, you just drag the NPCs back to the base and turn in all their quests, since you already have the resources. Exceptions do exist, but they're rare.
So, what's the ultimate goal in Edge of Space? I'll tell you. Since the game is distributed via Steam, you can earn exciting achievements. For example, you need to jump a million times and dig a million tiles. If you jump and dig at the same time, and do nothing else, it will take you roughly 10 days of play. Unfortunately, this will be the most engaging part, because the rest of the process is just as monotonous and boring, and you won't get anything for it.

Bought the game during early access, I got back to it just now. Massive improvements ! The game is very funny and entertaining.

column8:
I've played the game long enough now that I can give a basic review for the game. In terms of the knowledge progression I'm about 6% complete or so it says. I can say confidently enough that the game is interesting and has some decent mechanics that set it apart from similar games like Terraria and Starbound.

However, this game is very much a buggy mess right now and I would not say this is worthy to be called V1.0, it is very much still an early access game in my mind and if you are hoping to play this game without upset, I feel I need to tell you that you will be let down.

-Mining
Mining feels clunky at the best of times, it doesn't work like terraria or starbound where if you click on a tile then that tile gets removed, it's a directional thing and the mining tool isn't center with the playable characters model, it is off to the side a little and it makes mining a real chore.

-Monsters
The monster spawns are attrocious, they spawn anywhere even in the air, which makes falling down elevators you dig suicidal, it encourages the use of teleportation but really I find this a constricting mechanic and very poorly thought out by the developers. A fix that would make everyone happy in my opinion would be to limit mob spawns to front tiles or certain background tiles (such as dirt, clay etc)

-Monsters continued
Mobs can spawn in the air, regardless of the foreground or background tiles, I have confirmed this, and this doesn't only effect elevators and general exploration, mobs can spawn inside hangers you built for your vehicles, and those ships will die as the mob mindlessly floats back and forth rebounding off walls etc. This is completely ridiculous and wastes your resources needlessly.

-UI
The UI is a complete mess, it is extremely user unfriendly and lacks specific interactions like shift clicking to place items into recipe facility entities like the carbon refinery for example. You have to mouse them in one by one and when recipes require 5 items that are cluttered around your inventory, it is not fun to micromanage and makes organising inventory space and much more, a very annoying task.

-UI overlays
To add onto some of the UI problems the game has, the UI overlaps the screen in some instances, such as when "dominating" an area (or setting am item recipe as a task), the overlay that displays you have conquered the area acts as a none transparant pop up, basically it stops you from shooting or building while mousing over the overlay and this can lead to some pretty cheap deaths as I have experienced.

-Gameplay
The gameplay for the most part is fine, you progress at a steady pace and you are rewarded for killing monsters and mining generated tiles. However the dungeons you come across such as the zombie rooms seem to feel extremely off. You have to destroy 4 spawners and once that is complete, you have to plant 3 bombs, leave the chunk and then the entire land is just blown up. Any decoration blocks you might have wanted from the room are deleted, and you're left with an unappealing piece of land that does nothing. The game says you've "dominated" the land but you're just left with an ugly crater. Furthermore, you aren't rewarded in the slightest by blowing the chunk up, no EXP, no loot, nothing.

-SNAILS
HOLY FUCKING SHIT, SNAILS AND FROGS HAVE TO BE THE SINGLE MOST ANNOYING MECHANIC I HAVE EVER WITNESSED IN A VIDEO GAME. PLEASE NERF THEIR SPAWN RATE, IN FACT THAT BRINGS ME ONTO MY NEXT POINT

-Spawn rate
Monster spawn rate either seems to be so few or so disgustingly unbearable, the amount is completely random, you coulld be spelunking in a cave and come across one or two mud crabs, but then teleport back to base and an entire army of frogs, snails and crabs will rain from the sky.

-Frame rate
This is a really unfortunate aspect of the game, I have a really high end computer and I get frame lock ups quite often, it's not a long lock up but it is very common and happens in loaded chunks even if I am standing still. I don't have a clue what causes it and as far as I can tell from other reviews this seems to be a common problem.

-Rare crashes
The game as crashed a few times on me now. both times have happened when starting up a pregenerated world and entering a container too quickly. I am sure this will be fixed but it added to the frustration this game is to play right now.

-Instance glitches
In an instance you are similar in proprties to that of adventure mode in minecraft. You cannot place or remove blocks basically. If you happen to click too fast on a door (which is basically a teleporter to another part of the dungeon) yoiu can very easily be teleported out of bounds and you have to exit your game to fix the problem. The items needed to enter an instance dungeon aren't cheap so I find this to be a very harmful bug that impedes progression.

-Exploration
Now this may be due to the overall difficulty of the game, and I may be playing the game without fully understanding the metagame and what not, but I find exploration into the second biome (I think it's refered to as the comet biome, it's the ice themed one) to be extremely unforgiving. I have the weapons to deal with the monsters there in small numbers, but as I have said, as you fall down to lower levels, mobs spawn in the sky and can basically 1 hit ko you as you fall, but that's not the only problem, as you land on the surface of the main tier 2 biome, mobs that are faster than you are generated all around you, on the ground and in the sky and that makes exploration and progression an absolute chore. I have tried to find a way to set my spawn down there instead of on the first biome and I'm not sure how. The wiki for Edge of Space is extremely outdated and many pages are missing.

-Exploration continued
I have solved the issue of teleporting to lower levels, you have to build 2 command centres to teleport between areas. However now that I don't have to deal with the annoying elevator scenario, I have discovered that towards the lower half of the second biome, bears and penguins spawn in great abundance, regular bears can 2 shot you, and have more than doube the players moving speed so in tight spaces it is very hard to escape, they spawn almost everywhere in the cave systems down there and I simply cannot progress further below. I enjoy a hard game but I think something seems off with the spawn rate, they appear so frequently that I feel stunted to go any deeper. You might be thinking that I should gear up a little more before progressing, which is true, but all the radium I can find in the ice and all the illuminated crystals (that can drop radium) have been mined up in the top half of the biome. I made the mistake of building one of those NPC anchors with the radium (he was a useless NPC as well, did 100% nothing and that brings me onto my next point shortly) and now I lack the amount to create the desert armor set.

-NPC Anchors
I really like this idea, it's another resource sink and the potential for some really cool bonuses is there, but the developers really missed the mark on most of them. I believe Rob the robot is the most useful, fully upgraded he will drop Titanium ore for you occasionally, I have about a stack and a half of the stuff just sitting around and as Titanium is a pain to harvest, I like this NPC and my investment was worth it. However, NPCs such as Vinny (The potato plant) do nothing, regardless of the investment, his one ability is that every time you feed him 5 biomass and 5 ice, he will glow in the dark. That's ridiculous, I have lights everywhere, the investment and the space for his anchor completely outway his use. This is very similar for the other NPC's too, they could provide cool bonuses like 5% to sneak, or ore in a radius will glow, something that would actually be fun to invest these resources into. But nope, glow in the dark plants are apparently useful.

-Hit word limit, much more is broken-

column8:
So we got a snarky deloper, who while rude as can be, is still light years ahead of steam in the customer service deparment. Unfortunatly due to developers attitude it due a lot of similar unwaned criticisim. trust me when I say, it was only only Edge of Space that gave me issues on trying to play. 

the game itself is a decent game at best. It is perfect for those who have nothing better to do with their lives but masturbate. I expected much more at the time of its inception. I was wrong. If you pay more than $4 you overpayed. 

thanks again to the unpleasant dev, Shaggy,  who answered in a reasonable time frame. Even if he isn' deserving of the title lord.

column8: Brand, brand new!! Got this game shortly after watching a stream on twitch with the devs.  I liked the look of it on the demo stream and definitely loved playing it in early access.  Since it's full release, I've put in about 12 hours on the game and am loving it!  I like the crafting system, the machanics, and the dry humor of the NPCs. The music is excellent also.  I definitely recommend adding this game to your collection.

column8:
I was skeptical about this game when I first looked into it, the reviews on steam seems to have a really hit and miss feel to the game.  Since the game was on sale I decided to take a chance with it since I'm really drawn to the artstyle and general concept of the game itself.  I'm actually surprised that I liked the game as much as I do since I played Starbound before and it didn't really impress me as much as EoS does.

A few things I do have to mention though is that, yes the tutorial isn't that informative but since a lot of people have played games such as Starbound or Terraria and Eos is in the same genre, a lot of the functions and basics are the same as well.

Another thing is the lack of any active server searching function within the client, as far as I know of right now, servers are spread through word of mouth or in forum posts, but most of the big servers have been shut down already so there isn't a huge population in multiplayer that anyone can just jump in (Again, I may be wrong since I've only been playing the game for a little bit)

Last thing I really wanna recommend to anyone thinking about playing the game is to really stick with it during the beginning, because things are slow and gathering seems like a drag, but once you start getting into the game more, you'll find that Eos has a lot of depth, potential, and it's own personality that separates this game from the other games in the same genre.  Seriously though, you can build a giant mech suit, what more do you need to convince you to buy this game?

column8:
Maybe the starbound crowd finds this game too complex. 
If you're not afraid to die a lot while unraveling a great game, BUY it.

It's about as good as it gets for a side-scrolling Minecraft-topia style world. 

It's worth every dollar.

column8:
Surprisingly a very well done game! Though a few things make it a lil rough, some of the enemy AI and how things are a bit "edgy" take a small bit away from the gameplay and overall aesthetics. But that being said, it is a very fun game and it's great to pass time! 

7/10 Enjoyable game

i guess in total it equals to amount an hr and a half of gameplay. i DID pause here and there.


part 1 showcases character creation. and a few quests(tasks) to that oh so loveable shark. and me messing and learning with the controls. plus i farm a few things

part 2 showcases me finally understanding how to upgrade and learn more stuff to craft. from there i get more dareing and start exploreing and killing off the hostile that plague the planet. 

after a bit of reading. i think im suppose to take over the planet and teraform it to my liking while bathing my self in the richs of all the amazing things i find.

AH PS. my videos are long. i dont cut them via edit. all raw footage. 

overall great game. i love what the devs have done. the price is just perfect for the type of game it is. and for a game at launch. i can see atleast a few hundrend of hours in terms of time sink to get to that end game feel. as said in my videos i've only scratched the surface of unlocking stuff.
i've barely even gone down 70ft into the planet. if people keep ranting that this is just another "2d voxel clone" just ignore them. this game is really worth having and it has that sci fi feel that i've always wanted. 

10/10 laser sharks with human teeth, would have him for soup if it was possible.

column8:
This game has come a long way since when it started in Early Access.  It is now the first 1.0 'Official Release'as of last week.  I'm a thumbs up but if you read my full review you'll see below what can be impoved on as well.

I've stuck with this game and I still enjoy it.  It is a crafting, exploring game in 2D... but it's in space!  And if you like space games that are open world and exploritory, I think you'll find this one not to like.  The are lots of materials to search for, interesting knowledge tree to work towards for crafting new gadgets and gizmos, and plenty of creepy monsters and weird vegetation to learn about.  So if you like figuring out the unknown, you'll like this.  It's kinda like Terraria, Metroid, and Star Trek blended together, with a dash of Avatar but something kinda unique too.

The Edge of Space development team says they will keep improving this game post release and I hope they do.

3 things which need some immediate attention by the development team include:

-  The game engine processes data and movement too slowly compared to other games in this genre.  The result is that movement is slow and battle can be clunky for game play.  I don't think this is my processors' or video card's fault as I play similiar games with even better graphics and gameplay, without so much latency.  Maybe the coding could be tighter / more real time.  Seems like a lot of processor overhead going on.

- The opening movie is pretty untelling still.  It's better now that it's 1.0 but this is supposed to be the intro to the adventure.  The user doesn't get a good sense of what the background story is and where they fit in.  And what's with the other 3 organizations with different symbols?  Are they competitors or allies?  Are they the Ark Corp council?  Are they the ones who blew up our ship or was it an alien war?  It's hard to tell and it shouldn't be.

-  The addition of Fineous the Shark has helped teach new players (and older ones) what the controls and game mechanics are.  It could be a little more obvious though.  Probably the best way is to make sure the Codex has more content and the user knows right away that this is their one stop shop for learning about their new world, and how and what an agent of Ark Corp is supposed to do and try to acheive.  Some more work on the goals of the game are needed.  The Codex should be like our 'Hitchhikers Guild to the Galaxy'; everything you need to know when you thunk on a new planet in a Cryopod without any friends or contact with where you blasted off from, after a long cryo-frozen nap. I like the sense of humour though so far; keep that going.

That's my thoughts on this game so far.  I recommend, as long as you don't expect perfection just yet but I think it's worth supporting and playing.  It's fun and interesting to explore.

This Review was written Sept. 20, 2015.

column8:
If you are Looking at this Game, I would recommed it, with a note, keep in mind their vast majority of content you will begin to notice will be once you have played this game for a few hours. many negative reviews are either early access or are less than 5 hours in. Much Like Terraria and Minecraft this game has much more than meets the eye.

These Developers are noticably active, I've seen them post questions for negative reviews always seeking to better their game. They are very open with their community.

column8: i wasted 10 dollars on this game to get a complicated and confusing hard drive waster. The game seemed like it would be alright but when i got it i had no idea what to do. But then the complete version came out and it deleted my old character and wouldnt allow me to create a new one. Making the game impossible to play . I dont know if this just happened to me or not but with my experience i highly do not recommend this game.
column9: i wasted 10 dollars on this game to get a complicated and confusing hard drive waster. The game seemed like it would be alright but when i got it i had no idea what to do. I dont know if this just happened to me or not but with my experience i highly do not recommend this game.

column8:
Here's my experience:
Create Character
Accedentally Delete Character
Create Another Character
Enter World
Find Zombie Nest
Killed By Zombies
Complete First Quest
Spend 2 Hours Trying To Figure Out How You Get Soft Chitin For Quest 2
Complete Quest 2
Find Redeemer Fragment
Spend 2 Hours Figuring Out How To Open Door
Get Stuck In Wall
Restart My Game
Find Crab Nest
Spend 1 Hour Trying To Get Into Crab Nest
Killed By Swarm Crabs
Game Got Super Laggy
Restart My Game
Now I only Have 1/4 Of My Game Screen
Make A Jellyfish Mount
When I come Back, No Longer Have Jellyfish Mount
Something Not In That 1/4 Shoots Me With A Laser
Uninstall My Game

column8:
Never done a review before but I felt like this game deserved it.  I think the negative reviews are born mostly out of frustration with how long the game took to get from early access to release- this game has come a long way and, with it's 1.0 release, compares favorably with other games in the genre.  

Edge of Space is a lot of fun to play- its bones are basically sci-fi terraria, but they've fleshed it out with actual character progression, mechs, rocket assisted dinosaur mounts and a ton of humor.  

If you like this genre, Edge of Space is well worth your while.

column8:
Full Preview - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FiwTvbTF14s

Edge of Space is a 2D survival sandbox game were you attempt to go deeper into an unknown planets surface.

Positives

- A ton of items and equipment to craft
- Lots of random events, dungeons and bosses to defeat
- Great game to unwind and relax to

Negatives

- Can be grindy if you're not playing with others
- Power system is unnecessarily confusing
- Searching through craftbales is a bit messy

column8:
Basically, if someone saw the concept art for starbound and tried to make a clone of that but for the Sega Genesis...

I bought this game AGES ago, but because of the negative reviews, I thought I'd wait till the 1.0 launch to give it a propper chance.  It feels very much unfinished, and there is no real goal to the game.  Progress feels very slow and grindy
(e.g. an upgraded version of something takes lots of resources, but then is not noticably better)

Graphics 3/10
Gameplay 3/10

I think many aspects of this game may have seemed like a good idea in isolation, but unfortunatly it just hasnt come together well.  I dont think this game can be improved much though, because many of the problems are fundamental game-design issues.

I imagine people who would like this game would also like Starbound.  Anyone who has played Starbound will see how heavily EOS has borrowed from it.  I have problems with starbound too (slow development, bad community management, broken promises). That said Starbound is a much more polished game than EOS, and has much more game play (from what I have seen so far).
even its its slow, poor development never reaching the and of beta state.

I really wanted to like this game... but I just can't do it, after 2.6 hours of REALLY trying to.  The game play is responsive enough, and I have found only a few bugs.  I would suggest watching a gameplay video before buying though.

column8:
8/10

-don't trust the current steam rating, the majority of the negative reviews are 1-2 years old, this game deserves at least a 80% rating. (imho)

-fresh outta EA, this games has a few little bugs here and there, which is only natural. but there's certainly nothing game breaking.

-unlike other devs, you can be sure that these guys will fix bugs within a reasonable time and answer 99% of your questions in the forum.

-similar to terraria and minecraft, this game won't hold your hand: there are some npcs and a in game guide (codex) that give you some hints, but quite a few things you'll have to figure out by yourself, so at least bring a IQ of 80 with you.

-taking terraria as a reference value, EoS does some things better (again, imho):
--> better ambiente: mainly due to the excellent in game music, EoS feels beautifully melancholic and mature without being depressing, it makes you thoughtful. coming back to terraria, you'll figure yourself on a happy LSD trip.
--> better in game music (see above).
--> placing tiles works smooth and easy from the beginning.
--> beautiful art style, and it gets even more beautiful the deeper you go, especially the individual zone backgrounds!
--> devs are 10/10 straight.
--> progression is more versatile: get exp, spend in many different tech trees, find hidden stat upgrades in the world, random stats and bonuses for weapons.
--> you can fly from the getgo with a jetpack, yay! (watch your fuel though!)

Keep in mind: Overall, Terraria in it's current state is better, naturally. Terraria started this whole 2d sandbox genre: Due to a astronomically higher budget and a longer development time, you can't really beat it. If you played Terraria ad nauseam though, if you want to play something similar yet in many ways different, get EoS.

column8:
Edge of Space has come a long way since I first started playing. Movement feels a lot better; I have fun just jetpacking around and taking jumping-trickshots at the wildlife. The last minute addition of an entirely new category of weapons (melee) is fantastic, and I really like using them. There is a ton more content in every respect; creatures, events, billboard tasks, crafting, base decorations, and resources.

A lot of people have mentioned that it's a bit tough getting into the game at the start, and I would have to agree with that. Fineous's dialogue options help, but it can be really difficult deciding where to spend those first precious Science points.

My best tip: upgrade your jetpack (fighter, explorer, or builder) and make a better primary weapon (phase or melee) first! Having an upgraded jetpack makes a huge difference to mobility, and the starter weapon really seems to only be there to get you used to crafting -- by making you craft a better one.

All in all, I'm having a lot of fun. Thanks for the game and congratulations on release!
column9:
Edge of Space has come a long way since I first started playing. Movement feels a lot better; I have fun just jetpacking around and taking jumping-trickshots at the wildlife. The last minute addition of an entirely new category of weapons (melee) is fantastic, and I really like using them. There is a ton more content in every respect; creatures, events, billboard tasks, crafting, base decorations, and resources.

A lot of people have mentioned that it's a bit tough getting into the game at the start, and I would have to agree with that. Fineous's dialogue options help, but it can be really difficult deciding where to spend those first precious Science points.

My best tip: upgrade your jetpack (fighter, explorer, or builder) and make a better primary weapon (phase or melee) first! Having an upgraded jetpack makes a huge difference to mobility, and the starter weapon really seems to only be there to get you used to crafting -- by making you craft a better one.

All in all, I'm having a lot of fun. Thanks for the game and congratulations on release!

column8:
Cautious Recommendation.

I waited till post launch to play this game as it was something both me and my bf were looking at since we enjoyed terraria so much. So I will go through a few pros and cons from my experience thus far.

Pros 
- Gameplay is fun when playing with multiple people, there are features such as resurrecting dead players that you will miss out in if you play singleplayer.
- Questing is quick and easy normally. It can be a bit grindy for some of the quests but the rewards seem to usually be worth it. It instills a sense of progression that is enjoyable to experience.
- The details on your character armor and progression trees that allow you different armor if you play a certain style give a unique vibe and add potential replayability.
- Knowledge skill trees give you lots of ways to specialize as you progress in early game and it is especially helpful if you have multiple players with you, letting you all specialize in different ways and combine your knowledge to progress quicker.

Cons
- Do not try to exit game and try to get back if you are running a server. The steam client will not allow you to start game back up till you take your server down. This is also a huge problem if you crash or have any gamebreaking bugs.
- [strike]Got stuck in a wall by jumping into it during first hour of play, only way I could solve it was to quit game and log back into multiplayer server.[/strike] Issue fixed as of sept 19th hotfix.
- Exploding monster nests can leave the sound of bomb alarms going off long after its been destroyed, making an annoying sound that just wont disapear.
- Monster ai leaves a  lot to be desired.
- Building seems to take a while to make anything worthwhile and there is not as much a need to build actual homes like other games in this genre.
- It is incredibly challenging to figure out how to get many types of building materials, leading to constant searching of wiki to figure out how to find many types of materials.
- Certain materials that were used in many types of items were incredibly rare to find, making it so that more people you had with you, the more challenging and difficult it was to even find enough materials to get everyone basic items.

Overall, I would recommend waiting on this game for a few more patches or unless you like what you see. The game is enjoyable but there is quite a few issues with it that can lessen the enjoyment in both singleplayer and multiplayer post launch.

column8:
meh.

First, this is just an opinion of mine. Second, others may feel completely different then me about this game.

I bought this way back in the beginning on desura when it was just a wee pup. Did some basic exploring, fell a million feet to the hard crusty core a million times, got bored and didn't touch it for a couple years. I thought the final game would be well rounded with some good end game content and perhaps missions etc, what I see here is the same boring game from day one. I.... just... coundn't... get into it. Game progression was dismal. I haven't found any cool structures or bases or bosses or anything other than stupid space jellyfish and floating orbs of death. I dunno, perhaps if I put in an additional 100 hrs I'll find all that I'm missing in the game but ain't nobody got time for that. I say buy it on sale if you really want a go at it or else find a more polished 2d minecraft-esq game.

Pros:
The graphics are pretty awesome
The creatures are very original
You can build huge fortresses
You can craft a whole lotta sh.... stuff.
Multiplayer!!

Cons:
Quite boring playing solo
Enviroments are very much the same as far as I could tell
No actual story line or Lore to keep me intrigued in the world I was living in
No NPCs to interact with, buying selling of goods and such
No Goals that I could find
No real point to playing.... I feel sh... bad saying it but there it is....

 Sorry Devs, I really hoped it would turn out better.  I wish there was a "Not Yet" button in the recommendation field. Keep my money though, at least you finished developing the game. I'll check back next year and see what improvements you have made.

PS: I thoroughly support the development of indie game such as this and while I particularly am not satisfied with EoS, I would still pay full price for this game just to see more like it come into the light and to keep 2d platforming alive.

LONG LIVE METROIDVANIA GAMES!!!!!

column8:
Hello guys and girls, I am long over due for my thoughts on this game. 

         Lets get started shall we, I am amongst the first people who Green Lit this game and helped it out during its earlier iterations. This game has come a long way from where it once was, and only a few of us can attest to this because we come from an opinion that goes back to early alpha. On here it says I put 13.8 hours into it, but off of steam I had actually put 60+ hours into it. That was all mainly dedicated to testing out the new builds as they were being released and the new systems. This game went from being hard to figure out, to hard as nails, and then an awesome tutorial came through. Guess what, they kept up with the new tutorials making them more stream lined and easier for new players to pick up and play. Mind you, the tutorials at the very beginning were not nooby friendly, but they fixed that, and that was all based on players feedback. 

          From personal experiences, this game is a lot of fun and offers a lot to the player base at an extremely low price. These guys have worked day and night to bring a better experience to the table with each major update coming out with new fixes and added crafting recipes down to materials. More feedback is always a must when it comes to the on going production of a title, especially a creation one. StarBound, Terraria and Edge Of Space offer different experiences all together and yet each one has worked on content for each other to help promote one another. Edge Of Space for me is a gem in itself and it shouldn't be looked over because someone elses troll review. 
           
          Instead of trolling why don't you just go and tell the developers what is wrong? Because that would make to much sense I guess, give this game a try, 10. bucks isn't a bad deal and you are getting way more then that back in the content that is currently available. I give this game     "awesome out of awesome"

column8:
I bought the game when it was on Greenlight a while back, and while it has somewhat improved since then, there's still some lingering issues with the game.

The gameplay itself is fairly solid. If you're familiar with other side-scrolling survival games like Terraria or StarBound, you'll be right at home. The progression system to be able to craft better items for your base and gear gives you goals to work toward. Crafting that one weapon that plows through enemies you were having trouble with is always satisfying, and having missions to clear out an enemy nest is a good change of pace from resource gathering.

The biggest issue I've had with the game is the UI. Tooltips for players new to this particular game would be helpful. There are times when the screen becomes cluttered by the menus and crafting screens, and the screens themselves will become somewhat unresponsive at times after long periods of play.

Regardless of the game's issues, which I hope can be fixed in future patches, this is still a fairly fun game, and it's good for a change from the other survival side-scrollers. Give it a look if you can.

I don't understand why there are so many negative reviews, but I'll give my two cents in support of this interesting project.

I haven't encountered any critical bugs. The interface in 1.0 is user-friendly, and there are no more freezes when crafting.

The combat is quite interesting, and the crafting, in my opinion, is moderately labor-intensive.

I can't comment on the tutorial; I learned to play in Early Access, and it was different then.

column8: Edge of Space is very addicting...just like any other Gathering / Building game! You can very easily find yourself losing track of time as you dig a hole on a quest for that elusive material that you need for your next craft. Really enjoyed the music and the colourful settings! The crafting can seem overwhelming, but once you get the hang of it...it's really easy! Only wish there was a fullscreen or windowed fullscreen mode (maybe there is, but i couldn't find). This game would be fun to play with friends, as you can become a fighter, builder or gatherer...so there'd be some nice synergy with a few others! Pick this game up!

column8:
Edge of Space is a Terraria but sci-fi effort in the same vein as the more popular Starbound, even going as far as to include Terraria crossover content, which was one of the selling points of the game for me. It is also one of the most tedious and uninteresting games I've ever played. The basic gameplay loops are completely uninspired and dull. Terraria has wonderfully satisfying Metroidvania progression that makes slowly mining the world in order to acquire better gear and be able to defeat more difficult enemies an absolute joy to play. In the strictest sense, it's a very repetitive game, but it all feels so good that it's wonderfully engrossing. Edge of Space achieves none of that. It's a grind that just feels like a grind, and even in 1.0 is still a bit toward the wonky side, particularly the jumping mechanics.

I have issues with Starbound and it also misses some of what made Terraria work, but it at least feels like there's potential there, and even still in beta it is a lot more fun than this. Edge of Space needs fundamental design overhaul and the 1.0 release really is just polishing a game that never actually worked on the most basic level. One thing I can say for it is that I don't think the graphics are as bad as some other people are making them out to be. Don't get me wrong, they're certainly not great, but I don't think they're intolerable. In a very fun game, they'd probably be fine. Unfortunately this is not a game that plays well.

column8:
It's very difficult for beginners and those with little motivation.

That said, I made an active effort to play the game after learning more about the devs and hoping there was more depth and found that it indeed does have layers of depth. It still feels like there's more to be done with the game, like how Terraria has effectively been wrapped up, but I understand that such things take time. If you're patient, love the genre, and don't mind spending the money, buy it. If not, you know what to do.
For real, though, it IS VERY DIFFICULT TO WANT TO PLAY. Only in the beginning. Give it some effort and be inventive.

column8:
Have you enjoyed games like Starbound or Terraria in the past? Then there will be a lot for you to like here as well. If not this game won't change your mind about this genre of games. The developers seem to have a real passion and want to make this a great game, only time will tell if they succeed. The game has finally come out of early access with a slew of new features and bug fixes. So if you were on the fence before now might be the time to pick this one up.

Updated 12/22/2016

Looks like this game has been abandoned by it's development team, which is a really shame this game had a lot of potential. As the game is now I can't recommend it, there are just to many bugs and half baked game mechanics. I would look into picking up Starbound or Terraria if you haven't already.

column8:
Edit: There seem to be a lot of positive changes recently but this game is something for people that really want to comitt themselves into learning and finding out everything, readability and introduction are still making it very hard to get into the game. The fact that the setting has all sorts of crazy sci-fi things of which you do not know what they do makes it even harder to understand what is going on. 

I don't doubt that there is a lot of content and depth (and fun) if you want to comitt to the game,
but the usability and general UX / interface (+ missing visual consistency) makes it very hard to get going , and this was not a comittment I personally was willing to make and did not get over the first 15 minutes as of this big initial hurdle.

column8:
So I come to find out yesterdays negative review has been deleted.  Today v1.0 came out. Ever hear the term 1 step forward, 2 steps back. Prime example here. 

The tutorial is no longer available. Just some message flash on the screen, too fast for me to read. and off to combat you go.

You get 5 exps for every block you dig, it varies for plants and none for combat to a maximun of 5k. If you go over 5k, you don't get any more exps until you spend what you have. Techs start out at 500 exp cost and go up from there.

They've removed the graphic pictures of the items in the crafting window. You can no longer match the icon with what you're crafting with what you already have. So unless you know the game well or remember everything, you'll probably end up crafting the same item twice.

I took an instant dislike to this game when I found out they use "OR" "AND" "NOT" and some other gates to get your power working. Seriously!!? You shouldn't have take a electronics class to understand how to use power in a game, after all it's only a game that supposed to be fun, not a lesson in science. 

Some of the items have the same name. For example, the Bosom Blaster, it's in 2 different tech tables, Phased Weapons and Research 1. So apparently I have to buy it in both locations in order to build it. This part really isn't clear to me.

The other thing I don't like is in the tech tree is that there are no stats for the weapons. So it's hit or miss as to what weapons you research.

Frankly for me, it's too much grind and repetativesness and not engaging enough to want to come back and play this game more often.
