Potrebbe sembrarlo ma non Ã¨ il clone di Terraria. Il gioco Ã¨ piÃ¹ lento e piÃ¹ macchinoso all'inizio, dove bisogna imparare come sbloccare le "ricette" per il crafting. Ci sono varie missioni, dungeon e segreti sparsi per la vasta mappa da esplorare.
I mob sono presenti in quantitÃ  assurde, ogni tanto spawnano pure sotto i piedi, per fortuna molti non sono nocivi e possono essere tranquillamente farmati per il loro loot.

Il mitragliatore iniziale non rende giustizia alle varie armi che si possono craftare e che letteralmente annientano i mob, quindi se siete alle prime armi evitate come la peste di fare i Rambo e fatevi una buona scorta di materiali... poi iniziate a segare le maledette lumache che, mentre siete focalizzati su qualcosa, quelle arrivano e vi scarrozzano in giro, specialmente dentro la tana degli zombie che state cercando di epurare mentre siete in bilico sul bordo.

Con la versione 1.0 Ã¨ migliorato moltissimo, ora inizia ad avere un senso :D

Looks like I got this game on July 9, 2013. Today the game came out of Early Access as v.1.0, and unfortunately, the game is still rather hard to digest.


When I first played, the game had a few graphical issues, and it looked like it could have needed something like an editor to an author. Fine, I could always go back to it - though at this point I was beginning to regret buying this. At this point (and a couple subsequent playthroughs), I felt the game was not intuitive, unfriendly to beginners, and rather difficult for a game where you literally build your character to advance. Gathering materials? The laser pick was extremely weak and could not be as easily manipulated as Starbound's (as much as I don't like comparing, especially to Starbound). I took a long time gathering enough supplies (after dying a few times, some from mobs in the starting area and some from falling off the edge of the map) to make anything. Also, while the game no longer has the difficulty (sort of...) and the 10 free respawn limit, those things severely discouraged me from doing anything. So I waited.

Today, I opened the game with no expectations of things and found myself facing similar issues from the first time I played. The UI needs a lot of work - this doesn't look at all like a modern game with a futuristic setting - the dialog boxes look like just hastily placed rectangles and fonts (I spotted some serif fonts...) look like they were not even picked with intent. Some of the tips need editing in syntax and grammar, and overall, the game feels very much like a beta still. I wasn't pleased by the "tutorial" either, since the first thing I saw was a codex full of unnecessary text.

Nothing in the game has struck me as intuitive so far, even regarding the gathering of materials. I got the DLC items and the pick is marginally stronger than the starting one, and while it's got a wider beam (3 tiles wide), the width becomes useless because the pick target cannot be directly chosen - so if you just dig downward, for example, in the same direction, you just end up with a 1 tile wide chasm, walls either damaged or already "healed" to normal. Everything seems so grindy already - I know that games won't have you start off with good gear ready to kill bosses, but in the first quest of the tutorial, each one of those enemies (although they do no damage) took many hits to die. I don't see any fun in spending minutes killing common mobs (because face it, you're gonna attract aggro for all those missed attacks and some of those enemies move too fast with the starting rifle) and then spending minutes gathering.

I'm going to pass. Sorry, I tried, but more than 2 years did not give sufficient progress for me to enjoy this - too grindy and too unpolished.

This has been a fun game to play from off the shelf (so to speak shelf). It is a must have for those who love survival and learn as you go. This is one of those, as they add more to the game, the better it gets!

Edit: From the day before Release date (the day I purchased) to today, release day... the game is like AMAZING. I loved it before the release, but with the new content and the gameplay... changes to the UI. The game plays better, graphics update faster... and the sound track is still awesome!

I'll be playing late tonight...

column8:
My review is changed to a thumbs up after reccomendations to play after release of 1.0

So... since release I find myself instantly enjoying the game. I think this may just turn out to be the gem I had hoped it would be. Soon I will elaborate on what I like but I plan to sink many hours in before I do that

Update 8/10/15
So the whole thing has deffo improved vastly. There is a definite direction now and newcomers shouldnt come across any problems with starting. The steam forums are also full of helpful peeps and the Devs chime in too.
I love the humour in this game and the art is wonderful. It has a strange retro feel, like oil paintings done by stoned hippies in the 70s with some 80s and 90s cartoons and some Anime influence as well.

The Devs have so far been right on top of taking community feedback in and fixing bugs and while there are still specific issues which I hope are sorted soon, the game generally runs very smoothly and Iv found it to be quite stable.

I will write more further down the line.

column8:
Shogun wanted to love this game but my friends had to make new Characters just to get past the starting doors because it just picks if your charater is gonna be able to countinue on or be trapped forever in the starting room, but moving past all that we never gave up and made it to the end and this is what happend.

The very start we all picked different things to level up so we could all contribute in a team effort to go faster together.

We all built a base and struggled very hard to get our base working correctly with the power needed for each thing you place just so your stations will work so you can craft your things.

We tried out mounts and found them to be the worst thing in the game to invest your resources in for every reason you can think of, you cant take them into worthless dungeons, they die forever, they cost a ton and get killed super fast and are too slow to avoid damage as well as too big to get around like you thought they would be used for but no jetpacks are the best for getting around and always will be.

Dungeons are the most worthless waste of life in the game right next to Mounts, the gear you get from them is outdated the minute you can gather enough parts to make the dungeon key to enter it and the dungeons are so bugged you can't complete them most the time and the bosses are harder then the gear you have at the time to fight them to win, also most of your things dont work in the dungeon like jetpacks,mounts,doors, even entering the dungeon will some times crash your game and the doors teleport you to random locations some times making you unable to back track or even go forward or even leave the place alive so everything about it is a waste of life.

and at the end of the game you find yourself grinding parts and EXP to make your medic gear as well as waiting for your carbon fibers to be made because the dang machines just decide to eat your refined metals and not make any because the game is broken and super coolent is broken in the same way as well.

So in the end your friends all end up thinking the same thing as well as yourself...
Explorer armor is the best along with builder just so you can progress the game and its all about trying to get as far down as you can as fast as you can and all the side stuff to explore is broken because the far right of the map crashes your game and its just boring,filled with buggs that have never been fixed and have been around since the start of this game and they seem to be ignoring the community that has been reporting these buggs, im pretty sure a team of 3 people is working on the game and the rest are streamers and sellsmen that dont work at all and just screw around on tumblr talking about their feels.  Sorry for bad English~Shogun

column9:
[table][tr][th]
Edge of Space is a 2D sandbox game developed by Handyman Studios and published by Reverb Triple XP. It entered Early Access on Steam in 2013 and was released in 2015.
[/th][/tr][/table]

Edge of Space is one of countless unfulfilled indie promises: a game that showed great potential but was abandoned by its creators for being incomplete. But it's important to delve deeper than this aspect alone (a deal-breaker for some, I mean) and to focus on the game itself.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
It's often been presented as a Terraria-like, but Edge of Space's gameplay is more similar to Starbound, in terms of its space universe, mining mechanics, and character proportions. One of the first hurdles is understanding the game's capabilities and, quite simply, what to do and how to do it. To do this, you have access to a codex with tutorials, including videos, and, above all, a lot of text in a very basic format. This entry into the universe can be a bit of a drag, and you have to make the effort to read to better understand the mechanics that govern the game's universe.
At the beginning of your adventure, you meet a flying mechanical shark (equivalent to the guide in Terraria) who will give you a few quests (kill monsters and collect materials; admittedly, it's not always very varied) and then... nothing! It's up to you to figure it out, to go exploring. Exploration itself remains enjoyable even if the variety of biomes and enemies is limited; there's a joy in digging deeper and deeper, in search of something new.

[b]Art Direction[/b]
The graphics have an illustrative effect that I find quite ugly, but I imagine others might like it. The background of the environments is a simplistic motif (the same image juxtaposed eight times with a few more clouds at the bottom) that reminds us that the game was never finished. The shadows are poorly optimized in the game (too strong), which means you have to use a lot of light to see anything, meaning you have to put torches literally everywhere. As for the game's interface itself, it's cluttered and awkward (for example, it's difficult to navigate the crafting table).

[b]Audio[/b]
The music is calm and pleasant, like in Starbound, but quite repetitive. There are a few enemy-related FX, but I didn't find them very effective and they don't contribute to making the world feel alive or immersive.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
When the beta came out, I was very disappointed. The developers released a game that will never be finished, yet it still has a certain charm. Ten years later, I'm rediscovering it and I enjoy spending hours playing it.
I would recommend anyone who hasn't played Terraria and then Starbound to play those games first, as they are much more complete. That said, after playing them extensively and looking for alternatives, Edge of Space remains an interesting proposition. It's not worth the price, but if there's a major sale, why not give it a shot?

column8:
If Starbound was Legos, then Edge of Space is Mega Blocks. Sure you can build some of the same things, but it just doesn't have the same feel or quality. There are many animations or sprites that just don't "fit" in the world and take you out of the overall experience. Get the real thing, not a cheap knockoff. Having said that, I think EoS has a better soundtrack of the two. 4/10

Tried again, EoS is still unpolished.

column8:
Wandering around thinking what can i do. Going trough my "waiting list" i stumbled on EoS. At first i was not intrested when i saw it was 2D, looking old and something of the late 90's? 

Don't be fooled by it's "first glance" appearance, this game has a lot of gameplay and good times to offer! 
If you like space-adventure-survival you should buy it ( its only 13euros atm).
Don't let the graphics fool you, after a while you love it, you will see it's pretty on it's own very unique way.

Gameplay 8,5/10 -> its early access and the bugs it is having are annoying-> get past that and you will enjoy it
Graphics    ?? /10 -> you can't compare these with mainstream 2015 games -> it is an other leaugue of graphics
Price          10 /10 -> Early acces price is very acceptable

Overal result: Just buy it already :-)

column8:
This game is probably one of the best games I've ever played. It is filled with content from start to finish, never once have I encountered a single bug. 

Did the developers forget to remove the early access tag? With how developed it is, it shouldn't be early access.

I mean seriously one of the best well put together games, and its replayability? Unlimited.....simply unlimited. 

Terraria / Starbound can simply NOT compare to a masterpiece that is this game.

This game makes Terraria look like an early access piece of junk. Same with Starbound.

The tutorial explains everything so well, definitely the best tutorial I've ever seen in a video game before. The tutorial alone is worth playing the 13$ for, a lot of fun to be had. And it explains everything so well, with ZERO bugs.

Oh also, the combat? It is simply spectacular, tremendous, this game makes GTA 5, Mad Max, Metal Gear Solid all look like pieces of junk (compared to this game), hell any does not stand to the greatness that is Edge of Space. If I could give this game to everybody, I would, everybody deserves to play this masterpiece of a game.

column8:
[h1]just a slice of my thoughts on the game by no means encompassing the whole[/h1]

Last play through 31st August (about two weeks before release)

[u]::the good::[/u]
This game is a hell of a lot of fun.  I have spent my time building a main base and burrowing fully enclosed tunnels outwards in every direction to mine the resources whilst being able to protect myself after sun down.  The monsters are punishingly difficult to control and kill hence my paranoia.  I found the difficulty initially frustrating but having conquered my local landscape I feel proud.  Any attempts to venture outside my zone of control are met with caution but as my confidence grows I am becoming more able to endure the relentless onslaught.

[u]::the bad::[/u]
The science research tree is full of gaps.  For example, you will research tech level one in 'companions' and be able to craft your own floating torch but unlocking tech level two will garner you nothing.  Why not merge tech trees from different categories?  The intention may be to keep a certain clarity by separating 'companions' from 'weapons' from 'base building' but I am only just starting to understand that fact by writing down my thoughts.  At the time of playthrough the science tree just felt unfinished.  That is probably also symptomatic of early accesss games.

column8:
Two years in Early access, released as an unfinished game and even the dev's website is gone, FB, Twitter, Kickstarter, steam accounts visually abandoned. This game has not received any other news other than the last cryptic post from the dev team. The fact that they no longer are even caring about a game such as this is sad but I don't pity the dev team, they chose to release it unfinished. I will give my pros and cons for what the game has to offer, and then I will stop caring for the game as it's clearly abandoned and DEAD. 

Pros
+Upon entering early access, had potential and the dev team pushed out updates well enough.
+The game has potential.
+The game has a unique idea aside for what it's combat and gameplay is supposed to feel.

Cons
-Game is dead.
-Game costs almost 30$.
-I paid for a game that I believed had potential and the devs squandered it and now I believe this game should not exist on steam anymore.
-Combat system is indeed unique, uniquely horrible.
-Game relatively unfinished. Feels like it's lacking something and is defnitely lacking.
-Used to have a tutorial, where the hell did it go?
-For as simplistic the game looks and plays, it runs like junk on my comp compared to what it was advertised to be, similar to the game known as Terraria and hell that game runs better than this does.
-MANY mechanics unclear, building mechanics weird as all hell, the game doesn't tell you to push tab to remove background walls!
-Passed it's kickstarter funding and was successfully funded. This is another example that devs can fail to deliver, this lands worse than Mighty #9 and Mighty #9 compared to this game makes Mighty #9 look successful. Even though people were disappointed in it.

column8:
It's a pretty fun game, and people are sure to compare it to games like Terraria and Starbound. The difference between EoS and those other games is how you play it. EoS has a lot more technology items, like jetpacks and laser guns, and is more futuristic, while Terraria is a mix between a fairy tale world and the deepest pits of Hell. The art style is superb, and the background art is just nice to look at. Though there is somewhat of a story, it's pretty noninvasive and isn't forced on you. The story just tries to give a justification for why you're on these planets. Updates have been coming in a timely fashion, and it's about to come out of Early Access. All in all, it's a fun game to waste your time in.

EDIT: They pretty much just called it done and pushed it out, wouldn't recommend buying or supporting their other games. Barely any communication with players and they just let you down.

column8:
This game is garbage. I'm sorry devs but you messed up. The game falls flat on almost every respect. The map generation is awkward and boring, the UI looks like someone took too many statistics classes in school and there is no drive at all to actually make any progress in the game. The controls are gooey and unwieldy. The ai is unfair although very dumb. Everything about this game screams "I got this proof of concept, but it's kinda missing something.. Oh! I'll just add more content!" Content is not what this game needed. It needed a purpose, mechanics that work and a sense of direction. Oh you mean an entire game's worth of corrections? Yes.

[h1]My estimate of what it's worth to pay for it: $1.50[/h1]

Old review:
So at one point in starting to play this I thought "where'd they get Starbound's source code from?" and then realised it was just a little bit more than that. 
I'm not sure what to think of this, but I know one thing: over the years I've been playing games and then trying to recreate them in my own way, trying to get some idea of good game mechanics. This is what would happen if I successfully did that after playing Terraria and Starbound. 

The reason I can't recommend this is that I can't recommend Starbound either, - and Starbound even adhered to certain game design principles Edge of Space does not. For example, DLC or content purchases - and I can't help but feel like it's Starbound remade. 

/impressions

Since reviews aren't just opinion meters and-
Oh, they are. 
Well here's a breakdown anyway:

[h1]Art[/h1]
The art is quite good, but I can't look past the animations, which I personally don't much like. They seem slightly unnatural somehow, as if forced or overacted. 

The music is okay, and at times reminds of a certain game that parallels EoS a lot.
Then again, there isn't a whole lot of it yet, so I can't be sure.

[h1]Usability[/h1]
One thing I quite like is how the game is actually somewhat intuitive. I mean it has all that arbitrary stuff where you go through the tiers of equipment and unlock things that you would realistically have beforehand, but I can overlook that since it's an industry standard, no matter how dumb it is. 
The tutorial goes through the mechanics and controls at lightspeed. Something that's great for someone like I, who plays games like Xonotic, but would be really damn hard for anyone who isn't used to learning new controls extremely quickly. The rest of the game seems to just leave you to do what you want after the tutorial, which is good and bad, depending on how you look at it. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As usual, sandbox style progression using "tech", and unlocks of new gear.
There isn't much emphasis on building, possibly because there's not really much need, and possibly because the small hotbar and needing to manually stock it with stuff all the time is a nightmare, at least coming from games like Starbound which allowed you to place things by picking them up in the inventory. A small issue I have with it, but I'm sure many people would feel the same. 

[h1]Systems, bugs, exploits, map generation, etc.[/h1]
The map is automatically smoothed by making every top corner (tiles y-1 and xÂ±1 are air) 45Â°. Not a great feature, since building with this in mind can be very annoying. 

There are too many bugs to go into. I'm hoping this is because it's still in EA. 

The map generation algorithm is pretty basic. Very similar to Starbound, but less to explore for lack of content so far. out of the few worlds I've looked at, all are the same flattish top island with other small islands above and below. It's a little like an extremely dense asteroid belt. It's not incredible. 


Overall, this seems kind of interesting, but not so much so that a person who just bought the Weekly Bundle would give it a good review. 
I don't recommend the game, but I don't recommend not playing it either. It's one of those things where you just don't quite know how it'll turn out.

column8:
Wouldn't recommend you buy this at least until launch. They claim a launch patch is rolling out September 17th but it's August 22th, it's in 'beta', and the main quest is completely broken. Hard to think they'd launch when the previous version is so buggy. I can only hope it launches more complete.

The game itself, or at least what I've been allowed to play (what is not bugged) is pretty barebones, featuring very simplistic "randomized" quests (with a time limit, oddly enough), and an awkward MMO-style XP system (mine blocks, get XP, get slightly further towards your ridiculously numbered goal to level.)

All in all I'd recommend just waiting and reading reviews for when this game is more finished or just staying away.

column8:
Good enough gameplay out of this one, plays very like terraria in combat/building and everything else.

Difficult to understand even with the small tutorial. Dialogs are crazy sluggish, UI is entirely broken on some resolutions, and you can get trapped in some dialogs (inventory full) which locks you out of the save/quit menu.

Research is satisfying but confusing, and clunkily displayed. Buildings sometimes wont place, fsr. 'Map' brings up a blue sphere, and a colour pallete ':l

Worth a couple of quid maybe, but expect a pre-alpha build.

column9:
Review:
[h1]Edge of Space[/h1]

-Genre: RPG, Construction
-Theme: Science fiction
-View mode: Side Scroller
-Singleplayer: Yes
-Local multiplayer: No
-Online multiplayer: -
-Sandbox: Yes
-Main story length: -
-Recommended age: 3+

Pros:
-You can build anything.
-Variety of weapons, armor, and items.
-Randomly generated worlds.
-It's not a roguelike.

Cons:
-It's abandoned; there are no more updates.
-Poor optimization and very few graphical options.
-Not much to do, it's in Early Access, and it needs further development.

column8:
Full disclosure, I got this game in a Humble Bundle, I did not purchase it for this game. Now, I just have to say, in the smidget of time I've put in, I knew it wasn't a game I was going to ever play. The animations are clunky and the art just isn't great for that "retro style" devs have been shooting for. The user interface is terrible, the tutorial is obnoxious, and window placement is not efficient.

I know, I know, it's an early access game, BUT this has been early access for over 2 years now. How much longer would you be willing to wait for a game? When games are announced at E3 are you still interested 2 years+ later?

column8:
I enjoyed playing this game.  It has a lot of work to be done to get to the final stages, and it's clearly an early access project but seems to be getting there.

I got it as part of a Humble Bundle after having over-looked it so many times as another Terraria / StarBound clone.  While this is kind of true, the way they do it was in fact enjoyable.  

Would probably recommend it to others.

Like a derp, I bought this  on a Humble Bundle thinking it was Starbound *facepalm*

No matter - it only cost me around Â£3 - so fun times ahead regardless, I figure.

I figured wrong.

1/10 wouldn't get stuck in the tutorial unable to open the door at the end again

EDIT: Decided to give the game one more go, skipped the tutorial, so now I can actually play it! Having more fun this time around and have decided to give it the thumbs up. It feels a lot like Terraria - though even early early Terraria was a LOT more polished than this is.

Still..if you can get it for Â£3, I'd say do it. Just don't bother with the tutorial!

column8:
I would like to take this opportunity to call this game silly and bad. Terraria is better, cheaper, and the people who make it are nicer, so go get that instead. 

This is just not a good game, and to this day remains the one item of my library that I truly regret adding. With all others, I was intelligent about the purchase, and bought them only after careful research, playing of demos, reading of reviews etc. (or getting them in a bundle, of course)

I learned these habits from my run-in with this game. I guess you should get it if you're constantly giving in to impulse buys, so that you may learn the ways of the Steam Ninja Lords. 


too silly, didn't read; 4/10 go buy Terraria or Creeper World 3, which is a great game

column8:
EDIT: After checking recent news of this game, I had to change the review to not recommend it. The game does have bugs, and it seems it will never be fixed due to the developers abandoning the project. I'm disappointed when I learned about this, and I do wish that by some miracle, the developers will return to the project.

Unfortunately, I doubt this will happen, and thus I will leave this as a warning to not play this game.


Following below is my original review, to see my experience from when I was active.



Now noted, I played Terraria a few months ago, did some multiplayer with a few friends, and got bored of it. It has been a few months since I last touched it.

Going into this game, I was launched into the tutorial, and got a far better grasp of the basic mechanics than I did when I first got thrown into Terraria. While both do not require special placement for materials and such, this game gave a different emphasis that yes, even dirt is an important resource.

I think that's what really got me into this game. Every resource you mine actually has a use, and you don't have to dump piles of dirt into a chest so it doesn't clutter your inventory. You actually need dirt now.

Another thing that gives this game an edge against other games in this genre is the fact that you get decent ranged weapons through the tutorial. Normally you get a junk sword and all ranged weapons run on limited ammunition. Here, there's infinite ammo and it serves you well enough until you can research better schematics later on. I think that's important.

Finally, I just like the overall look. The background, the creatures, and your character all have a pleasing look that also saves resources so it doesn't eat up the GPU. It has an art style that branches off just enough where it doesn't look too foreign, but still has its own identity.

All in all, good game. If you get it on sale, you got a really good deal.

column8: Juego abandonado...

It's really hard to believe that this game is "finished" and shall be released September 2015, at the time of my review it's August 14, 2015.

I really can't get into the look and feel of this game and its game play, it certainly is no Terraria or Starbound, and there's nothing really unique in the first 1.5 hours that makes me want to keep playing. There's just the prospect to mine blocks, or grind creatures for XP, to "unlock" things that I can then build.

I think that the UI is terrible, it's visually not appealing, it gives next to no feedback, and it's unresponsive. But I think I already read that 2 years ago. Once you mass up (unlock) items to build it gets rather hard to use. The components required to build things are questionable at best. Dirt, mud, clay, rock, to build a large variety of items, huh.

There are billboard missions you can take to get more rare stuff (is it the only way?) like aluminium or uranium, they are simple and seem buggy. For example, having two missions to collect 50 dirt immediately completes both if you have 49+ dirt in your inventory, and collect just one more piece of dirt.

When you play the tutorials where you need to shoot humanoid training dummies, it becomes immediately apparent that the hit boxes are... let's just say, you have to hit them in a certain spot, their legs for example are completely off the hit box boundary.

If you have neither played Terraria, or the Terraria 1.3 update, I'd recommend that instead, or keeping an eye on Starbound. I've put over 100 hours into Starbound around December 2013, when they first made a public Alpha release, which really puts a unique spin on the whole Terraria feel and it has an absolutely amazing soundtrack.

column8:
This is a game that was advertised to be like Terraria and Starbound but dosent feel like either, but i like some of the concepts. I know its in beta so i cant be too critical but i would like to see some of these cons fixed in the future...

Cons-

-Plays like 20-30 fps, needs smoother animations
-There is no on screen toolbar without pulling up a window
-Some of the colors are off putting and too vibrant
-Enimies can be very difficult to fight
-Landscape is too scattered
-Needs more explorable dungeons and different landscapes to feel that real sense of exploration that  Terraria and Starbound had
 
Pros-

-Interesting Enviorments
-Cool Weapons and Armor
-Unique and Interesting Art Style

There is some things this game does do really good at, but more that it does not. It almost feels like it's trying to hard to be like Starbound/Terraria and it's failing to be. I think this game has potential but at the moment is just does not stack up to what i expected it to be, so i cant recomend this game :(

column9:
[h1] !!!ACHTUNG!!! THIS REVIEW IS WRITTEN FOR THE 2013 VERSION! [/h1]
When I bought this game, I thought I'd be greeted by a beautiful world of futuristic adventures, with an atmosphere of uncharted territories begging to be discovered. Honestly, I only reached for my wallet because the game's trailers reminded me of Avatar. It was precisely that atmosphere and landscapes that deeply touched my soul. But... I've never been so disappointed, and here's why:

[h1] Graphics. [/h1]
As I played the game, I increasingly realized that the creators of Terraria seemed to have taken the idea from a similar game, StarBound. Same space, same unexplored planets and creatures. Yes, everything seems to be the same, but there is a big difference. And the biggest difference (and probably the biggest mistake) is Early Access. The developer misplaced the game's development priorities, delving into something completely different. Crafts, clothing, decorations... They started cramming everything in, without considering that it still needed to be polished. As a result, we get a hodgepodge of features. There's something unfinished here, there's bug after bug there, and it makes you close the game in horror.
And I agree, the visuals are good in places, pleasant. But only in places. The climax was the "self-trolling" in the form of the Glitch Cape. (A cape whose animation seems broken. There's even a convoluted description.) Why did they have to add a broken piece of clothing and practically shove it in your face at the start of the game?
[h1] Gameplay. [/h1]
It's a cross between [u] Starbound and Terraria. [/u] A failed attempt to cross both worlds resulted in something incomprehensible. The crafting is painfully awkward, the combat is poorly executed. Again, this was a blatant attempt to copy Starbound. And exploring the world immediately turned me off, forcing me to dig a deeper hole, block the entrance, and sit and cry. The environmental imbalance sometimes forced me to run in panic from some cockroaches and practically dance as I mowed down enormous monsters with the same equipment.
[h1] My verdict: [/h1] 
I categorically do not recommend buying this game. (At least for now.) You're unlikely to even find a pirated version of this game, it's so unpopular. The developer treated Early Access with disdain, collecting patches as if they were part of the office. Without focusing on anything small, they decided to do everything at once and predictably stumbled. The game feels unpolished and unsuitable for a relaxing pastime. It's not so much the enemies that are hostile, but the game itself is hostile to the player as a whole.
Considering that I played it two years ago, I still don't want to touch it again, it was such a disappointment. But there were no Reviews back then, so I'm only writing this now.

column8:
This game should be a repleacement for Terraria or atleast a comparable thing. Unfortunetaly it is still in phase of development. After completing few startup things (gathering resources, protecting robots) it is coming to a point where You are bored because You can't find anything new (~15 hours) or it gives You a head punch with difficulty level that is too hight (in the game events like 15 mobs spawning and shooting at You light bulbs that is extreamly hard to avoid). I do not recommend this game because sometimes recipes are not finished and in some points it is not intuitive (that is very important thing). Good thing would be adding some kind of direct portals (that You could craft on place with quite huge ammount of resources) to epic boss battles which would give You either uncommon/rare loot or resources that would be only available to drop out of this boss.
Things that could be usefull:
1. More boss fight (and except needed gear, also tactic required) + rare epic loot 1 in 100 or 1000 to drop
2. More special monsters that grant a nice reward
3. Combo shoots that gives a player sense of power (for example charging power for killing monsters and than when You want You can unleash it upon all foes dealing massive damage)

My opinion:
For now it is not as good as expected, however it offers creation of own server that You could play co-op/multiplayer. This game could use some features that will make it better and 12 Euro is a bit too epensive (but it's standard for most of steam games).

column8:
So far, I am enjoying the game immensely. Although all the buildings I have discovered have been empty, I remind myself its EA and the content will come. 
The game so far has many features I love, that other sandbox games I have played are lacking; I love the crafting and research, the points system to unlock new tech, I love the companions and the mounts. Edge Of Space has dragged me away from the other sandbox games I am playing, and I can't wait for it to be finished so that all the content is in place. Do yourself a favour, if you buy one sandbox game this week, but Edge Of Space.

The one area however, where this game stands out against all others, is the extraordinarily first class interactions from the devs; I have never come across devs who are so quick to answer questions from the community, actively seek feedback and entrench themselves amongst the fans, and keep them informed constantly and consistently. This alone would make for a first class title, but factoring in all the other features, many of which. I haven't even mentioned, should,  I hope, make EoS a cult classic.

column8: this game needs to seriously sort itself out
column9: this game needs to seriously sort itself out

column8:
OK, so early access is finally over. The tutorial system has been overhauled and when you start a world with a new char the codex screen comes up with tips and at the same time a flying shark comes and asks you for help, it's a little cluttery and overwhelming but thankfully its ok because even at night you are safe so you have time to read through everything. The new system is definetely a big step forward however the game feels extremely unpolished. There are glitches in the physics and the game has a few performance issues which is really strange. The lighting has been greatly improved but does bug out occasionally. Hopefully the game will soon be updated to polish up things a bit.

With regards to recommending it.... can I? Sadly no. If a friend asks me about this game, I would just tell him/her to buy terraria. The reason for this is because for a price 50% higher than terraria, you are getting a worser game. if this game with its issues was just 7.5 dollars, then it would be a good purchase however. One might argue that terraria has had years to develop while this game has just been released. That's true, but the price of terraria is still cheaper regardless. To be fair though, terraria is a seriously underpriced game, it should cost at least 20 dollars by now, considering all the content it has.

Despite the lack of recommendation, it must be stated that this game contains some really great innovations that are worthy of praise: 1) a build in link to wikipedia 2) a system that allows you to track down which materials you need to construct something. I really wish these two things were in terraria.

Edit: I am surprised by how obscure it turns out this game is. Not a single official reviewer has touched the game and there is only one user review on metacritic.

Edit2: While the link to the wiki itself is a great thing to have in the game, the wiki itself has barely any contect, another factor in making this game difficult to approach.

column8:
First review:

Played 15 minutes and had enough.
More a chore than a game. Graphics are poor and over saturated, gameplay is clunky and the inventory system is a pile of sâ™¥â™¥â™¥.

Second review:

After my first review the developer sent me a message asking what I didn't like and saying that maybe I havenâ€™t played enough to like it. Well guess whatâ€¦ I played it again (another 15 minutes). 

The game should be enough and shouldnâ€™t be so needy to rely in the codex. Is a real pain to read that much instructions for something so simpleâ€¦ find stuff then build stuff.

The game is derivative, is like the Frankenstein of games but in a bad way. The graphics are just wrongâ€¦ â€œHey lets draw one sprite that make no sense and is not iconic and multiply it all across the screen, no matter if nobody understands what that is.â€

Very poor move making enemies harder just because you go deeper... lack of imagination.

On the bright side it has a lot of funny bugs like the moonwalking and how the whole screen trembles whenever you try to pass through a gap in a wall.

By the way the collision system is a complete mess, it reminds me the game CheetahMen form Action 52â€™s for NES.

For those who donâ€™t know what CheetahMen is (or what NES isâ€¦) here it is:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tD6wAjpPbro
column9:
First review:

Played 15 minutes and had enough.
More a chore than a game. Graphics are poor and over saturated, gameplay is clunky and the inventory system is a pile of sâ™¥â™¥â™¥.

Second review:

After my first review the developer sent me a message asking what I didn't like and saying that maybe I havenâ€™t played enough to like it. Well guess whatâ€¦ I played it again (another 15 minutes). 

The game should be enough and shouldnâ€™t be so needy to rely in the codex. Is a real pain to read that much instructions for something so simpleâ€¦ find stuff then build stuff.

The game is derivative, is like the Frankenstein of games but in a bad way. The graphics are just wrongâ€¦ â€œHey lets draw one sprite that make no sense and is not iconic and multiply it all across the screen, no matter if nobody understands what that is.â€

Very poor move making enemies harder just because you go deeper... lack of imagination.

On the bright side it has a lot of funny bugs like the moonwalking and how the whole screen trembles whenever you try to pass through a gap in a wall.

By the way the collision system is a complete mess, it reminds me the game CheetahMen form Action 52â€™s for NES.

column8:
[h1]Not a very well-rounded Game[/h1]
[b]Read past this first paragraph if you don't want to read what someone posted made up of hate comments and cranky statements[/b]

I only wish that steam would have accepted my refund request. They probably would have, if they ever played the game, and had access to the notes you can add if you say "My reason isn't here". I realize this game came out a long time ago, and I might like it more if there were actual guides on how to do stuff, rather than a little note saying what there is. Even if this game came out long ago, that just proves the developers are lazy and have no idea what else to do! Maybe post an in depth guide? Try doing something that hasnt been done many times before? Nope! They just went straight for clone of a game that is way better: Terraria. The only things I see different is that this game has some back story, and the scale of character to block is larger. And even then the developers are trying to only get good feedback by deleting every post with some negativity. I'm sorry, but this game needs some serious work to make it worth the money i'll never get back.                                                                                                               

Now that that's out of the way, some things to fix: 
[list]
[*]The scroll function is backwards, which gets annoying. 

[*]They fact that there is an area that counters all exposure protection, completely takes away the usefulness of exposure protection, I never get any warning about exposure with Earthen Armor anyway! 

[*]General Turk's (or was it Tuck? Turck?) introduction makes no sense, and I don't even know what happened after hes said to make a bunker! Was that it? Will I see him again? Or is he a useless NPC designed to make you annoyed and confused? 

[*]The knowlegde tree that grants locomotion isn't all that useful, in that it take almost 200,000 experience to get to stuff that doesn't require a cloning machine, which is also near impossible to get, becasue I have no idea how to unlock the knowledge tree that grants you it! 

[*]The Research knowledge tree also seems useless, what does it even do? All I see is a button to spend your EXP, and some pictures of guns. 

[*]The decoration items should also be unlocked through the Base Constructor knowledge tree, because nobody wants to spend valuable EXP which can be used for much more useful things instead of a useless knowledge track that is only apealing to fashion freaks.

[*]After you play for about 4 hours, you just get stuck. What else can I do? What is there to find but a large background with clouds that never changes unless it becomes night? The game is just to empty or lacks hints as to what else you can do.

[*]Maybe reduce the amount of EXP it takes to unlock the Raptors? After seeing a screenshot of them I rapidly aquired EXP to get them only to find that i needed over 20,000 EXP to get access to them.

[*]Maybe add in a health regen system? This kind of game needs one otherwise you just get frustrated everytime you go underground and find a couple Lively Slime who are very hard to kill and reduce your health to about 1/4.

[*]Maybe add to the flying laser shark thingy (sorry I forgot his name, I feel really bad) an option that lets him explain the knowledge tracks more in-depth? Such as making an option that opens up another list of options for him to explain the knowledge tracks separately. Some of them are very confusing and seem like useless things made to confuse you (as I said before).
[/list]

I hope this review draws the attention of sereval developers, and for the Steam user looking for a game to check out: I wouldn't recommend this game until it's out of early access or unless you can find an in depth guide out there that tells you what you need in order to progress beyond what 5 hours can get you.


[h1]Responses To Developers:[/h1]

LordShaggy:
About Turk:
He May have been triggered by me having what I think to be mid tiered weapons, such as the first Sniper Rifle available in-game, and the Assault Rifle-type weapon with a 35 round clip (both of these being researched under the weapons that require no ammo to be made)

Although I would love to do internal testing for a game, I am sorry but I cannot "go out" to any streams, as I am actually only 13 and my mom or dad arent really interested in taking me anywhere. If I could still do internal testing even though I cannot meet the Edge of Space team in person I would love too!
If you guys are willing to contact me through Steam or Skype (prefferably Steam, Skype takes up a lot of processing power that I would rather use for gaming, and it makes the frame rate drop majorly at random times) I can also do that! I look forward to your responses! =)

(Please note that I do not have a face cam that works with my computer).

column8:
***DIsclaimer***
I purchased this game upon release into early access.  At that time, many of the advertisements were compairing this game to Terraria, hence the nature of my review

I had a lot of hope for this game.
  
Let me preface this by saying I love Terraria.  I played a ton of it with friends and by myself back when it was first launched, and again with all the updates with my girlfriend.  I went from thinking it was a 2D Minecraft rip off to a great game that reminds me a bit of your old school games (Ghost and Goblins comes to mind with the new Expert mode)  
  
Terraria had its charm in the exploration.  You died, a lot.  You learned from said deaths.  You learned different materials make different items.  You fail a lot, in funny and unexpected ways (i.e. Farming Wall of Flesh, then realizing that I had been equipping my armor in the social slot).  The exploration was in both the world itself, and the mechanics.  They gave you nothing, said "Here is the world, have fun" and that was it.  
  
Edge of Space forgets that.  I start a new character, and I am inundated with tutorials as if I was a toddler.  The game literally stops everything to tell you to right click to pick up an item from a chest, including a video.  I am all for tutorials done right, but this one is just patronizing. 
 
The UI is just trash.  I have a character menu, inventory, tech, ect.  They are all small enough to fit on the screen all at once, yet they are their own movable UIs with wasted space.  Not to mention if I want to craft something to equip, I may have to go through three different menus for it.  This developer took a huge step backwards in design. 
 
The character control is also a problem.  It just feels slow and unresponsive.  I felt like I was on a server lagging in single player (and with the rig I have, this game should not give me any delays whatsoever).  The feel of everything was just off too.  Mining is aiming a laser at a rock and waiting.  Terraria did it right, because you would hear the clanking as you mined, making it feel like you were doing something. 
 
Lastly is the performance.  It felt like it was running at 30, because I was getting that same blurriness I would get at lower frame rates.  The game however has a FPS counter that was staying at a solid 60.  I pulled up the Steam FPS counter, and low and behold, while it did stay around 60, it would very occasionally dip, but the in game FPS counter stayed at 60.  I have a feeling that this counter is not accurate, and the developer has static text up there, but I will not say 100%. 
 
I will end with this, Have I been harsh on this game, comparing it to Terraria?  Yes, very much so.  They have marketed it as the spiritual successor to Terraria, and thus started the comparison.  Sadly, it fell very short of the mark they were aiming for.

I wish to put this into the actual review itself, since this actually has me hopeful about the future of this game.  From the head developer in the comments from this review "Thank you for your review, i think there rae some valid points we are trying to address. At the same time the game is meant to feel different."  The developer actully listens top criticism in a positive way, which could make this game potentially great in the future.

column8:
Game is pretty good! I love this genre of game and yes there are others like it but edge of space has way tighter graphics. i am getting a little tired of the pixel look. i liked it for a while but now it seems lazy. Edge of space has regular updates, check the log. i have been burned on early access but with regular updates i feel like there is an end in sight. starbound has been early access for two years does not have the reguar updates this one has and is not done yet. btw i also own starbound, the only reason i mention it is the obvious comparison. my time playing is not fully represented by the amount shown. Game is creative , clever and nearly infinite in scope due to the sand box nature and mods.

i also own terraria, craft the world, king arthur's gold and dig or die, as i said i like the longevity of this type of game. edge isn't up to craft the world or terreria yet but it is still young and terraria was made in 2011. so it has time to play catch up for a truly fair comparison.

the best thing i can say about it is i had a free review copy but bought it anyway.

column8:
I'm giving this game a recomend.
Keep an eye on this game. I enjoy it, and I believe it will be a really good game when it's finished.
I don't usually write reviews for early access games, but I'm giving this a positive because it has so many unjust downvotes from people who didn't give the game a chance. I believe the review system as-is doesn't quite work for early access games and needs a redesign that would be more fair to the product and it's changes over time (or lack there-of) and the reviewers who give their opinion.

The biggest positives of this game:
If it has a bug, the devs will fix it as quickly as possible.
They update the game regularly.
The devs really listen to the feedback, and replies from the community managers and devs themselves are often.
I enjoy the game and the gameplay. This one is last because it's an early access game that is unfinished and somewhat unpolished, but I'm positive this game will keep getting better and better (as it already has been), and it will actually reach a 1.0 version and players will be happy with it.

column8:
My first review on Steam, I wish it could be more positive, but I am tired of spending money to discover low quality lurking behind these overly positive reviews.

  What can I say, this game has been done many times before, and in much better ways.  The time in development (in my opinion) should have seen "Edge of Space" in a much more polished state than it currently is, considering the 2D style of the game.  *For the record, I understand the nature of "Early Access", but I do not believe that games should forever exist in a state of early access simply to justify financial or developmental limitations.  Having said that; open world, 2D scrolling, space exploration, voxel-based laser mining, crafting matrix, etc....   we've seen this song and dance play out again and again with the expectation that, maybe this time, something new and refreshing will find us.  Well, for me at least, it did not with Edge of Space.  I could have overlooked the poorly rendered and seemingly unrelated intro clip, a clunky tutorial that introduced an even clunkier UI, and even the low-res character, enemy, and background models.  What I couldn't overlook, however, were the poor aiming/targeting/tracking mechanics of the various starter (and presumably all) weapons and tools.  Proper hit detection, field of effect, and cursor-reticle alignment are so critical to a game like this, that to experience immediate frustration and difficulty utilizing said tools told me most of what I needed to know about Edge of Space.  I know, I didn't even play for a full hour, but let me be clear: This is a Starbound, and thus, a Terraria clone.  Unfortunately, it doesn't even rise to the level of quality those games possess, not to mention the lack of charm.  I appreciate the seemingly responsive nature of the developers, and the consistent development blog updates, but this one seems to have hit a creative wall both visually, and technically.  Sorry for the detraction, but I will be placing this game on the back burner for now.

<3

column8:
This game has been in early access for far too long, I don't see this ever reaching completion, at this rate, my children will actually get a decent shot at a finished game. The UI and gameplay changes so often it's like your trying a new game every month... that glitches and falls apart within minutes. (yea yea beta blah blah, how long are you allowed to stay in beta/early release?) 

"Terraria" feels finished, "Edge of Space" looks like it's in its first  stages, but sadly it's not. The game promises a lot of potential, but it just looks awful. There are numerous amounts of graphical glitches and things that just seem out of place. The H.U.D. and game mechanics are just.... awful. 

Skip this one for now, until then check out "Starbound".

(Notice how I didn't wait 1-2 hours to write my review?)

(Notice how I didn't wait 1-2 hours to write my review?)

column8:
*ATTENTION*
What follows was the first glance I had after some time and probably will be or is already fixed, depending on when you are reading this. It is still in discussion down here, but nevertheless, I changed my mind about it. (The developer was also really receptive and answered the comments to try and discover what is the issue so it can be fixed)

----------

I like it a lot, you guys seem to be doing some slow improvement on your "beta" status though, wich I was following since the beggining, but you guys never finish it.
The fact that now you can't even disable accessories pisses me off so much I want to puke. I don't want that stuff in the face of my character, please add a config so it can be disabled!
And the longer you take to make the game, it seems that you make it worse, framerates drop every update, my computer can run every new game in the market at 60 fps but yours it stays at 42 at most. 
The movement is really awkward, it seems that I'm on top of a rail cart, as the character also slides on the floor. The jetpack is basically a joke, it barely lifts you up of the ground and it has already ran out of fuel.
The training dummies can't be hit below their waist wich makes no sense whatsoever.
The aiming and shooting is another awkward feature leaving you empty handed.

I really liked this game at first, at the start, but every update I see you guys publish is another piece of the game that comes back broken. I don't like the way this is going, but I'm just one person. I hope you guys can rescue it to all its glory, because the idea is absolutely astounding.

I hope you guys don't get me wrong this is not an empty critic, and I mean no harm, but anyway, best of luck to you all.

column8:
First off, this game is amazing even though I haven't played it recently so I don't understand why there are bad reviews. I hardly ever write a review but I felt this game is worth my time reviewing. With all the new updates, I am actually going to set out some free time to play it again. In fact, I enjoyed this game even before all the big updates and patches were made (wipes included).  


It is similar to Terraria in the aspect of genre but uniquely different in terms of content. 

Edge of Space speaks for itself what it's about (almost). You are an alien thrown into an unknown "world". Whether it was a planet or on an asteroid, even I'm not quite sure. Everyone complains it's hard to grasp but there is a tutorial at the beginning which I happened to accidentally skipped. Even so, I didn't find the game entirely hard to follow if you know the basics: collect materials, build a house/base, kill monsters, etc. Not to mention all the cool pets and mounts you can create. Come on...a laser to collect materials and space guns?! Jet packs to fly! It really sticks to the sci-fi feel. Oh, I would also like to add I love how smooth the movements are in this game.

The challenge is in figuring how everything works and the satisfaction when you do. 

Since last time that I played, the only thing I really would complain about is how each character was bounded to certain worlds if they were made in multiplayer/single player. You can't select any character to load into a world if that character wasn't made in that particular world. Some materials that can be collected in single player were unable to be gathered in multiplayer (but before I stopped playing this issue was already fixed). There weren't as many boss fights as I would like and their drops weren't always anything special. Overall, when I stopped playing I was merely waiting for more content to be released. 

I've seen a lot of reviews comparing this to Terraria and Starbound. If you like those games more then play those games instead of comparing it to this one. Why? Because if this game was exactly like Terraria then...that defeats the purpose of making a uniquely different 2D Sandbox game. Also, if you hop into the game for less than an hour and deem that it's awful then you're not even giving the game a chance. 

I would also like to repeat that this game is in EARLY ACCESS. There will be bugs and the sort so if you don't want a game that's in DEVELOPMENT, I would advise you to wait if you have no patience for an unfinished game rather than buy it and give it a bad review because it has a lot of potential.

column8:
This game has suffered mass criticism from players, critics and just gernerally people don't like it. I DO NOT see why people hate it...This game is great...Better than Terraria? Nope but still better than other side-scrollers and also you cannot compare it to Teraria as they are pratically two different games.

First off, you create a charater, mine an awesome-looking female with a mask which screams fuck off to any crab,jellyfish or any 'badguy' that thinks they can take a piece of me. 

Then we have the tutorial. I have read reviews where they say that the tutorial didn't help or it didn't give enough depth...well I'm sorry but you must be playing a different game. The tutorial has a video in the bottom right corner of the screen which demostrates how to do stuff and what you needed to do in order to advance through the tutorial. Yes I admit that at times the video played a bit fast so I couldn't keep up with the voice BUT there was text above the video so I didn't even have to worry about it.

Once the tutorial finishes you are thrown straight into the world with little knowledge of what to do next. My thoughts were to build a base...Captain Obvious here...Digging is simple, just like other games, and it wasn't long before I had a decent amount of materials in order to make a base. Now I had two options, Build it in the sky surrounded by jellyfish or on the ground overrun with plants and creepy crawleys. My choice...the sky. 

Now I'm not going to run it for you...Try the game you will like it. The ideas that are in this game are truely awesome...There are different guns and ones I would of never thought of such as the Ark Light which shoots torches for quick and easy light...'Oh boy I wish that was in Terraria' was said a few times.

Good side-scroller...Check
Good ideas...Check
Flaws...a few but none ruined the experience
Game of the year...Maybe not but still good
Terraria or Edge of Space...Terraria but I'm am still a devoted fan 

This game will grow...New patches often...New features...Yes I've played only an hour or so but my first hour was a good experience so here's to the next 2218947947918 hours of my life :D

column8:
As Iâ€™m sure you can see I have only played about an hour of Edge of Space before I uninstalled it and asked for a refund. I cannot claim to know almost anything about the game itself in terms of if it has storyline, how good the mechanics are later on in the game or what kind of a sandbox it is. Iâ€™m simply writing about my experience with it and what I should have done to avoid this. 

Personally what I didnâ€™t like about the game which is unfortunate for the developers was the introduction. The thing that really allows you to make your first impressions (excluding the tutorial of course), sum up what your experience with this game is going to be like, how everything works etc. I had no problem with the tutorial. I very much enjoyed the general mechanics of the game. I liked how it works, I also could get used to the overall â€˜lookâ€™ of the game and how it varies from Terrariaâ€™s cute pixels. However as soon as I started the actual game itself it all went down-hill. 

When I spawned I was confused. â€œWhere was I?â€, â€œWhat was going on?â€ I was hoping for some kind of guide (yes, like in Terraria. *sigh) to help me however I was instead met by a distressed, flying, talking shark who after saving politely asked me to make him a toothbrush out of uranium or something. Now, I DO NOT like the addition of quests and things like that on a sandbox. (And again itâ€™s my fault for not watching or reading any reviews) so I was annoyed that I had been restricted already so soon into the game. I like having freedom in a game however a clock timing me down to gather materials to make a toothbrush was very annoying to say the least. However this not what annoyed me, no what annoyed me was the fact that I could not find any Uranium anywhere. So I decided to screw the quest thing and do what I had bought the game for. Explore a new alien world, and have no idea what to expect. However I soon fell off a cliff and almost died. Then I fell off another cliff. And another. And another. It was only then that I realised I must have spawned on the top part of the picture in the Menu of the game where there are many floating islands. I didnâ€™t like this at all as I felt I was restricted to the area island where my spawn was. It didnâ€™t feel like one big map for me to explore, rather different areas I would have to go to as the game progressed. So I decided I would go as far as possible and see if I could find a dungeon or something. After mining things from pretty far away from the spawn point I was told I had a full inventory. So I moved some stuff into the bin last of which was a block of ice which after being deleted I thought nothing off. However when I looked back into my hot-bar, my mining laser had been replaced by this ice. And as there donâ€™t seem to be any instructions beyond the simple things shown in the tutorial I had no idea how to get my mining laser back into my hotbar. The UI was extremely confusing and I was rapidly losing my patience with it. I then killed myself again and spawned back to pod only to realise random things in my inventory were now ice. On top of all of this you cannot move anywhere in the map without being constantly attacked by flying jellyfish and millions of little â€˜wolf thingsâ€™ on the floor that are much faster than you meaning they start to accumulate faster than you can seem to kill them. All this just seemed rather unprofessional and I still had no idea what the hell was going on and why a flying, talking shark needed uranium for his toothbrush. The gameplay was not at all what was displayed in the second trailer and the story so far involved a talking shark. Was he to be my guide??? I just wanted to get to the building, exploring and killing bosses part. I suppose it's maybe just not that sort of game.

Itâ€™s not that the game was â€˜badâ€™ as such itâ€™s just that I believe the trailers were a bit misleading within the fact that one shows a Terraria like style of gameplay where your character is free to build and explore and the other shows a very interesting backstory that looked pretty prominent and seemed like something you would progressively learn about throughout the game through recruiting NPCâ€™s, slaying bosses etc. None of this was in the introduction.

Itâ€™s entirely my fault that I neglected to look into the game before I bought it. In all honesty I am basically one of those people who just wanted a â€˜Terraria in spaceâ€™ thing. I should have watched other people play it before I blindly went in and bought it. The main two reasons I bought it Edge of Space over Starbound was A) It was Â£5 cheaper or so, ( Í¡áµ” ÍœÊ– Í¡áµ” ) :D and B) I know the lead developer is a friend of Redigit and had permission to use some Terraria bosses (which makes my Terraria in space fantasy even more realistic) and must mean it will have some Terraria qualities. I know that the game is still in Early Access so is obviously far from perfect, but I just expected better. 

I suppose the whole point of Early Access is so that people can post their constructive criticism and the developers take it into account. So maybe I will purchase the game again when itâ€™s properly released. I just wish the game had a little more freedom from the start, coincidently just like Terraria does (*another sigh) and not have a random quest to make a toothbrush for a shark out of uranium. Either way, make sure you WATCH GAMEPLAY for Edge of Space before you buy it because it can be different from what it seems. (I'm no proffesional, I just wanted to get my opinions out there!)

Thanks for reading!!!

*Edit: Just thought I would say that Steam did promtly give me a refund for my purchase within about 2 hours.

Either way, make sure you WATCH GAMEPLAY for Edge of Space before you buy it because it can be different from what it seems. (I'm no proffesional, I just wanted to get my opinions out there!)

Thanks for reading!!!

*Edit: Just thought I would say that Steam did promtly give me a refund for my purchase within about 2 hours.

column8:
Edit 10/31/16: Well too bad they apparently aren't ever going to finish it. Game had a lot of promise, but isn't at a state where I would consider it a finished product worth paying for knowing that this is its final state.


I picked up Edge of Space on Desura when it first released, played about 20 minutes and thought WTF DID I JUST WASTE MY MONEY ON. I guess I knew it was early access but... at that point it was REALLY early access. It was the skeletal framework of the game and nothing else.

Fast forward to my picking it up on steam, and the game is completely different, more fleshed out and with its own unique personality. It's still very clearly not done yet. But the parts of this genre that make it fun to play, mining, gear and stat upgrading, and base building, are functional and enjoyable. It sounds like the developers have a clear vision in mind for what the game will be, and as it progresses in development that vision becomes more and more clear each patch both in the game's functionality and tone. 

TL;DR - It's early access done right. Game has regular updates and gets fleshed out more and more with each one. It's also fun to play in its current state of development.

Edit 10/31/16: Well too bad they apparently aren't ever going to finish it. Game had a lot of promise, but isn't at a state where I would consider it a finished product worth paying for knowing that this is its final state.

column8:
Funny story, actually. I bought this thinking it was Starbound, and was horribly disappointing. I have no idea what build I was getting into.

What I got into was pretty much "build a base with a couple of buildings as a home-base, upgrade your characters and build armor and weapons, then kill the like 20 or so different enemies in the game."

I mean the way to progress your character was to get little data-chips that would increase your xp.

It was cute, but it took waaaay too long to progress, and when you did a lot of the time it felt like half of your progress was for very little.

Now it's been a while, there's a pretty clear line between enemies that act as a faction that alert each other and gang up on you(can get really tedious at times, but as long as this is a beta that's all good) whereas there's other wildlife enemies where some'll be more aggressive, but less factional in that they communicate with others of it kind, and then other creatures doesn't really care that much, but gets mad or scared if you attack them.

Base construction used to have a power generator and a command center's CPU-distribution as their main sources of power for the base equipment. Now they have Command Centers that power parts of bases, but command centers will conflict with each other, so you'll either have bases build into segments, or bases placed in completely different edges of the map, still connected by the Command Centers as one can teleport from one CC to another.

There's the separation between Phase-type weaponry (that doesn't use ammunition) that does less damage than projectile-based weaponry(which does use ammunition), there's signs that they'll end up giving us energy-based weaponry as well.

Game's also got a few vehicles, as of patch 0.4458 we have the Zephyr, decent hp, medium speed vehicle, pretty large, would guess about 6x7 blocks-size or so? There's also a Thunderbird, which I haven't tried, but it's supposed to be more armored, but slower. Other than these mechanical vehicles there's mounts: A crab, a jumpy raptor, a fast raptor and a net with captured jellyfish that works like a hoverbike. Jellyfishbikes have very little fuel, but are way faster than traveling by foot, never tried mounts as I was worried their lack of ability to fly or hover would make it hard to traverse in any useful terrain, as there's not much to gain by scouting the surface, unless you're on-foot killing enemies for loot and XP.

Hope to see the ability to equip and upgrade vehicles and/or mounts with different types of weapons/mining equipment in the future(choosing between phase, projectile and energy, potentially even one additional weapon slot in specific cases would add interesting layers into the vehicles section I think) Definitely hope to see refueling stations/refueling kits in the future as some vehicles are way to expensive to have them permanently expire after traveling a short distance, not to mention that giving the vehicle retrievability until it's destroyed could justify increasing costs of vehicles, and giving it said weapon/armor upgrades as mentioned earlier.

Not sure what the devs have in mind in terms of npc's or vending machines, but so far this game is intriguing.

The different AI behaviors are also interesting in terms of there being completely passive AI, passive-aggresive AI, faction aggressive AI's and some that will camouflage themselves rather than attack you for survival.

Nature yielding multiple resources as well giving different elements like sap, bark, the leaves and seeds, which affects what players can do in terms of crafting. It's half interesting due to different categories of crafting materials (Inorganic(processsed)/raw, minerals/chemicals/organic etc) but I also halfway feel like plants and gems end up kind of taking up a little bit much inventory space, as much as I adore the complexity. It works, but with a limited amount of inventory space it's definitely tough if you're going solo. Which also makes the swarmy enemy spawns a bit tough to deal with. Haven't tried playing with friends yet, so would say this'd be way more fun multiplayer.

All in all, in its current state I think that if you wish to roll solo and only go for weapons and armor upgrades I think the game'll last a few days. If you're going for exploration, building bases, upgrading yourself and essentially minmaxing on everything on your own it'll be worth everything from 1 week and up depending on how fast you are with these kinds of games and how much time you have to play it. I'm thinking 15+ hours a day being super efficient and lucky with weapon stats(Because weapons' stats are semi-RNG. Dmg per shot, in-game gun visuals, accuracy, crit rate, Ammo cap, MAYBE reloading time, and refire rate/rounds per second). Although it's a bit buggy and pretty slow in its current state, its simple "complexity" in crafting and although the devs(and their resources) are in charge of how much they can do with it I think it has sick potential, even if they end up sticking with the content they have right now, although more stuff's always beyond appreciated. 

I'm very glad I stumbled across this game, and I hope it goes even further as this is awesome so far.

PS. Devs. PLEASE give me a way to change my looks. I'm stuck with a thing on my face that won't let me see the helmet-art.
Also, there's a bug where when you blow up a thing that explodes upon death with an exploding projectile, the explosion caused by the dying npc will destroy the projectile post-explosion and will cause a chain explosion in projectile and dead enemy, which nearly killed my application. If there was a way to fix that that would be great, meanwhile I'll make sure to only kill explosion upon death units with normal bullets.

I will still try it out every now and then and see if it "clicks" at some point.

column8:
Amazing early access game, meaningful updates, few bugs, but thats expected from an early access game. Overall great. 8/8

EDIT: well its 1/21/2016 and this game hasnt done all that much to fix the bugs that its had for like ever, plus its added some new ones. The constant freezing gets to me pretty bad, every few seconds its gonna freeze for like 1-5 seconds, gets me pretty triggered. I've played a lot of Terraria, Minecraft and now that I have 130 hours I can say that this game is 5/10, not great. It's ok to play when watching a streat on another screen, other than that its pretty dull, repetetive. I would just rather play it with a friend than by myself all the time.
Side note: I'm sure no one is even alowed to stream this game since I almost never see anyone stream it unless the person is companied by a dev or someone. How is this good for a game like this that isnt even that good? Your choking yourselfs devs, by doing this and hurting the potential of your game.
It's so grindy and easy I could probably get 100% research with my eyes stapled to my fukin nuts.

Stay away untill the bugs get fixed and people can stream this shitty game for the plebs.

I've had fun with this game ever since it first started on early access, but especially with the latest updates it's really gotten a lot funner and more polished all around. Watching the developer streams has made me pretty excited for the coming updates, with a player-drawable map and a bunch more NPCs and content coming.

I also really love the atmosphere and presentation in this game, and while it still has quite a bit to come before a full release, I think it's definitely worth trying if you like what you see.

column8:
If you yearn for that authentic "early access" experience, look no further! Do not be fooled by the fact that the game has been released almost 2 years ago, nor by the fact that those 2 years were filled with hyperactive developement - it still feels like a proof of concept. 
Every time I return to it after a long hiatus (caused, usually by frustration at being unable to progress because, to give a few examples, the devs couldn't decide where some resource or other should spawn and deciced not to put it into the game at all, or there is a typo in a crafting recipe) my saves won't work, half the in-game systems have been changed and the others are broken (dev-speak for those is "not balanced yet").
I want to love this game, I've spent a lot of time playing it, but untill the devs decide what they want to actually do with it it's very hard to recommend.

EDIT: I'd like to clarify, now that my hissy fit is over, that if there ever was a game that shows promise, then EoS is that game. It's just that, well, I want my saved games to work - at least for my character, if not for the world itself.

column8:
I bought this game a long time ago on that other thing... what was it... desura! pre-order kind of thing that gave me access to the demo. when it came to steam, I remembered that I bought it and started looking to see if I could get a code to import my desura copy to steam or if I had to strap myself down with another content management thing. I could! wonderful.

The game plays well enough, its a bit goofy really. Thing is, its a bit under the radar as far as games I keep my eyes on. updates are always going on, and over time they really do make a difference, but somehow I always forget I have it. Then one day, I spot it and realize "oh hey, thats a thing I have. lets see whats up. oh these are neat changes." Ill play it a bit, and then get distracted again. Its a decent game though. It's been streamlined and improved quite a lot since I got it all that time ago.

There are a lot of negative reveiws for edge of space though, looking through them I see that it's down to the devs comparing it to terraria. Personally, that was a mistake on their part. When you take game giants and start throwing comparisons around, inevitably people will become incredibly salty about it because "WHAT!? THIS GAME IS LIKE THE GAME I LIKE!? LETS JUST SEE ABOUT THAT!!! WHATS THIS? THIS GAME IS DIFFERENT THAN THE GAME I LIKE!? *insert verbal abuse and hate aimed at others who do enjoy it and it's developers here*." Edge of Space is NOT terraria, it is it's own game. Take my word for it, give it a try and you'll see.

column8:
This game, is amazing! Very spacy feel, with enjoyable graphics. As a big fan of Terraria this was an instant win for me.
Lots of things to build, and it sounds like there is more to come. The leveling system is really cool, and pretty easy to figure out. I would rate this game an 8 out of 10. Great game for the price.
 However, I bought this game for multi player use, and there seems to be no hope for a user friendly  multi player selection. That being said sadly i would rate this game now a 4 out of 10. I hope they fix this it was a huge let down.

column8:
Good game!
It has it's flaws, what game doesnt? But, overall, the game is pretty well. The music is fantastic, and the adventure is outragously long! 

There are so many positives, and I don't feel like explaining every single one. I'll just sum it up.
If you like space? Like shooting things, and working with your buds? Hell, even questing it up, with rewards and a research system, then this is your kinda game!
Don't get my wrong though, the game isn't the "sh*t". Yet, atleast. It deffinately has a LOT of potential. Expecting a lot out of this game in the future, we just have to be patient!
I give it a 6 on a scale from 1-10. I am predicting a 8 out of 10 when it's done being developed! 

Hope this helps some of ya!

This system keeps the game fun, since you always know what you can go after. [However there are ALOT of things that can be discovered that the game does not just throw at your feet].
