column8:
I wanted to thumbs up this review but at this time I wouldn't recommend it to others.  It is a work in progress but a couple of key issues are preventing me from doing so.  

To keep this as brief as possible, there's not hardly any "How to" up to date resource online - most of what I found was from more than 12 months ago and a lot of the game content has changed since then.  The in-game tutorial is better than nothing but it only goes over the basics and the in-game codex doesn't offer the detail needed.  If the developer would put up some current video tutorials it would help out a lot.

When I first started playing it was a major red flag to me that you couldn't pause the game in single player.  The game can be fairly complex (which is a good thing if you have a resource to explain it) and most of what's available online is fairly outdated.  People were left to ask questions on the forums.  Not a major issue for people that have been playing since 2013, but for new players (even ones with experience from playing other similar games like Terraria or Starbound) they can lose motivation to continue quickly without knowing what to do next to progress.

It's not a bad game, it has potential and it's still in development.  However I could not recommend it at this time.  I have uninstalled the game and will check back in a few months.

column8:
A lot like Starbound but with far less polish.  After over an hour of playing I had no idea how to add tech, progress or move forward, even with online resources.

Edit for Shaggy:
The training was boring but informative... As a game consumer I am looking to maximize my engagment and fun per hour. Those first 20 minutes were low on the fun per hour.  Once I got down to the planet, mining was intuitive, but the super black pixelation of the light underground was kind of a bad experience. From a beauty/comfort stand point a smoother less grainy light pixelation on my mining apparatus would make the game much more fun. 

Once I figured out torches and my basic gear upgrades... I didn't know where to go. I had no forumlas unlocked and had no clue where to find or make them. There were few online guides or resources that made any sense (many seemed to have been written for previous version) and I got stuck within an hour.   While I think the game has a lot of potential it's not quite playable for me yet.

column8:
Normally I don't do early access reviews. Partly because early access is really about development, not playing (and reviewing) a finished product. Partly because everything is in too much flux for the review to be valid for long.

Mostly because I'm too lazy to write reviews for finished games, let alone one still in alpha/beta.

But I'll make an exception here, because even in it's current incomplete state, it is already one of my favorite games. It's also a fine example of what early access should be: An engaged development team that listens to feedback, works with the community, and simply wants to deliver a great experience to the people who buy their product. 

From an investment standpoint (which is how early access should be approached IMHO), this is exactly the type of product I'd want to back. The fact they're making a game I want to play makes it even better.

column8:
Review Updated as of 4/3/2016

How far my hopes have fallen.

This games started out with such great potential. Nice graphics, good crafting and world building mechanics. Even the inclusion of EXP and special in-world events! There were even going to be NPCs. Notice how I say 'were' in that last sentance.

The Developers seem to have left this game behind. In December, they assured us that the next update would come out after they got back from Christmas break, but days turned to weeks, and eventually into months. No update, no word from the Developers, no hope for this game.

The end product is a lot of good ideas that never got to see their full potential. The framework of a great game is there, but now it's never going to be completed.

I had high hopes for this game, and I have no idea with the Devs vanished so suddenly. But despite my dashed hopes, I cannot recoment this game to anyone.

column8:
If you played all you could of Terraria and Starbound and absolutely love the sandbox genre of games then you will love Edge of Space. This game combine many of the elements of Terraria with an Edge of Space trim to it. The gameplay itself is similar to Terraria, but with a Starbound spacey theme. The game is unique in its own way. Game music is good, better than starbound but not as cool as Terraria. The game is more complex then Terraria and Starbound which can deter players who play it for the first time. 

The tutorial explains the basic controls and concepts of the game, but in my opinion, more could have been done to explain the game mechanics for crafting. 

You have to read your codex entries after the tutorial to figure out what you need to do. Once you do that the game becomes very fun to play. Explore, craft, fight... All is open to your disposal. 

This game is still in beta, the developers are constantly patching the game and adding new content. The game only gets better from here.

column8:
If you come looking for another Terraria clone... you will be shocked, you will be surprised, and you will be.... kinda WRONG.  It's a great game, it's pretty original in its crafting system, breaking things into their component catagories so that one thing can be used in place of another if it's in the same catagory.  New updates are always fixing things, and the new research and XP system is awesome!

A highly entertaining and humorous game, as well as a very unpredictable one!
9/10

column8:
Almost missed this title due to mixed reviews. Glad I didn't! Please do not let mixed reviews scare you off like almost happened to me. I will tell you why. Most negatives were probably from the early stages of this game and from people who expected a full game during early access.

Pro's:
-Excellent grahics for the genre.
-Good sound effects.
-Many innovations, like vertical progression and unlocking new craftables with Science points.
(at first I hated the science points thing but grew to love it once I understood how it worked)
-Darn good tutorial for an Early Access game.
-Very few bugs so far.
-Very involved and helpful devs and community.

Con's:
-Even though it has a good tutorial I found it still hard to know what to do next after start and what path to take to progress into biomes below after start.

So there you have it, I think the label 'mixed reviews' is very misplaced. I can't stress enough that this is a solid and good game with friendly devs.

10/10 Would commit suicide to bring my stuff home again.

column8:
This game shouldn't even be in early access. I just played multiplayer with a friend and with-in 5 minutes the game crashed. The in game window that notified me that the game crashed wouldn't even close. The Ok button doesn't even work. So you are forced to terminate the program to close it. I mean come on the Ok button doesn't even work. 

Other thing to know. Game is very unclear on what to do and how to do it. Many many many bugs.  They are constantly deleting the worlds you create so don't plan on getting very far before its deleted. So you are forced to start from the beginning again. 

You may say "well the games still in early access." Yes it is but that's no excuse. I mean the OK button doesn't even work. That's not early access that's just poor programing. They didn't even check to see if what they programed worked. They just enter code and assume it works with out checking it. That's why there are so many bug. 

This game has potential but the makers really need to wake up. It almost seems like they have given up on their own game. Save yourself some money and don't buy this. You will regret it. There are many way better sandbox games available that will not disappoint you like this one disappointed me. So sad to see a game that could be great frustrate me so much I don't feel like playing it anymore.

Don't let the trailer fool you!!

column8:
Edge of Space game team presents nicely polished product. Proven concept of Terraria taken to space works very nicely. Constant flow of updates ensures new content as well as bug fixes and patches that are already polishing the game despite its early access. Content is already rich in current build, more biomes are coming and planned. I personally hope for linux support which is currently not planned but there is only minor thing as it was not promised in the first place. Sound part is nothing to be ashamed of. Catchy song in main menu proves this 100%. Graphic is nice and art fits the theme very well. Interesting design of enemies should be mentioned. Where else are you going to meet bear with rocket launcher on its back or legions of crabs swarming you all directions.

Early access is a big thing recently and it's up to us, gamers, to drive it in the right direction by supporting the developers who deserve it and excluding those who don't. Very responsive community management of EoS to all concerns shows how developer-community relationship should look like. This is certainly one of the best parts of the experience. Handyman Studios shows how early access should be done. By very active approach they are building nice community and nice reputation.

Very, very alpha, beware!  Do not buy this game expecing to be able to play it right now.  There is a lot of content missing or outright broken.  Several portions are completely unplayable.  Additionally, there is no promise (there actually seems to be a point of pride) that the game as it is right now will even represent the game as it eventually will be.  That takes a lot of fun out of playing it as there are so many bugs that are game ending and the bugs may never be fixed as they might change the direction of the game before they get around to fixing it.

Sorry, I can't recommend this game right now.

column8:
Edge of Space pits you against the environment as you progress downward as opposed to side by side.   You gradualy start to encounter bigger badder challanges that not only require you to be well prepaired equiptment wise, but it also requires you to bring more advanced tools.   

The versatility in Edge of Space's tools seperates it from alot of other sandbox games because you can choose to have a longer, less powerful range, or a shorter more powerful version of your tools.   This gives you options to work with.

The armor sets also differnt from other games in the aspect that they are not necissarly combat focused.   Instead of Ranger, Mage, Melee, you get  Builder, Explorer, Fighter.  Each armor catering to a particular task rather then a weapon role.  All items are created from crafting data of a specific sub catagory in crafting, so you can specialize and focus on one area at a time rather then pooling all of your science (aka accumulative xp pool ) into everything at once.

Edge of Space also offers a challange factor with it's dungeons.  It disables things like jet packs and grappling hooks and building so that you can not cheese the boses for easy wins.   

This should give you an idea of how the game plays out and how it differs from other games of it's kind.

*Feb 25, 2015* 

Development Stage: Early Access

Early Access Compitence Rateing:  9/10  -  Things were bumpy at first for what ever reasons, but things turned around quickly.   The developers never gave up despite the road bumps and updates are comeing in frequantly.   Edge of Space is a very good example of Early Access done right.

Exploration:  9/10 -  The environment can be dangerous, there's danger around every corner and you need to prepair accordingly.    There are events and outposts that keep you busy and though it is currently in an infant state of things, I can see how the world will gradualy become more and more full as time advances.

Crafting: 8/10 -  Crafting is based on xp and tends to get a bit grindy, but it's quite rewarding once you unlock new things.

Game Controls:   8/10  -  Some obvious bugs are still around, but it will not hinder the game experince too much.   Jetpacks can also go wildly out of control and some of the grapple mechanics can send your character bouncing about.

Game Play: 8/10  -  I suspect the game will greatly improve with time, but at the moment there is a limited amount of content to keep you busy, so the game becomes a bit grindy.   Again, I suspect this will change greatly in the near future.

Music:  9/10  -  The music is very fitting for the game and quite immersive.

Graphics: 8/10 -  It's gritty and retro, but also very fitting for the game style.  Some of the texture look weird, but it's a fair representation of what it is conveying.

Newbie Friendly:  7/10 - Newbies will catch on eventualy, but the learning curve is a bit harsh.  But in a good way.   It is suggested to have some platformer experince before attempting Edge of Space.  Newer generation gamers may have trouble where as older generation gamers will have little trouble with landing platforms and timeing jumps.

Community and Moderators: 9/10 -  Very few fights, healthy interactions.   Strong communication, very good staff members.  Moderation is fair and efficent and well handled.

Developers:  10/10 -  Very approachable developers, they are always happy to answer questions.   They have sense of humor and are reasonable people.   Very good company to invest your faith and funds into.

TL:DR Version:

Is it worth it:  YES!

column8:
I tried this game, i really did.
I bought this game because of the crossover event it had done with terraria and terraria is one of my favourite games, and the trailers and screenshots looked cool.
However, once i had bought it it took about a few minutes to install but once i had started it up it took about 15 minutes just to load the intro level. Once i had actually started my own world i almost instantly found myself falling from a floating island into a pitch-black hole with no source of light except my mining tool's laser pointer which was next to useless. I looked around for possible solutions to this on the internet (getting out of the hole, being able to see more than 5 pixels of my surroundings at a time, etc.) but i couldn't find any good sites that really gave me a good solution.
If you have bought this and expect it to be as good as terraria, please just don't waste your time on this game.

Als ich das Spiel sah war ich sofort begeistert!
Und obwohl es noch gar nicht komplett fertig ist spielt es sich jetzt schon erstaunlich gut!
Auch ist das Herstellungsinterface mit der MÃ¶glichkeit verschiedene Materialien fÃ¼r ein rezept zu verwenden sehr handlich!
Auch das Konzept: [b] Je lÃ¤nger du spielst, desto mehr lernst du. [/b] ist hier wirklich sehr gut gelungen!

Komme ich nun zu meinen lob und kritikpunkten.

Lob:
[olist]
[*] Ist eine gelungene Abwechslung.
[*] Gelungenenes Herstellungsinterface und System.
[*] Bietet jetzt schon viele MÃ¶glichkeiten.
[*] Bietet auf langem Zeitraum spielspaÃŸ.
[/olist]

Kritik:
[olist]
[*] Unausgeglichene Mobs. Manche Mobs teilen viel schaden aus bringen aber nur wenig EP.
[*] RÃ¼ckwand abbau system. Es mÃ¼sste ermÃ¶glicht werden auch mitten in HÃ¶hlen WÃ¤nde abzubauen ohne vorher eine lÃ¤stige Schneise ziehen zu mÃ¼ssen.
[*] Ep Balance stimmt noch nicht ganz. Teilweise dauert es Ewigkeiten bis man gewisse Forschungsstufen erreicht.
[*] CryostÃ¤be funktionieren nicht? Ich denke sie sind sowas wie extra leben falls man zu oft stirbt (siehe ecke oben links) aber sie funktionieren bis jetzt nicht?
[/olist]

Alles in allem ist es ein schÃ¶nes Spiel ich freue mich schon auf weitere content updates und Bugfixes. Ich kann es jedem Sandbox Fan nur empfehlen.
column9:
[h1] Is already recommended! [/h1]

When I saw the game, I was immediately enthusiastic!
And even though it's not completely finished yet, it's already playing amazingly well!
The crafting interface, with the option to use different materials for a recipe, is also very handy!
The concept: [b] The longer you play, the more you learn. [/b] is really well done here!

Now I come to my praise and criticisms.

Praise:
[olist]
[*] It's a nice change of pace.
[*] Successful crafting interface and system.
[*] Already offers many options.
[*] Offers long-term fun.
[/olist]

Criticism:
[olist]
[*] Unbalanced mobs. Some mobs deal a lot of damage but provide little XP.
[*] Back wall removal system. It should be possible to remove walls even in the middle of caves without having to first create an annoying path.
[*] The XP balance isn't quite right yet. Sometimes it takes forever to reach certain research levels.
[*] Cryo rods don't work? I think they're like extra lives if you die too often (see top left corner), but they haven't worked yet?
[/olist]

All in all, it's a great game. I'm looking forward to further content updates and bug fixes. I highly recommend it to any sandbox fan.

column8:
Professional Preview (Italian): http://www.everyeye.it/pc/articoli/edge-of-space_provato_24950

Abstract translated in English:
Edge of Space is a promising heir to the 2D sanbox legacy initiated by Terraria, which introduces deep changes in one of the fundamentals of the genre: the crafting system. Having to invest your hard earned experience points in developing every single Research branch to discover their advanced recipes is both an incentive to explore the world in solo play and specialize your character in multiplayer games. There are bugs here and there, but the developers are actively supporting the game through continous patch deploying. We can't wait to see what new features will be introduced in the next updates: we'd like to see a compass that aims to your last bound cryopod or a geological probe to see what resources can be found in the area.

Commento in Italiano:
Edge of Space Ã¨ un promettente erede della tradizione sandbox bidimensionale iniziata da Terraria, che introduce novitÃ  incisive in una delle meccaniche principali del genere, il crafting. La necessitÃ  di sviluppare i singoli campi di ricerca, investendo i punti esperienza ottenuti interagendo con lâ€™ambiente, per scoprire le ricette piÃ¹ avanzate, aggiunge un incentivo a procedere nelle partite in solitaria e, allo stesso tempo, permette una maggiore personalizzazione dellâ€™esperienza di gioco in multiplayer. I bug non mancano, ma le continue patch pubblicate dallo sviluppatore mitigano in parte la situazione, oltre a introdurre nuovi elementi di gameplay. Non ci resta che vedere quali altre feature verranno introdotte nei prossimi aggiornamenti: magari una bussola che punti verso la propria criocapsula o una sonda geologica per mappare le risorse presenti nellâ€™area circostante.
column9:
Professional Preview (Italian): http://www.everyeye.it/pc/articoli/edge-of-space_provato_24950

Abstract translated in English:
Edge of Space is a promising heir to the 2D sanbox legacy initiated by Terraria, which introduces deep changes in one of the fundamentals of the genre: the crafting system. Having to invest your hard earned experience points in developing every single Research branch to discover their advanced recipes is both an incentive to explore the world in solo play and specialize your character in multiplayer games. There are bugs here and there, but the developers are actively supporting the game through continous patch deploying. We can't wait to see what new features will be introduced in the next updates: we'd like to see a compass that aims to your last bound cryopod or a geological probe to see what resources can be found in the area.

Commento in Italiano:
Edge of Space Ã¨ un promettente erede della tradizione sandbox bidimensionale iniziata da Terraria, che introduce novitÃ  incisive in una delle meccaniche principali del genere, il crafting. La necessitÃ  di sviluppare i singoli campi di ricerca, investendo i punti esperienza ottenuti interagendo con lâ€™ambiente, per scoprire le ricette piÃ¹ avanzate, aggiunge un incentivo a procedere nelle partite in solitaria e, allo stesso tempo, permette una maggiore personalizzazione dellâ€™esperienza di gioco in multiplayer. I bug non mancano, ma le continue patch pubblicate dallo sviluppatore mitigano in parte la situazione, oltre a introdurre nuovi elementi di gameplay. Non ci resta che vedere quali altre feature verranno introdotte nei prossimi aggiornamenti: magari una bussola che punti verso la propria criocapsula o una sonda geologica per mappare le risorse presenti nellâ€™area circostante.

column8:
Three words: Hire an Artist

This game just looks bad. From horrible character design to tile graphics that are actually painful to look at, this game is in desperate need or proper art design.  Everything is muddy, hard to look at, of disjointed styles, and just plain ugly, overlayed by one of the worst looking and most unintuative UIs conceivable.

Besides it's horrid appearance, and despite some interesting ideas in crafting and cunstruction, the gameplay is just frustratigly unfun. Talk of features like terraforming and such drew me in when I originally purchased this on Desura long before it's Steam release, but if these features are implemented, I have never gotten to a point in the game where I could see them,  Instead, I have been confronted with a constant, and often fruitless hunt for materials to construct devices that ever seem to opperate as expected.

Frustration always takes me over, and I quit in disinterest.  Not a great entry to the Scifi crafting genre.

This game is ready for primetime and worth the cost, with active developers who have made a fun project.

If you like Terraria, you might like this - it's not as crazy-full of content, but it doesn't have the benefit of time and money that Terraria has had.  It's fun and different enough from Terraria that it presents some unique value.

There are a couple cons: balancing and game progression.  You get relatively little guidance in the overall 'purpose' of the game - what you're trying to accomplish, all the features, crafting progression, etc.  This can be annoying, especially absent a robust wiki which Terraria possesses.  Moreover, the damage done by enemies is all over the scale, and it's hard to predict how a particular tier of armor will prepare you for the next group of baddies.  Right now it feels like enemies can swarm very quickly and do crazy amounts of damage quickly.

column8:
Edge of Space is in no way enjoyable in its current state. It is repetitive, bland and pointlessly grindy. 

There is no joy of exploration because there is hardly anything to see. 3 Biomes with the same mechanics just reskins and renames of previous resources. And a handful of pre-built dungeons instances that you can travel to, and are awful.

The combat is terrible, there are only 3 weapons that just get reskinned over and over again. And worse, they are so horribly imbalanced that you use the rifle for 95% of combat, the mortar for cheesey splash-damage-through-walls tactics on the other 5% and the carbine is completely pointless as a crappier version of the rifle.

The mechanics are clunky. You can't run down sloped tiles and jump, even though the dungeons are designed with downward sloping jumps in them. Hit detection is dodgey, enemies in certain positions can be invulnerable to direct fire because terrain hit boxes seem to register before enemy ones so your shot somehow ends up blocked by the wall behind them.

The enemies are dull. There's like 16 all told, and half of them are just reskins of the same run-at-player-bump-to-damage design with bigger numbers.

The design is darn well ass backwards sometimes too, for example: 

In the dungeon where all your digging and wall placement tools are disabled, the enemies ghost through walls. But out in the sandbox where you can cheese the mechanics, enemies are blocked by walls. Why, in the one place where you can be guaranteed the enemy NPCs can't be path blocked would you put in the world's most annoying terrain ignoring floating enemies?

You have to unlock higher tier crafting by spending experience on generic tech level up consumables and using them, and the amount of unspent experience you can have at any time is capped. So you have to stop every 5 minutes and craft more tech consumables through the laggy crafting menu or start losing out on experience. Why the heck would you try to half-ass it through the existing crafting UI rather than give it its own UI to spend experience directly? And even more why the heck would you cap it? Especially cap it so low you have to stop and spend it about 20 times to level up even one tier at later levels.

The whole game is extrodinarily grindy. Everything of value beyond the starter tiers requires converting hundreds of hundreds of junk tiles into a general purpose crafting material (Carbon fibre and super coolant). When enemy specific drops -are- needed, the same enemies drop like 10 different types of item, of which you only need the 1, so you have to farm enemies for 10x longer before you can craft one of anything. And unlocking new crafting tiers takes waaaay longer than it takes to get bored of the last reskin you unlocked hours ago.

And that's why I can't recomend this game even with furter development planned. Hardly any of the updates are exciting or ingenuitive, just more reskins called content. The design choices make no sense. And every system currently in place is poorly implemented. I have not one piece evidence the devs are capable of polish or exciting design in all these gigabytes of early access game.

They can make lots of hi-res sprites though. So there's that.

column8:
This game is utter shit. The crafting is clunky and nonsensical, making machine rifles out of dirt and mud and other things. It is also clear that it's aping Starbound's layout but being even more irritating and difficult to use, needing to push the craft button multiple times in a specific place for it to even work. the worlds are impossible to navigate without dying from a massive fall, there is almost no character customization unless you count the person's face. And just their face. 

Just get starbound. This game is fugly and the enemies are nearly impossible to fight due to them being tiny and do half of your health bar's worth of damage on a hit, and utter lack of melee weapons. 

Now for me, the aesthetic is garbage except for maybe the backgrounds and sky of the game. It's like one of those minecraft knockoffs with 'HD' textures that look like garbage and not because of the fact it's a voxel-based sandbox world building game. 

Do not get this game if you are thinking of getting it over starbound.

column8:
If you like Terraria, then yes this is a game to get. 
True, it is in the early developmental stage and there are a plethora of bugs, incomplete items, and overall balancing issues that still need to be worked out. 
For a game still well into its beta, i find it damn impressive that it wants me to keep playing as much as it does. 
Gameplay is not as smooth as i would prefer, e.g. no invinicibility frames upon taking damage, enemies ridiculously hard to hit with guns, having a ceiling on the max amount of ammo you're allowed to have for everything besides phase weapons. In all honesty, I felt that Terraria handled the ammo situation for projectile weapons very well, where you could have as much as you wanted as long as you had inventory space. Reloading of course is something they didn't incorporate but the upper limit on ammo makes projectile weapons nearly obsolete. Haven't tried energy weapons yet, hope they are better, otherwise its sticking to phase weapons forever just because of ammo constraints.
Mining can be tedious, as i have not found any new ores or reasons to mine besides the fact i need resources to farm xp from the enemies flying around, and your upgraded picks dont seem to be digging that much faster. 
Dungeons on here are very exciting to explore, i was amazed when i first discovered the headhunters dungeon, and again when i found maps to other dungeons as you went lower. 
Transportation mounts, like the raptors, can't teleport with you to different command nodes, which i found to make them  not very useful since you get to them so much later in the game and need to move around between your main base and hub bases quickly. 
random events that happen are interesting, they are usually pretty tough, although the rewards are severly lacking. Kill x/x monsters and you get a couple blocks of some ore thats not very rare? not worth it. 
also can we get a map early on? exploring's a bitch without one, even if we have to make it but make it available from a fairly early point please.
I am very excited to see this game get completed, hope that this review persuades others to invest in this game and help support the developers.

column8:
First time I loaded it up I created a char. When I started loading a new world it froze at 75%.
Alt+F4. Tried again. Froze at 75%
Reinstalled and tried again. Froze at 75%.
Verified game. Still froze. Reinstall. FINALY it worked.

Start off with a tutorial covering basics on how to move around the world and open things. Also gives you some info on how to use the UI. I found it pretty difficult to use myself. Then it moves on to the crafting system and has you make a "laser pick" out of dirt.... what? Okay whatever. The crafting system is pretty off the wall, I can deal with that.  

Then you move on to the combat system tutorial using a gun you made out of dirt again. Some stationary targets then some moving ones... Odd test dummy looking guys running around backwards. 

After the tutorial you are dropped on a cluster of floating islands with some pretty rough enemies that you'll have to grind to get items to craft higher teir weapons/armor/tools. 

I understand this is still in dev and a lot has to be done. With that. I'll be back when things a a bit more smooth
column9:
First time I loaded it up I created a char. When I started loading a new world it froze at 75%.
Alt+F4. Tried again. Froze at 75%
Reinstalled and tried again. Froze at 75%.
Verified game. Still froze. Reinstall. FINALY it worked.

Start off with a tutorial covering basics on how to move around the world and open things. Also gives you some info on how to use the UI. I found it pretty difficult to use myself. Then it moves on to the crafting system and has you make a "laser pick" out of dirt.... what? Okay whatever. The crafting system is pretty off the wall, I can deal with that.  

Then you move on to the combat system tutorial using a gun you made out of dirt again. Some stationary targets then some moving ones... Odd test dummy looking guys running around backwards. 

After the tutorial you are dropped on a cluster of floating islands with some pretty rough enemies that you'll have to grind to get items to craft higher teir weapons/armor/tools. 

I understand this is still in dev and a lot has to be done. With that. I'll be back when things a a bit more smooth

column8: As a person who was hyped for Starbound, this game brings to the table a lot of what I wanted from it. While it still is very much an incomplete game, it offers a comfy environment to build your bases in and already enough diversity to satisfy my curiosity. If you enjoy fighting monsters, mining for resources, raiding dungeons with your friends, or just messing around then this game with its 12.99 price tag is absolutely worth it. If you have doubts, buy it now and wait for it to be finished. The team is giving regular patchs and communicating with the community.

column9: Really like the game, wish more of the crew played though.

column8:
I've been updating this review throughout its development. Tl;dr, it was decent, but now its garbage, and will never get better.

First Entry:
Terraria is better, but only because its a fully developed game. This one is still in progress, but is incredibly addictive, even more so than Terraria in my opinion. They've implemented a skilling system, where you repurpose dirt and mud etc into experience data which you then use to level your skills up in order to unlock new weapons and armor. Its a little complicated for those who just came from the simplicity of Terraria, but you catch on pretty quick.

Its a little unbalanced, but what can you expect from an early access game? I say if you liked Terraria, you'll probably like Edge of Space a lot too, but you'll want it when it comes out fully. The world's a little too big, with not enough to do, and the Arctic Biome is really dangerous, but again, I'm expecting these things will be expanded on eventually.

Final verdict: Currently not nearly as deep and immersive as Terraria but has INCREDIBLE potential to become an even better game.

9.5/10 cant wait for the released game


8/14/15 REVIEW UPDATE

Sooo... im not exactly sure what the devs are doing to make this game better. So far they've managed to slow down the engine, make the controls more buggy, add some unneccessary new looks, increased the loading time, and made NPCs. Instead of trying to add icing, cherries, and candles, they need to finish baking the cake first. It's been a long time, and the game seems to have only gotten worse, and while they appear to be "finalizing," their core game mechanic is horribly broken, and they've fixed things that didnt need to be fixed, and they've broken things that were working just fine six months ago. Not to mention trying to "balance" the game by making it slower, harder, and more annoying to get traction; they've increased the learning scope. In general I'm noticing way more bugs than a while ago.

On the plus side, they've automated the annoying crafting process, but so far that's the only good thing i can see.

Final verdict: I still have hopes for this game, due to my love of Terraria, but frankly it's dwindled quite a bit, and if you're looking for a Terraria clone, you'll find something that throws away everything that made Terraria fun, and added stuff that made it annoying and buggy. DEVS IF YOURE READING THIS, PLEASE FIX THE BASIC STUFF, like MOVEMENT, GUNS, and THE FRICKEN TARGETING OF THE LASER PICK, before moving to things like CREATURE SKINS, MISSIONS, QUESTS, GRAPHICS etc. Make the game playable before you make it pretty.

7/10

12/7/2016
It didn't get any better. Apparently the devs left, so it won't get any better. What a bummer. I've given up hope. Just don't buy it.

column8: So far I enjoy this game. It's colorful and fun to look at, the music is beautiful and somewhat trippy, and it's a standard 2-d mine and build game. I assume an actual 'walking backwards' animation will be added at some point. But yeah, I recommend it for what it is at the moment.

column8:
I will keep this short and sweet, 8/10

good:

multi leveled world, deeper than terraria
balanced resource scrounging, nothing is handed to the player
an absolutely unforgiving survival situation, where one step can and will kill you.

Bad:

the tech tier is off a bit, making it nearly insane to get the stuff to explore the lower levels of the world.
The inability to move your spawn point. It wouldn't even need to be moved, if there was a way to remove the tiles underneath it.
The combat damage is way to OP, 90+ damage from flying jellyfish is a bit much.

But none of the bad things listed should detract you from trying this great game out.

column8:
Been playing for a few hours now, and it's really awesome the sheer amount of content that has been packed into an alpha game. There's a huge amount of depth to this game already. However, this does come with some drawbacks. Not everything is mapped out for you, and while this may not seem like a big deal, with so many branching options on how you want to progress in the game it can become overwelming fast. Some sort of talent tree system, or unified menu for research and it's current level would be a huge help. A wiki for this game is something that the community is more responsible for, but as it gains momentum this type of resource will come naturally. 

Updates for this game are seriously quick and seems to flow constantly. Be ready for new content or fixes often, and tweaks to things you already know. 

Yes, I highly recommend the game for those who like sandbox games, and especially those who have a friend to play it with. Just remember that starting out is tough, and the end rewards are worth it. This is no terraria or minecraft or any other crafting game you've played. This is Edge of Space

column8:
Hello readers!

Let's get the obvious out the of the way: it's in Beta. There will be changes. There are glitches. Boo-hoo. 

Pros:

 It's engaging, especially compared to the garden variety of miners and crafters out there. There is a multifaceted approach to crafting that requires both raw materials and the know-how of a specific skill to be able to craft. Science Points (SP) are awarded for everything - killing baddies to laser-punching dirt - and are used for increasing skill levels in broad categories such as Base Construction (BUILD BIGGER CHESTS!) to Utilities (MAKE STRONGER LAZERBEAM!) to Consumables (WHO NEEDS CRYORODS ANYWAYS?). Once your skill level is increased you can then craft a better item for yourself! Enough on crafting.. 

Enemies! They're gorgeous! They're varied! They kick my ass =( They have weaknesses that make it an engaging combat game beyond point-and-click. Angles of attack, parabolic arcs, and reload times all need to be taken into consideration when fighting the local floral and fauna. Build stronger weapons! Fight bigger baddies! Get more SP! Build Data from SP into building better weapons! Rinse - repeat - pwn. 

Dungeons!  Just when you think you've found it all - suddenly you're platforming through a mega-dungeon fighting off mechanical brains with well-timed plasma rifle shots! Loot Loot Loot Loot. 

More dungeons!  Did you know penguins like pre-marital sex and Daft Punk? Play this game to find out why. They're promiscious. And deadly. More Loot! Why do I need all these brain stems? SCIENCE!

Cons: 

It's in Beta. Lighting sometimes shits itself - sometimes there's no shadows at all! Hitboxes have been off before - but appear to have been patched. Nothing gamebreaking that I've run into with my 38 hours. 1/2 the world isn't filled in yet - but I'm sure it will be amazing when it is! There's more than enough to explore as is. 

The only gripe I have is lack of map - but it is a planned implementation, and I'm sure will be here soon. It's a large and confusing world - even with teleportation available you still get your ass lost. 


OVERALL GRADE:

WOULD BUY AGAIN / 10 

I give it a solid 8.5 - with the possibility to be a 9 or even 10 when all the bugs are worked out and content is added. The time I have put into  it should say enough. As a fan of Minecraft and Terraria - both Vanilla - the Edge of Space more than meets my expectations and is my current crack.

column8:
DONT BUY GAME IS ABANDONED AND STILL ALPHA STAGE


[strike]Finally Early access done right.

Regular updates, it already got two different huge biomes !
Devs are posting regularly in the steam forums.
This game remembers me of an insane mix of metroid and terraria.
Your an astronaut and embark on a mission to reclaim and terraform a split up planet. The deeper you get the more radiation you will discover so dont forget your protection !
Of course you can setup your outpost and craft all shiny furniture. You can research different armor sets and weapon types like phase and projectile weapons. It got even nice upgrade mechanics like improved health , deploying mini turrets or even a grappling hook !

Now you say what ? Only 2 biomes and terraforming isnt implemented yet ? With terraform i mean turn the land into a more livable space with less radiation and hostile creatures. Base building you can do from the start!
Dont fool yourself the biomes in EOS work much differently than compared to terraria. Terrarias biomes are rather small and can be traversed quickly. But on the other hand EOS's biomes really feel vast and huge. So those areas really invite you to explore and discover new lifeforms and alien buildings :)

Basically the end end goal upon release is to turn the planet back into a livable space with oxygen etc. But terraforming is a future feature.

I think in the past 2 months this early access title did do huge steps in the right direction. I was just on a server now and got disconnected. So i was confused, but actually they pushed an update right now ! So those devs are really crazy with the updates. For example the christmas update included 2 new dungeons , 1 new boss, 1 special event and several new items to craft.[/strike]


TL;DR
Basically its a blend of 2d metroidvania and terraria. Ranged combat is a huge deal with many rifles and laser guns.  Each crafted weapon can get different stats and clip sizes etc.

It maybe starts slow and you need to get used to the crafting and research mechanics, but im sure after 4-5 hours you feel right at home :)
[b]But take notice Win Xp is NOT supported !
Mac and linux arent supported yet, but get a future implementation! [/b]
Just check out the forums to get a better picture whats going on.
When starting the game first time i strongly recommend doing the tutorial first.



Edit2: Not recommended anymore, because its abandoneware. The website shut down and community manager got fired!

column8: Honestly... I just don't like this game. I love Terraria and Minecraft though. (like Terraria, I don't think it should be compared to Minecraft). The game just doesn't look good in my opinion, is very slow paced, and is just generally boring. I also think the tutorial should be taken out of the game; if you buy this game, you have most likely played Terraria or Minecraft, so you know about crafting and things like that. Some of the fun from these games is learning what to do yourself, and one of the common complaints from the console versions of Terraria/Minecraft is that they even feature a tutorial. Not to mention that it is just FAR to long.
column9: Honestly... I just don't like this game. I love Terraria and Minecraft though. (like Terraria, I don't think it should be compared to Minecraft). The game just doesn't look good in my opinion, is very slow paced, and is just generally boring. I also think the tutorial should be taken out of the game; if you buy this game, you have most likely played Terraria or Minecraft, so you know about crafting and things like that. Some of the fun from these games is learning what to do yourself, and one of the common complaints from the console versions of Terraria/Minecraft is that they even feature a tutorial. Not to mention that it is just FAR to long.

column8: This is an early access review. That being said the game has a lot of potential, and with fingers crossed updates continue to come regularly since I started. column8:
tl;dr Game is probably worth about 5-10 bucks due to how unpolished it is; buy it on a sale which usually sells it as 3 dollars or so. The game is fun and interesting if you look past the roughness of the UI and controls.

I bought this game awhile ago back when it first game out on steam and recently noticed it in my library, I decided to try it out again and look into the history of the game because it is abandoned. After playing for awhile I can only describe the game as one thing:

[b]A gemstone in the rough.[/b]

The interesting floating island generation, structures, and interesting creatures all bring back that initial feeling of wonder and exploration you normally lose after playing sandbox games for a long time, or playing many sandbox games.

The storyline is basic, but the NPCs that you can talk to aren't too bland or cliche, which is refreshing.

Pretty much all of the gameplay elements feel well thought out, such as the XP/Research system, questing, and dungeons. 

Soundtrack is also nice.

[b]The thing that sets this game back however, is the lack of polish.[/b]

The UI and controls are a mess, which takes longer then it should to get used to, and I never really got used to them in the end.

The tutorial isn't really gradual, but rather if you want to learn to play you need to sit through a bunch of tutorial videos and text that are in the a "Help" screen.

Combat is underwhelming, you mostly kite enemies with your jetpack and shoot them or use melee when your energy runs out. There is no way to dodge or negate damage.

I feel that if this game was picked up again it could stand up to the likes of Starbound and Terraria, but that is merely a pipedream at this point.

column8:
Edit: 6/15/2020: I do encourage you to read my original review...and while I am not changing the recommendation-I do want to let people know that the devs quickly tucked tail and ran after the game came out. It is still an "ok" game and fun to play for a few hours though.

Since I first started playing EOS I have noticed a ton of improvement.  The game gets regular updates and the devs are very involved with the community here on Steam.  One thing I really enjoy about EOS is the multi-leveled crafting.  Each resource is needed from the start to the end, so I don't feel as though I'm waisting my time gathering dirt, mud and rock on the way to the more valuable resourses.  You unlock new crafting opportunities by earning XP.  With this XP  you can "buy" data.  The data (once you get enough) gives access to better equipment.  I really like this system, I'm hoping that this is the one the devs settle on.  
There are a few frustrating things about the game, such as the amount of time required to gather resourses for the equipment you need to progress.  Also, much like Terraria, the player is super vulnerable at the start of the game (this can lead to much frustration for players not accustomed to this type of game). The issue I struggle with the most is the lack of direction in the game.  The crafting is so much fun, but I have no idea what certain resourses are for or how some of the better equipment is crafted.  If you get too lopsided with buying data from one or two catergories you will be totally lost.  Make sure you unlock the data evenly to avoid any problems.
In conclusion, I totally recomend EOS.  I remember being frustrated as hell when playing Terraria after it first came out, but as time went along and I slowly learned new things the game became really fun.  I am 100% convinced that EOS is offering the same type of experience, who knows, maybee it will be even better than Terraria when all is said and done.

column8:
This game is an attempt at an evolution of terraria. The problem is that it isn't updated much and the base game didn't have much content for this to be enough. 

The largest problem with this game is that it has no end game. The further you progress, the less you get in return until you eventually can't progress unless you're good at farming, as there are no middle grounds for progression (Such as two types of armour at a stage instead of one, or very few upgrades for mining tools). 

The game isn't fleshed out enough for you to invest time in it.

column8:
Not worth it. Just feels like a cheap rip off of Terraria and Starbound... which it is?

I'm aware this is an early access game and I hate to give a beta game a negative review but...
this game is SO boring. It is supposed to be similiar to Terraria and Starbound but it falls VERY
short of making any attempts to surpass them. I cannot even force myself to play this game 
for any longer than the amount that I did. 

The goals in the game are in a codex you have to READ to really understand what your next step
is to continue or progress. It just seems lazy to me to force a player to read paragraph after paragraph 
explaining what to do. This was a huge turn off for me and I regret not doing more research before
investing in this. 

Other comments have mentioned that there is room for improvement, but I'm going
to be brutally honest and say that this game needs a HUGE overhull to give it any actual potential.

Edge of Space ist der kleine Gegner von Terraria, aber mit etwas mehr Tiefgang.
Wie der Name schon erahnen lÃ¤sst, spielt EoS irgendwo im Weltraum auf einem fremden Planten und es geht, wie auch in Terraria, um Ã¼berleden. Zu anfang nimmt euch ein kleines, aber gutes, Tutorial an die Hand und zeigt euch die bis dahin wichtigsten Aspekte des Spiels, danach werdet ihr auch schon auf einem Planeten ausgesetzt :D.

Pros.
- die AtmosphÃ¤re des Spiel ist sehr dicht
- Grafik und Animationen passen zum Spiel bzw. zum Gameplay
- Gegnervielfalt und Landschaft sind sehr schÃ¶n gemacht
- GegenstÃ¤nde, massig GegenstÃ¤nde.....
- Crafting ist einfach und selbsterklÃ¤rend......

Cons.
- ....aber auch ziemlich zeitaufwendig
- manche GegenstÃ¤nde erst auf den zweiten Blick sinnvoll

- abbauen der Ressourcen dauert gegen Anfang recht lang


Fazit:
Edge of Space ist keine einfache Kopie von Terraria, aber es fÃ¼hlt sich an manchen Stellen an wie ein AddOn zu Terraria oder ein Teil 2. Trotzdem muss ich sagen macht mir das Spiel sehr viel SpaÃŸ, vielleicht gerade deswegen.
Also, wenn ihr Terraria liebt und auf der Suche noch etwas vergleichbarem seit, Edge of Space ist dann vielleicht genau das was ihr sucht. Gebt dem Spiel eine Chance, denn die hat EoS verdient.

PS: Die Updates kommen in guten AbstÃ¤nden und die Verbesserungen machen sich auch bemerkbar (ist ja nicht bei jedem Early Access-Spiel der Fall)

column9:
Short review of "Edge of Space":

Edge of Space is Terraria's smaller rival, but with a bit more depth.
As the name suggests, EoS takes place somewhere in space on an alien planet, and, like Terraria, the goal is to conquer. A short but good tutorial guides you through the most important aspects of the game so far, after which you're dropped off on a planet :D.

Pros.
- The game's atmosphere is very dense
- The graphics and animations fit the game and gameplay
- The enemy variety and landscape are beautifully done
- Items, tons of items.....
- Crafting is simple and self-explanatory......

Cons.
- ...but also quite time-consuming
- some items only make sense at second glance
- enemies are very strong at first
- mining resources takes quite a long time at the beginning

Conclusion:
Edge of Space isn't a simple copy of Terraria, but at times it feels like an add-on to Terraria or a part 2. Nevertheless, I have to say I really enjoy the game, perhaps precisely because of that.
So, if you love Terraria and are looking for something similar, Edge of Space might be exactly what you're looking for. Give the game a chance, because EoS deserves it.

PS: The updates come at regular intervals, and the improvements are noticeable (that's not the case with every Early Access game).

Greetings and happy gaming, Sword

column9: I read the comments below... Honestly, the game doesn't live up to Terraria, and it never will, no matter how you look at it. The gameplay itself is different, although similar in many ways. I don't like the crafting system; it's too complicated for a game that looks so simple. Terraria isn't easy either, of course, but at least you quickly figure out what's what. column8:
Updated review from my last one.

In my previous review I stated how bad this game was and how it seemed to be going nowhere. It felt amateurish and pointless. The tutorial was vague and taught very little.

That was at the beginning of the year and I recently reinstalled the game to see what was new and if things have improved. I'd like to talk about these changes after some brief gameplay:

The first impression that I got was that the tutorial is way better. They aren't always necessary for this kind of game, but before I was baffled on how to build things, now I know. Immediately you are given a gun, fairly weak, but it does the trick, whereas before there seemed no way to kill enemies other than using the mining laser on them or the plasma saw or whatever it was.

So what do I think now? Alot better, my hat is off to you guys for improving upon a royal mess. Not perfect, but still not released. At this rate of improvement I am confident, however, that things will get ironed out.

Some minor problems:

For some reason the install for a game of this type and look is enormous. 1.5 gb download and 3gb disc space. Where it all goes, I'm unsure, but as the art seems to be bitmap and bitmap has large file sizes, I'm inclined to think that it is that.

Screen tearing is quite bad.

Bloody snails pushing me around. Probably by design but annoying.

The worlds seem extremely small. Could perhaps do with you being able to go to other planets or at least make the worlds alot bigger.

Overall, my opinion has swayed. I see potential in this game and I am impressed with the improvements. Keep up the good work.

column8:
Dear readers,

I highly recommend this game, for a range of reasons. Perhaps most importantly, it is actually fun to play. I was initially dubious, since I am new to this genre of game, but, at the behest of a friend, I decided to give it a chance. I am very glad that I did, because flying (even for short distances) with a jet pack is all that I hoped it would be. I am still waiting for my real-life jet pack, universe! 

As I have never played this type of game before, it took me longer than the average person (I assume) to get through the tutorial. This was not, however, because the tutorial was not well-structured. In fact, it taught me all the basics I needed to know for this game without much superfluous fluff. I just had trouble with, for instance, remembering that I could jump down platforms. 

In addition, it is clear from the regular patches and updates that the developers are highly invested in making the game-play experience as bug-free and enjoyable as possible. This is the first early access game that I've purchased, and thanks to my positive experience with Edge of Space, I will be taking my chances on other early access games in the future. 

Best,
CV

column8:
This review is based on the December 2014 version of the game.  As it currently stands, it holds alot of promise, but suffers from usability problems.  For example. there is nothing you can do with your old gear - when you make new equipment, you can't salvage or sell your old items that are no longer useful, you have to delete them (or store them if you're a pack rat).  Also, the UI is still pretty rough - some recipe names don't match up to what they create.  This is a problem when you are trying to figure out where the 'crafting bench 1' recipe is, because its actually the 'computerized work bench' recipe.

Overall its decently fun, but the clunkiness of the UI drove me to give up on figuring out what I needed to do next.

column8:
"editierte Version nachdem das Spiel aus der EA Phase raus ist."

Ein Grauenhaftes Spiel aber irgentwie spielt man es dann doch...

Die Ui ist so Attraktiv wie Windows 3.1, beispielsweise sind Dialogfenster einfach nur groÃŸe        Rechtecke hÃ¤tte man einfach schÃ¶ner gestalten kÃ¶nnen aber sie erfÃ¼llt ihren Job.

Das Craften und die Techstufen sind relativ unÃ¼bersichtlich.

Verbot des Jetpacks in Headhunter Dungeon ist ein Krampf, da die Engine nicht drauf ausgelegt ist. Das Springen an SchrÃ¤gen  treibt einen in den Wahnsinn. 

Es gibt nur 3 biome(Startbiome/Dschungel,Arktis,WÃ¼ste) + 4 Dungeons(2normale und 2 Feiertagsdungeon mit towerdefense) + 3 Boss Gegner. 
Ein Teil der Gegner ist einfach nur hÃ¤ÃŸlich, andere haben wiederum ihren Charme. (Headhunter als Negativbeispiel und Pinguine und PolarbÃ¤ren als positives Beispiel)

Dinge die mir gefallen haben waren die Fahrzeuge bzw Reittiere + Npc System.

Fazit wer noch nicht Terraria, Starbound oder Darkout kennt sollte sich lieber diese Titel zulegen bevor er hier zugreift und in den meisten Punkten enttÃ¤uscht wird und wer nicht genug von 2d Crafting Spielen kriegen kann wird diesen Titel ebenfalls in sein Portfolio aufnehmen.

Ein weiteres Manko ist das Charaktermanagement, man muss fÃ¼r jeden Server einen neuen Charakter erstellen, bzw. umstÃ¤ndlich auÃŸerhalb des Spiels Avatardaten mit dem Host austauschen.
Sorry da erwartet man einfach mehr im Jahr 2015.

 Da man schlechte Spiele spielen muss, um die Guten schÃ¤tzen zu lernen ^^
column9:
"Edited version after the game left the EA phase."

A terrible game, but somehow you still play it...

The UI is as attractive as Windows 3.1. For example, the dialog boxes are just large rectangles; they could have been designed more beautifully, but it does the job.

The crafting and tech levels are relatively confusing.

The jetpack ban in Headhunter Dungeon is a pain, as the engine isn't designed for it. Jumping on slopes drives you crazy.

There are only 3 biomes (starting biome/jungle, arctic, desert) + 4 dungeons (2 normal and 2 holiday dungeons with tower defense) + 3 boss enemies.
Some of the enemies are just plain ugly, while others have their charm. (Headhunter as a negative example, and Penguins and Polar Bears as positive examples)

Things I liked were the vehicles and mounts + the NPC system.

In conclusion, anyone who isn't familiar with Terraria, Starbound, or Darkout should get those titles before buying this and being disappointed in most aspects. Anyone who can't get enough of 2D crafting games will also want to add this title to their portfolio.

Another drawback is the character management; you have to create a new character for each server or exchange avatar data with the host outside of the game, which is cumbersome.

Sorry, you just expect more in 2015.

Because you have to play bad games to learn to appreciate the good ones ^^

column8:
tl;dr: Dug up a mushroom, got Uranium; woo! Play this game, it gives Early Access a good reputation.

Every single day, this game becomes more and more appealing to play. balancing, additional content, 
The averaging out of the reviews say the general feeling on this game is mixed, but the top reviews are nearly all absolutely positive, 
Whereas for Starbound, the general feeling is listed as very positive, but the top reviews are nearly all absolutely negative.
Why?
Because a game that was more polished at release with less attention from the developers (Starbound) is just isn't as good as a less polished game with more developer attention (EoS). This is why Edge of Space is in my favourites and Starbound is not.
Yes, this game DOES need more everything: content, detail, variety, bug fixes, polish, et cetera. But in the same volume, it is RECIEVING what it needs! DEVELOPER ATTENTION!! It warms my heart to see devs responding to reviews and comments and implementing changes based on community feedback~!

There are, however a few small issues I can think of which would address immediate issues.
- Some method of pausing the action
- an option to reverse the scroll for the hotbar
- Beautiful as the background music is, possibly a touch more variety would be welcome
- changing the tiles the master cryopod sits on would be fantastic for base decoration.

On a side note, I purchased the standard version of the game, and then later decided to buy the special edition, but none of the special edition content shows up at all. If it hasn't been implemented properly yet, I'm willing to wait, but I just want to ensure that this isn't simply a bug.

Overall, this game truly lives up to what the developers have claimed, and is improving every day. Keep up the good work devs, you love your game and we love you for it!

Edit:
Sadly, this game seems to have stalled. What could have been a very promising game has hit development hell and it does not seem to be changing that anytime soon, being incomplete and still essentially alpha for a full release. Sadly, I must not recommend this game, that held so much potential but now lies abandoned.

column8: This game is completely awesome. Starbound was great for a while, but it will never have the "chase the dragon" addiction this game offers with it's leveling system. If you played Ultima Online, compare it to that with more control. You spend your mined resources on data for certain skills which allow you to build nicer items in that particular field. It seems very class oriented. There's like 13 skills right now as well as 6 stats. 3 armor skills and 3 weapon skills, giving you a fair amount of customization. Your skills allow you to do things like build different vehicles, different accessory buffs, an interesting spin on animal taming where you clone different animals that each have their own separate function, specialize in gathering+passive buffs, similar to UO Alchemy an entire skill dedicated to consumables, and even a cosmetic skill to make your forts look nicer. If these developers know what's good for them, they will continue to add more skills without changing the actual skill system.

column8:
*Early Access Review* *Not final review*
This game is a 2D mining sandbox game, but it's not a generic clone of Terraria, but it does feel like a clone. First off, combat only consists of guns right now, this is quite annoying, but the amount of guns is pretty good. Crafting is very complex, you can substitute some materials for others, but this also makes the crafting system feel slow and clunky, which I hope this is fixed later on. The developers update the game VERY often, and make changes based on community feedback, like an early access game should. I recommend this game based on sheer content alone, but buyers beware, it's early access, there ARE bugs.

column8:
I've put about 13 hours into it at this point, and I'd say that it's definitely worth it at the current sale price.  It's obviously a work in progress so there are things that are in flux and there are tweak issues (finding particular types of elements), and what feels like a memory leak (not confirmed yet...the last hour was getting laggy and warping, but the twelve previous hours ran perfectly).

I admit I was slightly cautious about picking the game up for months because the art seemed a bit "fuzzy" (not as crisp as some of the other similar games), but didn't seem that way when playing...maybe it was an impression I got from early gameplay videos.

Gameplay is close enough to Terraria that you won't be totally lost; though there are a lot more items to craft and there's more of everything.  The variety of weapons and the distinction of the armor, etc, are a plus.

The world is alien and more broken up than Terraria...morea bunch of floating islands, some of which are quite large.  I haven't played it enough to distinguish layers and there is some environmental damage mechanic which resulted in the odd death when going to far down but is still a bit mysterious in its workings.

Monsters and combat are more complex and interesting.  One thing I find interesting is that somethings are neutral under certain conditions and then hostile in others (sleep mode?).  You will often be in a situation where you have to decide how you will engage because indiscriminate shooting may aggro otherwise neutral beasts or plants that will jump in your combat and make your day really bad.

There is a bit of silliness, but so far the majority of the game plays pretty straight...just had the occasional polar bear with jet boots thing but otherwise seems staple scifi.

So yes, I would recommend if you like this type of sandbox game and are willing to do your own research rather than have everything spoonfed in one guide.

<Note:  Reservations below are describing the current gameplay experience I am having.  They are just things to note and may be addressed tommorow for all I know.  On the whole, I am enjoying the game and look forward to seeing it get the polish that will really make it shine.>

My main reservation is that, especially in such a "complex" type game with many concepts and crafting being such a main component, that documentation is sparse.  Of course documentation is one of the last things put in a game but even the community is really light in consolidated guides (at least in English...there are other language guides that may be more fleshed out).  This isn't a reason to not pick up the game but it will get a lot easier to play when you don't need to troll forums for basic game info (ie: what are dungeons, what do you need to go there) or how do you upgrade weapons.

Other more minor reservations include "Hmmm, I build this item and put it in my base...just what does it do again?  Perhaps pop up tooltips for placed crafting stations or maybe an intergrated icon to jog the memory.

Ladders, or other ways to go UP besides jump packs.

Some sort of ablative heat shield/air bag for when you jump into an abyss that is many screens deep.

In the crafting menu, have another grouping "misc" for all items that don't fit under weapons or base items or any of the other crafting subgroupings, so that when you want to craft something you don't need to scroll through the "all" category to find it.

An interface to show you what items you can make in list form all on the screen at once (and the ability to hide items that are outdated).  Sort of a tech tree at a glance.

The ability to choose how long info stays on screen before disappearing, and the ability to configure what is displayed.  IE:  I don't need to know xp as it accrues, but I would like to know when I ding a level in crafting what new recipies I had without looking through the browser.

I assume XP bar fills and you get no more?  If so, maybe some sort of on-screen alert so you know to burn that XP instead of wasting time doing things with a full bar.
column9:
I've put about 13 hours into it at this point, and I'd say that it's definitely worth it at the current sale price.  It's obviously a work in progress so there are things that are in flux and there are tweak issues (finding particular types of elements), and what feels like a memory leak (not confirmed yet...the last hour was getting laggy and warping, but the twelve previous hours ran perfectly).

I admit I was slightly cautious about picking the game up for months because the art seemed a bit "fuzzy" (not as crisp as some of the other similar games), but didn't seem that way when playing...maybe it was an impression I got from early gameplay videos.

Gameplay is close enough to Terraria that you won't be totally lost; though there are a lot more items to craft and there's more of everything.  The variety of weapons and the distinction of the armor, etc, are a plus.

The world is alien and more broken up than Terraria...morea bunch of floating islands, some of which are quite large.  I haven't played it enough to distinguish layers and there is some environmental damage mechanic which resulted in the odd death when going to far down but is still a bit mysterious in its workings.

Monsters and combat are more complex and interesting.  One thing I find interesting is that somethings are neutral under certain conditions and then hostile in others (sleep mode?).  You will often be in a situation where you have to decide how you will engage because indiscriminate shooting may aggro otherwise neutral beasts or plants that will jump in your combat and make your day really bad.

There is a bit of silliness, but so far the majority of the game plays pretty straight...just had the occasional polar bear with jet boots thing but otherwise seems staple scifi.

So yes, I would recommend if you like this type of sandbox game and are willing to do your own research rather than have everything spoonfed in one guide.

column8:
This game has a good chunk of potential. Of course, some stuff could be changed, but overall it has a good plot. It's like Terraria in some ways, aside from the content. (It has Terraria content in it, but that isnt my point.) Terraria and EoS have similarities, and those similarities are:

- 2-D
- Plot (This more relates to Starbound's plot, but its the basic idea.)

Those are the only similarities I can see right now. They have differences; many, as a matter of fact, and some of those differences are:

- EoS has people with longer legs
- EoS has no servers as far as I know of
- EoS involves spaceships

There is one thing I would like to change, although people may disagree with what I want changed, and that's ok, but you may as well continue looking. That one thing I want them to do is:

Reduce complexity; this game is a bit too complex. It has a good plot, and it has a good start, but it's too complex to do. Of course, I only just started this game, but it would help if you made it simpler, and easier for players to grasp control of what they can do.

Overall Rating: 7.5/10 - Acceptable

column8: This is probably a great game
column9: This is probably a great game

column8:
I'll start by saying that this game is fairly fun, but only if you like Terraria and Starbound type gameplay.  The game starts you off in the wilderness wearing some basic light armour, a jetpack, and a rifle in-hand.  Using your laser pick you can mine out the natural resources of the world, and using your rifle you can blast the natural fauna of the world.

At first you only know a handful of recipes, so as you go you will build data disks to unlock more recipes and more data in order to advance even further.  Unlike in say Terraria, you don't know every recipe off the bat, and unlike in say Starbound, you don't have to deconstruct or kill a boss to learn new recipes.

The game seems simple and easy, until you get hit by a random event, in which case you might end up losing all of your clones in a matter of minutes as an unrelenting anomally continually destroys you as soon as you spawn.  For this reason, it's very much recommended to upgrade your gear as soon as you can.  Good luck!

column9: Edge of Space is a continuation of the Terraria concept. In my opinion, the game should be viewed as Terraria in a sci-fi world, and contrary to most reviews, I think the games are very similar. The main problem is the high entry barrier and the virtual lack of information online. While everything about Terraria has already been explained, here you have to figure it out yourself. For example, I spent an hour trying to figure out how to create and remove walls (you have to press tab when a regular block is selected (to place it) or a beam pickaxe (to mine a wall)). Even with Early Access status, the playability is quite decent, but bugs and crashes are now common not only in Early Access. So far, the project has left a positive impression on me, but it's more difficult to understand than Terraria.

column8:
I can't recommend this game to be honest, the game feels very unintuitive and unpolished. Of course it is in early access and various aspects of the game get improved and expanded upon but I bought this game quite a while ago and since then the progress has been rather slow, there are new refinements and added content but it usually ends in a large amount of bugs and other issues.

Overall the game just feels to "raw" and has a lack of progress, there is no sense of progression or much to do. It's pretty bare bones at the moment and needs major work. So please, think twice before buying this game.

On another note, the developers of this game seems extremely unprofessional at times as seen on the forums. Their way of talking to the customers is not acceptable in my opinion, they seem also be rather easy going instead of focusing on it. But don't let this judge your view upon the game.

column8:
Updated February 5th, 2019

Can no longer recommended as the game's been abandoned.

November 28th, 2014

Picked this up during a sale. I own Terraria and Starbound but the latter left me burned with it's launch and follow through by the developers, but this isn't about that.

I'd been interested in Edge of Space for some time and had it on my Wishlist for a couple months before finally picking it up. A quick look through the history of the games shows I missed some of the blunder years the game held and am playing it after a UI and tier revamp so I can't comment on anything prior to the date above.

The game looks good, though I wish there were more customization items for characters, the style they've presented works well and I had no probably playing my marathon session of the game these past 2-3 days (17 hours) and the music is pretty darn good as well. Normally I listen to my own music collection during these types of games but I left the background BGM on and didn't grow to hate it. 

The controls are smooth as well and how you can move is really limited to your gear and how well you can control your jet pack, using weapons can be tricky sometimes however. The game has a few different weapon types in its starter tier from the basic automatic rifle, sniper rifle, and mortar launcher. I've found myself using the sniper rifle and mortar exclusively. You have unlimited ammo but there is a reload timer but that's not why I don't use the automatic, the main reason is damage and difficulty hitting enemies. I played exclusively in a local hosted server with friends and there were times were you can't hit an enemy due to their size, movement, and shots just passing through (most likely due to the server lagging) so we found more success with the area damage of the mortar and taking the risk with the sniper rifle.

Crafting is pretty extensive as well. There are three armor types and many branches of crafting to "skill up" by using Science XP gained from mining, crafting, and hunting monsters (which is the best gainer later on) and unlike Terraria and Starbound the dungeons aren't found in the world but you rather transport to them after gaining enough coordinates to get to them. Once you enter the dungeon the rules change, you can't use your mining laser or jet pack. Having these taken away really changes how you go against an enemy as you now have to time your jumping and can't block or tunnel away from an enemy (or through a stage) and personally I feel is nice change. Unfortunately I haven't seen the dungeon boss yet as during the dungeon we had problems with the game failing to load or players games blanking to grey in the dungeon.

Overall however, I am really pleased with the purchase and look forward to future updates with the game. It does have a learning curve and some of the UI elements are weird (I've hit escape hoping to clear a open menu more times than I can count, it doesn't work) but overall at it's current stage it's fun and playable.

column8:
Below you will find my original review of the game while it was still being worked upon and refined. Here I will tell you not to buy it. 

I have spoken with Lady Aijou the PR assistant for the game and she has left the team upon the "release of the game". The devs instead of working the kinks out released way ahead of reasonable time and ultimatly the game has no support at all at the moment and for the forseeable future. Its sad really because i had a lot of hope for this, the devs put time into the game, crafted it and took suggestions and listened to feedback. I cannot recommend the game now and its a shame :/

In short the game has become abandonware. Hopefully the devs return to fix the mess they left on a decent game. Dont buy this game. Id honestly recommend Starbound or Terraria over them as both are excellent and still being tweaked.



======================================================================


Ok, So I have seen some users complain of the developers abandoning their game, this simply is not true. Now whether this is based upon Starbound (the developers are Chucklefish and have no affiliation with Handyman) it really is unfair to everyone working on Edge of Space.

So, what am i doing with this post? Im going to show you through my own experience and time with the game what it looked like when i started playing around januraryish up to now. Yes there will be two or three videos going to my youtube channel, No you are not asked to subscribe, like, etc this is purely for those that are looking for things that were added to the game and just general gameplay. 

First off, were going to talk about where it was when i started. It was a barren game, not too much content. Few enemies and a fair amount of bugs. The intro screen was also completely different to what you see now. The music however is the same. Below is the first comparison video you dont need to watch much to get the gist. A lot of features are not there, The zoom that we have now, All the enemies you currently see, the headhunter dungeons are not there, the trees are stiff and there are not as many armours, weapons, and in general crafting stuffs as there are now.



YouTubeâ„¢ Video: Edge of Space : Part 1 : Not Terraria but Crabs! 
Views: 5,878
This is Edge of Space, a game related to Terraria by some design only, well, and the fact that the guys at Handyman work closely with the Terraria devs because they are awesome!



Now take that and look at what is now in the game.


YouTubeâ„¢ Video: Huge Update : Edge of Space : Part 11 
Views: 325
So Edge of space got a Huge update and there were a lot of things i couldnt get too that were added in the game, i doubt i can show every tiny thing but i shall be showing every possible thing i can.



YouTubeâ„¢ Video: Assault Bears and Leaf Armor : Edge of Space : Part 12 
Views: 6
Ok, so i finally got to a point to show you guys a bunch of new cool stuff and some stuff i never imagened i could show you! I found an assault bear...a bear with giant guns on it....yea!


What i mentioned earlier is in there, though not in this particular video. There are things however i did not count on ever being in the game such as assault bears (big bears with giant â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ guns that shoot you) Anomalies which are random such as a mob of powerful creatures that will obliterate even the most well trained and armoured ArkCoNaught.

The starting zone is now a much tougher place full of stuff to kill and explore rather than an empty almost lifeless planet. That is not abandoning of a game. So please take this into consideration as well as the fact that the Devs are very active here on the forums, and even on the videos that people upload. They are happy to hear your suggestions and reflect on them and if it be deemed incorperate them into the game in some way. They are doing this to make the best game they possibly can and ill be damned if a few people take it away from them. As from what ive seen, the timely patches and fixes and contet additions Handyman is a very good studio

Keep in mind the game still needs fixing and updating as it is in early access/beta at this moment. I know people are wary of this, but, coming from experince these guys are working hard to bring us a fun game with tons of content and fun ideas. So before bashing and accusing them of stealing our money, at least look into the developers history and into the game itself as well as videos others do of the game to see if infact your bias is justified.
