A lot of features are not there, The zoom that we have now, All the enemies you currently see, the headhunter dungeons are not there, the trees are stiff and there are not as many armours, weapons, and in general crafting stuffs as there are now.



YouTubeâ„¢ Video: Edge of Space : Part 1 : Not Terraria but Crabs! 
Views: 5,878
This is Edge of Space, a game related to Terraria by some design only, well, and the fact that the guys at Handyman work closely with the Terraria devs because they are awesome!



Now take that and look at what is now in the game.


YouTubeâ„¢ Video: Huge Update : Edge of Space : Part 11 
Views: 325
So Edge of space got a Huge update and there were a lot of things i couldnt get too that were added in the game, i doubt i can show every tiny thing but i shall be showing every possible thing i can.



YouTubeâ„¢ Video: Assault Bears and Leaf Armor : Edge of Space : Part 12 
Views: 6
Ok, so i finally got to a point to show you guys a bunch of new cool stuff and some stuff i never imagened i could show you! I found an assault bear...a bear with giant guns on it....yea!


What i mentioned earlier is in there, though not in this particular video. There are things however i did not count on ever being in the game such as assault bears (big bears with giant â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ guns that shoot you) Anomalies which are random such as a mob of powerful creatures that will obliterate even the most well trained and armoured ArkCoNaught.

The starting zone is now a much tougher place full of stuff to kill and explore rather than an empty almost lifeless planet. That is not abandoning of a game. So please take this into consideration as well as the fact that the Devs are very active here on the forums, and even on the videos that people upload. They are happy to hear your suggestions and reflect on them and if it be deemed incorperate them into the game in some way. They are doing this to make the best game they possibly can and ill be damned if a few people take it away from them. As from what ive seen, the timely patches and fixes and contet additions Handyman is a very good studio

Keep in mind the game still needs fixing and updating as it is in early access/beta at this moment. I know people are wary of this, but, coming from experince these guys are working hard to bring us a fun game with tons of content and fun ideas. So before bashing and accusing them of stealing our money, at least look into the developers history and into the game itself as well as videos others do of the game to see if infact your bias is justified.

column8: Edge of Space just does not even come close to being a decent game. In beta for a while now nothing seems different, it feels like someone just ate terraria and starbound and barfed them back up with some crap GI joe action figures they ate as kids. I have tried a few times over the months and I cant see this game becoming an outstanding game. Maybe I will be wrong which I hope I am, because at this point I have paid for something that is just as good to me as a banana peel in the garbage bin. How the terraria guys even let them put some of their content into this game is beyond me its really not that fun. Go get starbound thats in early access and it is a joy to play. This game just does not have what it takes to be an amazing game.

column8: So. I played this game for an hour or so about 6 months ago. Then, in the same day, played some multiplayer. It was then I realized how early the game was in developement still. So we didn't play it for a few months. After giving it a second try. We found out not much had been done. Don't buy this. Its not worth the head ache. The game has the nerve to compare it self to Terraria and offer so, so much less then it. But then want more then Terraria costs. I am a firm believer that early access games are a plague on PC gaming. This experience has confirmed that. Paying for beta? Get that shit out of here.

column8:
Great game in the vein of Terraria or Starbound, but honestly it's quite a lot different. The art style is quite great and the newest update really fleshed this game out and made it a ton of fun. I've had it early access for quite some time now and was a bit afraid when the updates stopped coming, then all of a sudden BAM they put out the king of updates. I cane safely say this game is well worth the price especially if you like metroidvania exploration platformers. The interface takes some getting used to, but works very well once you do get used to it. It actually makes quite a lot of sense for something so far stretched from similar games. 

Really honestly give this a chance, it's got a lot of potential and they are certainly doing their best to make us happy.

column9:
This is a difficult decision to make.
It's a kind of clone that popped up like mushrooms after the Terraria hit, and while the Terraria logo gives it a special feel, it feels completely unrelated in terms of the system.
With StarBound already available, it's hard to compare it to a sci-fi version of Terraria.
The slightly larger characters are nice, but I have some doubts about the system.
The content is hard to compare to Terraria, but I just can't see how well the crafting research system works.
To put it simply, you accumulate experience points to unlock categories of crafting items and get recipes, but unlocking each category makes it hard to understand the breakdown of categories. So I don't know where the facilities and items I want are categorized.
Unlocking them one after the other requires endless digging and defeating small enemies to earn a ton of experience points, which becomes monotonous.
To begin with, there isn't enough content, so the progression itself is a bit monotonous, which makes it feel even more dull.
Even in other Terraria clones, like Darkout, you unlock research all at once by obtaining key materials, and you get excited when you get a new item.
The difficulty of obtaining resources and the number required don't seem right.
The map is a bit novel, with a floating island in the sky like Laputa, or rather a group of giant rocks, but it's narrow on both sides and the starting point is at the top of the map, so you have no choice but to dig down, which makes you feel like "Oh, There's also no "I can just go wherever I want" feeling.
But this game is updated very frequently, and it's been constantly changing and being wiped out, so it feels like it could suddenly become interesting at any moment.
I'm not sure I'd recommend it yet, but I think there's hope.

Addendum
As of v1.04, the shortcomings of the crafting research system I mentioned previously have been largely resolved.
Thanks to this, it's become much easier to play, and you can really feel your progress.
The mobs that appeared in large numbers, were unusually tough and fast from the start, have been improved, reasonably strong weapons have been added, the acquisition rates and amounts of materials that were previously extremely rare have been balanced, and a lot of content has been added.

After all, The developers here seem to love this game, and they update and fix it frequently, which I really appreciate.

However, the progression is still linear (which can be seen as a good thing because it makes things easier to understand, and I think the developers probably prioritize that), and the controls are still incredibly poor.

I think this could be improved by making JetPack (which you can skip from the beginning of the game) the W key, or by changing the laser torch's effect point to a cursor position like StarBound.

Also, it's just not possible to reload a gun without actively firing and auto-reloading (and the reload is incredibly slow).

Other things I've noticed are that the plasma torch's lighting range is too narrow, isn't it? Wouldn't it be better if the inventory was a little bigger? It gets so difficult once you progress a little, and I could go on and on about anything else, but I definitely feel like it's getting better.

I actually like the slightly clunky feel of the graphics, so this is a plus for me.

column8:
This is a review in it's current state.

I understand this game is still in beta, but in it's current state I'm not a fan. I definitely see the potential of this game and can forsee it being a really fun and addictive game like Terraria. Right now it's just frustrating. Especially since this game has been out in beta for over a year and the feel hasn't changed. It's sad when 3 of my friends and I can't stand to play this more than an hour every 3-4 months we try it.

Many items that you find early in game have absolutely 0 use or in the item details it shows "Will be updated in the future" or some nonsense. The inventory feels clunky and can be buggy when swapping things in and out of your actionbars.

For those of you who played Terraria, if you enjoyed the helper dude being there to somewhat guide you in the right direction you're going to have a harder time. The beginning gives you a brief sense of direction but then it's gone. To understand what a lot of things do, you must either spend lots of time trying to figure it out on your own or look it up on the wiki.

While I feel games do need to have a little but of challenge in them, I'm not sure the start of this game goes in the right direction with that. Your mining tool is painfully slow. Your starting weapon is painfully weak. Materials needed to upgrade anything are way high. You also have lives in this game. So as you're digging down trying to find some sort of material you need to make an item you have no clue what it does, you come across some crabs that take 15 shots to kill with your weak gun and they kill you. You've spent 20 minutes digging, lost a life, and still have 0 of the material you need.

The soundtrack is nice. Which is one thing I expected after playing Terraria and Starbound. Visuals look good for the most part. The gameplay just has a long way to go until I feel it will be fun.

If you want a new Terraria style game, go pick up starbound instead. You'll be completely satisfied! Maybe in another year I can say the same about this.
column9:
This is a review in it's current state.

I understand this game is still in beta, but in it's current state I'm not a fan. I definitely see the potential of this game and can forsee it being a really fun and addictive game like Terraria. Right now it's just frustrating. Especially since this game has been out in beta for over a year and the feel hasn't changed. It's sad when 3 of my friends and I can't stand to play this more than an hour every 3-4 months we try it.

Many items that you find early in game have absolutely 0 use or in the item details it shows "Will be updated in the future" or some nonsense. The inventory feels clunky and can be buggy when swapping things in and out of your actionbars.

For those of you who played Terraria, if you enjoyed the helper dude being there to somewhat guide you in the right direction you're going to have a harder time. The beginning gives you a brief sense of direction but then it's gone. To understand what a lot of things do, you must either spend lots of time trying to figure it out on your own or look it up on the wiki.

While I feel games do need to have a little but of challenge in them, I'm not sure the start of this game goes in the right direction with that. Your mining tool is painfully slow. Your starting weapon is painfully weak. Materials needed to upgrade anything are way high. You also have lives in this game. So as you're digging down trying to find some sort of material you need to make an item you have no clue what it does, you come across some crabs that take 15 shots to kill with your weak gun and they kill you. You've spent 20 minutes digging, lost a life, and still have 0 of the material you need.

The soundtrack is nice. Which is one thing I expected after playing Terraria and Starbound. Visuals look good for the most part. The gameplay just has a long way to go until I feel it will be fun.

If you want a new Terraria style game, go pick up starbound instead. You'll be completely satisfied! Maybe in another year I can say the same about this.

It just isn't a very well made game with a confusing overall game play. Even if it gets updated into a good game, I still am not going to come back to this game. I only recommend buying it with caution. 

              The overall rating I give this game is a 5.

column9:
I bought EoS at the end of July. I played for a couple of hours and then gave up â€“ it didn't grab me at all.
A month later, I noticed that the game was being updated almost every week. I got interested, played for a few more hours, and was surprised by how much had changed and suddenly felt somewhat playable.
On November 20th, a fairly major update was released â€“ the leveling system was completely overhauled, along with many other things. And then I realized I was finally hooked =)

Yes, a lot hasn't been finalized yet. Yes, there are still some bugs. It's a beta test, after all.
I still recommend it because I'm impressed by the speed of development: minor updates almost every week, major ones about once a month.
At this rate, EoS has every chance of approaching Terraria's playability in a year... maybe we'll see.
I don't regret the money I spent on the sale anymore â€“ that's probably the most important thing =)

column8:
Update: 7/16/2019: Game is dead, developers have abandon it. DO NOT BUY

Updated Review (10/10/16): I tried to give it a chance. The only discernible difference from when I reviewed this game until now is there is just a lot more clutter on the planets. It's just not a good game and from what I can see the dev's have largely abandoned it. RIP

Not worth it in it's current state. This was my first "early access" game before I even know what EA was, I unfortunately fell for the trap of some cool trailers and the incorporation of some Terraria elements, making me hope this was a Sci-Fi terraria. 

While the fundamentals are the same (a 2d minecraft), the execution is just not even close and the polish of the current state of the game is going to make me wait unto 1.0 release. Upon character creation and the 10+ minute load time (I timed it once) you're forced without choice to go through a tutorial which is extremely frustrating after a character whipe. It lays out the very basics which you then shortly forget and feel very lost in the coming gameplay moments. 

Building and equipment progression seems confusing and not very straight forward, it's difficult figuring out where to get some of the less common materials without just randomly digging and hoping to hit a vein and what exactly you should be building next. Unless they aren't implemented yet, the distinct biomes are non existent. I walked a bit away from my spawn point and jumped down a few ledges and started taking environmental damage. I presume this is a barrier to prevent you from digging a hole straight down (a-la terraria) and gathering the best materials within minutes of starting a new game. 

I'll update when the retail version is released but at this time I won't be spending anymore time with this game.

column8:
Love this art style for sure and how helpful and friendly the dev team is. I play this game solo and really don't have any plans to play MP. 

I do enjoy the idea that all the fighting (for now) is with guns rather than melee. It is hard to get used to because enemies are smaller and fast but you get better over time. 

The game itself has just had a UI overhaul and progression is being changed up right now. I have no fear that this game will turn out to be bad in any way. The team listens to us and makes great decisions on their own as well. 

I have been part of some rough early access games (Warz :( , The Stomping Land :((  and Starbound :-\ ) so I have had my share of ups and downs. Edge of Space has kept me even, while I want the game to be done I am not demanding them. I know they are working on everything and it will be great no matter what. 

I originally came to this game because Starbound was updated and it killed a connection to a mod that made the game fun. (survivalist mod) Obviously starbound is so easy, no challenge at all. This game is actually much harder and makes you feel the need to be careful and play safe at times. 
Give Edge of Space a try some time or just keep it in mind and watch for updates!

column8:
Edit years down : Changed to negative. No updates in years and game was abandoned after an extremely early "release".

Edit for 1.0 release : Been super hyped for this and now that it's actually out, it didn't disappoint.

Tldr; Buy the game. Best case scenario you love it and have a new game to play. Worst case scenario, you find out it's not for you and you can just get a refund.

Pros : 
Toooooooooons of content
A much needed optimization (went from 25-30 to 60fps)
Easy to set up multiplayer as long as you know what you're doing
3 seperate tech trees for armor and 3 seperate tech trees for guns as well as a tech tree for melee.
Every tech tree has 15 layers/ranks
Armor looks unique and pretty
Introduction of nests that can be taken over (nice challenge at the start of the game)
3 bosses already in the game with more planned for the future
Sound effects sound great, especially for the weapons
Overhaul of world generation. No longer are titanium, ice, and other ores rare in the first phase of the game. 
Game promotes a natural progresion in that exploring, digging, and fighting will all give you exp you can put towards tech 
I really really like this soundtrack (thanks, Lori)
Different types of weapons feel different. Phase are weak but infinite weapons, projectile are strong but very limited, and energy are strong but require you to decide between using them or using your jetpack since they both use the same energy.
Wide range of enemies and great for people who like making very technical bases (with logic gates implemented and an easy to use power system)
Funny loading screens to help pass the tedious but necessary parts of every game

Cons :
Weapons are a little hard to get used to and are sometimes hit and miss. Like with any game release, it has its fair share of bugs
After the tutorial with Fineous, it's kinda hard to know what to do next
Over abuncdence of snails and frogs can get annoying.

Game doesn't feel as grindy as other people make it out to be. I don't find it to be too gindy since there's always a lot of things to do.


Finished playing Terraria with a friend and needed a similar game to play. With Gaben's infinite knowledge, steam recommended this game. After looking around and reading reviews for a few days I can honestly say I do not regret buying this a bit. Game felt grindy but with the new system being implemented, that's going to change completely. The devs are active and actually pay attention to people's positive AND negative reviews and react positively to both (Unlike starbound...). The reviews on the developers played a huge part in my purchase and I'll be buying a copy for my friend in the near future (aka the steam sale). Couldn't recommend enough.

column9:
[This is an old review for the old version. I haven't played the new one yet.]
I was hooked on the well-known name of Terraria and bought it. Now I can't stop wondering what else I could have spent that money on.

The game has a good concept, proven by others. Dig, build, craft, fight, but somehow it doesn't grab my attention. Updates come out frequently, but it doesn't improve. The fact is, no matter how hard I try, Edge of Space is simply not comfortable to play.
- The art is jarring, even though the animation is good.
- There are ranged weapons, but enemies don't react to hits.
- There are caves and tunnels, but it's hard to find anything other than death in them; the game is stingy with resources.
- Not all crafting is available from the start; you need to earn special upgrades to unlock new recipes.
- The interface is poorly designed and hasn't been fixed yet. It's glued to the screen, each window opens with a separate button and can only be closed with it. Pressing esc pauses the game but doesn't remove the windows. You can select items on the hotbar using the numbers, not the mouse wheel, and I'm not sure the hotbar buttons can be remapped. Items can only be used from the hotbar; if you find a recipe, you first have to insert it, then select and use it.
- There's a jetpack in the game, but it takes off reluctantly, as if the gravity on a planet is under 5G, even though the character can jump quite high.
- The world is randomly generated, but it's very monotonous and awkward. There are tons of islands that drop off, and it's unclear whether there's land below or how far it's going to fall.
- There's no map, so it's unclear how to navigate.
Conclusion: the developers came up with an interesting game and did everything they could to make you not want to play it. Not to mention that it's a carbon copy of Starbound, which is much more convenient, larger, and prettier.

column8: This review will only be a short one becasue I dont have much to say about it and I would only be repeating myself. Edge of Space is a Retro Sci-Fi which is about exploring and seeing diffrent things. This sounds great but it quickly gets dull. After the tutorial it seems that most of the fun is gone. There just isnt much to do. I know people are going to say its an Early Access game but that does not change everything. It improves on what it has. So far I would nit recommend this game so far. If you wanted a better game that is simular get Starbound or Terraria. The only good things I can think of are that the art style looks great and the controls are good, the music fits the world that you play in but thats about it. I am going to rate it a 4 out of 10. column8:
What can I say... I bought this with a hope of having a experience similar to Terraria, 
since they were in parcery with Re-logic and hadding Terraria based content.

But I only got disappointement!
The menu with your items is confusing! In the start, once you get in the planet It's very difficult to stay alive, mostly cause of weakass weapons, and the mining takes too much time for the same reason! 
Both tools and weapons are poor in perfomance!

But I didn't judge like that cause in the future you would take better stuff... right?
Nope! To upgrade anything, It takes amounts of various materials, not to mention:
-the time to mine them (is slow)
-search for them (too much time)
-you have to walk FAR to find more, go into holes and a maze of caverns, making you lost from your outpost.
-limited area (that radiation thing that kills you when you go too much down)
-enemies stronger than you (and weak weapon)

And if you fail for the first time, you will notice you actually got lives!
YEAH! LIVES! Who puts lives on a game based of Terraria?!
But you can make more "lives", but you will have to decide on what to do next! 
Spend your materials in making lives and search materials so you can upgrade your weapons, armor and tools, but you will end up lost, surrounded by enemies, and you will eventually will die. Then, you must do more "lives" so you don't lose your progress!
Repeat this times and times! That was my game! A vicious cycle of losing, nerves, and boredom...

I don't recommend this game...
Play Terraria instead... they never disappointed (at least me) with their updates and content...

column8:
Edge of Space needs significant improvement before I would recommend that anyone purchase it. The controls are nonintuitive, the interface feels too small and crowded, and currently the game feels like a bad Terraria clone. Your money would be better spent on Starbound if you're interested in this theme.

EDIT: Just went back and played through the tutorial after several months. Everything looks and feels the same. The game is as cumbersome as ever and I did not enjoy trying to get started playing. Once you leave the tutorial level, it is unclear what you're objective within the game is. I had heard mention of UI improvements, but to me, everything looks exactly the same. 

I don't know if I'm supposed to play this game with a wiki page open, telling me step by step how to play it all the way through or not. I will admit that Terraria and Starbound have you basically playing with the wiki open as well, but Edge of Space seems to offer very little encouragement when you actually get into the game. Upon exiting the tutorial I was beamed down to the surface of what I assume was a planet, and immediately attacked by floating jellyfish who took a frustrating amount of time to kill. I was given no actual objective, only tossed forward into this environment with very little explaination.

Bottom line: I would not recommend edge of space to anyone. I bought the 4-pack when it went on sale and after playing the game informed my friends that they should not waste any bandwith or hardrive space on it. This game has EXTREMELY cumbersome controls (double tap 'x' to pick up a torch? Really?), lacks visual pop, and has poorly designed UI. Do not purchase this game. Go get Starbound. Some have said that Starbound is a glitchy, dead project. This is untrue. The game is very entertaining with a few friend and totally worth your time.

I understand that this game is still in early access but it needs so much more work before anyone should play it. I've owned it for a long time and am still waiting for any significant progress to take place.

column8:
So far i cannot reccomend this game. 

Pros:
- controls feel nice
- art style is nice
- flying fox that holds a lamp. pretty cool.

Cons:
- Game atmosphere isnt their
- music is average
- sounds are poor
- Little direction to what to do. Yes i know you can explore and mine, but i mined stuff and explored several cave's and only encountered crabs and jelly fish, neither offering any chance of a worthwhile reward for my discovery/victory.

As it is, i feel i wasted my money and i should have read my reviews prior to my purchase. Comparing this game to something like terraria or starbound cannot be done because they properly immerse the player into the game and make you feel at home with the great sounds/music. 

The game however is being updated frequently which is really nice so if any descent patches come out after my review, you may be able to ignore my review all together, as i too hope to see this game become something awesome.

column9:
The guys are late with their creation. Since it's a flat platformer, they should have released it in a decent form before Starbound. Basically, that's what they did. They made a killing in that gap and apparently decided to slow down all development.
This product is not recommended for purchase, even for fans of the genre.

The main drawbacks include:
1) The terrible color combinations across all levels and planes. It's a headache for some, and a pain for others.
2) The interface and gameplay are unnecessarily complicated.
3) Lack of sufficient in-game content.

It's unlikely that this product will ever become playable.

column8:
I have mixed feelings. I can tell its good and it has tons of potential but has allot of room for improvement. I'm a big fan of Terraria and can see the relationship but well everething seems alien to me hehe.... the crafting system is kinda confusing.. Clearly the simplicity of terraria is  gone. this brings up a question as to whether intuition will work for humans in other life inhabiting planets cause this game certainly does not think so...  the starting area is so hard! 

 I havent been able to properly host a server yet, neither has my friend ..... yes we have looked up instructions... all of them.... nothing helps... we are not cutout to be networking savy people... I'm really hoping that they do somthing to make it eassy for us common folk. 


I am recomending it because of its potetial and need for support. the more feed back the better right?

Cons
-interface locks up and cant recover unless rebooting the game
-server instability
-no control option
-no in-game configurations


Pros
-Looks good
-weapons feel right for the theme of the game
-fighting monster is very enjoyable
-kind of gives a Super Metroid vibe

This is my review as of today and as you can see I didn't play a lot. Why cause there are issues that were very visible.  I can see that the game has a lot of potential but I'll recommend that you save your money and wait for more updates.

column8:
I have played over 200 hours of terraria.
so i know what i'm doing in these kind of games.
-----------------
I hope that the game is still under development, it could become great.
Right now the start of the game feels very slow and repetitive. I have been playing for 4 hours now and i do not have the feeling that i accomplished something.

EDIT:
24-4-2015
The game has been improved, it feels a lot more playable in terms of actually being fun. The start of the game is much faster now, thanks to the fact you can collect ores much quicker both through mining and killing certain creatures. The inventory system has been slightly improved, you can actually make multiple items at once now! Progress has been made and its getting better! Keep it up!

column8:
Good game for early access. runs smoothly at 50-60 frames a second on my decent lap top, however there is a lack of things to build and craft, and from my knowledge there is only 2 enemies at the moment. (one of which doesnt even deal damage) there is always fun in exploring and getting meterials and i think this game will definetly be something great when it is fully released, however there are definete comparisons to Terraria and Starbound. however i do not think this game will ever surpass terraria, it is still a good game and great for all those fans of Terraria to see their favorite armors and bosses carried through to this game, its good to try but i would maybe recommend holding off until more content is released, but if your excited to see what its all about then i prompt you to try it, thanks. (story is unfinished at this time as well)
6/10

column8:
I came to Edge of Space expecting a lot, having heard so much about it in relation to Terraria and Starbound.  I suppose that was a mistake on my part, and I'll admit as much.

As such, I tried my best to look beyond the horrifically clunky and unhelpful user interface, the occasionally slightly janky graphics and the various spelling mistakes, grammatical errors and so forth...  And, for a while, I did.

Unfortunately, what lay underneath wasn't all that great.  Yes, being able to "fudge" resources and use one thing in place of another is nice, but you can't combine two different types and the drop-down list bugs out if you have too many candidates.

But then we get to the matter of the actual tech tree and what you're building with all this space junk...   The game praises its "unique, Borderlands-style procedurally generated weapons", but all this means is that rock gun 1 may have +2 minimum damage and +1 clip size, while rock gun 2 has considerably less of either but 15 more accuracy (note, I have yet to discover what, if any, effect "accuracy" actually has on anything.  It certainly doesn't do anything with the projectile spread) and a different abstract "quaility" [sic] rating.  And between the three first tiers of weapons, with a really vast difference in required resources, there was only a tiny upgrade in regards to damage and clip size.  All other stats were pretty much the same, and they all looked like so much jumbled bulk.

There's no smooth progression, as all tech is unlocked by picking up and consuming data bricks that get dropped randomly by enemies.  Yup, you're gonna have to shoot a LOT of electric jellyfish before you can build that kitchen counter you always wanted.  You'll also need to do a spitload of grinding to get all the metals you need for anything beyond just dirt guns and mud armor, because ore veins are very rare and often stupefyingly dangerous to go near.

Speaking of danger, this game incorporates a life system.  It's not game over once you reach 0, but if you die after that all the items in your tragically small inventory will get expunged onto the surrounding terrain.

This game is early access, VERY early.  It's fully possible it will shape up in time, but right now it's clunky, incredibly grindy and half the items in the tech tree are obscenely expensive and serve no purpose.  In closing, I figured out how to infinitely duplicate any resource in the game before I managed to work out how to split a stack in two.  Wouldn't recommend in its current state.

column8: This game reminds me on Terraria, really fun game. If you have Terraria, you should buy this to :)

This game has come a long way. I bought in on a whim in my early terraira burn-out phase. Wasn't much then, but the developers have been working hard to improve the game and it shows. Countless patches later this game could launch today and it would get solid reviews. I recommend this one to anyone with a love for rouge likes and has a taste for the sci-fi our fathers used to enjoy. Outside of that, this is at it's core a mining/crafting game. Nothing special to remark outside of differences from other games in genre. Overall not bad compared to other offerings either when it comes to controls, content and depth. Sure, it's not on the same scale as Starbound, and nothing is as polished as terraira, but this game has character and immersion. The rough edges of this work in progress are limited to a lack  of good interface and general tutorials that leave much to be desired. I haven't truly logged enough hours to speak about end game, but I want you to know that I havent regret my purchase since day one (well over a year before this review). Check it out, I think you'll probably end up feeling the same.

(Additional Edit: 4/26/15)
I just wanted to update my review based on the current state of the game. I noticed recently that this game was at a "Mixed" review status. Please, if you are like me and weary of seeing such things before you purchase, give each and every negative review a read to make sure. This game is a work in progress. It should go without saying, but this is going to have bugs. It's going to have wipes. They are going to release patches that break, change, or completely destroy previous things. Accept it or dont buy early access titles. For what its worth; I still give this game the "safe to buy in" approval. It's a little clunky here and there, but they have really done SO much to improve the game. Its got everything one would expect from a game of this genre. If you're a fan of SciFi and Crafting/Rouge-likes, you would be doing yourself a disservice to not take the dive on this one. Its a solid game already and the Developers are VERY attentive and constantly updating. Don't let the mixed review status turn you off. From what I have read, there is alot of nit picking over what is a really early access title that, even after two years, is STILL being worked on constantly. Jump in, help out with the progress of this game, and enjoy the glorious Science!

column8:
I want to like this game, but the controls are so hilariously bass akwards that you cannot even accomplish the simplist of tasks without massive frustration. Odd that they felt the need to re-envent something that everyone was just fine with. Keep it simple, stupids. 

Dev's, I (and many, many like me) have dozens and dozens of unplayed games. Messing with the controls like this is an instant turn off in an age when we're over exposed to cheap entertainment. Put your efforts into other forms of individuality. 

I'll keep an eye on this an update if necessary.

This game has been a great experience, it seems quite complex at first because it has a somewhat lack of tutorial and guide on how to start out but figuring it out was half the fun. I can tell I will be sapping fun out of this game for a while since there's so much content to explore and it's really tricky getting ores.. .-. But eventually I'll probably find an easier way to do it.

I would recommend this game to anyone who likes to explore but yet build structures that link with eachother in complex ways as well as some simple functions that aren't complex.

column8:
"Edge of Space" is a construction/adventure game in the vein of Terraria, only in space!  It's a very simple premise, but somehow, as of this writing, the game doesn't quite deliver on either its potential or the intellectual legacy of Terraria, which great effort is put into establishing.

The first thing to realize about this game is that there are some really cool ideas!  You've got a laser drill, and you start with projectile weapons!.  The graphics are a miss for me (I'll get into why later), but are certainly more detailed than Terraria's, and may not be as offensive to another gamer's eye.

(The following edited as of 21 May 2015...)

The game has vastly improved since my playthrough last year!  The general user experience is far less irritating than it was, and actually warrants my giving this game a chance now.

[b]What Works[/b]
The game's crafting system is awesome.  Pretty much, the game is already similar to the "Terraria Leveled" mod in some ways mechanically, but the research lines are well-defined, and the experience amounts required to unlock a tier feel correct.  What's more the amount of things you can craft without a crafting station is great for upgrading your field arsenal (from what I've seen so far.)

They fixed the guns to always hit.  This was [i]the[/i] dealbreaker for me before.  Thank you.  Note to other game developers: in an action game, RNG-based miss mechanics are [b]very very bad[/b].  What's more the base tier of stuff after completing the tutorial is [i]actually useful[/i], which is nice!

Speaking of the tutorial, it appears simplified from the version I played earlier, and is effective at basically teaching the game.  Less was indeed more!

You can rebind keys.  This helps to mitigate some of the confusing keybindings in this game, and let you play Your Wayâ„¢.

[b]What Doesn't Work[/b]
First, you still spawn on a sky island instead of the planet's surface.  I think this is a mistake, even with jetpacks being available immediately, because jumping into a void beneath your little sky island is too much of an early risk, that I don't think a new player wants to take - at this point, we're still getting a feel for the game and the world.

Second - re-evaluate your default key bindings.  V for crafting and C for character are really counterintuitive to me.  While providing rebindable keys is nice, nailing a good preset will help this game immensely.  It was irritating to have to click the menu button every time I wanted to craft something, until I found the hotkey.

Speaking of crafting, the way you spend XP feels [i]incredibly[/i] clunky, and the increment/decrement textfield used to implement it clashes with everything else.  Since the upgrades are straight lines, not trees, why not just allow me to click an upgrade or a button on the upgrade in order to "buy" it with the XP?

The visual style to me is hit or miss, but this gets into personal preference; if Terraria is a Saturday-morning cartoon, then this is [i]Archer[/i] on Adult Swim, which is what I think they're going for.  This point may or may not be a sticking point for you; this "Doesn't Work" bit is purely subjective.  Some sprite mods or the ability to create sprite/tile image mods might be a good idea, though.

[b]The (New) TL;DR[/b]
Once, I did not recommend this game; it wasn't ready for the public.  Luckily a few patches seem to have come and gone to help resolve that situation.  The developers need to study up on good User Experience (UX) quite a bit more, and take it as a lesson learned going forward - UX seems to be one of their weaknesses that they have to fight against.  However, the interesting ideas in this game seem significantly closer to fruition.

I recommend watching this title more closely...

column8:
***I will retain the original review here, but I will add and mark new points. If  you want my most up-to-date review, scroll down.***

I'm going to be completely honest; there's a lot of potential here and I hope it reaches it, but so far I'm just not seeing it. I'm trying not to be too harsh, I respect the dev team and their game, but here are my impressions...

    The first thing that comes to mind with this game is; There's alpha games, and then there's ALPHA games. While I play a lot of games in alpha and beta stages, I usually enjoy the experience because they often bring something new and innovative to the table to make them interesting. Sadly, I'm just not seeing it with the alpha of this game. There's little that I would consider standout, innovate, or unique. The mining lazer is cool, but not groundbreaking, and mindnumbingly slow without any upgrades in sight. At the very least, it should have the option to heat the targeted rock and at least one sqaure of the rocks around it at a slower rate. This would speed up the process while still allowing precision. Jetpacks are cool, but the limited energy and energy regen followed by blind jumps makes them more frustrating than anything. If nothing else, the early jetpacks could use a massive buff until more is added and that situation is sorted out strictly for exploration purposes. Beyond those two features, the game doesn't have much to offer.

    My next gripe is the actual game's goal and layout. The game gives you the goal of terraforming, and that's about it. I really didn't like that goal. I don't feel like it's a goal at all. Terraforming is just something you DO in this kind of game from start to finish. I don't feel like something I'm going to be doing anyways -and can do at any point- should be my final goal. It gives little to work towards other than "look I mined out this rock lol." If my goal is to terraform, than I want to be given a final idea of what I'm terraforming towards, rather than just changing the landscape slowly. Which brings me to my other argument; the real "goal" players give themselves is simply going downwards. I feel like the only way to progress is to mine resources and then continue falling downwards in hopes of new discoveries. There's also multiple levels as you fall downwards, resulting in higher risk areas. This is great and all but then why terraform anything on the top levels if the better resources and more interesting stuff is downwards? Why even set your roots and your house at the top just to work your way back down and farther again? I'm not trying to be harsh, I just think some good thought has to be put into these concepts before the game moves forward and falls flat on its face.

    I'm hoping that my investment, and the investments of everyone else gets put to good use here. I think somewhere in this alpha is a great game, but right now it's barely in a playable stage. It's just very unsinspiring when compared to the games everyone, myself included, will immediately pin it to- being Terraria and Starbound. Both of those games have unique and recognizeable art, music, gameplay, and attitude. Even the art in Edge of Space feels cluttered and weird and just like it needs to have its own personality to it. I will say that I love the music at the opening menu though. 

    Closing thoughts; I don't regret supporting this game and I hope it continues getting support so that it can become a full-fledged competitor with other similar games, and hold a meaningful spot in a steam library. That said, until the game brings proof that it's serious and has something to prove to the gaming world, I wouldn't recommend putting coin into it to have it gather dust in your steam library.


*** As of Jan. 30th, a few months after original review

    Well I'm not entirely sure I can list everything they did, but the devs are pulling through on this one. With some UI overhauls, and massive variable tweaks, even the initial few minutes feel much more active and fluid than before. The progress curve is much more obvious right now and you have to work towards your progress points individually. Exploration is a bit easier now as jetpacks have recieved decent buffs, nulling my earlier complaint about them. Also mining has been considerably buffed, with an early "overcharged" mining lazer now available that damages at least 2 layers of blocks at a time. So my mining complaint is decently nulled. There's a bunch of other tweaks/buffs that improve fluidity of gameplay including changes to weapons, monster health, so on so on.

    My initial impression before was that the game was an unplayable wreck and I was a bit disappointed in it. Right now my impression is that I can really start to get into this game. Although I feel it's a bit lacking in overall content right now, yaddayadda it's an alpha, we've been here before. It could just use a bit more... Variation? Maybe just several different sprites for the wildlife or something. The sights get a bit repetitive at the start. I haven't moved too far in yet as there is quite a lot of grinding involved now. 

    All-in-all I'm refraining from saying I recommend this game just yet. While it has shown significant improvement and I feel like the devs have listened to complaints and worked to better the game, I'm still not ready to recommend this game. I'm going to see if the devs are still dedicated to improving the game and adding content, and if they seem committed and the game starts to come together I will change it to recommended in a heartbeat.

column8:
You've just crashed on a planet. All you've got is some utilities from your ship you were able to grab. You can mine, you can build, and you can craft. What will you do to survive? 

[b](tl;dr at bottom)[/b]

If you're a fan of Terraria, but want something a little more bizarre, and more focused on space, this is definitely your game. Don't see it as Terraria or Minecraft knock-off, though. This game is one of the most unique games of this type that I've seen. Most notably, the crafting system. The way this game's crafting system works is just fantastic. Rather than picking around for specific blocks, you are able to craft things by finding blocks to fit the requirements for density, permiability, and other criteria for creating an object. There is more to this, but I'd rather let you find that out for yourself, as there are many machines in this game that would take a while to fully explain. 

As you can see the graphics in the screenshots, and audio in the trailers, I'm not really going to dive that deep into them. The only thing I'd like to note is character creation. There is at least a moderate amount of customization for your character off the bat, and even more when you consider vanity and armor further in the game, so if that's the type of thing you're into, consider it another plus. 

This game isn't completely great though, and I won't be able to stress enough that this game is EARLY ACCESS, and that's what you're paying for. A lot of it isn't done. There are bugs and glitches (though not really anything that will ruin the experience). 

[b]tl;dr[/b]

[u]Pros:[/u]
+ Crafting system
+ Plenty of other machines to play around with
+ Block variety (there are vending machines, TVs, etc that you can craft)
+ Customization
+ Boss fights
+ Misc. world events (worm holes and such will crop up here and there)
+ Concept (the idea is cool)
+ Playtime (lots of playtime in this, even at this stage)

[u]Cons:[/u]
- Graphics (while the graphics aren't bad, you could get sick from watching the world backdrop)
- Not finished (bugs - bugs everywhere)
- Emphasis on not finished (not that much content)

I'll expand this review if anyone actually reads it, or has any questions.

column8:
While I do not reccomend getting this game at this particular moment, I do reccommend the game for near future. I came over from Terraria, expecting a similar game, but Edge of Space isn't another Terraria. While some core features remain the same, the game styles are very different. I am very fond of the developing team, and I think they're amazing so far. Their updates go as scheduled, and if there's a bug or a problem, they address the issue right away.

I have really high hopes for this game, and I believe it has a lot of potential. I really look forward to seeing this game out of early access.

column8:
Don't get me wrong the game is solid already,  but even at this point early access,  the base game just doesn't feel very involving.  You start out in a game with a spawn point and are given lots of blueprints to activate then craft.  Where I get pretty annoyed and usually give up is the whole downward scrolling aspect of the game.  To reach the first 'layer' of a surface, you need to drop down,  which requires building stairs back up to the initial block of dirt you spawn in to presumably build your starting base.   

Getting back to the whole verticle scrolling aspect of the game.  Going up and and down all the time requires building lots of stairs and frequent use of your jetpack.  The problem is, it recharges extremely slowly,  resulting in a lot of time just waiting to use it.   Lighting is also trickier than in other survival games:  there's a few flareguns and torches to be placed,  but they all require using the crafting menu,  which is tedious. For example, to craft an item you need to select the materials you want to use first,  sometimes there's a huge list of materials you need and if you are missing one, you'll have to re-select all of them again if you want to try and craft again.   A lot of the time you'll find yourself in the dark trying to climb out of a pit of some sort, and hope you don't accidently fall further downwards to certain doom.

Speaking of tedious,  everything just feels tedious to me about the game.  Mining is about as exciting as watching blocks smoke from heat before turning into collectable ores.  Crafting requires dragging a blueprint to your inventory slots, selecting the slot,  holding left click to activate the blueprint,  then right clicking the inventory slot to remove the blueprint.  This is just a typical example of how something is done in this game and honestly I don't feel like any of it is as intuitive as it should be.   

Combat is also pretty sleepy.  You shoot enemies,  and they die.  There's no real weight to the combat and it's just not very gratifying.  

Overall tho, the game does feel solid as I say.  Personally I just fall asleep trying to figure something out,  but that's just me.  Many will find the game appealing because there is much to do and there's a lot of content,  so if the aforementioned things don't bug you, feel free to dive in.
column9:
Don't get me wrong the game is solid already,  but even at this point early access,  the base game just doesn't feel very involving.  You start out in a game with a spawn point and are given lots of blueprints to activate then craft.  Where I get pretty annoyed and usually give up is the whole downward scrolling aspect of the game.  To reach the first 'layer' of a surface, you need to drop down,  which requires building stairs back up to the initial block of dirt you spawn in to presumably build your starting base.   

Getting back to the whole verticle scrolling aspect of the game.  Going up and and down all the time requires building lots of stairs and frequent use of your jetpack.  The problem is, it recharges extremely slowly,  resulting in a lot of time just waiting to use it.   Lighting is also trickier than in other survival games:  there's a few flareguns and torches to be placed,  but they all require using the crafting menu,  which is tedious. For example, to craft an item you need to select the materials you want to use first,  sometimes there's a huge list of materials you need and if you are missing one, you'll have to re-select all of them again if you want to try and craft again.   A lot of the time you'll find yourself in the dark trying to climb out of a pit of some sort, and hope you don't accidently fall further downwards to certain doom.

Speaking of tedious,  everything just feels tedious to me about the game.  Mining is about as exciting as watching blocks smoke from heat before turning into collectable ores.  Crafting requires dragging a blueprint to your inventory slots, selecting the slot,  holding left click to activate the blueprint,  then right clicking the inventory slot to remove the blueprint.  This is just a typical example of how something is done in this game and honestly I don't feel like any of it is as intuitive as it should be.   

Combat is also pretty sleepy.  You shoot enemies,  and they die.  There's no real weight to the combat and it's just not very gratifying.  

Overall tho, the game does feel solid as I say.  Personally I just fall asleep trying to figure something out,  but that's just me.  Many will find the game appealing because there is much to do and there's a lot of content,  so if the aforementioned things don't bug you, feel free to dive in.

column8:
Note: This review is only for the game as of 8/2/2014

The big drawback for this game is the user interface (which is so bad that I gave up after less than an hour, hence the lack of play time). At its current condition, the UI is far too complex and spread out to be used effectively. There's something like 5-10 different 'windows' that you can bring up, each with their own UI's and submenus, all of which the player must navigate in order to effectively play the game. Did I mention that the windows can only be brought up by hotkey, and have no onscreen hint as to which hotkey brings up what?

Compare this to similiar games such as Starbound,  Terraria and Minecraft, which are far more streamlined in terms of UI. Starbound is the most complex out of the three, but even that has only a couple of "main" user windows - the inventory/equipping/status menu, and the crafting menu. Minecraft has a similar setup, with a combined inventory/equipping window and a crafting window, plus some other assorted windows depending on gameplay style. Terraria has only one "window", which is the inventory/crafting/equipping/status overlay that is accessed via the escape key.

The graphics are ok, and the gameplay is nice, but unless the user interface gets a rework, I wouldn't recommend playing this game - you'll be stuck navigating windows, menus, and submenus half the time.

column8:
I CURRENTLY, do not recommend this game. It seems like Terraria without the self determined learning and progression curve, its like a wiki page that only releases 3/4s of a recipe for a super health potion and says click 3000 times for the last piece of the puzzle. Explained below:

The problems i have with this game are: 
The crafting and exploration (lower sections of planets) are gated by long and tedious kill grinds for skill ups. 

I cant explore lower in the earth until i get better armor, i cant get better armor until i get more skill ups, i cant make a generator to use some of my other craftables until i get more skill ups, i cant make a different cryopod so i can spawn in my base when i die or come back into the game because i dont have enough skill ups to make one.

So far ive only see around 5-6 resources in minings: dirt, clay, mud, biomass, uranium, aluminum. These of course are refinable to other resources but none of these resources are currently usable because the schematics that use them are not unlocked yet. Of course there may be more kinds of resources, but i cant go lower in the earth to find out cause the armor i need to do so, i cant make. 

So currently if i want to play the game, im stuck killing crabs with my nerf gun until i get enough skill up chip things to make them, and with the current skill level it takes about 40 or so of the same type to level up, and they only drop one per of one type and there are around 6 types. So on average i need to kill about 200 crabs or jellies to get anywhere.

column9: When this game first came out, I gave it a very poor review. I was sceptical about everything: the clunky interface, the sloppy combat, and the unfriendly guide. So, I put it aside for a while, thinking it was just a way to fill my Steam library, with no further development. But then I noticed that the game was updating incredibly quickly. When I returned to it, I was surprised. The game had changed dramatically, from the interface to the tutorials and the streamlined crafting process. While I wouldn't call it a complete failure, it was definitely less polished than other 2D side-scrolling sandbox games, and I found it uninteresting. But not anymore. I'm definitely enjoying it. It's not as good as Terraria, but it's comparable to the sluggish update speed of Starbound. I highly recommend it.

column8:
This game really is on another level as compared to its other successor, "Terraria".  I liked Terraria a whole lot but when I played Edge of Space, I was blown away.  The tutorial let alone was quite deep and informative but exploring was another thing because you just want to keep going and going!  I also like the researching aspect in the game as compared to Terraria because it feels like grinding on some monsters actually serves another purpose, so props to the developer on that!

Although it is in Early Access mode with the casual grammatical and spelling errors, I would definitely recommend it to anyone who has time on their hands.  If you are looking to have a quiet time with a couple of friends, this game is for you!  

One last point I want to make is that the game's graphics is quite amazing.  When I bought the game, I thought the graphics wouldn't be quite nice but you will be surprised when you go in!~

Definite 10/10 for me.

column8:
I have a split review about this game, (9/19/15 edit NO LONGER SPLIT) so below you will find my pros about EoS. 

Pros:
Amazing graphics, sure there is better, but the graphics amplify the futuristic feel of the game rather then the classic 8-bit.

Kind playerbase, I have been to many a server on EoS and only 1-2 of them have had a non-userfriendly community to come along with them, but those that do i mostly delete from my server list.

Understanding Devs, unlike most early acces games, EoS has devs who always respond to complaints and try to fix them. Most of what usaully turns me away from early acces games is the devs forget about the players after a bit and turn the game into a money grab for them, but thankfully Eos's devs show no sign of doing so. (thanks guys)

Addictive gameplay, EoS has a feel that you have to keep on going to the next thing, boss after boss, domain after domain. 

The fact that you have categories instead of a specific item being needed for every recipe. In my opinion, this really helps because you can swap clay for dirt for mud for rock etc. This helps because you dont have to grind your way through the world looking for specific resources.

It has a story, unlike most games (except starbound) this game follows a story that explains why you are randomly stuck on a planet with a cryopod as a respawn point.

Cons: As of 9/19/15 i cannot think of any cons

The advertising video is a complete lie: 9/19/15 edit: not anymore!!! the trailer pretty much sums up the gameplay (congratulations to the devs for finnaly completing it)

The sections of the research list (my hotkey is L) of Experimental armor, Assualt armor, and Recon armor: 9/19/15 edit: no longer relevant =x

Also you cant get structure blocks for a base until a few hours in: 9/19/15 edit: FIXED: can get this almost immediately after creating the world

Almost forgot to mention the tiny damage of the starter gun: 9/19/15 edit: FIXED ;D starter gun is now has fair damage and guns are easier to craft Good Job Devs

Understanding Devs, unlike most early acces games, EoS has devs who always respond to complaints and try to fix them. Most of what usaully turns me away from early acces games is the devs forget about the players after a bit and turn the game into a money grab for them, but thankfully Eos's devs show no sign of doing so. (thanks guys)

Addictive gameplay, EoS has a feel that you have to keep on going to the next thing, boss after boss, domain after domain. 

The fact that you have categories instead of a specific item being needed for every recipe. In my opinion, this really helps because you can swap clay for dirt for mud for rock etc. This helps because you dont have to grind your way through the world looking for specific resources.

It has a story, unlike most games (except starbound) this game follows a story that explains why you are randomly stuck on a planet with a cryopod as a respawn point.

Cons: As of 9/19/15 i cannot think of any cons

The advertising video is a complete lie: 9/19/15 edit: not anymore!!! the trailer pretty much sums up the gameplay (congratulations to the devs for finnaly completing it)

The sections of the research list (my hotkey is L) of Experimental armor, Assualt armor, and Recon armor: 9/19/15 edit: no longer relevant =x

Also you cant get structure blocks for a base until a few hours in: 9/19/15 edit: FIXED: can get this almost immediately after creating the world

Almost forgot to mention the tiny damage of the starter gun: 9/19/15 edit: FIXED ;D starter gun is now has fair damage and guns are easier to craft Good Job Devs

column8:
Sadly, I cannot recommend this game for a variety of reasons:

1) the GUI is quite clunky, and not intuitive.
2) the gameplay is choppy, and slow
3) there are random words/text obviously placed in the game.

I know this game is really early development, but come on! At least have some generic description of the items or dialogue! Not "Insert Description Here"...

I think the problem with this game is that it has POTENTIAL, but unfortunately the majority of the kinks have not been ironed out, and unfortunately, could be the downfall of this game.

Don't get me wrong, I love Sandbox games.
I love Space.
I love exploration.
Unfortunately, this game is way less than mediocre, and is hurting because of it.

If I could rate this out of 10 stars, it would receive a 1.7/10.

Please fix the problems with this game that would make it much higher in my book!

I would love to review this game again, maybe in 6 months or so, but as of now, stay away from it.

column8:
EDITED AS OF VERSION 0.3765, 3/31/2015

I was going to leave my old review below to compare, but Steam has a character limit so I didn't. Consider this first paragraph a big fuck-you to whoever implemented a character limit ON REVIEWS.

Now, the actual thing.

First I want to acknowledge issues I had previously that have been fixed, the foremost of which is the ability to craft better weaponry. The devs clearly listened to their player community on this one, replacing the old system with a way of generating research data and using THAT progress to create better guns (and better everything else as well!) 

The ridiculous placeholder drops on the second biome flora have been replaced with the real deal, and though I suspect it took me about as long to get there as the last time (seeing as I have neither x,y coordinates nor a map nor my old world to reference for comparison) I found the trip less crappy for having a weapon that can KILL THINGS. This is a major improvement over the last attempt.

Some of the new tools available include better saws and picks. THANK YOU, DEVS. THANK YOU SO MUCH! Being able to mine -quickly- makes generating both resources and science xp (used for science) much, much faster and more reasonable to accomplish. I am also fairly certain that either the costs of chests (in terms of aluminum) have gone down or the availability of aluminum has increased: either way, THANK YOU AGAIN. Early game resource management sucked the last time, much less so now.

Combat got more fun. This is partly due to the fact that I CAN KILL THINGS NOW because my gun NO LONGER HAS TRAINING WHEELS. Seriously, I cannot say enough how this particular change makes the game better (and I also cannot say enough how confused I am that the old loot % system was used AT ALL before, eminently terrible as it is: good change is good). The enemies feel overall a bit less the same, and I genuinely live in terror of those little blue bugs in the second biome. Guh.

Now for the less cool stuff.

Screen shake. Cool effect, but this (like controller rumble) should always have an off switch. Making it non-optional is excessively lame to your players.

Weaponry NEEDS a key that reloads it that is NOT shared with another function. Maybe the R button? Just a thought.

Disabling jetpacks in headhunter temples. This is kind of awful, honestly. I have the entire rest of the game to get used to using my jetpack to maneuver, only to have to change my reflexes in the more challenging parts? Where I would dodge basically without thinking before, here I am forced to remember a change in play that IS NEVER PREFACED while in the middle of genuinely tougher combat. Let the player use the tools you've given them in game. Let them think laterally. Don't feel like you need to take away one of the most fun parts of your game to add "challenge": execution challenge isn't satisfying. Depth challenge is satisfying. At the very least give some warning about the change beforehand.

Weapon customization needs to happen. When reload times are long, a mod to make them shorter is muy bueno. When ammo counts are small, a mod to make them bigger is muy bueno. Not having this sort of thing to replace the old random weapon stats system? No bueno.

Tl;dr, The changes I've seen are massive, and merit me changing from a not recommended to a recommended. Way to go, game devs! You guys genuinely fixed things that were broken, and what I'm seeing now is much, much more enjoyable than when I bought it. High hopes, guys.

column8: I really wanted to like this game, but as of right now.. I can't recommend it. The tutorial kind of sets you off right till they send you the the alien planet where you need to complete some objectives in order to go to another part of a space station. well, for me it was at night and this games lighting system is the worst part of the game for me. Literally you can't see jack and how the heck are you supposed to find stuff when you cant even see 1 inch past your character. After jumping around looking for stuff, how the heck should you know when your next jump will just rocket you 1000000 feet below to your death? nothing.. literally jumping around then you just die or fall in a 100 foot hole in the ground with a little fox with a horrible light that instead of 1 inch, its now 2 inches from pure darkness. So! right off the bat, I don't like to explore because everytime I leave something kills me or fall to my death and the crafting is kinda clunky. You will be mining a lot and the mining laser takes ages for 1 or 2 squares of dirt..... really....really... boring. So, I tried to enjoy this game and I think it could have a lot of potential, but after watching a youtube video that was posted 5 days ago from this review, not much has.

I cannot recommend it yet...  The UI is just too hard to work with for me.  I could rebind all the keys, but honestly I just wasn't captivated enough by the game to want to spend the time testing bindings...

column8:
Edge of Space muss sich wohl in vielerlei Hinsicht den Vergleich mit Starbound und Terraria gefallen lassen, denn im Grunde gehÃ¶rt es zum gleichen Genre. Dieser Vergleoch ist nicht in jeder Hinsicht hilfreich fÃ¼r Edge of Space, denn was Steuerung und Spieleinstieg angeht, kann es mit den Konkurrenten zur Zeit noch nicht mithalten (Das Spiel ist aber auch Early Access und daran wird noch viel gearbeitet - jeder Patch ist ein Schritt in die richtige Richtung). Wenn man Edge of Space nur 20 Minuten Zeit gibt, seine Pracht zu entfalten (wie es eineige Rezensionen hier getan haben), dann wird man nicht viel Freude daran haben. Die Charaktere wirken steif (die Animationen sind wirklich mÃ¤ÃŸig), das Tutorial ist langatmig und die wirklich wichtigen Informationen musste ich mir aus Video-Tutorials und Wikis holen. Da haben die Entwickler noch groÃŸe Schritte vor sich um das alles zugÃ¤nglicher zu gestalten. Das Problem dieses Spiels ist aber auch gleichzeitig seine StÃ¤rke. Denn viele Spielelemente haben einfach mehr Tiefgang als bei Terraria und co, sodass sie besser erklÃ¤rt werden mÃ¼ssen. Das GefÃ¼hl von Fortschritt ist meines Erachtens nach deutlich besser als bei Starbound. Man kann und muss alle gefundenen Materialien raffinieren um sie zu besseren Items zu craften. Bereits frÃ¼h im Spiel beginnt man mit Elektrik in der eigenen Basis zu arbeiten (alles was ich bisher dazu gesehen habe, wirkt so, als kÃ¶nnte man damit im spÃ¤teren Spielverlauf richtig komplexe EnergiekreislÃ¤ufe herstellen um seine Basis zu verteidigen). 
Ich finde, wer Terraria gespielt und gemocht hat und wem Starbound noch nicht reicht, der sollte Edge of Space ruhig mal eine Chance geben. Man sollte ein bisschen Geduld und ein ordentliches Wiki mitbringen, dann kann man (auch zusammen mit Freunden) wirklich SpaÃŸ mit Edge of Space haben. Und wem das nicht gefÃ¤llt, der sollte sich das Spiel vielleicht zu Release mal ansehen. Bis dahin haben die Entwickler sicher an der ZugÃ¤nglichkeit und dem SpaÃŸ gearbeitet.
Was definitiv nicht stimmt ist, dass die Grafik viel schlechter ist, als bei Starbound, alle VordergrÃ¼nde und HintergrÃ¼nde sind handgezeichnet und ordentlich in ihrer QualitÃ¤t. Gerade die HintergrÃ¼nde fine ich schÃ¶ner als bei Starbound.
column9:
In many ways, Edge of Space probably has to accept comparisons with Starbound and Terraria, as it essentially belongs to the same genre. This comparison isn't always helpful for Edge of Space, as it can't yet keep up with its competitors in terms of controls and ease of entry (but the game is also in Early Access, and a lot of work is still being done on thatâ€”every patch is a step in the right direction). If you only give Edge of Space 20 minutes to unfold its splendor (as some reviews here have done), you won't get much enjoyment out of it. The characters seem stiff (the animations are really mediocre), the tutorial is long-winded, and I had to get the really important information from video tutorials and wikis. The developers still have a lot of work to do to make everything more accessible. But this game's problem is also its strength. Many game elements are simply more profound than in Terraria and the like, so they need to be explained better. The sense of progression, in my opinion, is significantly better than in Starbound. You can and must refine all the materials you find to craft them into better items. Early in the game, you start working with electricity in your base (everything I've seen so far seems like you could use it later in the game to create really complex energy circuits to defend your base).
I think anyone who's played and enjoyed Terraria and isn't quite satisfied with Starbound should definitely give Edge of Space a try. You need a bit of patience and a decent wiki, and then you can really have fun with Edge of Space (even with friends). And if you don't like that, maybe you should check out the game when it's released. By then, the developers will have surely worked on making it more accessible and fun.
What's definitely not true is that the graphics are much worse than in Starbound; all the foregrounds and backgrounds are hand-drawn and of decent quality. I find the backgrounds, in particular, nicer than in Starbound.

column8:
I'm not a fan of this game. I bought it on sale and I am glad because I uninstalled it after beating on it for an hour. It's just YATC (Yet Another Terraria Clone). Instead of allowing the player to discover crafting recipies this game adds a grinding/research mechanic to earn them. Surprisingly this didn't add to the enjoyment for me. I don't know, there is something to be said for the simplicity of the crafting systems of Minecraft and Terraria. 

I give it a 5 out of 10

column8:
This game is marketed like as a clone of Tererria. This is only partially true. I really like Tererria, but I don't like this game. I understand that this game is still in early development, but based on what I have seen so far it is headed down the wrong path. 

1. Everything is much bigger in this game. The character is bigger, the blocks are bigger, everything. This means you cannot fit as much of the game on the screen at a time, so you cannot see as far.

2. There is no map. I use the map all the time in Tererria to find my way around and locate resources. One of the things I like about the map in Tererria is it shows open areas near you, so you can dig towards them. Since this game does not have a map it also does not have this ability. Finding resources is extremely difficult. I have spent hours digging around and ohly found very limited usable resources. Instead Edge of Space has a radar system that you have to craft, and beacons, which you also have to craft. Since it is so hard to find resources it is very difficult to find enough to make these items and so it is difficult to find your way around. Even with the radar, all you get is a little blip on a small radar screen to try and find your way around. This is so much less effective than having a map.

3. So far I have not found any hidden treasures. In Tererria treasure chests and breakable containers are a great way to get resources and gear early in the game. This game does not have these so you have to manufacturer everything yourself. This results in the game moving a lot more slowly. 

4. This game does not have biomes like Tererria. For example every Tererria map has desert, jungle, forest and ocean biomes. These go along way to add variety and keep the game interesting. Since this game does not have these it gets boring really quickly. In tererria you also have weather and other events, like blood moons and such. This game does not have anything like that.

5. Weapons suck. The only weapon you have is a gun and it has very limited ammo and has to take time to charge. This is a big pain because if you get attacked by a mob you quickly run out of ammo and have to run away until it charges back up. This makes figinting really difficult and not fun. In addition gun are not good close range, so if the enemies get close you will not be able to hit them. Upgrading the gun is also a slow process. You first have to get enough experience to unlock the plans for a new weapon before you can build it. Since gathering experience is slow it can take a really long time before you are able to upgrade.

6. This brings me to my next dislike. The experience system is completly messed up. There are 18 different categories for experience, and upgrading them depends on which items you pick up. This means you may find a lot of upgrades for furnature, but not for weapons, which has happened to me, and so you have great items to place in your base, but really crappy items to fight with. I like Tererria much better because you only have to gather the materials and you can make anything.

7. You cannot use items directly from your inventory. To use an item, even things like health and other consumable items you first have to put them in your quick bar and then switch to the item and use it. Then when you have consumed all of them it stays in your quick bar with a big red X over it. I would prefer that the item was removed from the quick bar when it was used up. Your quick bar has a very limited amout of space, only 8 slots, so you will be juggling things in a out all the time.

8. Detail screens are split up into 4 different screens. In Tererria if you hit the esc key you see your inventory, weapon, item, and vanity slots and everything else. In Edge of Space you have to hit I for inventory, V for crafting, C for armor and item slots, and L for Experience. The 4 different screen also cover each other up and cannot be moved. So if you try and drap something from the inventory to the armor slot you have to juggle the two screen and make sure they are not covering each other or else it is impossible.

9. The bug reporting system is lousy. When you go to submit a bug you fill out what looks like a standard email form with a place for your email, a subject, and a message. However it is extremely limited in that if you make a spelling mistake or want to go back and clarify something you cannot just use your arrows or mouse and go back to previous text. The only way to go back is to use the backspace key. This means you loose all your typed text up to where you want to change.

All I can say is I am glad I bought this game on sale because if I had paid more than $5 for it I would be extremely upset. Right now I am willing to wait and see if it gets better.
