column8:
I was expecting a lot of fun combat, with mining and exploration but Edge of Space dissapointed me... Maybe I didn't played long enough, but in my opinion game shouldn't need 6 hours to get to "fun stuff". 

Doing same boring stuff for 2h just to drop one item I needed for gun upgrade. It would be OK for late game grinding for maniac players but at the start? Getting all aluminium I needed was also pretty non-exciting. I don't mind mining, I like minecraft, terraria or Starbound and all the mining didn't get me bored there. But here there is almost nothing interesting to find underground (or anywhere else TBH) and ores are sparse.

Sure it's early access - but I played many early access games that weren't that boring.


+ crafting system - every material belongs to few "classes", crafiting recipes often require generic materials (for example - if recipe requires raw/metal  you can use aluminium or titanium or whatever else belongs to raw/metal),

+ upgrade system - enemies drop upgrades that after use give you point in given subject (for example Armor), after gathering enough poinst you unlock new recipes,

+ interesting world concept - small and large floating islands,

+ base that actually is a base (different stations - like rafinary or w/e - need to be connected to main command center you build by blocks you craft - can't get away with dirt house)


- your first gun is shitty. It's pretty weak, you reload more than you shoot and bullets are ugly and slow flying making shooting fast moving enemies nightmare. And you won't change it fast (after 6h of playing I managed to upgrade it to a bit less shitty gun that still looks and behaves similar). I loved how guns "felt" in terraria (speed, sounds, power), here basic gun is terrible, it feels like shooting from plastic toy and you are stuck with it for long time.

- I met only few types of enemies so far. Jellyfishes that suck your energy, small crabs that are freaking hard to hit with basic gun, flying brain-tentacle-thing that shoots at you and some kind of... errr... something that fires homing balls of death that get you through walls (and are hard to shoot down). And there were no "Hordes of enemies", usually just few of them at same time (and more would get you killed)

- upgrades are pretty random, I still didn't managed to discover other classes of weaponry,

- it's hard to tell how long will you fall after you jump (world consists of flying islands), you often die by falling down few screens because of missing island you couldn't land on beacues you didn't know its there,

- islands don't vary in any way,

- your pickaxe is slow (6h of play without getting a upgrade), ores are hard to find. You spend a lot of time at slow mining.

- UI is bad:

     - prompts you all the time (everytime you craft it shows you result in a window. it would be enough to show prompt only for weapons)
     - selecting stuff to craft item and amount just takes too much time
     - if you click outside inventory it will ask you if you want to throw item (again - prompt!) instead of using it. it order to use item you have to put in hotbar (annoying when building or using upgrades)

+- sci-fi feel (compared to Starbound, with is kinda mix of fantasy with sci-fi)

+- I don't like graphic style of game (but that's very subjective)

+- no swords in space (on the other hand I was begging for some melee weapon in some situations)

column8: Este juego la verdad me desepciono, pense que seria como Terraria o Mejor, pero no, ademas, no entiendo una mierda, no tiene logica y es aburrido jugar solo... Spawneas con un pico y para hacer el "Hacha" hay que hacer alto enbole para matar una banda de bichitos y minar minerales solo para hacer un laser hacha de porqueria... Yo estaba entre comprar este juego, si es que se le puede llamar juego, o Point Perfect... La verdad aun me arrepiento de no haber comprado Point Perfect, RECOMIENDO CUALQUIER JUEGO ANTES QUE ESTE, HASTA HELLO KITTY ONLINE.
column9: This game really disappointed me, I thought it would be like Terraria or better, but no, besides, I don't understand a shit, it has no logic and it's boring to play alone... You spawn with a pickaxe and to make the "Axe" you have to do high enbole to kill a gang of bugs and mine minerals just to make a crappy laser axe... I was between buying this game, if you can even call it a game, or Point Perfect... The truth is I still regret not having bought Point Perfect, I RECOMMEND ANY GAME BEFORE THIS ONE, EVEN HELLO KITTY ONLINE.

column8: éžå¸¸å¥½

Game play is a cross between Terreria and StarBound. 
 The mining system is a point and shoot. The blocks could break faster but, I'm a hurried kind of guy when it comes to mining. It doesn't take hours to mine what you need to get started though.
 There is a research system. Your player upgrades skills as you play. Finding data pads and new tech is awesome.
 You can develop a base as you play as well. You still have the freedom, as in Terreria, to build as you wish. There are also set static items, just the same, such as a tool bench.
  Your character gets a jet pack. I mean come on, any game with a jet pack in it is a good thing right?
  The graphics are more refined and crispy in comparrison to Terreria or Starbound. It is a very pretty game.
  The combat system is simple and straight forward. Guns can be developed and upgraded. Armour the same.

Over all it is a great Beta game. Still needs some polishing in a few areas. That is to be expected.

column8:
I realize this is still a beta, so consider this a "beta" review. As of now, the game has a complete dearth of content, the pacing is beyond slow, and it feels like there is no direction and very little point to even playing it yet. It needs some massive tweaking, more linear and logical crafting progression, and more things to actually do.

*update years later*

Abandonware. No updates since 2016, total waste of money.

*update to the update*

So now they're back... but have nothing concrete to announce. Buyer beware, YMMV.

column8:
(Written 7/18/14)

Terrible UI, Clunky Controls, I just didnt find myself having even close to the amount of fun I had with the other "space Terraria" game, Starbound. Over complicated Menus, and lack of direction made me bored pretty quickly. This is Early Access, so of course this stuff can still be kinda fixxed. I might come back later to see how it turned out, but I think I will stick to Starbound for now. But No, I don't feel like I can recommend this to my friends. I hope it gets better with future patches though.

column9: This is the first time I've played such a fucking game. The user interface is fucking awful and I really held on and endured it thinking, "What kind of game is this?" and barely managed to build a base and now I thought it was worth playing around with so I created a new world to find some resources and haha. The world I created just disappeared. If it's going to disappear like that, why don't you just make it build it by purchasing it? I have to dig up the ground and gather materials one by one and make it. I can't help but sigh at what a piece of shit this was. If there had been even one warning message, I wouldn't be so angry and swearing. This game has a bright future, but I'd rather play Terraria 10 times than play this game.

column8: Fun and interesting-sadly its a bit prolonged to progress and it seems like overall it will be rather short-thats only because its in development-there are two areas I've seen and two more that you can't survive in yet(far below where you spawn at) however it seems like it may develop into something drastically more interesting-including if the biomes gain their own variation of biomes(currently biomes only represent a certain relation of depth) so I feel that this game has potential to develop into an amazingly fun game.

column8: At the current time the game is in early-access. The game-play has great potential but at the moment lacks in the quality and ease of getting started that should accompany this genre. While its by the same creators as Terraria, and has been called 'Space Terrarria' i find very little to no similarities between the games. There is plenty of moments that lead you to a point of 'what do i do next' or 'i'm lost, where do i go' pretty regularly. This all being said i'm sure these quirks and issues will be worked out, upon full release a proper review will be made. As of know, my only opinion is the game leaves me wishing there was more to it. ~Remmy

column9:
It's a little difficult.

It looks like an evolved version of Terraria and looks fun, but
it's difficult when you actually play it.

I learned the basics from the tutorial,
but maybe because it's mostly in English, I'm not sure what to do next.

I've realized once again that Terraria is an amazing game that you can get into naturally.

However, I'm looking forward to future updates. It might be even more exciting if there are Japanese mods, so I recommend it.

column8:
ORIGINAL REVIEW 2014.07.17: Have not gotten far into this yet. So far, not as enticing as Terraria.Thumbs down.

EDIT 2015.09.20: The game is quirky, and has really been fleshed out in the 14 months since my first review. While I haven't played it as much as Terraria, it has a narrative with interesting characters (e.g., the laser shark) and a fascinating world. 

If you like side-view exploration and crafting games, you should consider getting this.

Not sure yet.

For an early access game it certainly shows some potential, but there are a few things that really bring it down for me.

Pros:

- I like the art style, characters/enemies/backgrounds all look nice.
- Some character customization is nice.
- Space age laser pick axe type thing with rifles to defend yourself is always promising. 
- Has a decent tutorial that I would have probably been 100% lost without. 
- I liked the quest/task system in place that was used for the tutorial. I would love to see this used a good bit in later builds of the game. Random quests/tasks/challenges while exploring the world would add a good bit of excitement for me.


Cons + personal opinions/feedback:

- The UI. Oh man the UI. This is the one thing that, if not updated significantly, will stop me from playing this game again. Every time I'd look for something I felt myself straining my eyes trying to discern exactly what I was looking at. Similar looking icons in inventory, small text in several places, and a very clunky and unrefined crafting menu (in a crafting game) made it so that every time I'd stop blasting things with my laser saw to go look at my loot or craft something I would grumble to myself a little bit about how I had to go back into the menus. I hope updates are coming for some of UI/menus, especially the crafting menu and/or system. Please oh please.

- Also didn't care for the health/jetpack meters being on such a noisy panel up in the corner like they are. It was a hassle to try and read while running/fighting anything. I would rather just have a couple of bars or numbers above my character or some such thing so that I can see a gauge while I am looking at my character and moving about.

- The [lack of] transition from day to night was so abrupt that I thought it was a bug or my game was crashing or textures had stopped drawing. Day/night is great to have, but needs to be a transition, not instant.

- It seems like the way to unlock new things to craft is by collecting these little book things that give +25 or so to various crafting skills. I don't much care for that as a gating mechanic, maybe it would be better if more was available initially or if there was a better indication of how using different materials to craft the same item would make a better one. Additionally, I really didn't enjoy that I would find these little books, then have to go into my inventory, select them, equip them on my action bar, and then pull them out and use them in order to gain experience from them. Unless they are to be used for something else I am unaware of, I don't understand why they are inventory items instead of just experience type pickups that occur automatically and scroll a nice little "+25 Furniture!" or something over your head.  

I should stop rambling. There's my 2 cents.

I hope some of this has been helpful if anyone's read this far. I know people compare this game to Terraria, which I have not played. It may very well be that much of what I don't like is based around Terraria's success and these elements I don't like just aren't to my tastes. If that's the case then I guess it just isn't for me - ignore all that junk above. :)

My conclusion - As it exists now, several different issues come together to make a disappointing experience. I hope that is just due to it being in an early stage, and that we'll see much more polish/improvement in the next few months. I think that when/if the right things are made better the whole game could come together quite nicely.

column9:
Before you read, I'll let you know that the game is still in beta, and I understand that perfectly well!!! Things could change! Now that you've read my rant, you can start writing your review!

I don't like the game so far. Compared to Terraria... what comparison can I even compare it to... Edge of Space is like a miscarriage of a disabled person with syphilis. Terraria was great in many ways, one of the main ones being the fun design, pretty cool characters, funny animation, and the overall colors of the blocks. Even the backgrounds (for different biomes) were superb. Simple, but they suited the design and didn't get in the way. The game itself was interesting, I wanted to replay it. After playing Edge of Space for 15 minutes, I felt sick of the design; it's completely idiotic (in my humble opinion). I don't like anime and all that crap, but everything here is done in this style, I can't stand it. The characters are now proportional (in a real sense), which might be good, but they don't fit the gameplay at all. It turns out that the heroes are drawn more or less seriously (not in a cartoon or Mario style, like in Terraria), but then the world doesn't fit the style at all. Damn, it's hard to explain. It's like adding characters from Lineage or some other crap to BATTLEFEILD 3. Basically, these things don't go together if you're creating a serious project. Regarding the backdrop: IT'S HORRIBLE. As far as I understand, it consists of three layers that shift between each other when the hero runs somewhere, which is very disorienting. Plus, it's so bright that it's really in the way, you can't see a thing. They overdid it; I think if you play for more than an hour, you'll definitely get dizzy. Another downside is the gameplay: if you're just starting out in Terraria, it'll take you a maximum of 2-3 minutes to get to know the game, and after 5, you'll be happily hacking away at wood to build a house. I couldn't figure out the controls for a long time; damn, why make such a complicated system? This isn't a fucking simulator like ARMA, where you have to know a ton of buttons to get a ton of options. But why the hell does Edge of Space have so many menus? Can't they just combine inventory and crafting in one menu? No, you could just craft like in Terraria, it's much more convenient. No, here we have to study scrolls or some other crap and then go into the crafting menu. The developers figured that if they knew the game and its interface, the players would understand everything (they're not stupid, after all). Well, that's also hard to explain, but I'll try. Imagine Einstein knew the theory of relativity, every aspect of it, and then he decided to write a book, wrote down the formulas, and started publishing it, saying, "Well, he knows this theory, so others will understand it without further ado." In short, I'll sum this whole nonsense up: Edge of Space is very different from Terraria. If you like a confusing interface, dumb design (techno-modernism from a moron), emo-fags (by the way, the hero's pose is appropriate, especially when he dies), and uninteresting gameplay, then you'll really like this game! Good luck! Terraria FOREVER!!!!!!

column8:
Currently, the game is in VERY Early Access, without a significant amount of content or progression.  However, what is here is all good.  Edge of Space, unlike other games of this genre, is much more combat focused - collecting "tech" upgrades and data from the creatures you murder unlocks the next tier of craftables, which is a pretty nice change of pace from the genre staple "dig downward to win" scheme.

How it works as of this patch, however... kind of grindy.  It's definitely in need of tuning (and the devs have mentioned it's going to get said tuning) but the system itself is a nice change of pace.

What the game sorely lacks now is content - the core systems appear to work well, so it really just needs to be loaded with items, enemies, ores, and mores.

Currently, the game is in VERY Early Access, without a significant amount of content or progression.  However, what is here is all good.  Edge of Space, unlike other games of this genre, is much more combat focused - collecting "tech" upgrades and data from the creatures you murder unlocks the next tier of craftables, which is a pretty nice change of pace from the genre staple "dig downward to win" scheme.

How it works as of this patch, however... kind of grindy.  It's definitely in need of tuning (and the devs have mentioned it's going to get said tuning) but the system itself is a nice change of pace.

What the game sorely lacks now is content - the core systems appear to work well, so it really just needs to be loaded with items, enemies, ores, and mores.

column8:
It's the love child of Terraria and Contra. If you dig the suvival crafting genre you owe it to yourself to try this game out. It's by no means perfect with its occasional bugs and hiccups; but if you can get past its flaws it's a wonderful experience.

Edge of Space has a killer soundtrack (reminiscent of Mass Effect), it has RPG elements in it that make it unique in the genre, and it's only gonna improve more.

So, as it stands, I'd give the game a 6.7 out of 10. Not because it's bad, but because it's more of a sugar rush experience due to the game not having all of its intended content.

column9:
The game is very raw; when I first bought it, I was skeptical, thinking it was an abandoned project. I replayed it a month later, and there were already a ton of patches, and many of the annoying things had been fixed. It became much more enjoyable to play.
The crafting system is very interesting: to craft the next item, you need to level up the corresponding branch, and to do that, you need to drop items from mobs. Also, the gear is created with random stats, which adds to the interest. Overall, the game is similar to Terraria and Starbound (which I also liked), but it has its own unique features. It's missing more recipes, bosses, and other content, which I think will be finished soon.
It's worth getting with a discount if you don't mind the game's rawness.

so i've played this game for a while and its been fine, but i got to the point where i saw what beta actually means.
this game isn't finished, there is no progress system and no real reason to play it unless you just want to roam around but you can only go so far down without needing better equipment.  i realise it says its in beta and isnt finished but its been like this for a looong time. i dont suggest buying this until its completed, its not like terraria that the base is done, and rest is just Dlc that they add up. if its ever complete you should get it if you're into a complex crafting system that dont really explain itself lol

column8:
I got this on a sale and my only regret was getting a 4 pack of a game I now know for sure I cannot gift with a clean conscience. 

The early game plays [b]nothing[/b] like the pretty screenshots and trailers. Instead you will be hard pressed to find the necessary materials and blueprints to progress down the tech tree. Only dirt and rock as far as the eye can see. And you cannot get everywhere you can see either: radiation exposure will keep you from delving deeper unless you craft the requisite playtime-padding gear. I get the feeling this game is deliberately padding its time so as to ration the little content it seems to have.

Except for the artstyle, this game is outdone by the much similar Starbound, even though this has been on Early Access for much longer. And we all know how Starbound turned out.

I should have learned my lesson to not trust Early Access no more. This just buries the remaining hope I ever had for such a model.

column8:
This game has the single worst crafting UI I've ever seen.  It's awkward, unintuitive, slow, and very, very poorly explained.  Good luck making anything useful out of whatever you gather/mine, because it's a journey to even begin to figure that out.

Gameplay is also rough--if you're facing more than a very few enemies, expect to be slaughtered, as you're constantly reloading while your weapons have nearly no pushback or AOE capacity. 

Big thumbs-down for the game being so barely improved in over a year since its release, also--a year later and the "revamped" Tutorial is still a huge mess.  This bodes really poorly for any hope of content being added at anything more than a snail's pace. 

You'll have more fun with Terraria or 7 Days to Die than this.

Terraria in space you may be thinking, except Terraria was actually a freaking amazing game. This game is a farce, and it requires so much TLC to live up to Terraria it's fucking pitiful and obnoxious. Where is the progression system that actually makes sense? Where are the melee weapons? Where are the chests in the world full of all sorts of random goodies? Where are the bosses and any goddam thing that's fun? The game world just feels empty as all hell. Starbound is also way the hell more satisfying.

Don't waste your money on this bullshit.

column9: Red's recommendation of this game is simply an attempt to criticize Starbound's release... but I doubt it's high enough to rival the quality of Starbound's finished product. I played it, and it's a constant battle to obtain upgrade books (to increase your tech points). Not to mention the monsters are the size of rifle bullets (in-game), and their bizarre movements make me question the AI's dedication... Overall, the experience is like trying to swat a mosquito with a grain of rice. You have to fight, and it's disgusting. The ore distribution and terrain generation are incredibly weird. I really wanted to mine, but I only found three in an hour. Without any ore, I couldn't move on. And then there were those tiny monsters that attacked me. It was boring... it was just a constant collection of materials... If you want to stick with Terraria-style 2D sandboxes, wait for Terraria 2.0 or the finished version of Starbound. And the art style is not very appealing, it looks like a bunch of different things... The gameplay of this type of game is indeed the same, mining, killing monsters and leveling up, but for this EOS game, mining is uncomfortable, killing monsters is uncomfortable, and leveling up requires great patience, so please continue to wait and see, and my review will follow up when it is updated later~

column9:
Developers, please! ===>
For an early version, it looks quite excellent.
The game is very intriguing, and I'm curious to see what happens next.
Pros:
- An unusual world, straight out of a Soviet science fiction novel
- A pet appears almost from the very beginning, which is a nice touch
- The mechanics are reminiscent of old anime cartoons
- A bit difficult to master, but it forces you to think through your actions
- Pleasant music
- Strange creatures
- The unique features of the various weapons
I thought about the downsides, and there are practically none. The flaws are quite typical for this version.
Conclusion:
The game is worth buying, and it's well worth the price.
But! You'll need to be patient, as you'll have a long wait for the final version.
____________________________________________________________________

Six months later, the game has been generously updated. The world looks more natural, the interface is much more user-friendly, and there are more and more items. If they add more randomness, perks, and bosses, the game will surely take its place of honor alongside Terraria!

=>>>
Developers!
Add events and language support! :(

Developers, I've aged just as much as you. Many have already died without waiting for updates or answers. Answer one question. Are you still alive?

column9:
Not a shred of resemblance to Tarraria or Starbount!
Cons:
1) It looks like a link between Terraria and Starbount, but everything is so primitive, unpleasant, and crooked.
2) Without knowing the language, even the tutorial mode turns into a "what the hell is there to do?"
3) It's hard to figure out what or how to craft.
4) The day/night cycle is so abrupt, the first time I played, I thought my eyes were going to explode...
5) And overall, nothing is clear during the game.
Pros:
1) None found, mainly due to the very difficult start of the game.

column8:
Also ich kann die schlechte Kritik Ã¼ber das Spiel nicht nachvollziehen und Aussagen wie; "die Steuerung ist doof", "das Tutorial ist schlecht erklÃ¤rt" usw. nicht bestÃ¤tigen, die Steuerung ist genauso wie in jeden anderen Sandbox Spiel in dieser Art (Terraria, Starbound, Windforge usw.) leicht zu handhaben, ausserdem kann man die Tastenbelegungen auch verstellen, und wegen dem Tutorial; ich habe mich sofort zurecht gefunden und finde dass das Tutorial gut erklÃ¤rt ist, ausserdem dauert dieses nur etwa 5 Minuten und erklÃ¤rt dem Spieler die wichtigsten Funktionen (Crafting, Steuerung usw,),

Das einzige was ich bis jetzt nicht so gut finde ist das MenÃ¼ und das Interface, das MenÃ¼ ist leicht verwirrend, bietet ausserdem kaum EinstellungsmÃ¶glichkeiten und beim Interface fehlt mir eine MenÃ¼leiste Ã¼ber der man per Mausklick in die verschiedenen MenÃ¼s wie etwa Crafting, Inventar, CharaktermenÃ¼ kommt, die Schatten und Lichtphysik gefÃ¤llt mir auch nicht wirklich, aber ich bin mir ziemlich sicher das dies noch verbessert wird, in ca 3 Tagen soll ja ein groÃŸes Update erscheinen, da bin ich mal gespannt was sich damit im Spiel alles Ã¤ndern wird.

Alles im allen gefÃ¤llt mir das Spiel bis jetzt sehr gut und spielt sich, wie schon erwÃ¤hnt, wie Terraria und Co, auch Pets solls geben, daher sollte jeder der auf diese Art von Spielen steht, einen Blick auf Edge of Space werfen.
column9:
I can't understand the negative reviews of the game and can't confirm statements like "the controls are stupid," "the tutorial is poorly explained," etc. The controls are easy to use, just like in any other sandbox game of this type (Terraria, Starbound, Windforge, etc.), and you can also change the key bindings. And regarding the tutorial; I found my way around right away and found the tutorial to be well-explained. It only takes about five minutes and explains the most important functions (crafting, controls, etc.).

The only thing I don't like so far is the menu and interface. The menu is a bit confusing and offers hardly any settings options. The interface lacks a menu bar where you can access the various menus, such as crafting, inventory, and character menu, with a mouse click. I don't really like the shadow and lighting physics either, but I'm pretty sure this will be improved. A major update is supposed to be released in about three days, so I'm curious to see what changes it will bring to the game.

All in all, I really like the game so far, and, as mentioned, it plays like Terraria and the like. There are supposed to be pets, so anyone who likes this type of game should take a look at Edge of Space.

column8: I got 10 hours out of it, which is about the same as Bioshock Infinite, Walking dead etc.  Although its not near as fun, it seems to be only about 15% complete.  Looking forward to the upcoming patches and changes.  The islands need to be bigger and more frequent as I find myself falling through them and finding nothing to dig/do a lot.  Only about 5 types of AI who miss 100% of the time if you stand to their left.  The ideas there and I see potential... its just a bit early.

column8:
A very enjoyable game even though it is still under its earliest of development stages.
I currently have played the Tutorial and replayed the Tutorial, during three different stages of the BETA.
I have also played the first accessible world Acheao and had much fun even though the BETA often changes things that can both make and break the game!
Uniquely, everything has remained stable, everything playable, and the only problem is the bugs that are few in number and worked out with every update of the BETA.
And every update has added either new items, craftables, creatures, events, or even progression forms.
I'm enjoying the BETA. I will enjoy the game when it leaves BETA too. It is a lot like Starbound, but set in a different dimension with slightly differents rules, laws, and phsyics. 
Oh, btw, if anything, you can customize your character to be a human, space kitten, cyborg, android, as well as being tenchologically altered, influenced by a slime symbiote, and more, so it all ends up really cool with character customization! Starbound has its races, EdgeOSpace has its many bizarre character feature combinations, inventing your own race and what not is easy (its only aesthetic though)!
I'll mention new things in my reccomendation as they come up... for now expect the occasional character wipe and the rarer world wipe as they alter and add things to the game.

column8:
Very fun, if you liked terraria you'd most likely get some enjoyment out of this one. My only concern is that with the infrequent but still coming updates they add content that they dont really explain. My biggest concern for the game at the moment is the lack of tutorials past the basic gameplay. i'm left completely confused on how to craft or even get the crafting materials for 90% of the items in the game + the machine i craft for it also have no tutorial or show-how that tells me what exactly they're used for and it becomes and guessing game that leaves me wanting more because i cant friggin figure out how to get a helmet or what i need to kill or mine in order to get a single piece of equipment for a new crafting recipe. 
otherwise it is still quite fun and some people may like that no hands-holding way of thinking. All in all i'd say as it is i'd give it a 8/10

column9: I enjoyed playing Terraria. I hoped this game would be just as good, especially with the new graphics. But the game has been out for a year, and there's been no improvement whatsoever. The crafting is pathetic. The last patch introduced datacores that drop from mobs, which are supposed to boost research. Datacores are dropping, and research is almost non-existent. Where is the freedom that used to be in Terraria? It's been stifled by some incomprehensible stat that gives a suit the ability to sink lower. Killing millions of mobs for this? Interest is below average. I think the developers are trying to outsmart themselves or are simply stalling the project with nothing in order to squeeze more money out of us... A long-term project with no future. In my opinion, they should just make a Terraria clone instead of inventing the nonsense we have now. Someone once said, "The best is the enemy of the good!"

While there are enemies, They are fairly non-threatening.  Keep an eye on this one.

While it lacks content (common for early access), it has potential to be a side-scrolling, sandbox heavywieght. Although, at its current state it has a more relaxed feel. While there are enemies, They are fairly non-threatening.  Keep an eye on this one.

column8:
Update  7/15/14:  Do keep in mind this game is far from done and my review below didn't have enough time in to see how far along it was.  The timer has a few days till the next update so I'll update this then but I have exhausted about all i can do in its current state in a few days time.  I do think it had more that is currently being rewritten that may be blocking me but don't expect the complete experience of a game like terraria yet but what is here is great and I'm happy to of supported this game early.  I could build more, explore for more upgrade capsules and such (and I may) but recipes are limited, just a warning.

Only 6 hours in so far but I like what I've seen.  This and starbound are apparently the 2 biggest games like this getting made right now (darkout deserves mention here since it could easily be the best if it gets more love) and with all the negative stuff I have read about starbound and the dev's attitude in general, edge was the one I chose.  Its fresh and new to me so I can't really critique it properly until I get to endgame to see how wiring and engineering possabilities stack up to terraria and have a better feel of the progression and what exactly is available  The fact that i have schamatics for various relays, switches and 'and gate' 'or gate' and 'not gate' makes me very happy even though I don't know if its possible to use them yet.  One thing I can say is that it will get enough time out of me to, at least, pay for the game in my eyes.  This won't be one of those many games on my list with 1.5 hours played and never touched again.  I'm more of a mechanics style gamer style game but I can already tell it has a ton of customization to those that like to decorate with TV's and such for whatever reason in the places they build.  I do appriciate the more advanced stats this has like various resistances and damage types.  Time will tell how it stacks up with terraria but I can't see any reason not to grab this if you want a new terraria experience to relax with at the end of the day.  It also has timers to show when updates are coming so thats nice and its kind of cool being in on the development cycle since I didn't play terraria till it was finished.  This way I get to see new stuff added and get ot be excited about it as it grows and expands.

column8:
I went into Edge of Space, hoping for something of a cross between Terraria and Starbound. Unfortunately, it did not deliver.

Firstly, there are several menus. too many menus, assigned to keys that you could possibly change, but why? why are there so many?
Navigating story text is also a pain, and the tutorial is horrible. it conveys the controls, but the way it does it is more of a chore it has to do, ticking off parts of the game on a checklist. You don't feel like you've learned anything.

Then there is death. this is perhaps my biggest axe to grind. it turns death into some complex process involving crafting a chamber, and using rods, and I just give up at that point.
I spawned in, tried to slowly edge down from the top of a goddamn asteroid field it dump-ed me into really? couldn't have started with rolling hills? something normal??) and died. I had no idea what to do or how to do it.


Edge of Space is a game full of potential. however, it is far, far too complicated. it has a LOT of work to do to get the gameplay user-friendly, and the death mechanic needs some serious reworking.

It feels like this game is trying to be terraria 2.0, while also trying to be starbound, but not grasping what makes starbound fun. It takes the sci-fi all right, but it takes the grungy abandoned-spaceship theme. Not the adventuring and simplistic controls.
column9:
I went into Edge of Space, hoping for something of a cross between Terraria and Starbound. Unfortunately, it did not deliver.

Firstly, there are several menus. too many menus, assigned to keys that you could possibly change, but why? why are there so many?
Navigating story text is also a pain, and the tutorial is horrible. it conveys the controls, but the way it does it is more of a chore it has to do, ticking off parts of the game on a checklist. You don't feel like you've learned anything.

Then there is death. this is perhaps my biggest axe to grind. it turns death into some complex process involving crafting a chamber, and using rods, and I just give up at that point.
I spawned in, tried to slowly edge down from the top of a goddamn asteroid field it dump-ed me into really? couldn't have started with rolling hills? something normal??) and died. I had no idea what to do or how to do it.


Edge of Space is a game full of potential. however, it is far, far too complicated. it has a LOT of work to do to get the gameplay user-friendly, and the death mechanic needs some serious reworking.

It feels like this game is trying to be terraria 2.0, while also trying to be starbound, but not grasping what makes starbound fun. It takes the sci-fi all right, but it takes the grungy abandoned-spaceship theme. Not the adventuring and simplistic controls.

column9:
Overall, it's fun!
It's more detailed and realistic than Terraria, and above all, the characters are beautiful.
However, there are a lot of bugs, perhaps due to the lack of patches. The world is small, which reduces freedom, and many in-game systems are lacking.
Furthermore, the game's overly realistic nature makes it challenging and tedious.
However, these issues will likely be patched over time (a major update is scheduled for six days), and the game's many fun elements more than make up for its shortcomings.
You won't regret spending your money on it.

column9:
July 20, 2014 Update
First, you need to constantly fight monsters to upgrade various technologies, then build various equipment and facilities. While the distribution of mines isn't as organized as in Terraria, you can still find them. Also, underground, there are various ruins where you can obtain a large amount of technology. Since it's not localized to Chinese, I don't know how to use many of the items...

Currently, maybe I just don't know how to play? But gathering even the basic materials is a bit too difficult (I've built two worlds and found this to be the case), so it seems like progress is slow. I even patched the basic command center, and only managed to assemble the most basic weapons and equipment for gathering materials, along with a bunch of other miscellaneous gadgets. Sigh, it's taken me ages to get this far. So anxious, I'll just put it aside for now...

=======================
As the spiritual sequel to Terraria, it's truly terrifying that this game isn't even popular in mainland China, lacking even a single introductory article.

Even though it's in English, it's pretty easy. I even finished the tutorial at a beginner level. However, the art style is... so different from Terraria that it's hard to get used to.

I just finished the beginner level and got a ship. I'll try it out more before updating. I'm posting this now because there are so few Chinese reviews for this game.

column8:
For those of you that are worried about buying this game while it is in early access, you have nothing to fear. The developers update this game VERY often, and most of the time they are ahead of schedule. I bought this during the steam summer sale and have already seen several updates roll out, fixing issues, adding content, etc. Without a doubt the most updated early access game I've ever bought.

As far as the game play, picture Terraria, but way more complex, futuristic and just full of pure awesomeness. I play with several of my friends and we all have a blast with this. I wholeheartedly recommend this!

third...goin on is worse..
keep your bucks with a movie with the girl next door...

column8:
First, the UI is clunky and kinda hard to get used to, since I played Terraria and Starbound a lot. This game doesn't feel anything as close as polished as those other two, even when they were at their early phases.

It's really slow paced, survival-based action, you will want to measure each movement, because just one step wrong will make a downhill of events resulting in a so-called "SAD event" (dying, and wasting your precious cryorods, which are basically your lives). The critters WILL fool you by their sizes, you will get anihilated by little crabs and lots of jelly until you get the hang of energy-management.

It is, indeed, a great game, or should I say, it will be a great game. The game obviously feels unfinished and kind of boring because of the progression, but it does have a brilliant future and I'm excited to see where this is going.

I would recommend buying now, because it's pretty much certain that it's going to get more expensive each major update. So get it while it fits your wallet.
column9:
First, the UI is clunky and kinda hard to get used to, since I played Terraria and Starbound a lot. This game doesn't feel anything as close as polished as those other two, even when they were at their early phases.

It's really slow paced, survival-based action, you will want to measure each movement, because just one step wrong will make a downhill of events resulting in a so-called "SAD event" (dying, and wasting your precious cryorods, which are basically your lives). The critters WILL fool you by their sizes, you will get anihilated by little crabs and lots of jelly until you get the hang of energy-management.

It is, indeed, a great game, or should I say, it will be a great game. The game obviously feels unfinished and kind of boring because of the progression, but it does have a brilliant future and I'm excited to see where this is going.

I would recommend buying now, because it's pretty much certain that it's going to get more expensive each major update. So get it while it fits your wallet.

column8:
Firstly, the combat is annoying and clunky, especially when all the enemies are darting around erratically making it infuriating to try and hit them; and when you do eventually land a shot, the enemy (in the first zone, less than 20 minutes in) is totally immune to your weapon, and firing back homing explosives which are very had to evade or shoot down. The AI is clairvoyant, always knowing where to aim at any moment, and the explosive weapon of one of the first three enemies you will face can break large holes into your base, allowing the rest to hit you directly, killing a player obscenely quickly. Secondly, the crafting is on a tech tree, requiring spelunking with useless tier-1 equipment to try to unlock tier-2 and so on, sadly, the depth you can reach is restricted, and a player will often never find anything before death forces them to their respawn point. The crafting is clunky and difficult, the UI is a battle to navigate with almost no quick access to the comically named "hotbar", and the tutorial is laughably incomplete. I bought this game believing I was buying into alpha software, and it felt like that, in mid-beta. The gameplay feels confused, torn between rogue-lite and Terraria-esque sidescrolling sandbox. 
Enemy variety is good, and the art style is unique and appealing, but the gameplay needs severe work. Avoid buying this title for full price, if you must buy it at all.

column8: So I bought this game late last year and have tinkered with it off and on throughout the year.  The game carries a lot of potential but needs a deal of polish imo. There are problems with crafting certain items and mining takes quite a while (even with the higher tier pick). Edge of Space is essentially a slower-paced sci-fi version of Terraria with an exposure system (which limits how far down you can go before dying) and some other aspects.  It's still a relatively barebones game a year down the road and I cannot recommend it currently.  Wait another 6 months or go try 7 days to Die in the meantime.

After speaking with LadyAijou extensively regarding Edge of Space. I would like to update my review with some further information.

The reason advancement isn't working is right before the steam summer sale most of the NPC code was gutted out for revamping, very similar to what Rust is doing. The team at Handyman Studios was not expecting to get featured in the flash sale and ended up receiving more orders during that eight hour period than they had gotten in their previous best week during the 2-1 sale.

The development team consists of two people, one of which had a system failure right after the change to the NPC code was implemented, which meant that what should have been fixed either right before or right after the flash sale was unable to be fixed. The chests dropping from nests is related to this issue because the nest/event has to spawn the appropriate creatures and then track that they have been killed, which with the changes to the NPC code is not working properly, so you're "failing" every nest/event you start.

This means that yes, at this particular moment it is not possible to progress past the first biome. With full aluminum armor you can make it pretty much to the end of the first biome, but beyond that is not possible. I will be leaving my review as "not recommended" for the time being due to the non-available features, but will hold my final opinion in reserve until such time as the current mess is cleaned up.

This game is essentially in early beta. It looks promising, but major features are either not implemented or not working correctly. Compounding matters, there is almost no (up-to-date) information on the wikis, leaving you guessing if your confusion is due to a bug or user error. 

Unless you like being frustrated,  come back to this one when it's out of preview status. It's not even ready for a public beta yet.

column8:
The game is overcomplicated, but it has potential.
From the small amount of time I've played, I can tell I won't be going back to it soon.

The HUD is confusing and complicated.
The item management system is clunky.
The tutorial is confusing (For me, at least.)
The movement feels average.
The lighting isn't that good (yet).
The combat feels terrible...

The game will get better over time, but in its current state, I can't reccomend it to anyone.
If you really want to play an early-access space game, go buy Starbound.

column8:
I bought this from kickstarter long time ago, during its ALPHA stages it was great and showed a lot of promise.

They removed most of the enmies for a long time which was kinda frustrating as the game felt like it only had 3 enemis to kill. 

They made the world smaller and only go donwards direction which makes it really hard to travel as you cant predict if your jatpack can take it or you die falling. 

The quest are a good addition but mostly impossible as with the weapons you can get early they do 1 damage so destroying a craps nest takes so long you cant destroy it before time runs out. 
Same thing with defend defence platform, once you take the quest 8 enemies will spawn inside the defence platform and destroy it less than 10 seconds hitting it 15 dam per tick inside the platform.
Also its kinda weird that enmies that hit it are seen in the game wilderness as non damaging mobs and yes they will even hurt you even thou they should not.

The new research system takes far too long to get anything build. Even the basics. As you need to grind load of enemies to get 15-25 points in certain research gategories at random in order to advance it further which requires 1000 or more per level and enemies wont drop reserach date always when killed.

Currently for some reason you cant even build the next weapon in line as its material tables are bugged and it wont allow you to put any of the right materials in to build it.

Also the current weapon system is kinda sad as you can only upgrade your weapon and not really build more weapons jsut the one you have.

Enemies can spawn anewhere, even inside you and they sure like to spawn inside your base all the time. You need to constantly clear it out.

Enemies also tend to have so much hp that with your 1 dam pea shooter you need about 30 shots to kill one enemy and yo ueven have to reaload it slowly. Thou the weapons are made randomly if you are lucky you might get weapon with 2 dam.

The lighting day and night system is getting an upgrade soon which is a great thing but at its current state it is horid. Black boxes that dont even fade in but appear instantly when night comes. Luckily this shoul be fixed soon but its been this bad for a long time.

There are many normal alpha game buggs that dont bother me like animatiosn are the wrong way, characters spazzing out when looking up ( this will be fixed soon too =) ), etc cant craft things, de-sync at servers, etc.

The developers are very active and have improved this game alot thou sometimes things have gone the other way too but currently I dont recomend this. This will prolly be good at some point but not yet. Consider buying terraria, 7 days to die, minecraft or maybe crea while you wait for this to pop up good.

I will edit this review as the game updates, hopefully it get better. I really hope so.

Let me put it simply: it's a terrible game. The interface is poor, inconvenient, and confusing. It's a pathetic parody of Terraria and Starbound. Maybe they'll turn it into a proper game, but at this point, it's not. 
And what's strange is that the game is in Early Access, but updates ("Official Terraria Content") are released that improve the quantity of the game, not the quality.

column8: The combat system is very precise and simply with it's four main options : X, Y, B, and O. X allows the player to immerse itself in the revolutionary ecomnomics system with a brand new feature: Sleeping. Y allows the player to buy various items, such as hat, boot, HP, MP, sword, and pancakes. B is for hitting, and O does not currently function as this is an early access game. 10/10 MOTYC

column8:
We are still in the early access, but so far it seems like the developer is improving the game. I'm hopeful this game will become worthing of being called "Terraria in space". At the moment it's closer to being Terraria's younger sibling. A bit more clumsy and less eloquent, but full of potential because of its youth.

The controls are a bit fiddly and not as fluid as in Terraria. Jumping from slopes triggers the jetpack instead of a regular jump, for example. 

The crafting interface is more organized by categorizing everything, but having to manually assign the materials from dropdown menus is clumsy at best. Worse, if you change quantity after you selected the materials, it resets the chosen materials and you have to pick them again. It'd be handy to pre-select the cheapest (or most plentiful) resources in a configuration which could build the item, by default. Changing quantity should preserve the materials already chosen. It might even change materials if that can make a recipe work when the old materials will not make it work.

The tutorial has improved. It used to be overly wordy and micro-managed you, and then it dumped you on a planet afterwards without so much of a hint as to what to do next. It's more to the point now, but after the tutorial you're still left in the middle of nowhere on a sky island without any real pointers as to what you're supposed to do.

The recent big patch added research levels which you can unlock by reading the research materials dropped by monsters you defeat. Massive improvement over the old system which basically gave you access to everything, but no clue what it did or why you would pick something. Now at least you have less choices so you can get familiar with the starter items and learn more from there.

column8: Fun if you like buggy Beta games. For a 3 month period or so, i couldn't even load the game without it CTD! The dev's fixed that, but it's still a long march to the finish it seems. Oh hey guys, Terreria content! C'mon, get some original ideas for Christ's sake! Pixelated avatars and a big skull boss do not make me want to re-install. Cool original content, maybe, but not re-hashed ideas borrowed from another game, pshhh! ******MMORPG.com - Best Indie RPG at PAX East 2014****** <--- this bothers me, because it's NOT an RPG, and it's being rated by an MMORPG report, which furthers my distain. Firstly, it's a sandbox crafting game, with zero RPG elements. Sorry, but being in control of an avatar does not constitute, otherwise EVERY game would be an RPG. And just because you can augment items does NOT mean it's an RPG, nor is that even an element. That being said, NOT AN RPG, and it's certainly not the best, and I'm sure there were dozens at PAXE2014 lol. In order for it to be a Role Playing Game, there needs to be an implemented stroy line with varried choices offered to allow alternate paths of progression.

Honestly, right now (still in development), it's pretty mediocre!!!

The story and the world aren't very interesting (at least not for me ;p)...
The textures and the overall visual aspect of the game didn't excite me...
The camera is positioned way too far away = it's hard to see your character and resources...
The crafting and harvesting system is completely unintuitive compared to Terraria or Starbound...

In short, it's too average for now. We'll see when it's finished, but I have serious doubts... ;p

column8:
EDIT

tl;dr Was on the way to being a good game, but ran out of fuel before it got there.

When I first played this game it had serious potential; there were unique and interesting gameplay ideas, regular updates, and most importantly devs who respond on the forum. I spent a fair amount of time playing the game, eagerly anticipating updates, until I felt I had got this jist of what the game was and where it was going, so decided to wait a couple of months before playing again. When I booted it up again half a year later the only obvious changes were some haloween gimmiks, as far as I could tell updates had ground to a standstill. A year (and a bit) later and no further changes, until I saw a post saying that the devs hadn't abandoned the game, however they could tell us why they weren't working on it at the moment (which was what promted me change my review). For comparison I've left my original review below, showing how excited I was for this game.

ORIGINAL REVIEW

This is a really promising game, with dedicated developers who are eager to share their creation with the community. 

It is not a finished game at the moment, but is what a beta game should be. Updates are designed to test specific features so that they can be polished, submitting tickets is on the main menu and the developers actually respond to posts in the forums. Although it sound like these are obvious aspects for any beta game there are too many early access games that care too much about people playing them, instead of testing them to make a better game in the long run.

The gameplay itself will be familiar to anybody who has played terraria, starbound etc, but with enough unique features to make it interesting. One of the best features is the crafting system that classifies materials (eg ice is a chemical, which is a raw material => raw/chemical/ice), therefore some recipes will require any chemical or any raw material etc.

Overall, if you are looking for a good beta that will turn into a great game, I would recommend buying it now. If you don't want to be actively involved in improving the game, then wait until it is fully released so that you aren't disappointed and forget about it.

column8:
Pros - Good game so far. Playable. Hours of game play. Survival. Dont have to remember Crafting. Music. Can make anything with anything. You have the right to record EdgeOfSpace I believe. Has Mutiplayer. Tutorial on basics at the beginning. Achievements(Not a good thing to the game, just something I like about games).

Cons - Needs bug fixes, and more ores to find early on. Crabs are too OP at the beginning. Run out of energy too fast. YOu dont regain Energy as fast as you loose it. Everything wants to kill you. No tutorial on how to make Energy work with the doors or CommandCenter(which i believe will be added?). No trading Cards(Not a downside, just something most steam games have, which I believe this game will have shortly later).

Personal Review - Ive only had this game for 1-2 days, but I can tell you, this game is a great game and has a lot of potential for a early access game. Look forward to the updates and how it will improve to be a better game than what it is now. I strongly recomend this game if you are looking for a game like Terraria and/or Starbound to play with your friends. The energy/electricty system is a little hard to understand first, but I hope it will get better with the updates. With mutiplayer you can get things done a whole lot faster, as ive played with my three other friends. If you want a survival game I recomend this game. The music is great, and has a spaceish feel to it. Mutiplayer is easy to use, just open your ports, and get the IP, boom youre in. Playabe, and has hours of game play just to get the basic things. 

I Love this game so far, and I am looking forward to the updates to make this game even better! I am planning to make a gameplay series of this game, show the updates, and how to do things in the game. 
Keep up the good work Devs!

column8:
Let's start by saying I've been playing this game since it first came out on Steam.  I also voted (before that) to have it "greenlit"...  Greenlighting a game in Steam means that out of several recommendations that Steam gives you for upcoming games they'd be willing to add to their service, you chose the ones you like best.  Not all games actually make it!

It didn't take much to impress me, this game had it all.  That's not to say it needs to improve highly, but the devs once promised there is a lot of updating planned for it. I really love this game so far, it has major potential.

Having played Terraria for some time, I knew this game would be a great addition to my Steam library.  It has a long way to go, even after it was released to the public, there is a lot of content that needs to be added, and lots of bugs that need squishing.  Nevertheless, I am looking forward to see that happen.

Still the best "Terraria In Space" anyone could find!

column9:
-= Opinion =-
Let's start with this: Don't buy this game. In a few months, they'll lower the gross price, and then they'll probably offer discounts.

The game greets us with an ugly menu, although it's better than when the Beta test began. After clicking Single Player, we move on to character creation. It's designed so that we create a character from a few hairstyles, several hairstyle colors, a few facial expressions, and that's it. We can't change the color of the "clothing," but we do have distinctive features like scarves. It's not a joke.
Let's move on to the Tutorial! A poorly made, poorly explained, and unclear Tutorial! It explains the controls, item creation, combat, and that's it. For completing it all, you get four achievements... There's one more of the five, for connecting to MP. MP is practically non-functional at the moment; you can buy a paid server, but for a game like this...
The graphics might be appealing, but I don't like it. The execution is ugly. The lighting is terribly odd. The torches glow in a square, and the "fading light" effect leaves much to be desired. I actually like the animations. The sounds and music don't fit the atmosphere.

General Cons: I really dislike the item crafting. For example, torches can be made from dirt, mud, or other crap... The building process is poor. I still don't know how to destroy things like a workbench. And the tutorial doesn't cover it...
There's no HP regeneration, and the Recipes don't offer any easy, cheap bandage recipes.
The biggest downside is the price. In my opinion, participation in the beta test should be free, and then removed when the full version comes out, so that players can equip it when they want to continue playing. However, I paid a whopping 15 euros (bought a few months ago), which I'll never get back. I regret it...

I also noticed this connection. I remember watching cartoons as a kid, which were creative, original, and fun to watch. And now, when I look at today's cartoons... They all either promote licensed toys or are based on a weak comic book, and even the original ones don't promote anything, but are boring, monotonous, and probably just for the sake of switching. Bakugan is an example of such a cartoon.
I see games like Sandbox RPG Adventure 2D the same way. First, the debut of Terraria, then the development of Starbound began, and now this...

As of now, I don't recommend it, sorry for any mistakes. This was my amateur OPINION. School-level rating: 2 - because it's a beta.

column8: What we have here is Edge of Space. Edge of space is a really interesting game, it plays differently from Terraria and starbound, it's truly a breath of fresh air for the genre. The weapon focus is more on guns at the moment, although they told me they are to add melee weapons in at a future time. As for graphics, the graphics are amazing and have a interesting feel, actually kinda throws me back to the days of the SNES, kinda breaking away from that pixel feel but also sticking to it. As for the music the music makes me feel a lot of things it's ambient and interesting it's kinda sad but in a good way. Point is, It's a fun game really, the level design is interesting and there are many canverns and areas to explore. The game is challenging as a rhino trying to climb a tree made of tomato skin, it takes some getting used to. It's a little slow at first but once you figure it out, it's awesome. On that note be sure to check out the tutorial and actually PAY ATTENTION to the words it says, there are quite a few giggles in the script too. Just pay attention and get immersed in the atomsphere and you will fall in love with this game as I did. This by the way, is coming from a terraria/starbound veteren. So purchase it and give the devs all your money as they're a fantastic bunch. 10/10 'nuff said. Also did I mention LAZER SHARKS.

column8: First of all dont listen to people who say "just get starbound instead" Yes starbound Is a great game but so is edge of space, eos Gameplay has its own style about it, In a gaming world where this style of game is a dime a dozen its good to see a game like eos try and mix it up with its terraforming, and enviormental style gameplay, Yes it shares alot with its crafting cousins but for the price its quirky monsters charming enviorments and unique power grid system is for sure worth your time, I would recomend it to anyone who likes this style of open-world crafting game and just wants to try something new, It is an early access title so for the time being with its current features I give it a 8/10 solid title.

column9:
Okay... I dug the game out again to see if anything has changed.
And lo and behold, 80% of my complaints have been addressed and improved... I even found myself enjoying the game...

The day/night rhythm is now finally smooth and no longer BAM! -> Day -> BAM! -> Night...

The crabs and jellyfish no longer try to suck your brains out for no reason unless you attack them.

The monsters no longer devour the Arklight's projectiles like they're chocolate crackers.

Thanks to the keymapping function, you can finally customize the key assignments so the game is playable.

Well... I still haven't discovered liquid water, but I can handle that.

The construction menu is now much better and more comprehensive than it was at the beginning.

The laser pick no longer takes what feels like decades to mine mud.

Yeah, was there something else? Oh yeah, after half an hour of playing, my computer decides to commit suicide and shuts down... which worries me a little :/ ... but I'll accept that as the game's anti-constant gamer feature.

CONCLUSION:

I wouldn't have thought it, but the game is slowly developing into a worthy successor to Teraria and, with tons of features, proves to be hours of gaming fun.
For this reason, after about half a year, my thumbs are now up... great work, guys... don't let up now and keep it up ;)

BUT:

I would still recommend waiting to buy it until it's out of beta... there are still too many bugs floating around that can quickly ruin your gaming experience.

Je vous dirais bien de l'acheter car il est certes bien, mais non. En fait je propose que vous attendiez de voir si le jeu se developpe un peu plus et un peu mieux pour vous eviter un achat inutile. 

La prise en main est legerement frustrante, l'equipement s'aquiert assez rapidement et n'ayant pas enormement de truc a crafter, on se retrouve tres vite stuffÃ© EndGame. L'Ia des enemis est assez basique mais efficaces vous donnant des enemis assez coriaces a abattre. L'ambiance sonore bien que vite redondante est d'assez bonne qualitÃ©, laissant place a de bonne musiques pretant a une ambiance Sci Fi de bonne qualitÃ© !

Bref je ne saurais que trop vous conseiller d'attendre. Ensuite on avise !

it hurts to play this, when i heard it had terraria content i bought it thinking it be a good exspreince, the terrain genoration is litearly just tons of flying boulders so you are most likely to die from fall damage at the start then mobs

also the mobs can spawn anyware, and i do mean anyware i built my own house and the only sapce i had around me was a 1x4 block, i went afk only to return to be incapasitated ebacuse 4 mobs spawned next to me in a well lit room, its a anoying system.

progression is hinderd not beacuse of difficult mobs but just gameplay itself.

terrain is clunky, mobs are terrible at just being there (not difficulty), and yes the tuturial does not exsplain things properly.

only hope in the future they sort this stuff out but its not worth the Â£9.99 i payed for and certainly not the $14.99 for the final product if it reamins in this state.

column8: Meio lagado mas bom

I tried, i really tried to like this game. To win the battle against the horrible UI, annoying crafting system, constant dying, dull surroundings, dull music, dull combat, dull mining, dull building, dull everything. And to find the "potential" that people seem to be talking about. But it was a failure. 

I mean, what were the devs thinking? You know, "BETA" stage of development starts when you have an almost ready-to-go product, so you just need to eliminate bugs and test some features. Not when you have a game that's almost unplayable, AS WELL as buggy and unstable.

Where do i start? The world is pretty tight, so you can only explore downwards, but since you have no way to tell what's below you, 90% of the time you'll end up falling from great height, crashing and dying on impact. Not to mention that you can't go too deep since the exposure and/or mobs will kill you there. In my book that's not "exploring", just pointless trial and error.

You can build a base, but what's the point if you can't even respawn there? And it's not like in Terraria, where you always build a base near the surface - here you won't be able to get back up there unless you die again. And if you build it deeper, then every time you die, you'll have to go and find it again in the midst of a thousand identical floating islands. Oh yeah, and who would've guessed that these super-advanced spacefaring guys won't have a device to make a MAP of the area.

So here's how your first couple of hours in EoS will look like: you'll be jumping around, searching for at least something different from the dirt\mud\clay surrounding you, trying to get deeper, but mostly falling and dying constantly. Even if you succeed, you'll see that nothing really changes down there, except for tougher and more aggressive mobs, and the exposure timer won't let you go deeper until you get better equipment. And unless you think that painfully slow mining and crafting some aluminium pants or whatever is fun, then that's it, that's your only option here - you won't have anything else to do. 

To make things worse the game gives you no clue on how things work and why would you need them. So i can build a GENERATOR and a COMMAND CENTER, cowabunga, now what? It won't even explain the basics. Like if you played Terraria, you know there's a difference between a block and a wall. But here, there are only "walls", by default functioning as blocks. You actually need to hit "TAB" button to be able to place your "wall" in the background where it belongs. Only you'll never guess it unless you stumble on it in some random guide, like i did.

Yeah, whoever in the devs team is responsible for the UI deserves a bullet to the face. Why can't i place items just by dragging them from my inventory? Why do i always need to bind a hotkey to do this basic thing? Why the crafting window is so bizarre and complex? Did you see how crafting looks in Terraria? Well, look again. 

Probably there is some difference in the later stages of the game, but i gave up here. It's not like "playing a game" to me, more like trying to fix a car without any idea of what you're supposed to do. And with the wrench constantly slipping out of your hands and falling so you need to go pick it up again and again. 
Overall, this is my most frustrating early access experience since Project Zomboid, but at least i didn't spend my money there.

column8:
As someone who greatly enjoyed games like Terraria and Starbound i have to say this was a huge dissapointment, I bought this game for me and a friend to play and neither of us got as far as the multiplayer screen since there was a confusing and easily broken tutorial that was compulsary to access anything else which is just stupid. The graphics are quite laggy (Not a cause of my computer) and very jerky, the movement did not work in the slightest and i had to anticipate where my character would move to due to a 10 or so second lag in the control inputs. I had to play the tutorial itself about 4 times over to actually unlock the multiplayer and overall around 7 times as it became unplayable due to something missing or not loading.

The gameplay elements seem very copied and remind me of a less playable version Starbound, the game itself just isnt worth the Â£9.99 and you could buy a much more worthwhile such as Terraria it self if you don't own it already. When i played it i got a certain something said by Yahtzee "Terraria? Never heard of it and also we're sci-fi and therefor different to the thing we havn't heard of" Which does describe this game perfectly. Putting the price at Â£9.99 for an unfinished, unplayable game such as this is stupid and Â£14.99 for the "finished" version (which will probably never actually come around) is even worse.

Even though this game is only in "BETA" (moreso to an alpha) it won't be excused, plenty of "Early access, BETA" games are being pumped out and this is the worst of the worst and at a higher price than most. Although if you have someone on your friends list that you really hate you can gift this to them. To put it at an end, Don't buy this game, go buy something else

Me esperaba muchisimo mÃ¡s del desarrollador del terraria.

Ha usado la excusa de que hizo el terraria para vendernos una castaÃ±a. Graficos feos, jugabilidad limitadisima... No es un "acceso anticipado" es un "llevo 3 meses, paga esta mierda que llevo, que va para laaargo".

Compro un pack con contenido especial de terraria y no recibo nada especial...

Nada mas entrar, me tengo que tragar un tutorial interminable, que no se puede quitar, ni terminar... (esto lo quitÃ³ a las 2 semanas con un update)

En fin, podrÃ­a ser un gran juego, pero con un planeta igual siempre (rollo montaÃ±as aleluya de Avatar), con los graficos feos (me gustan mas los del terraria....) y la dificultad de hacer cualquier chorrada, Starbound lo deja a la altura del betÃºn.

No recomiendo la compra.
column9:
I expected so much more from the developer of Terraria.

They used the excuse that they made Terraria to sell us a dud. Ugly graphics, extremely limited gameplay... It's not "early access," it's "I've been here for 3 months, pay for this crap I've been carrying, it's going to take a looooong time."

I bought a pack with special Terraria content and I didn't get anything special...

As soon as I started, I had to sit through an endless tutorial, which I couldn't uninstall or finish... (this was removed after 2 weeks with an update)

Anyway, it could be a great game, but with the same planet every time (like the Hallelujah Mountains from Avatar), with the ugly graphics (I like Terraria's better...) and the difficulty of doing anything stupid, Starbound leaves it in the dust.

I don't recommend buying it.

column8:
Absolutely amazing game.  Perfect amount of challege and an incredible huge world to explore.  This survival game is truely a gem which will keep you playing for hours on end.  The massive scope of this game includes a robust and in depth Power system (PIOS) along with Atmosphere Proccessing systems places the control of the world completely into the players hands.  Incredible enemies inspired by some the greatest classic games of our time will have you gawking in awe.  Bring your friends and together you can tame the world around but beware as the world will resist you at every turn.  

oh and do i really need to say it?

FREAKIN' LASER SHARKS!

Nuff said ^^

column8: waste of money

I would not recommend this game at this time, it is VERY dull within the first 3 hours, the first 30min-an hour you spend (if you play the tutorial) being told things that anyone who has played ANY other game like this for 10min could figure out. Needing to research the crafting recipes slows the game down a lot. The combat at the moment sucks, all weapons needing to reload and no weapons that are not guns, (that i have seen) and things to shoot that ether are to bloody small or move around so much you just kinda wag your mouse around and hope to hit them with one or two of your shots. These are just a few of my complanets but i don't want this to go on forever, i will finish this by saying I want this game to be good, but at the moment it just isent, Terraria and Starbound are just better games. 1/10 not worth the price, Its a 1-2 quid game being sold for 8 quid for the standard version or,  the bargen price for the special edition 15 smeging quid! When you can get both Terraria and Starbound for 15 quid, i would deffinitly recommend getting both of them over this game, at least fo the moment.

column9:
It's a great game!!! I recommend it to anyone who's tired of Terraria or Starbound.

But there are some downsides! It has very difficult bosses, poor lighting in the dark, bugs, small chests, limited inventory space, and even when you place an item in an action slot, it still stays in your inventory. The list goes on and on.

But I still recommend it, since it's only a BETA version.

If you can't beat the boss, add me as a friend and I'll help.
