column8:
UPDATED 10/5/2016
Game is unfinished and abandoned by developers. I don't recommend purchasing this as all the problems from when I initially played this game years ago are still present. 


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fYmSkERv3qs

Please remember that Edge of Space is not completed, and more features will be added as the game develops. As such, in the future this article may not be a fair representation of the game.

Edge of Space, developed by Handyman Studios and published by Reverb Publishing, is a 2D dynamically generated space adventure. Much to the likes of ever popular Terraria and recent debut of Starbound, Edge of Space allows you go venture through alien planets, build a home base, fend off the local wildlife, and most importantly, survive. It may seem like these survival games are a dime-a-dozen, but the fine folks at Handyman Studios have put their own spin on the whole â€œsurvivalcraftâ€ genre.

I am going to preface this by saying that Edge of Space is in a very early stage of development. It was recently updated and gained some traction through Steamâ€™s Early Access, but the fact of the matter Edge of Space is a bit rough around the edges as of right now. It can be quite a turn off to play a game so early in development, especially if it gives you the wrong impressions due to bugs and other strange anomalies. I will say, though, that in the two weeks that Iâ€™ve been playing the game, there has been a staggering amount of bug fixes and patches that have really improved the experience. I wholeheartedly believe that Edge of Space will improve in this respect as the developers iron out bugs, UI issues, and add in more content.

In Edge of Space, you play as a lonely operative representing the Ark Corporation. After catching some beauty sleep in a cryo-chamber, you wake up and realize that youâ€™re basically lost. Your only chance of survival is to depend on the amazing technologies that brought you to the, ahem, edge of space. The only problem here is that youâ€™ll have to find the materials you will need to survive amidst a hostile and dangerous planet. Actually, planet right not even be the right word for Edge of Space. Itâ€™s more like an asteroid field where you bounce to and from different small land masses.

One facet of Edge of Space thatâ€™s particularly interesting is how the environment is constantly working to kill you. Make no doubt about it, youâ€™ve arrived in a hell-hole that is out for your blood. There are plenty of enemies wandering around trying to eat you, but more than that, the entire gameworld wants your flesh. As you descend lower and lower in space, youâ€™ll take exposure damage if youâ€™re not fully equipped. This can really be a range of things, including radiation or lack of oxygen. In order to prevent this, youâ€™ll want to fully make sure youâ€™ll have the supplies on you to oxygenate the area, or get rid of the radiation. As an ArkCo Operative, you can also defend your new territory with a series of droids or turrets.

As of March 2014, combat in Edge of Space is completely centered around guns. There arenâ€™t any melee weapons as of now. However, there are some interesting ideas with the guns. My favorite example is the Arklight, a gun that shoots out a sticky, glowing canister. This is extremely useful when spelunking through the various caverns youâ€™ll find scattered throughout space, and it sure beats placing a torch down every 10 feet. In fact, torches have such a low-light radius that I tended to stick with the narrow glow of my laser pick and the Arklight.

As someone who has never played Edge of Space before, first impressions can kill the experience. Iâ€™m not going to lie, Edge of Space is pretty rough around the edges, especially in the first hour or so. Although it has improved dramatically since Iâ€™ve recieved the game, the biggest problem is still the UI. There are some peculiarities that really need adjusting to, especially if you compare them to the flexibility of similar games. One such example would be the hotbar, which is a bit complicated because it can take multiple clicks to slot in different items. The crafting menu is categorized into different sections, but youâ€™ll have to individually click each item you want to use in a recipe. I see what itâ€™s trying to do, and I really like the fact that in some recipes you can substitute many different items, but itâ€™s clunky.There are other little things like this that really drag down the experience despite the survival aspects of the game working as intended.

Edge of Space has a nonlinear sense of progression, but sometimes it is more complicated than itâ€™s own good. There are plenty of machines that you can use to craft items, but when it comes to weapons and armor, youâ€™ll have to go to an armory. This is really more tedious than it needs to be because youâ€™ll have to drop down various unmarked chutes, and youâ€™ll be given whatever weapon lies at the bottom as well as the recipe for said weapon. The first time I went into the armory, I fell down the chute and got a shotgun. Donâ€™t get me wrong, shotguns are awesome, but I didnâ€™t get to look at the other weapons I could have made.

In one of the recent patches, one of the developers of Terraria actually added a few things into Edge of Space. Itâ€™s great to see that Edge of Space has the support of a well-known and beloved developer, and itâ€™s even better to see Skeletron inside of Edge of Space. Omegatron, as itâ€™s called in-game, adds some much needed flavor to the typical crabs and floating snails youâ€™ll find outside your base, not to mention heâ€™s very difficult.

In the end, Edge of Space is still very much a work in progress. If you go in expecting a full-fledged game with lots of content and polish, youâ€™ll be sorely disappointed. What Edge of Space excels at is creating a unique environment with interesting gunplay and addictive gameplay. Itâ€™s tough to quit playing when youâ€™re in the middle of setting up a fortress, or going on an expedition to dangerous zones. Given a few extra months in the oven and I have no doubt that Edge of Space will easily turn into something that will be worth your money.
column9:
UPDATED 10/5/2016
Game is unfinished and abandoned by developers. I don't recommend purchasing this as all the problems from when I initially played this game years ago are still present. 


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fYmSkERv3qs

Please remember that Edge of Space is not completed, and more features will be added as the game develops. As such, in the future this article may not be a fair representation of the game.

Edge of Space, developed by Handyman Studios and published by Reverb Publishing, is a 2D dynamically generated space adventure. Much to the likes of ever popular Terraria and recent debut of Starbound, Edge of Space allows you go venture through alien planets, build a home base, fend off the local wildlife, and most importantly, survive. It may seem like these survival games are a dime-a-dozen, but the fine folks at Handyman Studios have put their own spin on the whole â€œsurvivalcraftâ€ genre.

I am going to preface this by saying that Edge of Space is in a very early stage of development. It was recently updated and gained some traction through Steamâ€™s Early Access, but the fact of the matter Edge of Space is a bit rough around the edges as of right now. It can be quite a turn off to play a game so early in development, especially if it gives you the wrong impressions due to bugs and other strange anomalies. I will say, though, that in the two weeks that Iâ€™ve been playing the game, there has been a staggering amount of bug fixes and patches that have really improved the experience. I wholeheartedly believe that Edge of Space will improve in this respect as the developers iron out bugs, UI issues, and add in more content.

In Edge of Space, you play as a lonely operative representing the Ark Corporation. After catching some beauty sleep in a cryo-chamber, you wake up and realize that youâ€™re basically lost. Your only chance of survival is to depend on the amazing technologies that brought you to the, ahem, edge of space. The only problem here is that youâ€™ll have to find the materials you will need to survive amidst a hostile and dangerous planet. Actually, planet right not even be the right word for Edge of Space. Itâ€™s more like an asteroid field where you bounce to and from different small land masses.

One facet of Edge of Space thatâ€™s particularly interesting is how the environment is constantly working to kill you. Make no doubt about it, youâ€™ve arrived in a hell-hole that is out for your blood. There are plenty of enemies wandering around trying to eat you, but more than that, the entire gameworld wants your flesh. As you descend lower and lower in space, youâ€™ll take exposure damage if youâ€™re not fully equipped. This can really be a range of things, including radiation or lack of oxygen. In order to prevent this, youâ€™ll want to fully make sure youâ€™ll have the supplies on you to oxygenate the area, or get rid of the radiation. As an ArkCo Operative, you can also defend your new territory with a series of droids or turrets.

As of March 2014, combat in Edge of Space is completely centered around guns. There arenâ€™t any melee weapons as of now. However, there are some interesting ideas with the guns. My favorite example is the Arklight, a gun that shoots out a sticky, glowing canister. This is extremely useful when spelunking through the various caverns youâ€™ll find scattered throughout space, and it sure beats placing a torch down every 10 feet. In fact, torches have such a low-light radius that I tended to stick with the narrow glow of my laser pick and the Arklight.

As someone who has never played Edge of Space before, first impressions can kill the experience. Iâ€™m not going to lie, Edge of Space is pretty rough around the edges, especially in the first hour or so. Although it has improved dramatically since Iâ€™ve recieved the game, the biggest problem is still the UI. There are some peculiarities that really need adjusting to, especially if you compare them to the flexibility of similar games. One such example would be the hotbar, which is a bit complicated because it can take multiple clicks to slot in different items. The crafting menu is categorized into different sections, but youâ€™ll have to individually click each item you want to use in a recipe. I see what itâ€™s trying to do, and I really like the fact that in some recipes you can substitute many different items, but itâ€™s clunky.There are other little things like this that really drag down the experience despite the survival aspects of the game working as intended.

Edge of Space has a nonlinear sense of progression, but sometimes it is more complicated than itâ€™s own good. There are plenty of machines that you can use to craft items, but when it comes to weapons and armor, youâ€™ll have to go to an armory. This is really more tedious than it needs to be because youâ€™ll have to drop down various unmarked chutes, and youâ€™ll be given whatever weapon lies at the bottom as well as the recipe for said weapon. The first time I went into the armory, I fell down the chute and got a shotgun. Donâ€™t get me wrong, shotguns are awesome, but I didnâ€™t get to look at the other weapons I could have made.

In one of the recent patches, one of the developers of Terraria actually added a few things into Edge of Space. Itâ€™s great to see that Edge of Space has the support of a well-known and beloved developer, and itâ€™s even better to see Skeletron inside of Edge of Space. Omegatron, as itâ€™s called in-game, adds some much needed flavor to the typical crabs and floating snails youâ€™ll find outside your base, not to mention heâ€™s very difficult.

In the end, Edge of Space is still very much a work in progress. If you go in expecting a full-fledged game with lots of content and polish, youâ€™ll be sorely disappointed. What Edge of Space excels at is creating a unique environment with interesting gunplay and addictive gameplay. Itâ€™s tough to quit playing when youâ€™re in the middle of setting up a fortress, or going on an expedition to dangerous zones. Given a few extra months in the oven and I have no doubt that Edge of Space will easily turn into something that will be worth your money.

column8:
Old Review:

Easily the most dull game of the year.

I've been playing Edge of Space the past eight hours; with the single thought in my mind of: "This game must get better eventually, right?"  well; I've been essentially in the same spot with the same equipment for the past five hours.  Killing crabs n' jelly fish, and mining titanium, aluminum, stone, mud, clay, and dirt does get old after a while.  I found a strange white box with a blue arrow on it in a cave and tried to us eit, but that just flashed some screen for half a second and went away; and I was unable to interact with it again.  But let's put things into points for the sake of organization:

Good things:
*Good movement system.
*Good art & music.
*Online co-op.
*Interesting concept.

Bad Things:
*Very unpolished.
*Bad interface & not very user-friendly.
*No explanation for the purpose of alot of things, for example the matter recombiner; the game does not tell you what it does, and the description is simply: "You can't even wager a guess as to how this crazy machine works.", normally checking a wiki would help an issue like this, but their wiki is ancient and not updated.  And then there are things like the random events that go on in the world like the crab nests, and random things such as the weird white box with blue arrow-  no idea what purpose the box served, didn't realize the crab nest was an event.
*Lack of things to do; the only goal you might have in the game is simply go lower.. And there is no reason to go lower as you have all the resources you need in the top areas.
*Lack of resources; it may seem like a good thing that alluminum is basically the most awesome freakin' resource in existence, but it really makes the game boring when you're not bothering to actually look for things.
*Uninteresting enemies.
*Uninteresting areas; why would the devs think it was a good idea to make the entire game take place on some floating rocks ?
*The relaxing music and police sirens(?) doesn't lower the boring factor of this game.
*Terrible enemy AI.
*Poorly made tutorial levels, tutorial more interesting than the actual game.
*Extremely useless chests; for this let me explain how chests work, you craft one then place it in the world; then you right click it to open it, you then have to manually drag and drop each item you wish to place in it, into it; and the chest only has three slots.
*Lack of creativity; how many times has the space shark and space animals concept been done now?
*Very unprofessional dev team.
*Just a shoddy game in general; people like to consider it as a terraria and starbound ripoff- but in all honesty that's an insult to both Terraria and Starbound.
*I'm fairly certain the preview images which show awesome things happening are all fake.
*Dropped items from full inventory disappear within seconds, made 7 chests to put my items somewhere- didn't realize my inventory was full,  chests vanish.  Make a full suit of aluminum armor, don't realize inventory is full,  poof.
*Glitchy items:  Made two chests, had two slots free- placed a chest, the other chest vanished into nowhere.  Used an emergency recall, had two in my inventory; the other vanished.

 If I had any suggestions for this game; I recommend they take a page from Windforge and add player made spaceships to fly around the edge of space.  

ps:  Don't use the Omega research unless you have good equipment, it just brings you to a boss whom will murder you if you still are using low level stuff.



Well,  all in all I recommend the game; but make sure you don't play it at night or else you're liable to fall asleep from the sheer boredom it causes; and if you're planning on buying the game because of the awesome screenshots you saw of like a desert and mechs and whatnot- those are definitely faked, there are four biomes; you can go to about two of them, a grassy biome and a cold biome.  There's also about 8 or so enemies currently and about six(?) different resources.



Edit August 2016:

So, it is now the distant future since I last reviewed the game; and honestly it's worse than before.  The game opens to a beautiful 404 page error after the Unity Logo and Splash screen.  And the game starts with you in the middle of nowhere with a shark with lasers and crap attached to it with a high pitch voice that asks you to do pointless tasks such as gathering dirt and clay for it.   Simple actions in the inventory system such as dragging an item to the trash drops the FPS immensely, nests are incredibly annoying to destroy as they infinitely respawn the enemy guards every time you shoot it; and you need to shoot one quite a lot to destroy it. 

AI is terrible, they wander back and forth not really trying to get to you, in part because their AI is considering the bullets you shoot as ground, so if they're jumping into the air and you shoot them, they will continue to jump as high as they want, or they'll just plain turn around when shot at with a little ? symbol.    The animations and art is weird, the physics is bad, the overall game is mayhaps more boring than it used to be.

But all in all, better than No Man's Sky.  So at least there is that.

column8: This game is bad, and with bad i mean realy realy bad

This review is for the beta product. I intend to return to the game once it is fully developed and see if it has been improved upon, but this review is for people considering purchasing the beta version.

I want to like this game the way I want to like every Terraria clone. Maybe this game will be good one day. Right now, it is not. The menu system is needlessly complicated and completely counter-intuitive. One thing I imagine will sadly not improve is the art design. Personally I play way more indie games than AAA titles - high end graphics aren't a selling point to me. But there is doing low res graphics well, and then there is this. It is terribly ugly to look at. If you want to spend money on one of these work in progress space Terraria games, Starbound is the only one worth paying actual money for currently.

column8:
Im giving this game a maybe for playing. Theirs barely any difference from this vs terraria. Oh wait their is, just a radiation exposure bar, and the game seems to be styled around metroid graphics.

Onto the real review. Okay basically your use to terraria, starbound, or minecraft. You assume you have the basics of building, thats check.

Now you assume you have the basics of base building, that is... barely check. You have a command center, but your given no real idea how it works, or how to use it. 0 Explanation behind it. (HINT) it supplies 2 available slots for structures that require power (Which AGAIN are not defined, nor explained) how to mine or make adjacent to a powered block (and to do that you need to mine the back, currently the mining in the background has been switched to TAB key).

Anyway... now assume after base building is scrapped, most of what you seen in the pictures, or the trailer video is either not implemented yet or considered non user useable. Thats... thats just false advertising. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME based on the trailier. You will be SEVERELY disappointed if you do!

Anyway, other than this review just remember... with a grain of salt.  Comparing this game to minecraft is laughable at best, as minecraft is one of the most fleshed out, well prepared games out their for survival. Just its block based graphics.

With Starbound you get the perks of it having terraria gameplay with a twist, mechs, turrets, space ship home & planetary home combine with world travelining leading to finte adventures.

With Terraria you get alota building functionality but... only one world, on the upside in Terraria you also get to transfer items on your character with you to other servers.

With this game Edge of Space you... get working building mechanics (barely anything to craft though), good music (when its not tearing horribly or desyncing), horribly slow mining, extremely aggressive enemy npcs that fight you based on how far down you go, and how pre-occupied you are not paying attention to your surroundings, and limited idea of how to really play altogether with out continued communication through the steam forums with other players, and the developer(s)/staff of Edge of Space.

If you want this game buy it, i bought 2 copies, but now im beginning to regret my investment considering how much is lacking, how much is currently missing, and what is functional, works, and what isnt combine with all the time lost to just... well... mining, searching, and trying to figure out this game altogether with searching the steam forums, and trial and error in the game itself. Anyway good luck!

Oh and so far it runs for me on a Asus Transformer T100 series (1.83ghz quad core, 2gb ram) with 15minutes load time, and on low/normal graphics (on my other laptops/desktops) the game runs at normal/high. Lag doesn't seem to be existant in any gameplay on this game on any of the computers i've tested it with (all being at 1.83ghz, 4.2ghz, or 3.9ghz quad core) computing systems.

*Note*

Still consider this game and check back on it though! It does show promise assuming alot of the negatives i've listed, not including thousands of other negatives listed in the forums are taken care of.

column8:
My god, where to start? The interface is unintuitive and clunky, the crafting is the worst I've ever seen in a game, the tutorial is horrible, the game's pitiful attempts at humor are ironically laughable, and the art is absolutely hideous.
The developers have taken a bit of a slapdash approach to most of the dialogue, with frequent spelling mistakes and the aforementioned terrible humor. The game even tries to poke fun at other sandbox survival games that have long since surpassed it in quality. The UI is somehow even worse than the environment art, and that's saying a lot.
Then there's the story. The game starts out with a 3D rendered cutscene that looks like it's from the mid 90s, teases some vague bullshit that I couldn't glean anything from except that there's some sort of corporation and there are 4 people who have something to do with it, then just says "To Be Continued" and then stops. I was shocked; it seems that the developers have heard of stories before but have never quite taken the time to read one. You need to get us actually interested in the story before pulling that, Handyman Studios!
In summary:
Don't. Buy. This. Game.
(Unless somehow the gameplay, tutorial, writing and art all get completely and totally revamped by the time it gets out of early access.)

column8:
Do not purchase this game.

Now that you've got a conclusion, let's cover the reasoning.  This game is, at best, a pre-beta.  It's not stable enough to be a beta, the mechanics are either half broken or entirely unbalanced, and the game lacks enough content to be playable.

This game is unstable, and runs poorly even on a beast of a machine (3930k and 7970 GPU).  I've had numerous crashes, and the game occasionally just hangs for a minute.  During that time I've been destroyed by numerous enemies, lost progress, and lost items. 

The crafting system is entirely broken.  Enemies level up several orders of magnitude faster than your equipment can.  There's no invincibility mechanics, so a swarm of enemies can strip even a well equipped character in seconds.  You bounce when an enemy hits under you, so you can be air juggled to death.  Numbers mean nothing.  You start with a paltry heath and shield, but coming back with 10 times bettter stats doesn't make you live longer, because the game occasionally just spawns a dozen enemies around you.  All of this is predicated upon oyu exploring, but that's realy a joke because any upgrade past to most basic will require hours of random tunneling to get anything.  The real kicker is the crap weapons.  You have to craft ammo, but even worse the weapons requiring ammo aren't great.

Content has recently been dramatically expanded.  The waiting for resources to process has been removed, and there's more to make.  Unfortunately again, this is useless.  You spend huge amounts of time now searching for resources, to synthesize into other resources, to synthesize into useable goods.  After all of that grind, you're left with gear which still allows the enemies to absolutely curb stomp you constantly.  If the point of this game is crafting, then they really need to go back and rebalance enemy strength, progression rates, and the insane cost of items.  There's no reason that you shouldn't have all research completed prior to finishing the second area, and even if you do some of the end game items require an amount of resources which literally exceeds those present on a single biome.  

In a single sentence: this game is fundamentally broken and the rate of progression indicates that we'll see completed project in a few years at best.




Negative comments generally warrant some thought.  In the case of a review, you should provide the people who made the prokect a way to fix it.  Let's start there.
1) Stop trying to be Terraria.  You've got guns with and without ammo, crafting, and resource gathering.  That doesn't mean you are as good as Terraria, and you shouldn't invite the comparison.
2) Ditch your current crafting system.  It requires too many diverse resources, it's convoluted, and there's no 1:1 comparison for item utility.  Combining that with the random nature of weapons means I can get a weapon worse than my current one, while spending much rarer resources.  That's frustrating, but what's even worse is having dozens of different armors that show no clear progression.  You've got a needlessly complex system, too many resources, and none of it is balanced.  Stop adding more, and just get the bare bones in place.
3) Rebalance enemies.  They're cheap, their spawns are a giant middle finger to the player, and more often than not they have too much health.  Spending 45 minutes fending off the Head Hunter boss isn't a challenge, it's a gruelling grind.  This particular point is arguably compounded by the crap weapons choice.
4) Develop the game.  I'm going to be blunt here, you aren't putting any appreciable effort in here.  It may actually be huge from your side, but I can't see it as the consumer.  In almost a year I'm still dealing with poor balance, no content, and unfulfilled promises.  Either discontinue the game, or finish it.  Right now this is looking to be an alpha we have to bay for, that will never be up to beta standards.  I can tell you that I'll never be giving another cent to anyone involved with this project unless they've got a completed game.  This extended beta is absolutely worthless, because its triumphs are drowned in a sea of failure and unfinished code.

After 3 separate returns to this game, I'm done.  You don't deserve anyone's patronage, unless you can tell us when we're going to get something worth the money.  This garbage surely isn't.

column8:
I personally feel it is tougher than Starbound, with less immediate tangible rewards and is really meant for co-operative play. While you can solo most of the game, it is pretty tough without friends. The music is very decent as well.

Fairly stable, server we had running did not crash. Took me a while to figure out how to get some of the other game mechanics running but once that is over, the crafting stuff works well. Only gripe is the crafting workflow could maybe improved abit. (too many buttons to press).

Overall highly recommended if you like Terraria & Starbound. Can't wait for the game to be completed.

column8:
Good game so far, definitely has potential, but has a long way to go.

The textures are ugly, the animations are a little poor, the jumping and jetpack system is really weird, and it's [i]HARD![/i]

But it is definitely coming along well, it's not very feature rich and I am finding myself bored with it after 2 hours, but I'm sure that the future updates will add more to the game to make it rich and much more fun, and that is why I am recommending it!

Faith in you developers!

column8: Edge of space is a terraria like game but with a new look and feel. This sci fi sandbox game gives you a whole new feel for sandbox games. The day I got it I must have played it for six hours straight. The controls are smooth and you can tell that the weapons and all the tools were really giving a great look over and made into great looking weapons with an awesome random stats generator. The developers are also on the ball with getting in touch with people who are playing and wanting to see how it's going personally, not just recieving emails from people who are having problems. They go to the community hub, the enter tha chat and talk with people. Suggestions are taken into consideration. All in all, the game is fantastic and the developers are fantastic. With the early access already being a lot of fun, I can't wait to see what the full game will be like.

column8: the "beta" aspect is VERY evident here. right from the start, the intro videos have been butchered and ruined by horrible artifacting and pixelization. the UI is in terrible shape, and it has you reaching all over the keyboard way too often for various menus and functions, where things like right click, shift click, and altclick, are almost never used. its possible to pretty much trap yourself in the tutorial before it teaches you wiring, too, requiring you to start a new game. i dont reccomend it *yet* but if i see a lot of changes during development to improve the look, and make it more user friendly and intuitive, that opinion is open to change.

column8:
This is a game that came before Starbound, and if you took Terraria and Starbound and inbreed you would get this game.

3/11/14 content and prior

Pro's 

Cheap price, and as of this review you get a bonus copy for a family or friend.
Nice backgrounds for biomes.

Sounds: Not Starbound and not as enjoyable as Terraria, but it fits the sci fi theme.

Jetpacks: Jetpacks!


Cons

Tutorial, Doors fail to open, chest have the wrong things in it. Command help comes a little too late.

Items that don't work, example starting gun you make does 1 damage a hit but enemies take 0 damage. You die before you can kill the weakest of things

Usual glitches that I will not list because this is an early access.


So in final I would tell anyone to give it a try while its cheap and you get the bonus copy, after that go watch some let's play of it or perhaps some one streaming on Twitch.

column8: j'adore !!!

Attention! Do not buy this game YET!
The game is playable but unfinished. The game starts with this vague tutorial. Ofcouse, tutorials are there to help you in-game but this tutorial is kind of weird. A tutorial should show what is really good in a game. But instead of giving that to you, they give you this level of an depressive room I guess.The game plays laggy and unsmooth. It feels just like a flash game. Seriously. In the trailer you see smooth NPC's/Players, but when I bought the game and started it, it wasn't that at all. I bought the game to quick. I'm a really big fan of Terarria and when I saw this, I was completely sold. But I felt betrayed when I played the tutorial. Yes, it is an Early Access Game. But do not buy this because you thought the trailer looked ''cool'' or whatever . (Me) But I do see alot of potential in this game and I hope that the developers make a great game of it. And that is because I DO RECOMMEND this game. Developers , please make a good game of this.

- Booker

column8:
This game is VERY VERY unpolished, i understand that beta is beta but this is just bad. The game starts you off with a gun that does hardly any damage and isnt accurate and gives you NO information on how to get a better gun. I sat for what felt like 5 minutes shooting one enemy. Also there is a system when you die, you use cryorods. You get 10 cryorods at the start and use one upon death, when you run out your character gets a stacking debuff that makes you weaker. To remove that debuff you need to use cryorods which the game once again fails to inform you on how to get more. I felt cheated out of my money.

Wait for the finished game, right now it isnt even fun.

column8: It's not a bad game, but I couldn't get into it.  Obviously I don't have much play time on it, but if it looks interesting to you Starbound or Terraria would be a better choice.  I prefer Starbound, it was a good game when I got it and it's just getting better.  Like I said it's not a bad game, but there are better ones out there.

column8: This game's Multiplayer is very broken. Extremely broken. Has potential, but I only bought it to play with a mate; it lags immensily every time it generates, which is every 50ft or so in game. Couldn't get past the first world after the tutorial without disconnecting and uber lag. Has alot of potential, but at this stage, it's hella broken. The UI, launcher and worlds are unpolished; rendering it quite an ugly game (looks like it's made in gamemaker pro), network issues out the wahzoo; and performance issues even on the best of machines. This game could be good in the future, but for now, it's not even worth $0.99, let alone $15.00. Very dissappointing.

As it is now, this game has tons of potential, and if you are fans of Terraria, Starbound and other similiar games, I strongly recommend this. However, if you have not yet played these Terraria or Starbound, I would recommend purchasing those before buying Edge of Space, as they are more developed, and provide a more in depth experience than the current version of Edge of Space. This being said, Edge of Space is a fantastic and adds new features and gameplay mechanics to its genre that make it both fresh and exciting for both first time players and veterans of the 2D Sandbox Adventure.

column8: After convincing him the game would be amazing, my dear friend Mason purchased four copies of this game for us and some friends. After only 10 minutes of playing, we all concluded this game was nothing but shit. I swiped my computer from my desk and it crashed onto the floor. I'm typing this review on a new computer I had to buy because of this game. We have all become very depressed, and Mason has even killed himself with satanic symbols drawn in his room and bloody scripture written on his wall that said "Edge of Space." I attempted to throw myself from a bridge but was stopped. I have developed paranoia, mild insanity, and depression from this game. One of my friends has been put into a mental asylum and the other has been caught using any blunt object to beat the shit out of himself. I think that the police know about the bodies that are in my basement. They wouldn't be there if this game didn't exist. I cannot stress how much you should not buy this game.

I'm hoping this game has at least some promise in the future, having bought my copy I find it currently has the same flaws as starbound in that its labouriously slow to start. I was hoping for something with the pace of Terraria which i love. Its early days so i will reserve judgement but for those thinking of buying I'd perhaps get it now while the price is reasonable and don't expect all the bells and whistles just yet. I will say that currently the trailer seems to show things that you will have to be playing for a long time to achieve, so at least it has longevity to it if you have the patience to stick with it,

Sadly the games was abandoned before being finished. Its still playable but knowing it won't have a true ending is a shame. Another example why we should be wary of early access titles.

shit

It's still in alpha, so it's no review. It's more about what I feel is good and bad in current state of alpha.

Good:
1. It has the terraria feeling about it.
2. Lots of different stats which you can tweak via equipment
3. Dungeons are much more interresting and larger than those of Starbound. They are almost equal good as those of Terraria.
4. I like the guns. Weapons are much cooler than the ugly ones of Starbound.

Needs improvement:
1. It's really user unfriendly interface. Example: Sometimes you need to press 'v' and sometimes 'f' to use stations. It wouldn't hurt if it was just one button for all stations.
2. Tutorial is horrible. It tells you to do different things and you have no clue what you need to do. Tutorial is try and error approach. It wouldn't hurt if they also showed more clearly where you need to go to craft things.
3. The spawn rate are quite frustrating sometimes.
4. It's to linear approach regarding what you can craft. So it wouldn't hurt if they changed the research. Skip it all together and just let us collect resources. If we collect a resource then all equipment you can craft with that resource shows up and you can see what's missing.

I don't recommend the game in the current state. I am sure it will be much better if above things are fixed.

column8:
Hello World,

I just got this game gifted by my wife. We both like Minecraft and love Starbound (Sorry EoS, you have to take this comparison).

IÂ´m no friend of harsh words, but this game can be summarized in one word: crap.

The controls are horrible. Its far from intuitive, after learning what to press you just hate the many buttons you have to press.
It actually feels like it came out 1991 for DOS and also looks like it.
The retro-style is one thing, but this game looks really terrible. I was inspired by the trailer, but the actual game looks nothing like it. The animation is clumsy, the backgrounds look like plain wallpapers. Stuff like your mining-laser... the length always stays the same, the grafic ignores the distance you point with the cursor - kinda confusing.

If the developers work hard on the controls and the designers put more work into the grafics and animations - it could get better. But just now I can`t recommend this game.

8 Months and a BS marketing scheme later..and I finally have an opinion of this game.

1.  Its still broken beyond belief.  They've had 8 months thus far to migrate the game over to its new "format"...and they are finally getting multiplayer launched...which was promised back in July.

Its still a pain in the butt to do anything in the game: the mining and gather is slow as molasis, the flow of the animations still feels like an old flash game, and they constantly have to "rework" the environment , monster spawns, etc.  Not just tweek it...but rework it.

I just dread having to start over in that game, unlike in other games of the same "genre" like Terraria.   And considering how infrequent and archaic their update process is....restarting happens ...painfully often.

2. Their latest marketing scheme to push dried up sales just kicks every Early Access owner in the jaw.  The people that adopted this game early...and tried their hardest to help improve the game....get called "Entitled" and  "Trying to smear the companies good name" by asking for their free copy of the game that they should get which is part of the new Early Access purchase.  No grandfathering the changes...just a solid FU tot he ones that helped make the game even possible (financially and development wise).

Its not like this is a Game Lauch sale...or a 8 months from Retail Release sale; its still in Early Access...like it has been for the last 8 months....at the same exact price it was back in June/July.

Yea...I can see why they dont want to give out the extra copies to the ones who already bought the game. Then they may not get any new sales imediately...because their game sales were already stagnant.  Whose the entitled one again?  This game and the comapny have been pretty "stagnent" since day one.  If they are trying a really big "last ditch" effort to generate sales before the game is even Launched .....while angering all the people who funded the game/company to get them to this point....it might speak a lot about the future of this company.

There are many reviews that go ionto specifics about the pros and cons of this game, so mine is going to be short and sweet:

As it stands, it is not worht the $12.99 I paid. I really want to like it, but it is clumsy, aimless, and unnecessarily challenging. A poor user interface only makes it more glaringly obvious that similar games are better. The art style for the characters is a nice touch, but the textures for the more common things like dirt and mud are ugly at best. The music needs work and there are some game-ending glitches. 

Wait to purchase this one until it has some polish. I wish I could say "more polish" but it feels like they haven't even started yet. I'll be going back to Starbound for the time being.

column8: The key binding could be better, would be really nice if you could close the windows with ESC. Actually switching to another engine would be WAY more beneficial but if you're gonna stick to it there are bugs with the lighting. The fps is 60 when loading and then drops to 20 while gameplay. There is no obvious way to go into windowed mode, the crafting is very complicated. There are lighing bugs with the laser and while moving and/or loading the game. Fps randomly drops to atleast 5 and then goes back to 20. Things would be more convenient if you could drag the items you craft into the toolbar. Most people including myself and 2-3 of my friends who tested it can't be bothered to read the instructions so maybe shortening them a bit would be nice since even tho i had read them i still had problems understanding how to do things. Overall as of right now i would barely give it a 2/10 very disappointed if this doesn't get fixed i would label it as a waste of money.

column8:
Spend the extra cash to buy Starbound or go buy Terraria instead of this trash. Both Starbound and Edge of Space are in Beta, but it's painfully obvious which one is much better. This might be worth buying later on, but it definitely isn't right now. Do not waste your money like I did. I implore you not to buy this, at least as it stands right now. If you like this type of genre, you more than likely have played Terraria/Starbound/etc. Keep playing those, ignore this. Trust me. It's not worth it.

EDIT: This came out on June 28 and it's almost a year later. From what I've played, it feels like it came out a few weeks ago. I'd hate to see the state this game was in last year.

column8:
This game has been in Early Access for a while, but it's an amazing game with great potential! For all of you who like games like Terraria, Starbound and Minecraft; this is a game that will either be just as good, or be even better. Buy the game, it's worth it. As a matter of fact, get the Special Edition!


EDIT: The game is out of Early Access now, and as I said, the game has all the potential. It looks beautiful, the story is nice, your character has a voice and opinion, the building mechanic is clever and the music is very nice on the ears. This still is a game worth buying. Make sure to support the team too! They're nice people!

column8:
So far this game is pretty fun and playable. If you're a big fan of Terraria-like games, this is definitely something to check out. 

It's a good deal more difficult and it takes a lot more getting used to than other games of its type that I've played. The UI, windows, and keybar are kind of a pain to deal with, but I'm sure that'll be fixed at some point. 

It's probably the most detailed of these pixel-y, crafty games out there, but I feel like the game should be a bit more "zoomed in" so it's easier to see all of those glorious pixel details, especially of your character. 

All in all, I feel that this could easily be a hit for.. Whatever the hell genre these games are, but, of course, after it gets worked on some more. For the moment, I'd say that if you don't have Starbound, you should check that out first. But if you already own it, then definitely give this a shot.

column8:
One of the worst games I've ever played, Beta or not.  Performance is horrible given the power of the gaming pc it's being played on.  Crashes extremely frequently.  User Interface is such a hassle to work with. Audio skips constantly, deaths are far too frequent, and several items that have appeared as collected on the screen never appeared in my inventory.  Bought this on a whim since I loved starbound and terraria and the latest version is supposed to include terraria content.  Too bad I can't stand this game enough to even get that far.  Perhaps when this is past Beta, I'll try it again, but this is abysmal.

*EDIT* 11/27/14

As of my last attempt at playing the game, many of the above issues had been rectified.  Performance is no longer sluggish, crashes are much more rare, the audio no longer skips, and dying is harder to do unless your early game gun's stats roll poorly.  I'm glad to see a developer actually working on their early access title and improving it greatly.  Unfortunately, the interface and structures in the game are not intuitive nor simple to use like other games in this genre.  Terraria took some getting used to, but it at least had a learning curve.  I sadly have to stick by my negative recommendation on this one.

the game doesnÂ´t work properly right now, either I get stuck on a tutorial and canÂ´t progress or the loading screen just freezes:(

Beware, this game is utterly broken!

I tried to set up a server and play with a friend of mine.
We didn't even get half way through the tutorial...

My friend got stuck when the tutorial wants you to open a door by pressing a button.
The problem being that neither the button is highlighted nor is anything in the room actually able to be interacted with.

After randomly jumping around the room for quite some time while hammering the F-key, the door miracoulously opened for me.
(It never did that for my friend)
But I got stuck in the next room when the game tells you to craft a laser something, which turned out to be impossible without having the required materials...
Needless to say that the game does not provide you with any materials at this point and even goes ahead telling you that everything is alright.
...until you continue along the tutorial (and some rather poor jokes about antibiotics) and are forced to use that laser something.
(Which - you guessed it - you don't possess because the game failed to provide the needed materials)

That was around the time that we decided to quit and wait for several rounds of patches and bug fixes.
To be quite frank: if the game utterly fails to guide you through a 100% scripted (and hopefully tested!) environment, how on earth would it be able to accomodate all the random stuff that we would hopefully have done outside of the tutorial?!

column8: Very reminiscent of Terraria, and plays very much the same. However, I enjoy this game much more than I enjoyed Terraria. The scenery if very beautiful, and I find all of the adaptations from Terraria, such as the pick turned into a lazer to be very interesting and enjoyable. I would very much reccomend this game to anyone who was a fan of Terraria, and honestly anyone who wasn't. Best Early Access Game I've played, and there's going to be so much more on the way, plus a very reasonable price.

column8:
The game is good. While the art is "love me or leave me" it somehow managed to add some originality to the sandbox concept. We all know Terraria is the godfather of this 2d sandbox style, and while Edge of Space has to compete with other big titles like Starbound (F.e) for its own space in this genre, it certainly has that "something" that draws your attention for hours even if its to grind for new weapons or build something pleasing to the eyes.

Give it a chance if you have the spare money, or wait for the full release. either way, even Terraria's creator, 'Redigit' approves this one.

This game is starting off in a great place. Any fan of Terraria or Starbound should pick this game up.
Just a heads up this is still in EARLY Access. Lot's of things are being added so be patient and have fun!

Multiplayer: In a seperate build is a highly updated build and so far it's very enjoyable. Frequent updates. I have a server running where my friends and I play.

column8:
I played Edge of Space since the early days of its EA release, and while I enjoyed it a lot, I have to admit it doesnâ€™t quite measure up to two more prominent games of its genre: Terraria and Starbound.

The majority of exploration and progress is top-bottom, as is fairly common for sandbox exploration/building games, but where other games take place at a single land mass, EoSâ€™ world is composed of numerous floating islands, some tiny, some very large. If you donâ€™t feel like digging down, walking to an islandâ€™s edge and jumping to the one bellow is always an option. (And having a jetpack from the start helps you not to fall to death this way. Usually.) 

When it comes to combat, Edge of Space gives highest â€œPlayer vs Environmentâ€ feeling than other games of its genre. Instead of challenging powerful bosses like in Terraria, EoSâ€™ focus in on fighting ever present and deadly â€œcommonâ€ enemies, who present constant and serious threat.

However, ever-present enemy threat has side effect of limiting playerâ€™s ability to build in lower areas of the world. Aside from danger to player, many mid-late game enemies has structure-damaging attacks, and will easily wreck both your base and landscape you were trying to preserve.

Also on the negative side, Edge of Space is rather lacking in variety: there are only 3 main biomes in the game, and they donâ€™t feel as unique as Terraria or Starboundâ€™s biomes. Visually the game isnâ€™t very pleasing to an eye either, and everything is mostly brown or metallic-gray (possibly done on purpose for â€œrealismâ€ â€“ we all know that Real Is Brown).

Overall, Edge of Space is quite good, and I can fully recommend it to fans of sandbox exploration/building, who already had their fill with Terraria and Starbound. And those who are more interesting in action than building will probably find that aspect of EoS even more appealing than that of other games of its genre.

And those who are more interesting in action than building will probably find that aspect of EoS even more appealing than that of other games of its genre.

column8:
UI is an unintuitive mess, progress is tedious within the first hour, there's no sense of direction whatsoever (labeling your game as a 'sandbox' is not a legitimate excuse for this) and the launcher barely works. That's always a good sign, right?

Might be worth revisiting in the future especially since it's nice how crafting isn't particularly picky about material type, but for now? Not worth the headache.

column8: Beschts spiu woni je ha gspiut

The game has a lot of potential, it's future looks brighter, but it makes no difference to the current state of the game. I'll put it simply; the game is complicated, too complicated. Refining materials is a key element to the game, and if you refine the same ore at different times chances are you'll get 2 random named metals that both cannot be used at once. The whole combat system is broken, along with it's promises of great intergalactic travel or something like that. Being this  complicated, you would assume a bussling wiki? Yeah, no. It's a regular wiki with stubs for LITERALLY every topic. Want to know a full list of tools? Yah, no-one has submitted an entry. The game doesn't have a functioning wiki, which is vital to a complex game that explains jack-shit to you. This isn't even in beta. Even if these "Features" do exist (And I am pretty sure they do) almost no-one will have the attention span to slowly dig tonnes of crap, build high level armor and get down to get to these places. It's boring and repetative.

I'm going to be honest. I bought this game thinking it was starbound. The only reason why I've "gotten into it" is because I wasted my money and can't get it back. Words are thrown around about this game, "Terraria Clone", and the like, but the one word I don't want thrown around is the word "complete". 

Check the global achievments. The only one is for starting the game, and only 13 percent have even touched the game. It needs a re-vamp, because I like it; enough to be sad if it does this badly.

column8:
With so many "mine, craft better pick, and mine some more" cames out there you might expect that they are all the same, however Edge of space offers more of a survival gameplay that makes the game very interesting.  The crafting system alows you to craft an item without having the exact resource, for example.  instead of neading sand it might say Raw/mineral  which means you can use any dirt/metal/ or stone for this part of the recipe.  

The vertical map design makes the gameplay more interesting as well.  The world is made up of floating islands of varying sizes and the dificulty and enviornmental hazards increase the lower you go.  

I truly have high hopes for this game and I recommend you try it as well.

column8:
I really want to like this game. But it has so any flaws. The progression is insanely slow and strange, very boring. And the fucking griding. Oh god the grinding, I don't mind grinding, but when you give me too much of it, and make the combat quite meh, then make some of the enemies I have to grind fucking bullet eaters, it's not fun.
It looks really fun late game, but honestly I don't think it's worth the 10 or so bucks.

I love the concept of this game, adapt or die in a hostile environment with nothing but technology to rely on! It's still in beta so there's still lots of improvements to be made and i can't wait to see them. So far the game mechanics seem stable and gameplay is alot of fun, the only problem is the somewhat awkward UI and lack of content, but what is already there is fun! The power grid system is simple to figure out and yet, can be extensive and complex in a good way. The developers look like they know what they're doing and know exactly how to put their vision of the game into reality.

I definitely recommend this game and at $11.99 currently, it's very reasonably priced.

column8:
Alright, so, I was urged to play the game again, in which I agreed to. Before writing this, I was reading other reviews, and I completely disagree with one of them, which said something about the game being a little hard or it being objectiveless, and even it being difficult to progress, and even when you did, you would not feel like there was even any progression at all(Review posted June 11). All of it is sorta BS because how is it hard if you literally have 3-4 minutes of night, when things start spawning?(In the caves) How can you feel objectiveless if you have a kick-ass NPC right from the beginning, asking you to help it, and even making cute little sounds when you agree to help it or not be mean to it? How can there not be any progression at all if when you even mine a single block, you get 5 exp, but it then adds up? There really can't be any objective if you set one yourself, or you ask the NPC right from the beginning, yet, I believe i remember the game even saying that you can talk to said NPC.

Anyways, although I did end up finding fun in the game again, like riding snails, or making pits of hell for passive crabs to jump down, it did a few things that irked me, even though it's in early access. Well, for one, the tutorial. When you spawn in, you get pretty nice videos, dont get me wrong, they were nice, but they took up the entire right bottom corner of your screen. I don't want to go and say that they're bad, but it would probably be better if a message popped up asking if you wanted to watch the videos during the tutorial. Another thing was that when it was 12:00 at night, and you were in a cave,(Especially early game) 1: The monsters that spawn hurt. 2: Why spawn in the middle of the night, only to stay during the day?

Personally, I'm very mixed on this game. It really varies from person to person. If I were able to buy it again, but with the current amount of knowledge I have on the game, I would wait until it comes out  with reviews. But you know what? I enjoyed the 34 hours on this game. No regrets. Not that I'm not going to ever play the game again, since i did buy the special edition. However, there are a few aspects that can be so easily exploited, like if you're going to die, you can just exit the game, only to appear at your cryopod, aka spawn point. Even at the tutorial, there's mounds of resources you can get, with no threats, giving a very significant edge in the early game.

TL:DR; The game is amazing, even though there are a few parts to it that can be questionable, but the exception is that it's early access, and it is already a game that has so much potential of being an even better game. Best to wait until it is released out of early access, but it can be even better if you choose to buy it during early access. It's always nice to see games grow.

Dont get this game, get starbound instead. Even if this is in early access, it still has barely any content that is worth mentioning because of it's lack of originality. If you do actually enjoy the game, i would wait until its finished and not waste your money now seeing as how the developer doesnt frequently update the game at all.

*EDIT*

Gameplay-wise: 
The UI and the crafting are terrible / counter-inutitive, inventory management and combat is sub par, and the atmosphere is just boring and lackluster. Music is either just ambience or just music that feels like it is someone's first time with FL studio.  There are the usually bugs gliches here and there but that is subjected to change since it is in beta.

Prometteur !

This is probably the most enjoyable Early Access Beta I've participated in.

The Dev support for this game has been stellar, with all my submitted bug reports and support tickets being responded to within a day at most, and the bugs themselves fixed within a few days. As of the Thanksgiving Patch, I have had no crashes or freezes, but there is also an in-game save option for those of us who get paranoid about beta crashes.

There's a lot of systems testing and bug-hunting going on at the present stage of development, but there is enough content to really have a blast.

The mobs at present are not pushovers, and can really tear you apart if you aren't careful. Personally, I like that the mob danger factor is so high, as it adds a real tension to the exploration aspect of the game. There is a mechanism in place for craftable respawns, which takes out some of the sting from dying. 

I've gone on some intense-to-the-point-of-adrenaline-rush missions descending down through the biomes to find and unlock tech upgrades, while mobs and missiles chased my tail. I love the descent into danger mechanism of this game, where there is always an element of risk involved, and skill with manoeuvring and shooting is rewarded.

The gameplay is a combination of resource gathering, mob killing, building, crafting, and exploration. 
There are quest/mission equivalents, in the form of finding Tech Waypoints, where the reward for success is unlocking boosted statistics and/or new craftables, such as better weapons and armour. 

There are also wormhole events - at present these are time-constrained events where you have a specific timeframe to explore and loot what you can before your time runs out and the wormhole collapses. (Word from the Devs is that there will be a number of different kinds of wormhole events, including boss battles, which I am looking forward to)

At present time, there are only two complete Biomes in the Beta, and a limited number of tech upgrades and crafting options. That being said, I haven't exhausted that limited content in the 30 hours I've played thus far, which isn't bad at all for a beta. Furthermore, from the official forums and chats with the devs, it looks like what is presently in game is but a small fraction of the content planned for launch and post-launch.

I've found myself losing hours to this game, and do not regret spending money on it at all. As of 30/11, Multiplayer is still disabled, but word from the Devs indicates that this is only temporary while they finetune the coding. So at present, and likely for a few more weeks to come given the time of year, the game does only have single player mode. 

That hasn't stopped me from having a damn good time with the game though. I definitely recommend it if Terraria or Metroidvania-styled gameplay tickles your fancy.

column8:
Edge of Space should get some kind of 'worst UI / user experience' award -- I found the interface very poorly thought through and unresponsive, downright unusable; combat -- the main part of the game, as it seems -- felt unresponsive aswell, with bullets sometimes jumping through mobs without dealing damage. Crafting was poor, aswell.

I honestly tried to get myself to like it so I could play it until Starbound arrives, but failed.

Dont get this.

column8:
Since my first view of this title, the developers turned a slightly clunky and obtuse mining and crafting game into a stable and enjoyable game. It is apparent that the developers have poured a lot of work into improving the early access prototype.

The controls have been tightend up, the crafting improved and a lot of content added - overall, the current version of the game offers more of everything then before.

If you were sceptical about weither or not this would turn out like a knock-off Starbound, rest assured - Edge of Space is sufficiently different to make it a worthwhile expirience for veteran starbounders too.

If you haven't purchased it already, I highly recommend you do so. If you have, get it for your friends too... :)

Update (12/30/2014):
Having played a good chunk of Terraria & Starbound, Edge of Space seems like it's coming into its own at this Early Access stage. Definitely recommended alongside those others. Starbound seems to be a bit more stagnant, or moved backwards in some ways (farming/survival is even less important now). EoS has added bunches of new stuff since I last played. EoS is also more futuristic with the ranged weaponry, whereas Starbound seems more reliant on melee, if that matters to you.

Original (10/13/2013):
"Terraria in space"? It's not a totally fair statement, yet this is also a title that the more famous Re-Logic has endorsed. If you're looking for something like Terraria, Terraria-ish in a new set of biomes, or otherwise wanting something familiar to your Terraria experience (but IN SPACE!), then Edge of Space is a good buy, even at this earlier stage in the game's development.

column8: Badass space version of Terraria. Graphics better but are more like SNES or Sega Genesis, so it still has that retro feel. Currently amazing even though it's in beta as I write this. Probably worth getting it at the "Dirt Cheap" special edition price, for an extra 5-10 dollars or so, but not sure yet. I am indeed enjoying it however. Ranged mining is quite useful too, crafting is simplistic, but it's a good challenge to get the materials. Night has been recently added to the game. The night could use a little work IMO. ( Without light you can see the background, which clearly has some form of light, [e.g. Stars] and your character perfectly fine above ground but when you look at the terrain, it's pitch black. Plasma torches are not hard to make, however you get one per craft. I'm probably overcomplicating; after all it's a video game. ) Once servers are running I'd like to have someone to play this gem of a game with. I recomend this if you enjoyed Terraria and/or would like more of a challenge and/or are into complex playing and/or retro looking games.

column8:
At the moment, don't buy this game. I was sucked in to buy it in early access, and I actually enjoyed it more then than I do now. Despite the game being obviously unfinished, the devs haven't updated the game since December 2015, and their last communication that I'm aware of was in April 2016.

Unless they decide to come back (which at this point I highly doubt) it's not worth it. Go get Starbound or Terraria instead.

column8:
Do not buy this game, period. It says it's in beta, hardly, try more like alpha. Virtually none of the systems are in place. They  list pets as a current feature? It's a droid that circles around you and does nothing. Loads of various armours and weapons? There are 4. Yes I played it for 51 hours, but only because I kept trying to figure out how to do things. For example it says on the wiki page that you need to build an O2 generator to fight exposure. Guess what? It's not implimented.

Do youself a favor and wait for Starbound.

column8:
Edge of Space (EoS) has just entered Early Access and is now up for grabs.

EoS is in the explore and self-direct style of gameplay that was pioneered by Minecraft and Terraria. So if you're familiar with and enjoyed those games, this will be familiar to you but space flavored.

If you've never played such a game, then let me boil it down for you. EoS is an action oriented exploration game where the world is created procedurally (randomly) and you possess no state goals aside from survival. You'll take your trust space pick and mine out a little bit of safety while hoarding resources to use later. Use on what? To craft bigger and more elaborate spacesuits, jetpacks, weaponry and gadgets.

Except, it is beta, so how far that road goes is sort of limited. If you're the type who enjoys seeing games get bigger and more fleshed out then take a chance now and support the devs. Otherwise wait for the full buffet to come out later.

column8:
http://store.steampowered.com/app/211820/

http://store.steampowered.com/app/105600/


-=== EDGE OF SPACE ===-

RECOMMENDED : Highly NOT (You shall not pass, run you fools)
Go to buy STARBOUND or TERRARIA



Reasons :

- Handyman Studios is one worst team on Steam. Look at Steam Community score : only 57% approved this game, that mean +3% during last year. All score <75% always mean problems with devs or game is simply bad.

- Don't waste time & money with pure rip off from original without bringing anything fun : Starbound & Terraria are both better experience.

- devs don't solve players problems and ignore them. After many monthes i reported problems they ignored me greatly because they said on forum : "we are small team we need time to investigate all problems". There is difference between "needing time" and never answer. They wasted time to offer Santa event outside beta and not to fix all problems on basic beta build. They call that "beta". One worst support team ever on Steam. I don't believe they act like ignoring person. They banned me to forum to be sure i'll never ask more about my crashes problem.

- full censorship on forum : you write they don't solve your problem, you aren't agree with devs, you said to them truth, they simply call admin to get your permanently ban. Its 1st time on Steam i got banned. They closed my mouth like that and continue to lie to sell more copies !!!

- gameplay : Edge of Space is bad gameplay. When you rip-off game, you have all time to improve  features from original. EoS gameplay is worst than Starbound or Terraria. This game require more tools bar, full control mouse UI. I don't know who designed UI but iam sure its not gamer, its simply someone who don't understand how computer UI should be. They lack of experience lead to boring UI which result in waste of time selecting and ordering what you want & need

- lacks of good balanced weapons ruin game : all i know is i won't made war with Handyman Studios. They understand nothing about war. They are so unexperienced you'll get death in-game. When you see all weapons which exist in real life, and play Edge of Space (game in future), you'll be convinced by this voluntary act of ruining game to create fake difficulty. 

- annoying crafting system : you need to allocate all materials each time (should be auto select by default with lowest materials matching). Tons of time wasted to craft something you need fast. Why to inflict that pain to players ?

- multiplayer : you join server writing direct IP. Never use your real IP because it's never safe & some hackers will be happy to use exploit from beta to hack your computer. I got lot of problems during beta multi. You'll play at your own risks. Because they banned me to not solve my crashes problem, i can't say its because i was hacked during play or its only because beta.

- Handyman Studios is small team : even if game is in beta, you won't get any answer from support if you are alone/few to experience it because "small team" mean not enough time to solve it. In real, they are able to get your money but not to correct all problems. They are able to build exotic patch like Santa but not to help each players to fix problems. They do exactly what they want. For me its last time i gave money for early access game.

- changing screen settings need to restart game

- tutorial : incomplete & bugged tutorial



- - - To end - - -

Save your money & time buying Starbound or Terraria instead of Edge of Space.
Don't feed Trolls
 - who try to seduce you with new games based on stupid ripp-off without bringing something better
 - who lie everyday on forum practicing censorship & permanently ban
 - who offer 0 support about crashes.

It's last time i give my money to indies during early access. Handyman Studios are blacklisted forever. 

Its time to start my Edge of Boycott : YOU SHALL NOT PASS !!!

Thx to read my evaluation.
